NEW DELHI: Auto stocks Tata Motors (up 2.94 per cent), Motherson Sumi Systems (up 2.92 per cent) and Bharat Forge (up 2.63 per cent) were trading in the positive territory during Monday's trade, Keeping the sectoral index up. 

The Nifty Auto index was trading 1.8 per cent up at 11,123 around 1 pm (IST). 

Shares of Tata Motors (DVR) (up 2.53 per cent), Maruti Suzuki India (up 2.08 per cent), Ashok Leyland (up 1.97 per cent), Amara Raja Batteries (up 1.95 per cent), Eicher Motors (up 1.74 per cent), Mahindra & Mahindra (up 1.72 per cent), Hero MotoCorp (up 1.26 per cent), Bosch (up 1.10 per cent) and TVS Motor Company (up 1 per cent) were also trading with gains.

Apollo Tyres (down 0.41 per cent) was the only component in the Nifty Auto index that was in the red around that time. 

Benchmark NSE Nifty50 index was up 71 points at 10,562, while the BSE Sensex was 228 points at 34,370. 

Among the 50 stocks in the Nifty50 index, 37 were trading in the green, while 12 were in the red. 

Indian Oil Corporation, Tata Motors, IndusInd Bank, Maruti Suzuki and Axis Bank were among the top gainers in the Nifty50 index, while Sun Pharma, Tata Consultancy Services, Infosys, Tech Mahindra and Wipro were among the top losers.

In a conversation with ET Now, at the Citi Investor Conference 2018, Surendra Goyal, Director & Head, India Equity Research, Manish Shukla, Director, Equities Research and Jamshed Dadabhoy, Citigroup Global Markets discuss whether the present blip is a buying opportunity or should one patiently wait it out. Citi is betting selectively on pharma, gas stocks, auto and finally private banks, where it remains overweight. Edited excerpts:


Give the broader view. What is the message at this Conference -- run for cover or put money to work?
Surendra Goyal: There is a lot more volatility this year compared to last year where we just saw the markets go one way up through the year. So, there is volatility and to that extent, there is more interest. People want to understand if the blip is a buying opportunity or should you still patiently wait it out. 

Interest is high, our view still remains that this is going to be a moderate return year. We expect single digit returns for the market by December of this year which is the view that we have already put out. Globally, our view still remains that this is not the end of the bull market. In fact, we put out an interesting bear market checklist which is saying that only 3.5% out of 18 indicators are flashing red. This essentially means that the bull market has more legs. We are taking the global view and in the context of that, India is still positive but this year is likely to be a moderate return year given the kind of spectacular returns that we saw last year.


When we look back six months from now or may be a year from now, do you think February 2018 will just look like a blip or is this the one time when you really need to reassess your equity allocation because a lot is changing? Central bankers are normalising their policy, bond yields are moving higher. Should we not get carried away by all the global literature which is floating around about bonds doing something and equity doing something?
Surendra Goyal: I try to articulate by saying that we are not really expecting the kind of returns we saw last year but to that extent, people should look at their asset allocation and they should look at what kind of returns to expect. We do not expect returns to be spectacular this year. What we are building in is a 7-8% return into year end, now accordingly, people will have to take a view of the kind of asset allocation to keep it this way.


Manish, you have mentioned that the cost of capital is going to go higher. Yet, you prefer private banks and NBFCs. My follow-up question would be if cost of capital is going to go higher, why do you like banks in general and NBFCs also?
Manish Shukla: If you look at the universe and Indian financial space, private sector banks -- at least the top ones -- have consistently delivered strong balance sheets and earnings growth and whenever they have come to raise capital in the market in the form of equity or raising bonds, investors have been more than willing to give them that capital. 

The distinction between the private bank and the PSU banks just keeps widening with every passing year. To that extent, wherever there is visibility on growth especially in case of banks’ operating profit growth momentum, those are the stocks that we like and that is the reason we believe that private banks will do well. 

Relatively, NBFCs are in a slightly weaker footing given the way bond yields are moving up because the cost of funds will go up. So, last three years, we have seen that everybody, every NBFC has went up probably it is time to distinguish the point that Surendra was mentioning that NBFCs across the board may not necessarily give you the same returns. You need to be a lot more selective in case of choosing NBFCs.


Surendra says that you should keep return expectations diluted. Do you think banks and NBFCs will outperform the broader market or will they also give diluted returns?
Surendra Goyal: If you look at our India model portfolio, we do have private banks as a significant overweight. That is the call that we are taking that these are banks which have been market share gainers and of high quality. Of course, valuations are high because the quality is good and the growth is good. We expect that compounding to continue. We are still taking a call that private sector banks are overweight in our model portfolio.


Do you like corporate banks? We know that the credit cycle has not picked up. Banks are still focussing on the retail piece per se. The retail piece is getting more comparative and some would argue that most of the retail banks are not cheap. Why do you like corporate banks when the higher frequency data points are not indicating a pickup in demand?
Manish Shukla: Our preference for corporate banks is driven by two factors. One we believe that we are probably at the bottom in terms of corporate stress. Incrementally in the fiscal 19 we will see asset resolution and we are already seeing the first 12 names of the NCLT list the top three-four names are very close to resolution. 

Once these resolutions kick in, we will have provision right back and we will have income recognitions coming in which will help your earnings. I am with you that the demand per se is not going to come back in a big way but you have inflation coming back which will push up working capital demand and given the way bond yields are moving, somehow the demand which had moved to the bond market would again come back to bank borrowings. We have seen that inch up in the system corporate loan growth as well. 

We believe that the trend will continue but our thesis on selectively adding overweight position on corporate banks is not premised on growth coming back, it is premised on NPA recoveries and it is premised on your ability to recognise income on NPAs which become standard assets.


I am sure a year ago, when you would have interacted with your clients they must have asked you only word, impact of Patanjali on the consumer staple sector but now for a moment it looks like the worst of the storm for the entire consumer staple sector is behind us because the volume growth for the quarter gone by was not bad?
Jamshed Dadabhoy: If you take a step back, it was good for the quarter for most of the corporates but you have to remember this was a demonetisation quarter. Go back and look at it on a two-year CAGR. Adjusting for the demonetisation quarter, you still have volume growth in the low to mid-single digits between 3% and 5%. It is not spectacular but we are probably out of the woods in terms of the issues that we have seen over the past couple of years. 

Last year, in FY18, GST disrupted things in the first half., before that you had demonetisation which disrupted for the second half of FY17. I would say we have had four quarters of wobbles for whatever reasons and now we are coming out of that phase. Hopefully, things are looking better.


But are the stocks pricing in all the good news? In a stock like HUL or even Colgate, the PE multiples are nearing 40-50 times. These are good businesses but are these good stocks to buy?
Jamshed Dadabhoy: Honestly, we are being very selective. We are not saying that these are good businesses. They have weathered a lot of storm and that will continue but we are not saying that they are good stocks. We do not have buys on both the stocks that you mentioned at this point in time. 
Surendra Goyal: If you look at our portfolio over the last say couple of years, we have generally tried to play the theme through some other sub-segments of consumers. Autos is something we have been positive on. The consumer durables space is again something we have been positive on. What we have been trying to do is play the same thing with stocks where valuations are lower. Within the staple space, I have generally had a big underweight and trying to figure out proxies to play that space so that is what we have kind of had over the last couple of years.


One very powerful call from Citi and you have bene on it is that you do not like IT as a sector and there is a great mention in your report where you talk about high frequency data points which are not indicating that the sector revival is here but when you see a stock like TCS trading at an all-time high, what are the markets missing out on? Are we missing on something or markets are missing on something?
Surendra Goyal: That is a very good question and in fact that is what the big debate has been since the start of this year. You have to keep a couple of things in mind here. While a lot of investors believe that the sector struggled over the last two-three years, it has broadly underperformed every year practically because global growth was slow and it is kind of picking up. 

But the fact is global growth or particularly US growth was not really bad even the last two years. Jobs data has been good for three years in a row and our negative view always premised on the business mix. 

If you look at these companies, they still have a lot of legacy business and that argument still remains unchanged. 

Having said that, there was always this risk because if you look at the end of say, the October, November, December quarter, both foreign investors and domestic investors were biggest underweight on IT. We always knew that if there is a little bit of a hope based recovery people will chase because they are big underweights. You want to cover your underweights because it really hurts performance in the short term and which is what we are seeing play out. If you look at some of the data points which have been coming out, all the companies globally who have guided for this year, are talking of a growth which is similar to last year. It is not materially different. The large US peer which just guided in early February, is talking of a growth which is very similar to last year. So where is the acceleration?

We will really figure things out in April when a couple of the Indian companies also come and guide but at this point, we still think that there is a lot of hope in the stocks and the underweight positioning partly got covered. This is what has driven this outperformance. On the point about stocks being highs, honestly every sector stocks are at all-time highs and IT did play a bit of a catch up in the last two months.


Which sectors do you think are at an inflection point either in terms of earnings or in terms of a market share gain or in terms of industry dynamics changing because the endeavour of any investor is to identify these sweet spots of inflection where markets are not bullish and businesses may be at the cusp of a turn?
Surendra Goyal: To be fair, in India we have had a few good years in the markets. So, it is difficult to say that valuations are cheap anywhere. The sector which has possibly been the most beaten down is pharma or healthcare. Even their valuations are not really cheap in any manner. Our view is in pharma and we are taking some selective stock calls which are a part of our model portfolio where we are saying that yes the sectors has gotten beaten down and some of the franchises which were doing reasonably well have also been beaten down. That is one space which we like. 

On the gas side, there are a quite a few mid-cap plays. Again, this is not really an inflation point but these are multiyear secular businesses where risks are low, they continue to compound at a very healthy pace. Again, on the auto side, we have a few good names, a combination of value and visibility. Those are the kind of pockets where we have a big overweight. Private banks still remain an overweight. Those are the big overweights for this year.


Most of the private banks are reaching the threshold limit for FII investor. Is that the biggest challenge that you like in this sector but – a) it is over owned and b) the existing large players do not want to sell. That does not really create enough elbowroom or headroom for a new buyer?
Manish Shukla: That is an issue if you really think the government will merge the FDI and FPI limits. The limit theoretically is 74%. Foreign ownership is really an issue only for one or two entities but these are reasonably large and liquid names. It becomes an issue only for guys who are benchmarked to indices where these stocks do not necessarily have weight because they have less foreign room. But other than those segments of investors, who are handicapped by their benchmarks, it is generally not an issue yet.


If a client walks up to your office after this interview and say Manish explain to me the entire NCLT process. How will banks benefit? Is this process transformational in nature or will nothing change in FY19? What is your view?The biggest question that we keep getting on NCLT is how is it different this time because over a period of years, we have had multiple laws to address insolvency in India. There is still an element of scepticism and that is the reason we need resolution of two or three large names from the first list of RBI for investor confidence to come back that this process is actually working. 

We actually have a stressed asset resolution panel tomorrow where we have two representatives from ARC, one law firm. We are going to debate those issues but the fact is if you see the way courts have been proactive in giving the verdict, it is not taking a long time. The message from the system is reasonably clear that we want to make this work and once we have the resolution of two or three large names, probably the confidence will come back. But I am with you that as of now, there is still scepticism among investors whether it will work because in the past we have seen that such laws have not necessarily worked.


Up until now, retail has been the great go to space for bankers and for investors. If you bought any retail franchise whether it is NBFC or private banks, you have made money. But I just get a sense that – a) the retail space is getting very competitive and the HFC companies at least the big ones are feeling the heat of some NPAs. So betting on retail do you think from a three-year perspective both in terms of trend and also in terms of cycle could that backfire?Retail as a segment is growing strong. That would probably continue especially as we discussed corporate capex is not there on the horizon. If you look at retail credit penetration in India, we are significantly underpenetrated by any benchmark. 

However, because of competition, the profitability may not be same as what you had seen in the past. While you will see the loan growth, it would be at lower margins. 

The question really is when does the NPA if at all it come and hit us, the beauty of the entire retail credit cycle in India has been there has hardly been any NPA. As you said, there have been some nascent signs right now in housing finance. We will have to wait and see if that actually spreads at the systemic level. What has changed in the last 10 years, since the DeMo crisis to now, is that the credit bureaus are working very well. Credit scores are working. Banks have implemented their internal scorecards and that is allowing them to price the risk better but it is a question of how long does the competition behave in a similar manner. 

So at least the way we stand right now, the NPA issue seems to be in very select pockets. We do not see it as a systemic risk but that is a space that we need to watch out for. But in terms of growth, there is enough room for retail as a segment to grow.


Is there is historical correlation between rising interest rates and auto demand?
Jamshed Dadabhoy: Very loose correlation. There is nothing very significant but I would say there is a very loose correlation and it comes with a lag of probably two years or so. When rates start to rise from the bottom, it is probably a positive sign because it means that the economy is picking up. So the issue that you have on rising rates right now, is not going to transpire into a cutback in auto credit at least for another year, year-and-a-half. It is when inflation starts going up even more, rates have already moved up 150-200 bps, that is when you start seeing a slight cutback in terms of credit. 

The sensitive sectors which typically go first include commercial vehicles followed by auto and then finally two-wheelers because the penetration of financing in two-wheelers is any way is very low compared to the rest of these sectors.


Is it getting difficult now to pick spots in autos because you got Eicher and Maruti on one side, and you have got Bajaj Auto and Hero MotoCorp which are languishing for a variety of factors. You have got Leyland somewhere in between. How do you view things for the auto sector, two-wheelers, four-wheeler or CV?
Jamshed Dadabhoy: We have generally preferred four-wheelers over two wheelers. In our two-wheeler coverage, the only buy we have is Eicher Motors. In four-wheelers, we have a bias on Tata Motors, Mahindra, Maruti. We had buy on even Ashok Leyland till about two-three months ago. We have generally had a skew towards four wheelers and I think that positive bias continuous.


How do you think that the 2018 conference apart from the fact ET Now is covering it is different from 2017?
Surendra Goyal: I am often asked is the interest low? Absolutely not. We have around 300 clients who have already registered here.


Is that a big number from last year?
Surendra Goyal: Yes it would be higher than last year. Corporate participation is as strong as ever. We have two days of meetings here and then we go to Delhi where we have a macro day. We have people from the government, experts, participating. I would say interest is pretty here.


Normally it is said low interest is good news that means bargains are available. If you have a high interest, that means cheery consensus wants to buy Indian stocks. Should not it be the other way round, low interest sometimes is good news?
Surendra Goyal: Yes, low interest is sometimes good news, But then low interest happens when the market does badly for a long period of time, here we are coming of a good year. We finally have some volatility. Market is down 6-7% from highs.

A sustained selling in private bank, financial, FMCG, metal and pharma counters weighed on the bourses. Investors were holding their moves down awaiting key macroeconomic data today. 

Shares of Infosys, UPL, Eicher Motors, Asian Paints, BPCL, Bharti Infratel and Cipla stood among the top gainers of the day.

However, Vedanta, HPCL, ICICI Bank, Hindustan Unilever, Indiabulls Housing Finance, Zee Entertainment, Axis Bank and Bosch remained among the top losers.

Out of 50 stocks in the Nifty50 index, 21 closed the day in the green and 29 in the red. 

As many as 47 stocks including Punjab National Bank, Bank of India, Corporation Bank, Dhanlaxmi Bank Limited, Gitanjali Gems, Lakshmi Vilas Bank, Bank of Maharashtra and United Bank of India hit fresh 52-week lows on NSE on Wednesday.

However, Ashok Leyland, Cholamandalam Investment and Finance Company, Venky's (India) and Zenith Birla (India) stood among the 18 stocks that hit fresh 52-week highs on NSE.

Stocks such as Cholamandalam Investment and Finance Company, Avenue Supermarts, Salasar Techno Engineering, Shah Alloys, Venky's (India) and Zenith Birla (India) also joined the bandwagon of stocks that hit fresh 52-week highs today.

On the other hand, Punjab National Bank, Bank of India, Corporation Bank, Dhanlaxmi Bank Limited, Gitanjali Gems, Lakshmi Vilas Bank, Bank of Maharashtra and United Bank of India were among the stocks that hit fresh 52-week lows on NSE.

Benchmark indices Sensex and Nifty50 were in the negative zone as investors were awaiting key macroeconomic data, due later in the day, amid a weak trend in global markets.

Sustained selling was observed in bank, financial and metal stocks, while pharma and IT counters saw some amount of buying. 

The NSE Nifty50 index was trading 63 points down at 10,492, while the BSE Sensex was 164 points down at 34,183 around 01:15 pm (IST).

Among the 50 stocks in the Nifty50 index, 13 were trading in the green, while 37 were in the red. 

Infosys, UPL, Cipla, Dr. Reddy's Laboratories and Eicher Motors were among the top gainers in the Nifty pack of stocks, while Hindustan Petroleum Corporation, Vedanta, ICICI Bank, Axis Bank and YES Bank were among the top losers.

Sustained selling was observed in bank, financial and metal stocks, while pharma and IT counters saw some amount of buying.

Infosys, UPL, Cipla, Dr. Reddy's Laboratories and Eicher Motors were among the top gainers in the Nifty pack of stocks, while Hindustan Petroleum Corporation, Vedanta, ICICI Bank, Axis Bank and YES Bank were among the top losers.

NEW DELHI: Continuing the growth momentum, auto majors Maruti Suzuki India (MSI), Mahindra & Mahindra (M&M) and Tata Motors today posted robust double-digit growth in their domestic sales for February.

Besides, two-wheeler players Bajaj Auto, Royal Enfield, TVS Motor and Hero MotoCorp also reported strong double digit sales.

While MSI reported 14.2 per cent increase in domestic sales at 1,37,900 units in February, M&M's domestic sales grew 20 per cent at 48,473 units as against 40,526 units in the year-ago period.

Tata Motors reported 38 per cent jump in domestic sales at 58,993 units, led by strong sales in commercial and passenger vehicle (PV) segments.

"We recorded a strong growth of 45 per cent, a robust sales performance on the back of our new generation products --Tiago, Tigor, Nexon and Hexa," Tata Motors' President - Passenger Vehicles Business Unit - Mayank Pareek said.

The company's passenger vehicle (PV) sales stood at 17,771 units as against 12,272 units in February 2017, up 45 per cent.

On the other hand, Ford India reported a marginal decline in total sales at 23,965 units in February. Its domestic sales however, grew 8.43 per cent to 9,041 units as against 8,338 units in the year-ago month.

MSI, the country's largest car maker, reported 15 per cent increase in total sales at 1,49,824 units as against 1,30,280 units in the year-ago month led by sales of the compact segment comprising Swift, Estilo, Dzire and Baleno.

Sales of its utility vehicles, including Gypsy, Grand Vitara, Ertiga, S-Cross and compact SUV Vitara Brezza increased by 13.8 per cent to 20,324 units in February, from 17,863 units in the same month of 2017.

In the commercial vehicles space, Hinduja Group's flagship Ashok Leyland recorded 29 per cent increase in total sales at 18,181 units in February 2018.

Mahindra's commercial vehicle sales during the month jumped 28 per cent to 20,946 units compared to 16,383 units in the same month of 2017.

M&M President, Automotive Sector, Rajan Wadhera said: "This performance comes on the back of a sustained momentum and demand, both in the personal and commercial vehicle segments, which we believe will also continue in March."

Tata Motors' domestic sales of commercial vehicles in the month grew 36 per cent to 41,222 units compared to 30,407 units in the year-ago period, fuelled by robust infrastructural developments, fresh tenders in car carriers, coal movement and the petroleum sector.

In two-wheeler segment, Bajaj Auto reported 31 per cent jump in total sales at 3,57,883 units in February against 2,73,513 units in the same month last year.

Overall domestic sales increased 35 per cent to 2,14,023 units against 1,59,109 units in February last year, Bajaj Auto said in a statement.

Royal Enfield, the two-wheeler division of Eicher Motors, reported 25 per cent growth in total sales at 73,077 units in February.

The company had sold 58,439 units in February last year.

TVS Motor Company's domestic two-wheeler sales increased 33.5 per cent to 2,30,353 units as against 1,72,611 units in the year-ago month.

Two-wheeler maker Hero MotoCorp today reported a 20 per cent increase in sales at 6,29,597 units in February 2018.

The company had sold 5,24,766 units in the corresponding month last year, Hero MotoCorp said in a statement.

By Chandan Taparia
The Nifty50 index continued its weakness for the third consecutive session and corrected towards the 10,450 level on Thursday. The index has been making lower highs and lower lows for last two sessions, and there has been sustained selling at every small bounceback.

The index formed an inverted candle on the daily chart, which indicated that the bears are putting pressure at higher levels. As long as it remains below 10,525 level, weakness could continue till 10,430 and then 10,380 and 10,350 levels, while on the upside, hurdles are seen at 10,550 and then 10,660 levels.

The Nifty50 has been consolidating between 10,276 and 10,637 levels for last 17 sessions and forming contradicting patterns, which is generally a sign of sideways momentum with limited upside.

On the option front, maximum Put open interest stood at 10,400 followed by 10,300, while maximum Call open interest was at 10,800, followed by 10,700. Significant Call writing was seen at strike prices 10,800, 10,700, 10,500 and 10,600 levels, which restricted its upside while Put unwinding was seen at immediate strike prices, which created scope for further declines. The option band signified a shift in the lower trading range between 10,300 and 10,600 levels for the coming sessions.

India VIX moved up 1.97 per cent to 14.07.

Bank Nifty opened in the negative and continued its weakness towards the 24,850 level. It formed an inverted hammer candle after forming a Doji on the daily scale, which implied that the bears are holding a grip on the market and putting pressure at higher levels.

Overall candle patterns indicated limited upside and volatile swings for next few sessions. As long as the Nifty50 holds below 25,250, further weakness could drag it towards 24,750 and then 24,500 levels, while on the upside, hurdles are seen at 25,350 and then 25,500 levels.

Nifty futures closed with a loss of 0.74 per cent at 10,442. Long buildup was seen in IDBI, NIIT Tech, Bajaj Finance, Voltas, Eicher Motor and IndusInd Bank, while shorts were seen in Torrent Pharma, OFSS, ZEEL, ICICI Bank, Vedanta, SAIL, Hindalco, HDFC Bank, Lupin, Reliance Infra and Canara Bank.

(Chandan Taparia is Technical & Derivative Analyst at Motilal Oswal Securities. Investors are advised to consult financial advisers before taking an investment calls based on these observations)

NEW DELHI: Auto stocks Eicher Motors (up 1.56 per cent), Exide Industries (up 1.13 per cent) and Mahindra & Mahindra (up 0.65 per cent) were trading up during afternoon trade on Thursday, buoyed by positive sale numbers in the month of February.

Shares of Tata Motors (up 0.58 per cent), Bajaj Auto (up 0.28 per cent) and Maruti Suzuki India (up 0.24 per cent) were also trading with gains.

In February, total trucks and buses sales for Eicher Motors grew by 26 per cent, while the total sales for Mahindra & Mahindra rose by 19 per cent. 

The country's largest car maker Maruti Suzuki India today reported a 15 per cent increase in total sales in February.

Tata Motors too today reported a 38 per cent jump in domestic sales in February, while Bajaj Auto reported a 31 per cent jump in total sales for the same month. 

The Nifty Auto index was trading 0.09 per cent up at 11,167 around 02:45 pm (IST).

Benchmark NSE Nifty50 index was down 12 points at 10,481, while the BSE Sensex was 72 points down at 34,112. 

Among the 50 stocks in the Nifty index, 27 were trading in the green, while 23 were in the red.

Since the market is not in its prime when it comes to spotting a trend, the best approach to go for is to have a mix of longs and shorts, Chart Advise founder Dr C K Narayan told ET Now during an interaction. Edited excerpts:


ET Now: Does it look like the pressure on PSBs could continue next week as well or do you think there will be an attempt to rebound?Dr C K Narayan: Well, I think there was a mild attempt to rebound already. That is because the long weekend would have prompted short sellers to lock in some profit, take it home and perhaps spend it across this long weekend, too. But I do not see any case here for going long on it. There would have been definitely some people eyeing some bottom fishing in these names, but I do not believe you will see that spillover next week. When the new week starts, approach to these banks stocks may be somewhat tentative. So, I do not believe there will be too much action, but it might not be a repeat of the selling action unless new skeletons really come out of the cupboard.


ET Now: Some recovery came in for some of the beaten-down auto names. Even Maruti after that touch and go moment with the 10K mark aided a smart move in the week gone by. You had some buying coming in for Eicher, and even Tata Motors had its good days in the week gone by. Anything that you would look to buy next week?Dr C K Narayan: Well, in the whole pack, Ashok Leyland wears the best look on the chart and is the most trended. And even today, it is trying to make big strides and was only marginally beaten back at the higher level. Eicher Motors numbers have come in line, but since the stock had got down over the past many many weeks, that is attracting some sort of short covering and maybe, a little bit of value is dropping. 

Tata Motors looks a little bit interesting. The auto numbers have come out quite encouraging, but today’s price action was perhaps not too robust, considering the fact that the overall market itself was quite somnolent. But the way Tata Motors is currently poised on the chart, if it makes a little bit of effort, it can get itself into the Rs 380-390 bracket without too much difficulty. For that, a little bit of support from the market should be sufficient. 


ET Now: For next week, what would be your trading idea and the stocks you would recommend?Dr C K Narayan: Well, with the market not looking overly robust in terms of a trend, we should have a mixed kind of approach mixing longs and shorts. IDBI stands out with its performance for this week. Not just for the week, the monthly set-up on the charts is also quite attractive as against the rest of the banking pack. 

There is something different with this particular stock. That would mean this is a stock to be pursued with a long position. It is trying to get out of a congestion. It is not a one-day, two-day kind of play, but then one will have to maintain some bit of patience. 

But I do think that will be avoided if you were to keep patience with Rs 80 current price. Buy it in that range of about a couple of points here and there. Maintain a stop at Rs 75, a move towards Rs 90 seems likely. 

BPCL could be another stock, for a rally has formed. It's is not very strong at Rs 440 levels. Buy it for a run to about Rs 450-455 during the week. We can mix this up with a short position in Motherson Sumi. There was some press call or an analyst meet which really has not gone down very well. The stock continues to remain pressured at the end of the week in the Rs 320-322 price zone. With a Rs 5-6 kind of stop loss, one can short it for an expected downmove to Rs 300-310.

Market bounced back in the beginning of the week from oversold levels, but closed moderately lower compared to previous week levels. Local and international issues were hotly contested by bulls and bears trying to overpower other’s territory, but none won. The government has given an ultimatum to PSU banks to report all skeletons of fraud within 15 days and this is expected to keep bulls away till that time. But all is not bad for PSU banks. 

Binani Cement lenders will face zero hair cut which has been acquired by Dalmia Bharat for Rs 6,700 crore through the bankruptcy court. Fast track loan recovery mechanism should eventually recover a good part of approximately Rs 6 lakh crore, which are choking the financial system. However, the current pessimism surrounding the PSU banks should slowly turn positive when the recovery bounty begins. 

Events of the week
MOIL has increased the price of magnesium ore by 5-10 per cent. NMDC has regularly hiked the prices of iron ore by 25 per cent in the last two months. Aluminum, copper, zinc and other commodity prices are increased every fortnightly. SBI has increased interest rates on all deposits by 0.5 per cent. Local and global inflation rates are on a rising spree, US Treasury bonds are pointing up on expectations of increase in interest rates. All these factors historically are against the equity bull markets. 


Technical outlook
In the last week note, we had mentioned that market will test 10,630 levels which it did during the week, following which the fall accentuated. The market is decisively into a correction of long haul. One more bounce is expected, but irrespective of that, another leg of downfall will begin sooner or later. Market will trade range bound for some time, which is the worst time for traders to participate. 



Expectation from the week
Market is glued on the global state of affairs currently. The domestic economy has kept the momentum at the ground level, February auto numbers prove that. Maruti, Eicher Motors and Bajaj Auto posted 15 per cent, 25 per cent, 31 per cent YoY growth in their respective vehicle sales numbers, which are encouraging. This should support a bullish case for the market. 

Comments of the new US Fed chief were nothing but reiteration of the previous policy stance, which has again rattled the bulls across the globe. Treasury yields are slowly falling after a rapid rise, which should offer some solace to the equities for the time being. But if the yields go beyond 3 per cent for the 10-year US Treasuries, then a massive fall is expected across the markets. It is time to be cautious and wait patiently before investing. Profits can be booked at every rise. The longer term trend is under pressure. Nifty 50 closed the week at 10,458.35, marginally down by 0.31 per cent.

Bears held sway last week as benchmark NSE Nifty failed to retake the crucial 10,500-mark. The index slipped to 10,458.35 for the week ended March 1, from 10,491.05 on February 23.

Gaurav Ratnaparkhi, Senior Technical Analyst, Sharekhan, said, “With a weekly negative close for the week gone by, the pullback looks done at the swing high of 10,631. On the hourly chart, the Nifty has broken lower end of a reverse rising channel. Overall, the set-up looks ripe for next leg down to start off, which can test the recent low of 10,276 and can eventually target 10,070 in the short term.”

Taking to ET Now, Mayuresh Joshi, Angel Broking, says he is positive on both Yes Bank and ICICI Bank and Dewan Housing and Chola among rural focused NBFCs, on any decline, in a staggered manner.Edited excerpts: 

A very interesting note from Credit Suisse says they are maintaining their outperform rating on State Bank of India (SBI) and Bank of Baroda (BoB). On the other hand, Jefferies says that Axis and ICICI Bank have been sharply off highs and they make for attractive buys. Would you say that these private corporate banks like Yes, Axis, ICICI Bank make for a good buy? Further correction is probably not ruled out for the corporate lenders but what you have largely seen specifically for the private corporate lenders is that the loan book has largely become a lot more diverse with aggressive lending happening on the retail side. The stress that you probably saw in terms of reported asset quality issues is slowly and steadily dwindling down. The reported watch lists and the divergence from the RBI list, the provisioning thereof, did take a toll into the excess provisioning that was required and elevated credit costs but my own sense is that these banks are far better equipped to both manage the excess provisioning at their end.

The new NPA norms that RBI has mandated would also have a say in terms of both their provisioning and cost to income ratios but with a large element of capital adequacy ratio, specifically tier-1 remaining strong and the skew towards retail advance growing at a fast clip and at the same time as PSU banks go into the recovery mode, the aggressive lending part for the private banks will continue. So, yes, the next quarter or two, you might see sluggishness in terms of reported numbers but the aggressiveness in terms of advance growth along with stability in asset quality should get reflected. 

So, yes, ICICI Bank, Yes Bank in terms of all key parameters -- whether it is the capital adequacy part peaking off on their credit costs and ROAs and ROEs improving drastically over the next few quarters -- cannot be ruled out. I remain positive on both Yes and ICICI Bank on any decline in a staggered manner.


On NBFCs, some of the brokerages believe that there is not much merit into buying into NBFCs. There is a downgrade from Morgan Stanley on both Inidiabulls Housing as well as Aditya Birla Capital. They are saying that higher rates are a reality right now and not an easy backdrop for NBFC multiples. Do you also believe that there is bound to be EPS pressure on these companies going forward?For a select few companies yes, but you cannot paint the entire sector with the same brush. Having said that, the kind of underperformance that PSUs can actually mete out in terms of advance growth as their entire portfolio shift happens towards recoveries and upgrades, you are probably going to see the NBFC universe and banks with their niche product offerings actually have a very stellar performance over the next two to three quarters. 

The second element becomes their borrowing mix and a lot of NBFCs have a varied borrowing mix composition at this point of time. Banks, NCDs, CPs, you have probably got that mix going in for them. Though bond yields have moved up very sharply over the last few weeks, there might be some constraints in terms of the refinancing for these NBFCs with a time lag. My own sense is that the NIMs should not get impacted significantly and at the same time the loan growth should be quite stable. A lot of the rural-focused NBFCs have actually moved to the 90-day reporting bucket on the asset quality part which actually gives them a lot more stability because their cost to income ratios have started coming down.

The asset quality pressures have started coming down and the natural leverage will create the impetus that the balance sheet requires. Within this entire universe, select housing finance names like Dewan Housing on significant declines is something that we will still continue to prefer with the kind of capital raising that it has done, the leverage that it can create on the balance sheet in terms of advances growth can be stupendous. 

On the other rural-focused NBFCs, Chola Finance is something which I believe can deliver stupendous growth. Asset quality pressures have come down significantly. You have probably seen strong advances growth specifically in its rural financing segment or the home financing segment and even the MHCV/ PV side of the business. So, strong earnings momentum, stable NIMs and again stable asset quality probably holds them out in this entire universe. I will be a little bit selective but a few stocks like Dewan, Chola is something that I will still continue to prefer on declines.


Do you think it is worthwhile to wait it out on Tata Motors or do you say leave it, there are many better opportunities within autos that you can have exposure to?Tata Motors has faced some stress over the past few years. First, the phasing off of their old models, then creating new platforms on the JLR side, they had created a Chinese JV operations which is looking far more stable but the reported numbers in terms of UK JLR sales have been patchy and that leads to a lot of disruptions as far as estimates are concerned. Though valuations might look very attractive, even the hedging policy issues is something that can be a cause of concern and headwinds when you are probably trying to pencil in numbers. 

On the domestic side, improvement has largely been seen both on the PV side of the business as well as the CV side of the business with discounting expected to come down but JLR is something that drives EBITDA for Tata Motors. The market likes growth stories and growth is very evident in stocks like an Eicher and Maruti I think we prefer staying in those stocks and a clear disclaimer we might be owning these stocks in our portfolios. So, for Tata Motors, better times might come but the struggle in terms of reported numbers and volumes might just continue to plague the company and the stock might actually underperform the auto universe over the next two to three quarters.

NEW DELHI: BSE flagship Sensex has come a long way from a multi-year low of 8,160 (on March 9, 2009) nine years ago to a record high of 36,444 this January -- and is still trading four times higher than the 2009 level.

While the market barometer jumped 4 times during the period, select stocks have raced ahead a whopping 763 times. This translates into up to 76,278 per cent return in 9 years.

On Friday, the index was ruling at 33,450 level.

Most of these stocks were smallcaps then, but managed to become midcaps later -- some even broke into benchmark indices. A few are still a ‘buy’ call by brokerages, but chances are slim that the scintillating show of the past will repeat itself.

Let's have some illustrations. Had you invested Rs 1 lakh in Avanti Feeds on March 9, 2009, you would have been sitting on a portfolio of Rs 7.63 crore. The investment in this stock has grown 763 times in the past 9 years. During FY09-17, the company’s revenue jumped 37.73 times. Net profit stood at Rs 224 crore in FY17 against Rs 6 crore loss in FY09.

This processed shrimp exporter is looking to increase its feed capacity by 1,75,000 tonnes annually soon. The company expects total feed sales of 525,000-550,000 mt in FY19, implying 25-30 per cent volume growth. Avanti Feeds is just one example. 

From a market value of mere Rs 174 crore, Bajaj Finance has climbed 35,000 per cent in the last 9 years to become a Rs 94,000-crore company in terms of market capitalisation. The NBFC’s annual sales have grown 18 times while its profit have swelled 54 times annually since FY09. The company management highlighted that the mortgage, rural business, new category expansion coupled with geographical penetration will drive growth for the next 5 years. 

Brokearge JM Financial values this company at 5.1 times March 2020 book value. The brokerage has a 12-month target of Rs 2,050 on the stock, suggesting a potential 24 per cent upside on the stock.

Despite the sharp slide in the Vakrangee stock, it is still up 388 times at 38,764 per cent over the last nine years. Sales rose 13 times, but profit skyrocketed 120 per cent since FY09.

Astral Poly, La Opala RG and Ajanta Pharma are three other stocks that have delivered 20,000-25,000 per cent returns in the nine-year period. 

Mayur Uniquoter has rallied 166 times during the said period. Centrum Broking expects this company to perform well in coming quarters, aided by continued recovery in the footwear segment, higher traction in exports.

“The company’s foray into the PU business and its new plant in Mysore will also add to its growth momentum, albeit in the medium term. Construction work has already started for the PU plant at Morena (MP) and production is expected to start towards the end of FY19. We remain convinced of Mayur’s medium-to-long term growth opportunities,” the brokerage said.

Shares prices of Sundaram Clayton and Indo Count Inds soared 140-150 times since the index hit multi-year lows in 2009. Royal Enfield maker Eicher Motors, with 128 times returns, made it into the Nifty50 club during the period.

"Increased acceptance of leisure biking trend is expected to continue, which would result in continued double-digit growth for 2-wheeler division Royal Enfield. However, moderation in growth rates due to supernormal growth in last 4-5 years coupled with expensive valuation would restrict gains from the stock," Sharekhan said.

Poly Medicure, KRBL Johnson Controls, Hitachi Air Conditioning, Natco Pharma, Venky's (India), Balkrishna Inds, V-Guard Inds, Somany Ceramics and Igarashi Motors too returned 7,000-10,000 per cent in the same window.

US President Donald Trump has put the global market on tenterhooks with his aggressive rhetoric on import tariffs. Highlighting the skew in trade balance, Trump has threatened reciprocal taxes on goods imported from countries that impose ‘unfair’ duties on US exports. 

While his ire is mainly directed towards large trading partners like Europe, China, Canada and Mexico, India is also in his crosshairs. How will a full-blown tariff war impact India Inc. and what will be its effect on the stock market? In a series of tweets, the US President recently pointed out that the US had lost $800 billion in yearly trade deficit because of its ‘very stupid’ trade deals and policies. 


Why the US is itching for a trade war 
The country has been running a trade deficit with India for several years.
 Figures are in $ billion
US jobs and wealth are being given to other countries and they have taken advantage of the US for years, said Trump, warning that he would not allow it anymore. Sounding confident of coming out on top, Trump has effectively let out a war cry: “When a country (US) is losing many billions of dollars on trade with virtually every country it does business with, trade wars are good, and easy to win,” he says. He has already set his plan into motion, proposing 25% tariff on steel imports and 10% on aluminium. These increasingly protectionist measures by the US, however, threaten to derail the global economic growth engine, warn analysts. 


Most vulnerable Indian exports 
Diamonds and pharma top Indian exports to the US
 Source: The office of the U.S. Trade Representative (USTR)

Trump’s rhetoric has prompted other countries to threaten retaliatory tariffs, followed by counter-threats by the US, raising concerns of tit-for-tat protectionist measures that were a feature of the Great Depression in the 1930s. Ambareesh Baliga, an independent market expert, feels an all-out trade war will prove detrimental to global markets. “Global economic growth hinges on the free movement of goods. 

If we revert to large-scale nationalism, it could set growth back by a couple of decades,” he says. If this plays out, capital markets will feel the heat. India is ninth in the list of US' trading partners that have a trade surplus. Trade surplus means that we export more to the US than we import from the country. India's exports account for a hefty 15% of US' aggregate trade with the world. Gems and diamonds are India’s biggest goods exports to the US, followed by pharmaceuticals, textiles, fish and petroleum products. 

As of now, these exports are not on the radar of the US, but there is a risk of retaliatory tariffs on these goods. Trump’s clamp-down on steel and aluminium imports will not impact India much as just about 4% of the steel exports flow into the US, while aluminium exports constitute 2% of total US aluminium imports. While the direct impact of higher metal tariffs on Indian firms will be limited, there is a possibility that muted metals demand, owing to cooling off in global trade, will put pressure on prices of these metals. 

Further, there is a chance that unabsorbed steel and aluminium exports from other countries may be rerouted and dumped on Indian shores. This incremental supply in the domestic market is likely to put metal prices under pressure, hurting the operating profits of Indian metals and mining firms, such as Tata Steel, SAIL and Hindalco, among others. “The US trade protection measures will lead to a temporary disruption in a few regional markets as new trade channels open up to cater to supplies left behind from reduced US exports,” says Abhishek Poddar, Analyst, Kotak Securities. 

However, the potential steel mill and aluminium smelter restarts in the US will not significantly weaken the outlook on global aluminium and steel. Especially, given supply side reforms in China in these industries, says Poddar. Trump has also come down heavily on higher import duty on US-made Harley Davidson motorbikes. He previously threatened to slap retaliatory taxes on motorcycles coming into the US from India. 

While the Indian government responded by slashing customs duty on imported high-end motorcycles to 75% from the earlier 100%, and eventually cut it down to 50%, the US President was left unimpressed and made it clear that the cuts were not enough. If the US decides to levy equivalent duties, it could affect USbound exports of two leading Indian twowheeler manufacturers—Eicher Motors and Bajaj Auto. The former exports its Royal Enfield range of motorbikes, while Bajaj Auto ships the KTM brand to the US. 

However, the volumes are limited to a few thousand units, with the total value of Indian motorcycle exports to the US at just about $6 million (`40 crore) in 2016-17. As such, tariffs are not likely to create a visible dent on these firms’ profitability, which enjoy a strong domestic demand. India’s IT services firms have been exposed to Trump’s protectionist policies for a while. Tighter immigration laws have affected how these firms hire local talent in the US and has restricted the flow of skilled personnel to the US. As things stand, India is not directly affected by the US actions, but the likely spillover effects could bring the domestic markets under pressure.

Eicher Polaris Private Limited, an equal JV between homegrown Eicher Motors and US based Polaris Industries for personal utility vehicle space has passed the resolution to shut the operations with immediate effect.

Incorporated in 2012, Eicher Polaris launched Multix personal utility vehicle in 2015 was aimed at independent businessman. After initial interest,sales could not be sustained in the subsequent years. Despite several initiatives, the performance did not improve, hence the decision was taken to shut operations, said the statement from Eicher Motors to Bombay Stock Exchange.

This probably is one of the rare blemishes for Siddhartha Lal run Eicher Motors, which has been on a very good run in the two wheeler space with the Royal Enfield and his joint venture for commercial vehicle with Volvo was amongst the profitably run CV business in the country. 

As part of the winding down process, the company will engage all it stakeholders (customers, suppliers, employees and channel partners) to implement the closure. The company will continue to provide spares and service for the existing Multix customers stated the company.

As of 31st Dec 2017, Eicher had invested Rs 289.90 cr Eicher Polaris Pvt Ltd and an equal sum by Polaris. The sum invested will be written off in accordance with the law. During the year ended March 31,2017, EPPL's net loss amounted to Rs 91.83 crore, 50% of which was consolidated with PAT of Eicher Ltd

NEW DELHI: Domestic market is likely to see a flat opening on Tuesday, tracking Nifty futures on the Singapore Stock Exchange (SGX Nifty) and global cues. Nifty futures on the Singapore Stock Exchange were trading 13 points, or 0.12 per cent, lower at 10,419, indicating a flat start for the Nifty50 on Dalal Street. Here is a list of top stocks that are likely to be in focus in today's trading session. 


Infosys: The IT major plans to voluntarily delist its American Depositary Shares from Euronext Paris and Euronext London exchanges, as the low average daily trading volume was not commensurate with the related administrative requirements. 


NBCC: State-owned construction firm said that no charges have been established against its CMD Anoop Kumar Mittal as allegations against him were not corroborated during the CBI investigation.

InterGlobe Aviation: India grounded 11Airbus 320neo planes of IndiGo and GoAir with immediate effect after occurrences of aborted take-offs and inflight shutdowns involving these aircraft, powered by Pratt & Whitney (P&W) engines. Grounding of the aircraft fitted with PW1100 engines was done keeping in mind the safety of aircraft operations, the Directorate General of Civil Aviation said in a statement on Monday. 


Videcon Industries: Financially distressed Videocon Group may give up India rights for two global brands — Philips in the TV business and Electrolux in appliances — after being unable to sustain production without working capital, which has caused a steep decline in sales, three senior industry officials said.


Bata India: Sebi has directed Bata on Monday to conduct an inquiry into the leak of price-sensitive financial information.The regulator has asked the company to take action against those responsible for the leak and strengthen its internal processes.


Bharti Airtel: The company has approved a plan to raise about Rs 16,500 crore through debt, including a fresh issue of $1 billion in overseas bonds, to help refinance loans and pay for spectrum, boosting the telco’s shares by almost 5 per cent. 


ACC, Ambuja Cements: Having put their merger on hold, ACC Ltd and Ambuja Cements — the two Indian units of LafargeHolcim — on Monday said they plan to enter into a ‘master supply agreement’ with each other. The agreement is for supply of cement, clinker and raw materials such as fuels, fly ash, slag and gypsum. This would also include spare parts.


Mahindra & Mahindra: Automobile major Mahindra & Mahindra has bought two floors in its own corporate headquarters Mahindra Towers in Mumbai’s Worli locality from a group company of Gautam Singhania’s Raymond Group.


Eicher Motors: Eicher Polaris, an equal joint venture between homegrown Eicher Motors and US-based Polaris Industries for personal utility vehicle space, has decided to shut down its operations with immediate effect.


Fortis Healthcare: Yes Bank has become the biggest shareholder of Fortis Healthcare with a 17.31 per cent stake in India’s second-largest hospital chain, giving the private lender a possibly decisive role in an impending takeover battle. The company’s promoters, Malvinder and Shivinder Singh, who are engaged in a legal battle with Japanese pharmaceutical major Daiichi Sankyo, now own less than 1 per cent in the company — 0.77 per cent to be precise.


SBI: State Bank of India (SBI) is likely to drag five Kolkata-based companies, including Burnpur Cement and four Patni group entities, to the National Company Law Tribunal for insolvency proceedings over Rs 3,250 crore in unpaid loans.


Larsen & Toubro: L&T Special Steels and Heavy Forgings Private, a joint venture of Larsen & Toubro and the state-run Nuclear Power Corporation of India, has received an order worth 442 crore from NPCIL to supply forgings for steam generators, the engineering major said.


BHEL: State-run power equipment maker BHEL on Monday said it has bagged an order worth Rs 736 crore from Nuclear Power Corporation of India (NPCIL) for the supply of steam generators to a plant at Gorakhpur in Fatehabad district of Haryana. The order has been received against competitive bidding, a BHEL statement.


IPO WATCH

Bharat Dynamics: The Rs 960-crore initial public offering (IPO) by mini-ratna Bharat Dynamics will kick off on Tuesday.The government intends to offload 2.25 crore shares (12.27 per cent stake in the offer for sale (OFS) in Rs 413-428 range. The retail investors and employees will be offered a discount of Rs 10 per share in the issue that closes on March 15.

On the other hand, Eicher Motors, Hindalco Industries, Tech Mahindra, Bosch and Hero MotoCorp were among the top losers in the Nifty pack of stocks.

China has become synonymous with cheap goods in India. But that can change soon. From cheap toys and phones that gave Indian manufacturers a run for their money, Chinese companies have now started rushing into the Indian automobile sector. 

A few days ago, Chinese auto maker SAIC Motor said it would invest over Rs 5,000 crore till 2025 to establish its presence in the country. It will introduce the Morris Garages (MG) brand in India in 2019. It's a British brand that SAIC acquired from Chinese firm Nanjing Automobile about a decade ago. 

Chinese automobile market is slowing down. The China Association of Automobile Manufacturers estimates China’s overall vehicles sales to grow a relatively lackluster 3 per cent this year, the same as in 2017 but significantly below the stellar 13.7 per cent gain in 2016, according to a Reuters report. 

China’s auto market, until recently an engine of growth worldwide, will only deliver “slow and steady growth” from now, Shi Jianhua, the association’s deputy secretary-general told The Wall Street Journal this month. The association anticipates 3% growth in 2018.

The Indian passenger vehicle market is one of the fastest growing — by over 9% in 2016-17 — and is projected to be the world’s third largest car market by 2020. That's one reason why Chinese automakers are looking at India. Of the $278 million Chinese FDI that entered India in 2016-17, 60% was in the automobile sector. 

However, Indian market would not be as easy for Chinese auto companies as it has been for toy makers or smartphone makers. Credibility, quality and after-sales service matter a lot for car buyers. Maruti's hegemony over Indian market through value-for-money products will leave little scope for Chinese auto makers to acquire any significant footprint in the Indian market. 

Yet, Chinese companies cannot be taken lightly. They know how to evolve to quality products as is evident from smartphone maker Xiaomi. Many of Chinese auto makers have acquired stakes in global auto brands which have presence in India. India's massive push to shift to electric vehicles will open up vast opportunities for Chinese companies which have already developed expertise in the new technology as China has become the world's biggest market of electric vehicles. China’s biggest electric-vehicle seller BYD, a joint venture partner of Hyderabad-based Goldstone Infratech, has bagged electric bus supply contracts along with Tata Motors for nine out of 10 cities. 

The two companies have beaten rivals such as Mahindra & Mahindra, Eicher Motors and JBM Solaris.

NEW DELHI: India's leading mid-sized motorcycle manufacturer, Royal Enfield, has unveiled its new parallel twin powered 650cc motorcycles in Australia. The company showcased both the Interceptor 650 and the Continental GT 650 in the country, however, they will be launched first in the UK and European markets.  While both the new Royal Enfield bikes are being manufactured at the company's Chennai plant, their India launch will take place only after April 2018.  The Interceptor 650 and the Continental GT 650 were introduced to Indian enthusiasts at the Royal Enfield RIdermania last year, following a global debut at the EICMA 2017. The company, however, refused to provide an estimation of their prices for the Indian market.  Like most of the Royal Enfield motorcycles, both of the new bikes are retro styled models. While the Continental GT 650 is a cafe racer -- almost identical to the existing single-cylinder Continental GT 535 -- the Interceptor 650 is an easy-to-ride, relaxed bike like the Triumph Bonneville.  The motorcycles are powered by an all-new 650cc, air-cooled, parallel-twin engine that delivers 47PS of power at 7,100rpm and a peak torque of 52Nm at 4,000rpm. The fuel injected motor also gets an oil-cooler for better performance and dual exhaust mufflers for true parallel twin harmony.  The bikes get features like large 320mm front and a 240mm rear disc brake, adjustable gas charged rear shock absorbers, premium Pirelli tyres and antilock braking system (ABS).  During the unveiling of the bikes Siddhartha Lal, CEO of Eicher Motors (which owns Royal Enfield), had announced that the gap between these new 650cc bikes and the 350cc bikes will be similar to what's between a 150cc and RE's 350cc motorcycles.  The upcoming Royal Enfield bikes are not expected to cross the Rs 3.5 lakh price barrier, and even if it happens, they will still be way cheaper than their respective competitions.  Other twin-cylinder options available in India include the Kawasaki Z650 and its siblings (Ninja 650 and Versys 650) which come with an ex-showroom price tag of slightly over Rs 5 lakh while the Triumph's modern classic starts at Rs 7.17 lakh (ex-showroom) for the Street Twin model.

Tata Motors and a joint venture between Hyderabad-based Goldstone Infratech and China’s biggest e-vehicles seller BYD have bagged electric bus supply contracts for nine out of 10 cities, leaving rivals such as Mahindra & Mahindra, Eicher Motors and JBM Solaris empty handed.

Competition termed some of the winning bids as unviable, saying that the two players quoted nearly 30% lower than the market price. The winners exuded confidence though. The development revs up the e-vehicle market in the country.

Goldstone Infratech’s joint venture with Warren Buffett-backed BYD, which is described by many as China’s Tesla, bagged contracts of Bengaluru, Mumbai and Hyderabad to supply 290 electric buses.

Tata Motors emerged the lowest bidder for contracts in six cities — Jaipur, Indore, Lucknow, Kolkata, Jammu and Guwahati — to supply 190 e-buses. Ashok Leyland bagged contract for 40 e-buses in Ahmedabad. The 10 cities called tenders in the last two months in a pilot programme partly funded by the central department of heavy industries.

Delhi is yet to come out with a tender to procure 700 e-buses using state budget, people familiar with the development told ET.




The government is encouraging e-vehicles with its Faster Adoption and Manufacturing of (Hybrid &) Electric Vehicles in India (FAME India) scheme, which provides 60% subsidy to cities to procure e-vehicles either as outright purchase or on supply-operate basis.

Given the different tender conditions in the 10 cities, there was a huge variation in prices discovered under both models, sources said.

Tata Motors placed the lowest bid of Rs 77 lakh per bus for a 40-bus outright purchase contract placed by West Bengal Transport Corp for Kolkata. The company placed bids varying between Rs 77 lakh and Rs 99 lakh for different models. “The price quoted by Tata Motors is an unviable number for many original equipment manufacturers (OEMs),” said an executive in one of the auto making firms.

“The Rs 77 lakh bid was a desperate attempt from the company after they lost to Goldstone-BYD in Karnataka,” the person alleged, speaking on condition of anonymity.

At current market rates, similar models could cost between Rs 1.2 crore to Rs 1.7 crore, depending on specifications, industry insiders said. Girish Wagh, president of commercial vehicle business at Tata Motors, however, said the company has a clear line of sight of profitability and remains committed to invest in the sector. He said Tata Motors has been investing extensively in research and development of electric vehicles for past decade.

“We have taken a longterm view regarding electrification as we believe that sustainability and development of full EV ecosystem would hinge on strong participation of local players who invest in end-to-end value chain,” Wagh said.

Goldstone-BYD placed bids as low as Rs 29.28 per km to bag a supply-operate contract for Bengaluru, followed by Rs 36 per km bid for Hyderabad. “This is an aggressive entry pricing strategy,” said another bidder on the condition of anonymity. “I don't think it will make commercial sense for any OEM to sell their bus at this price.”

Goldstone Infratech and BYD could not be immediately contacted for comments.

BYD has grown spectacularly in the decade after Buffett invested $230 million in what was then a little-known maker of mobile phone batteries.

The department of heavy industries had in December 2017 sanctioned Rs 440 crore to 11 states for procurement of electric buses, electric taxis and e-autos as a pilot project under FAME scheme. The sanction was for procurement of 390 buses — 40 buses per city, except 15 buses each for Guwahati and Jammu.

Bengaluru, however, called tenders for 150 buses while the Telangana State Road Transport Corporation in Hyderabad sought bids for 100 buses.

The recent sell-off in domestic equity markets has dragged the NSE Nifty below its 200-Day Moving Average (DMA), signalling that the index is losing momentum. So far this year, the 50-share benchmark has already slipped over 2 per cent to 10,155 till March 21.

More than 30 stocks on the Nifty50 are trading below their 200-DMAs. The list included Bharti Airtel, Bharti Infratel, Bosch, Hero MotoCorp, Eicher Motors, Hindalco, HPCL, Lupin, ONGC and SBI.

Even on the Nifty500, as many as 294 stocks that constitute nearly 60 per cent of the pack, are trading under their 200-DMAs. This shows that the market is facing selling pressure across sectors.

Stocks trading below this crucial support line include names like Aban Offshore, Advanced Enzyme Technologies, Asian Paints, Aurobindo Pharma, Bajaj Auto, Bank of Baroda, Cipla, Colgate-Palmolive, Corporation Bank, Cox & Kings, DCB Bank, Dewan Hosing Finance Corporation, Dish TV, ICRA and NMDC, among others.

Moving averages are a tool for analysing the trend of a stock or even an index. They provide useful information on the support and resistance points.







Usually, any trader or investor uses three major DMAs - Daily Moving Averages, that of 50, 100 and 200 DMA. When a stock is trading above all of its DMAs, it is usually said to be in a continuing uptrend.

During corrective moves, stocks are often seen coming off their highs and are slipping below moving averages. Shallow corrections see stocks testing their 50-DMA or 100-DMA, but any serious correction may cause the stock not only to test 200-DMA but also slip below it.

Milan Vaishnav, Technical Analyst, Gemstone Equity Research & Advisory Services, said, “If any stock trades below its 200-DMA, that means it is undergoing a serious corrective action. However, just because a stock trades below its 200-DMA does not mean that it is in a major bear trend. It just implies it is undergoing a major corrective move.”

Vaishnav told ETMarkets.com: “Bear trend in a stock sets in only if shorter term averages start trading below the longer term averages. As long as 50-DMA trades above 100-DMA and 100-DMA trades above 200-DMA, the stock just remains in a major corrective activity without any bear trend being initiated.” 

The 200-day average, also known as long-term moving average, acts as a crucial support for the index or a stock, while the 100-day average reflects a six-month timeframe and the 50-day average measures a quarter. A 20-day average measures a month and 10-day average two weeks.

S H Kelkar, Shree Renuka Sugars, Siemens, SJVN, SML Isuzu, Snowman Logistics, Tata Coffee, Tata Power, Tata Steel, UltraTech Cement, Va Tech Wabag and Vardhman Textiles are among other stocks trading well below their 200-DMAs.

The NSE Nifty index was trading 49 points up at 10,204 in early trade on Thursday. 

Sameet Chavan, Chief Analyst-Technical and Derivatives, Angel Broking, said, “We reiterate that traders should remain light within this consolidation and should rather focus on individual stocks with a proper exit strategy. Directionally, the market is still not done with the corrective phase and hence, booking timely profits in existing longs with a short-term view makes a good play for the momentum traders.”

Here’s a lowdown on top macro triggers that may move market on Thursday. This report was compiled from agency feeds.



Fed Hikes Rates by 25 Bps, Signals Faster Pace for Future Hikes Federal Reserve officials, meeting for the first time under Chairman Jerome Powell, raised the benchmark lending rate a quarter-point and forecast a steeper path of hikes in 2019 and 2020, citing an improving economic outlook. Policy makers continued to project a total of three increases this year. The vote to lift the federal funds rate target range to 1.5% to 1.75% was a unanimous 8-0. Seven officials projected at least four quarter-point hikes would be appropriate this year, while eight expected three or fewer increases to be warranted. 


US Slaps Anti-dumping Duty on Steel Wire Imported from India, ChinaThe US has decided to slap anti-dumping duty on stainless steel flanges imported from India and China after it found in its preliminary probe that both the countries provided subsidies to the exporters. The Department of Commerce has found that exporters from China and India have sold stainless steel flanges in the US at 257.11 per cent and 18.10 to 145.25 per cent less than fair value, respectively.


Green Ministry Eases Rules for Construction CosThe government has eased environmental clearances for buildings and construction sector, with the environment ministry more than doubling the threshold for construction projects requiring environmental clearances from the Centre to 50,000 square metres of built-up area from 20,000 sq metres. As a result, developers of an average sized mall with three floors or an apartment complex with 300 three-bedroom flats would be able to start construction with online submission of a self-certification that all environmental obligations would be met. 


Numetal Moves NCLT After ‘Ineligible’ Bid for Essar SteelNumetal has approached the National Company Law Tribunal (NCLT) against the decision of lenders to declare it ineligible to bid for bankrupt Essar Steel. Numetal moved the Ahmedabad bench of the NCLT. The tribunal will hear the matter on April 4 and has told the committee of creditors to decide on the eligibility only after its decision. Steel giant ArcelorMittal, whose bid too was rejected, may also move NCLT. The committee of creditors decided to go for a rebid with the condition that the entity that is awarded Essar Steel will be barred from selling its stake in the company to any firm not compliant with Section 29A of the bankruptcy code. 


PNB Pegs FY18 Fraud Loss at Rs 14,500 CrPunjab National Bank expects a Rs 14,500 crore loss on account of frauds in this financial year, including contingent liabilities, following the scam by diamond traders, the government said. The amount involved in the alleged fraud involving Nirav Modi, Mehul Choksi and their companies is now pegged at almost Rs 14,000 crore. The total loss reported by the bank due to frauds was Rs 341.03 crore in financial year 2015-16, Rs 2,633.82 crore in FY2016-17, and Rs 14,506.39 crore (including contingent liability) in FY 2017-18 (till date),” the statement said. 


Goldstone-BYD, Tatas Grab E-Bus ContractsTata Motors and a joint venture between Hyderabad-based Goldstone Infratech and China’s biggest e-vehicles seller BYD have bagged electric bus supply contracts for nine out of 10 cities, leaving rivals such as Mahindra & Mahindra, Eicher Motors and JBM Solaris empty handed.Competition termed some of the winning bids as unviable, saying that the two players quoted nearly 30% lower than the market price. The development revs up the e-vehicle market in the country.


US Suspends Premium Processing of H-1B Visa Petitions The US on Wednesday announced the suspension of premium processing of all H-1B visa petitions for fiscal year 2019. The US Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS) said the temporary suspension would help reduce the "overall H-1B visa processing time". The H-1B petition filing is for the fiscal year 2019 beginning October 1, 2018. It also announced petitions for H1-B visas will be accepted from April 2. The suspension of premium processing of all H-1B petitions, subject to the annual cap, is expected to last until September 10, 2018. 


Battle for Binani Cement ContinuesThe takeover war for Binani Cement between Dalmia Bharat group and UltraTech declines to ease as both the bidders remain unperturbed despite the revelation of alleged fraud on the stressed asset, and both remain fully committed for acquisition. The Resolution professional (RP) Vijaykumar V Iyer has moved the National Company Law Tribunal (NCLT), alleging suspect and fraudulent transactions in Binani carried out by an independent forensic auditor. Dalmia Bharat Group CEO Mahendra Singhi said the company too had found some suspicious transactions during their internal evaluation but declined to quantify the amount. 


Jewellery Chain Kanishk Gold Defrauds 14 Banks In yet another bank fraud, State Bank of India has requested the help of the CBI in January to investigate jewellery chain Kanishk Gold Pvt Ltd for loan fraud to the tune of Rs 842.15 crore. Kanish, which has a registered office in T Nagar in Chennai, is owned by promoters and directors Bhoopesh Kumar Jain and his wife Neeta Jain. SBI was the lead bank in a consortium of 14 public and private sector lenders to give loans to Kanishk. In a letter dated January 25, 2018 to the CBI, SBI charged Kanishk with "manipulating records, shutting shop overnight." 


Aadhaar Re-verifying Deadline for Mobile Nos ExtendedThe telecom department on Wednesday has extended the time limit for re-verifying mobile numbers through Aadhaar till the time the Supreme Court decides on an ongoing case on the validity of the identification number and its enabling law. It added that as per the changes, all communications including voice or text messages sent by carriers to their subscribers should not include any last date for re-verification.
