In mature markets like Maharashtra and Karnataka and even in Kerala, Eicher has been witnessing weakness for the last couple of years, Chirag Jain, Lead Automobile Analyst, SBI Cap, tells ET Now.Edited excerpts: 



What is concerning you about Eicher right now?
We have been having a sell rating since our initiation about nine months back and so it is not a recent downgrade. Our thesis is fairly simple. This is a differentiated brand and they have grown phenomenally over the last seven-eight years. In many markets, there are already signs that this brand is witnessing brand fatigue and mature markets like Maharashtra and Karnataka have been witnessing weakness for the last couple of years.

In fact, our recent channel checks with dealers indicate that this weakness is spreading to even states like Kerala which is the largest market for Enfield and even Delhi. They are still reporting reasonably strong growth on a reported basis but the underlying growth in terms of same-store sales growth or in terms of numbers in the matured market, especially in the southern and western parts of India have already started to dip significantly. 

The July numbers have been a big disappointment. They have been doing roughly 75,000 units for the past few months and the 69,000 definitely comes as a big negative surprise. From our perspective, this is clearly reflective of the weakening retail trends that the company has been witnessing in many markets now. While obviously this number could be a one-off thing because there could be an element of transporter strikes as well, but by and large, we expect numbers to remain weak and year-on-year growth to keep sliding from 18-19% YTD growth that they have delivered.


Is it easy to take a call on a category because Eicher is not an ordinary mode of transport. Those who buy Eicher bikes or Royal Enfield frankly do not care about barish hoga, nahi hoga, farm income mein kya hoga (Whether monsoon is going to be good, what happens to farm income) etc. It is a lifestyle and aspirational thing. Isn’t it too early to write off this aspirational trend?
From that perspective, I totally agree. Aspirations are definitely going up and customers are looking for lifestyle oriented products. Eicher has been the leader in that space. However, I would like to highlight something. One of the reasons this brand did so well was obviously because this was a differentiated in terms of positioning. It was unique. There was novelty factor. They used to do 60,000 units in 2010 annual basis. Now, they are doing almost 800,000 units on an annual basis. So, this bike is becoming more and more common and that itself is hurting its brand appeal. 

This is not a recent phenomenon. In states like Maharashtra, the business is down almost for the past two years and this is down like big number. The retails were down 25% last year broadly as per our checks and they are down another 15-20% even this year. Same is the case with Karnataka and now even Kerala. Retail sales since April have been down in double digit as per our dealer checks. 

It is more brand specific issue as against macro issue with respect to two-wheelers or any particular category in our view.


Coming on competition, we know Harley Davidson is coming but with BMW as well tying up with TVS Motors and that product hitting the roads, is it going to be a clear and present danger to Eicher’s dominance? 
Definitely. As you said, the options for customers will go up. Earlier it was largely Enfield in terms of the affordable price range but now many global brands like BMW are coming in through tieup with TVS. Even KPM and now Triumph coming with Bajaj. Harley is planning on similar lines. They want to come in the big category but at an affordable rate. To that extent definitely competition will go up. It would not be a single brand that could challenge Enfield because Enfield is definitely on a significantly higher scale and reach but collectively these brands definitely could impact the growth going forward.

This would be over next two to three years’ perspective. Before that, the company itself is facing challenges and that has more to do with their internal issues because of brand fatigue that we are witnessing in many markets.

Your capital will only get some appreciation after the growth for next two years gets factored in the company’s numbers, Manish Sonthalia, Chief Investment Officer and the Director of the India Zen Fund, Motilal Oswal AM PMS, tells ET Now.Edited excerpts: 


It has been a good July. Do you think markets have stabilised or was it a one-month wonder and it could be back to square one?
I clearly believe that we are more up than down. These daily volatilities will continue to be there, but my sense is that markets are definitely going to be higher from these levels if you were to take six-nine months or even one year point of view. 

We have already seen the bottom in the mid and the smallcap names. I reiterate that stance. I was also of the opinion that there will be reversion to mean on both sides. You had seen spectacular run in the largecap names. They are bound to see some correction and you have seen such spectacular falls in midcap and small cap names. They are bound to see some pullback. The markets are playing out just exactly that. 

Having said that, among the largecap names that have come out with numbers so far, it is slightly amiss on the overall Nifty estimates per se because of bad numbers being posted by ICICI Bank and Tata Motors. They are pulling the overall estimates down for the current quarter and the FY19 as whole. 

Apart from that, broadly the numbers have come through and profit estimates at least on the EBITDA front have been in line with what we were anticipating. Something like 20% top line growth and a 20% EBITDA growth of course has not exactly translated into bottom line growth which is hovering around 10% in expectations for something like 13%. But this was on the back of EBITDA nuances on individual companies. But I am more bullish than bearish at this given point in time.


Eicher Motors is turning out to be a very interesting story. There was that eight-day truckers’ strike which I believe the management says has hit their monthly sales data. There were also some stories on Harley Davidson looking at targeting the same segment that Eicher is in. We have seen the stock correction play out in the last three days and now brokerages are revising their price targets downwards in Eicher. How would you approach the story?
I am not in sync with what the consensus downgrades. These are temporary aberrations on a monthly basis. There were some problems in West Bengal and truckers’ strike. My sense is this 73,000-74,000 vehicles per month is par the course and the management has reiterated time and again that 10.25 lakh is what the production looks like in fiscal 2019. 

There will be volatilities due to situations out of the company’s hands. Harley Davidson story is 2021 and by that time, the yearly volumes of Harley Davidson expectedly is to be higher than the 10.25 lakh which they have been projecting. It remains to be seen at what price points does the 250 to 500 CC bike comes out of the Harley Davidson stable because it is one thing to launch a 250 -500 CC product and another point again to make profit out of the same. 

Harley Davidson being international brand, they are going to have an Indian vendor where they are going to produce all these vehicles and the selling price will determine whether they make money and whether they are going to be a real threat to Royal Enfield. The niche point about Royal Enfield is that it is offering a superior bike at a very favourable price point. That is the competitive advantage which Royal Enfield brings on the table. According to me, the story stays and there is nothing negative but there will be volatility and one needs to live through the journey.


With yesterday’s rate hike, don’t you think that for two-wheelers, this is going to be a spot of a bother once again because that is where the pricing of loan pinches the most? For a premium brand like Eicher Motors, with competition coming in and rates going up, would that impact demand?
It is not a problem with the demand per se. If you look at quarterly numbers of all the automobile majors which have declared numbers, there is no problem with volume growth. It is a problem with the raw material cost pressure that is having a bearing on the margins. It is bringing down the overall profitability. Whether you look at Tata Motors, Maruti, Hero MotoCorp or Bajaj Auto, it is the raw material cost pressure which has not yet got fully passed on to the clients. 

Obviously these costs are not going to be absorbed in house and has to be transferred to clients over a period of time. So demand stays pretty much intact driven by both rural recovery as well as urban demand. It is not a problem with demand at all. Having said that, with the interest rate hike of 25 bps, the downfall of the rupee which was not abating, is halted for the moment. Of course, the trajectory remains down to the extent of 3% to 4% every year but with the commentary that we have heard out of the Fed and the rate hikes that was on expected lines of 25 bps, I think the depreciation in rupee has halted. That augurs well for emerging markets per se. I am not talking about daily volatilities but my sense is the rise in the dollar has halted for the moment and that will be good news for emerging markets as a whole.


The top holdings that you have maintained for a long time are Bajaj, Kotak Mahindra Bank, Page Industries and Eicher. These have been the heart of your portfolio. Are you of the view that some of these so-called expensive or the haloed stocks will still give decent compounding returns for the next two or three years and I am again referring to a Bajaj Finance or a Page Industries or a Kotak Mahindra Bank, the stock which you have been owning for a couple of years now?
I do not see any reason to sell these companies. Quarter after quarter, year after year, profit growth just keeps on coming. The markets front end the increase in corporate profits on these companies much in advance. Look at something like a Page Industries which hit Rs 30,000 yesterday. I was hearing from every nook and corner that it was very expensive at let us say Rs 15,000 or even Rs 20,000, but see the sweet spot for the company continues. I would not be surprised that the profit growth which till today was between 20-25% can actually accelerate because it is not only an innerwear company, it is a total apparel company now with leisure wear etc contributing their bit to the volume growth as well as the profitability

Till last year they outsourced 25% manufacturing, this year onwards they are of the opinion that they are going to outsource 50% of the manufacturing. So you are going to have a lower cost structure and at the same time they are going to pass on these cost benefits to the clients.

This is the best thing that could have been possible, a premium brand being available at a very affordable price. The stock just keeps on getting expensive because the longevity of growth continues and it keeps getting bigger. The same story applies for a Bajaj Finance. Look at the machine that Mr Jain has created, now he is creating a second line and it is equally good or even better. It has a long trajectory. 

Look at the Kotak Mahindra Bank. It has given more returns that HDFC Bank over the last 10 years. If you look at the CAGR, Kotak Mahindra Bank has delivered 42% CAGR whereas HDFC Bank has delivered 30% CAGR. It is a silent performer. I really do not see the need to sell any of these positions. They just keep on delivering numbers and I am happy to hold them for long periods of time.


A market truism is if you buy a good business at a reasonable price, you will make money. Rakesh Jhunjhunwala said these companies will grow but to expect that they will compound as stocks would be difficult and he gave me the classic example what happened to Lever between 2000 and 2010. It was growing but the stock was static. Are we running that risk in a Bajaj Finance or a Kotak Mahindra Bank or an HDFC Bank? The growth may be there but you may not get compoundation in stock prices?
The whole example about HUL followed time and again or even some of the other FMCG names which have remained stagnant for three years. Did you eventually lose capital in HUL? Even if you were to take from 1990 till date, the returns are spectacular! HUL would have a CAGR of 20-22% even after not performing for 10 years. The whole point is that the company announced a buyback at Rs 600 and the entire street was of the opinion that the share should be tendered in the buyback. Today the stock price is three times that. And the story is just unfolding. 

These brilliant machines and this has something to do with Lindy effect, if you have read the book Skin in the Game. Companies which have survived for long periods of time have better chances of survival.

The old notion about whether Indian markets are expensive is not important. They always appear expensive at all points in time. The crux to making money in India is not anticipating the next two years of growth, it will always remain fully priced for the next two years. The point is if you can see the next five years and you will only make money after one-and-a-half to two years from the day you deploy your capital. Otherwise, we will be owning junk businesses available at very cheap prices and they continue to become cheaper. 

The mantra to make money in India even from a foreign investors perspective is not to look at the next two years, they almost always look fully priced. 
 
 
 One should look at the next five years because your capital will only get some appreciation after that growth gets factored in the company’s numbers.

NEW DELHI: Domestic stocks shed early gains to end lower on Wednesday, pulled down by financial and auto stocks, after the Reserve Bank of India raised interest rates for the second straight meeting. On Thursday, Asian stocks were little changed with sentiment fragile after the latest escalation in Sino-US trade war. At 08:10 am, the Nifty futures on Singapore Stock Exchange (SGX) were trading 10.50 points or 0.09 per cent higher at 11,369.50, indicating positive start for Nifty50.


Here's a look at the top stocks that are likely to remain in focus in today's session - 


ONGC, Marico to report Q1 results today: ONGC, Marico, MOIL, Pfizer, Indiabulls Housing Finance and Manpasand Beverage are slated to release their quarterly earnings later in the day. Godrej Properties, Torrent Pharma, Majesco and GIC Housing will also report their June quarter numbers during the day.


Dilip Buildcon, Venky's: Thirteen stocks including Dilip Buildcon, Goa Carbon and Venky's India will move out of the additional surveillance measures framework with effect from Thursday, said BSE in a circular on Monday.


Reliance Infrastructure: The company on Wednesday reported a 19 per cent decline in its consolidated net profit at Rs 271.68 crore for the quarter ended June 30. Its total expenses rose to Rs 7,962.59 crore in the quarter under review. 


ICICI Bank: The bank has received RBI nod for Sandeep Bakshi’s appointment as COO.


Tata Motors: The auto major on Wednesday reported 21.3 per cent increase in domestic sales at 51,896 units in July as compared to 42,775 units in the same month last year.


Eicher Motors: The two-wheeler maker sold 69,063 units last month, up from 64,459 units in July 2017. The company shipped out 2,062 unit last month as against 1,302 units in July 2017.




Hero MotoCorp: The two-wheeler on Wednesday reported a nine per cent rise in its sales for July 2018. The company said its sales of two-wheelers increased to 679,862 units from 632,269 units sold in July 2017.


Tata Global Beverages: It posted 6.55 per cent decline in consolidated net profit at Rs 133.60 crore in the June quarter, on the back of certain exceptional items including some restructuring cost.


Kotak Mahindra Bank: The private sector lender will raise up to Rs 500 crore by issuing preference shares on a private placement basis. The funds are to be utilised to boost the capital under Basel III norms which are to be adopted fully by Indian banks by March 2019.


Hindustan Copper: The Cabinet on Wednesday approved a fresh equity issue of 15 per cent by Hindustan Copper which will help the state-run company raise Rs 900.6 crore. Hindustan Copper (HCL) will issue 13.87 crore fresh equity shares, to the extent of 15 per cent, which will bring down government stake in the PSU to 66.13 per cent.


IDBI Bank: The Union Cabinet has cleared the purchase of 51 per cent controlling stake in IDBI Bank by state-run insurer Life Insurance Corporation (LIC). 


L&T Tech: Larsen & Toubro may sell 41 lakh shares, representing 4 per cent of paid up capital, of L&T Technology Services at a floor price of Rs 1,400 per share. 


Excel Corp: Agrochemicals firm Excel Crop Care on Thursday said its board has approved a proposal to merge the company with Sumitomo Chemical India.

Buying in pharma, financials as well as oil and gas stocks made domestic equity markets come alive for the week to August 3. 

The BSE Sensex advanced 219.30 points, or 0.59 per cent to 37,556.20 on August 3, from 37,336.90 on July 27. The NSE Nifty index added 82.40 points, or 0.73 per cent, to 11,360.80 during the week gone by. 

Dr Reddy’s Labs, Lupin, Coal India, Hindustan Unilever and Power Grid rallied up to 9.50 per cent in the Nifty index last week. Eicher Motors, HDFC Bank, Tata Motors, HDFC and Grasim slipped 1-7 per cent. 

Below are the stocks and sectors that made headway during the week.


Reliance Communications: Shares of Reliance Communications rallied more than 5 per cent on Friday after the Supreme Court approved the settlement arrived at between the company and Ericsson India over a payment dispute and asked the Anil Ambani-led firm to pay Rs 550 crore to the other part by September 30.


Relief from ASM: Select companies, including Dilip Buildcon and Venky's India, hogged limelight this week after they moved out of the additional surveillance measures (ASM) framework with effect from Thursday. Venky’s India rallied nearly 49 per cent during the past five trading sessions while Dilip Buildcon gained 13 per cent. Bhansali Engineering Polymers, Bharat Seats, HIL, Himadri Speciality Chemical, Man Industries, Goa Carbon and Tinplate Company of India were among those that came out of the ASM framework from Thursday.


New listing: Shares of women's apparel maker TCNS Clothing tumbled over 8 per cent against its issue price of Rs 716 in its debut trade on Monday. After making a flat debut at Rs 715, the stock ended 8.12 per cent lower at Rs 657.80 on the BSE on July 30. The scrip closed at Rs 668.40 on Friday. Shares of HDFC Asset Management Company are set to debut on the bourses on August 6.


Jet Airways: Shares of the airline major plunged 7 per cent on rising concerns over its financial health and pilots on the warpath over proposed pay cuts. Jet Airways, however, on Friday expressed confidence of overcoming the current issues as it said the mismatch between high fuel prices and low fares is the biggest short-term challenge.


Top 5 gainers of the week: Venky’s India took it all as the top grosser of the week in the BSE500 index. It was followed by 8K Miles (up 27.56 per cent), Manpasand Beverages (27.49 per cent), Kwality (26.78 per cent) and HDIL (26.15 per cent). 

Manpasand Beverages on August 2 reported 1.30 per cent rise in net profit at Rs 36.37 crore for the quarter ended June. The company had posted a net profit of Rs 35.9 crore during the year-ago period. The company is planning to invest Rs 1,500 crore to set up 10 new manufacturing plants in the country by 2020 in its effort to drive volumes, according to PTI.


Top 5 losers of the week: For the week ended August 3, Redington (India) (down 14.04 per cent), SpiceJet (10.52 per cent), Tejas Network (9.53 per cent), Magma Fincorp (9.05 per cent) and Can Fin Homes (8.98 per cent) cut a sorry figure with maximum losses on the BSE500 index.


Sectoral performance: Barring the BSE Auto index (down 0.60 per cent), the rest of the sectoral indices settled the week in the green. The BSE Healthcare climbed nearly 5 per cent, followed by Oil & Gas (up 2.50 per cent), Metal (2.30 per cent), FMCG (2.20 per cent) and Power (2.10 per cent).


@fresh all-time high: As many as 33 stocks on the BSE500 index hit their fresh lifetime highs during the week gone by. The list included stocks such as HEG Ltd, Dabur India, GAIL (India), Havells India, Indiabulls Ventures, IndusInd Bank, Page Industries, VIP Industries, Graphite India, Britannia Industries, Mahindra & Mahindra, Nestle India and Relaxo Footwears.


Cabinet clears LIC-IDBI deal: The Cabinet on August 1 approved Life Insurance Corp's proposed acquisition of up to 51 per cent stake in debt-ridden IDBI Bank. Shares of the IDBI Bank advanced 3 per cent to Rs 61.90 on August 3, from Rs 60.10 on July 27.


Eicher skids: Shares of Eicher Motors, the parent company of motorcycle manufacturer Royal Enfield, slipped nearly 7 per cent during the week amid reports that American motorcycle major Harley Davidson is turning aggressive on Asia and hopes to unveil a lightweight motorcycle for India through an alliance with an Asian manufacturer. The stock came down 6.88 per cent to Rs 26,971 on August 3, from Rs 28,963.80 on July 27.

Talking to ETNow, Kunal Bothra, independent market expert, says the market has sailed higher in the face of global negative cues, and this bullish streak may stay.
Edited excerpts:


ET Now: This week, we have spent a large part of our time just circling around the 11,300 mark, with some intermittent dips also coming in. What are we in for next?


Kunal Bothra: It was that kind of a week for the indices, but there were no two ways to look at midcap stocks, because the market breadth remained positive for good part of this week. I sense that, with the market breadth now coming positive and midcap stocks making a comeback, largecap stocks have got that breather in terms of correction. I believe, it is going to be quite positive to take away. 

This week Asian markets, as well as the emerging market cues were extremely negative. Despite those negative cues, our market has sailed higher. In technicals, we look at price action and respect what the price says. The prices indicate that we are into a bullish trajectory and this bullish momentum should continue for the indices going forward as well.


ET Now: The entire auto pack was active this week, especially because of the monthly auto sales numbers. There were concerns around Eicher. The fact that it is richly valued, what is going to happen to it once Harley Davidson comes into play? You saw this week that Eicher Motors got pounded for three consecutive trading sessions. Is it building up for a higher move or do you think the pressure on the stock would remain because of this report? It will report its numbers also next week.

Kunal Bothra: I believe that the pressure is now getting into the stock and it has made a negative candlestick pattern. Generally, when you expect bottom formation processes to happen, we expect the stock to remain sideways for good amount of time without any negative triggers, at least in terms of price patterns. But, what you saw this week, compared to the last week, price action is more of a bearish engulfing price pattern. The indicators on monthly charts for Eicher Motors have broken lows, which were almost closer to 2,009-2,010 when the stock was at 8,000-10,000 odd level. So, with indicator action breaking on the long-term charts and the weekly price patterns getting negative, I believe that the stock is building towards the downward trend or opening up a downward trend and you might see the stock correcting.

So, I am not sure how the stocks would react post results, but if the stock breaks this 27,000 mark support levels on weekly basis, you should see a bigger correction for the stock.


ET Now: Do we see Reliance Industries scale up fresher and fresher highs because the move has been steady after its AGM?


Kunal Bothra: Absolutely. I think from 2017, when the stock broke that 9-10-year of sideways range, it has not looked back anytime in the last one-and-a-half years. Yes, on the long-term patterns, the stock is getting into that high acceleration mode where you see higher price appreciations, that too on a short span of time. I think that should augur well for the stock. If you see volume built up happening, which is what the charts are now showing, it means there is increased amount of participation into the stock prices. 

So, it indicates that this stock may not see that kind of volatility which could have been surfacing couple of months or quarters back and the stock is into a stable uptrend. I believe Reliance could continue to ride higher from current levels as well.


ET Now: Any interesting trades for Monday morning?


Kunal Bothra: Quite a few. I think one of them which I am suggesting to buy is Hindalco from the metal pack. I think it is making a good comeback over the last couple of days. Even though it has been sideways, but the price patterns have become positive for Hindalco so that is a buy, target of Rs 230 and a stop loss of Rs 204. 

State Bank of India, I believe that the stock has now confirmed a strong weekly breakout at this 290 odd mark. It also crossed the 200-day moving average quite convincingly last week, so that is also a buy with a target price of Rs 320 and a stop loss of Rs 289. 

The third stock is a midcap stock, Bombay Burmah. I think the stock is staging to a bullish flag pattern breakout. It is a liquid midcap name, would suggest a positional buy with the strong upside of at least Rs 1,700 to Rs 1720 zone, stop loss to be kept at Rs 1,555.

NEW DELHI: Renewed trade tensions between the US and China and a 25 bps rate hike by the RBI failed to dampen the bulls' spirits, who showed who was in-charge in the week gone by. 

On a weekly basis, BSE benchmark Sensex gained 0.58 per cent to end at 37,556 while NSE's Nifty added 0.73 per cent at 11,361.

"The gradual tightening by the RBI with a focus on maintaining balance between inflation and growth is a welcome sign. Moderation in crude price on the expectation of oversupply and better quarterly results is expected to extend the current positive momentum," said Vinod Nair, Head Of Research at Geojit Financial Services. "Largecaps and consumption-related sectors which offer safety net for investors are likely to do well." 

So, what's in store next week? Here's a look at major events that will shape the market in the week ahead. 


Next set of Q1 results: The coming week will see some of the leading names of D-Street unveiling their June quarterly numbers. Among big names, Adani Ports is lined up on August 6 while Mahindra & Mahindra will come out with its report card on August 7. Bharat Petroleum Corporation, Cipla, Hindustan Petroleum Corporation, Lupin and Siemens are all due to report their earnings on August 8. Aurobindo Pharma and Eicher Motors will keep their date with earnings on August 9. For GAIL (India), Hindalco Industries and State Bank of India, it's August 10.


India to impose import tariffs on US goods: According to a Reuters report, India will impose delayed tariffs on some US goods in September. Trade differences between India and the United States have been on the rise since US President Donald Trump took office. Bilateral trade rose to $115 billion in 2016, but the Trump administration is keen to bring down its $31 billion deficit with India and is pressing New Delhi to ease trade barriers, the report said. 


Sino-US trade war: Tit-for-tat tariff sanctions between the two largest economies -- the US and China -- on the trade front is likely to keep investors on edge. The Trump administration tightened pressure for trade concessions from Beijing this week by proposing a higher 25 per cent tariff on $200 billion worth of Chinese imports. Striking back, China on Friday unveiled new sets of additional tariffs on $60 billion worth of US goods ranging from liquefied natural gas (LNG) to some aircraft. 


US jobs data: US job growth slowed more than expected in July as employment in the transportation and utilities sectors fell, but a drop in the unemployment rate suggested that labour market conditions continued to tighten, Reuters reported. Non-farm payrolls increased by 1,57,000 jobs last month, still more than the roughly 1,20,000 jobs per month needed to keep up with growth in the working-age population, the report added. 


Monsoon progress: Monsoon rains will be normal in August and September, the India Meteorological Department said on Friday. "The rainfall during August-2018 is likely to be 96 per cent plus/minus 9 per cent of LPA (Long Period Average) and expected to be higher than predicted in June," it said. However, Skymet has downgraded its forecast for this year's monsoon, stating that the country might receive below normal rainfall, citing the continuing warming of the sea surface in the Pacific Ocean.


HDFC AMC IPO listing: Shares of HDFC AMC will list on the bourses on Monday. The IPO, which ran on July 25-27, was a big hit with 83 times subscription. Experts believe that the stock will see strong listing gains. HDFC AMC is India’s most profitable fund house and made a profit of Rs 722 crore for the year ended March 2018 and ranks No. 2 by assets under management (AUM) in the local mutual fund industry.


What does the tech chart say?
The Nifty50 index on Friday formed a large bullish candle, just a day after it made a Bearish Belt Hold candle on the daily chart, suggesting that the bulls were not ready to give up easily. “The uptrend shall remain intact as long as the Nifty50 stays above the 11,230 level, which can be regarded as a stop loss for all long positions. It looks prudent for traders to book some profits as we head towards the said resistance zone,” said Mazhar Mohammad of Chartviewindia.in.

This apart, trend in global markets, investment by foreign and domestic investors, the movement of rupee against the dollar and crude oil price movement are other factors that may have a bearing on investors' thinking in the coming week.

ET Intelligence Group: The transport and highways ministry has reduced in part the additional load trucks can ferry, perhaps minimising the anxiety of investors in heavy-vehicle makers that faced a likely fall in demand.

Now, the maximum safe axle weight in a vehicle of single axle, with two tyres, has been changed from 7.5 tonnes to 7 tonnes. Similarly, the standards have revised down the load to 19 tons from 19.5 for 16.2-ton trucks. So, the effective increase in maximum load carrying capacity for this category will now be 17 per cent instead of 21 per cent earlier.

When revised norms are implemented for different categories, the maximum load carrying capacity of a truck will increase by 15-20 per cent, compared with projections of 25-30 per cent based on the notification issued on July 16. This means lower incremental load carrying capacity than earlier, giving a breather to medium and heavy commercial makers such as Ashok Leyland, Tata Motors and Eicher Motors.

Furthermore, the new notification has made it clear that old vehicles (manufactured after July 16, 2018) will be allowed to increase the maximum load. This removes ambiguity among fleet operators as they can pay nominal fees to increase their maximum load carrying capacity as per the new axle norms.



The Street had been factoring in MHCV volume growth in the range of 10-15 per cent for the current and next fiscal years. The latest modification in axleload norms is likely to result in a major tweaking in projected volume growth for several reasons.First, the incremental load carrying capacity has been trimmed by 10-13 per cent after the new notification. This would allay investor concerns of overcapacity in the system and pressure on fleet operators’ profitability.

Second, new axle norms affected only 20-25 per cent of the total MHCV volumes, and this could have resulted in only a few percentage points impact on the total demand. About three-quarters of MHCV volumes such as tippers, intermediate commercial vehicles and cargo carriers remain unaffected by changes in new axle norms. Third, the approval time for a new vehicle complying with revised axle norms is likely to shorten.

This implies that new truck sales may be affected just for a few weeks. Investor interest is gradually reviving in shares of truck makers as the underlying demand buoyancy starts reflecting in their volumes in the next few months. 

The price-earnings multiple of pure play commercial vehicle company Ashok Leyland took a sharp cut to 14 times its projected next year earnings from 20 three months ago.

Rupee gains 5 paise against dollarThe rupee on Wednesday further consolidated its gains by 5 paise to end at 68.63 against the US currency, extending its recovery momentum for the second-straight day.


RBI to pay govt Rs 60,000 crore dividend
The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) will transfer Rs 50,000 crore of surplus as dividend to the government for the fiscal year ended June 2018, about 10 per cent higher than what economists and investors estimated. This is also higher than the Rs 30,659 crore paid last year.


FIIs buy Rs 569 cr worth equitiesForeign portfolio investors (FPIs) bought Rs 569 crore worth of domestic stocks on Wednesday, provisional data available with BSE suggested. DIIs were net buyers to the tune of Rs 30.25 crore, data suggested.

NEW DELHI: Domestic stocks are likely to see a muted start on Thursday, tracking weak Asian cues and Nifty futures on Singapore Stock Exchange (SGX). At 08:12 am, the Nifty futures on SGX were trading 2 points or 0.02 per cent lower at 11,476, indicating subdued opening for Nifty50.


Here's a list of top stocks which may hog limelight in today's session - 


Eicher Motors, JSPL to report Q1 results today
Eicher Motors, Jindal Streel, Jet Airways, Engineers India, Future Retail, IPCA Labs, United Bank, MRF and Page Industries are slated to release their quarterly earnings later in the day. PNB Housing, ICRA, Apollo Micro Systems, Godrej Agrovet, Whirlpool, Manappuram Finance, Hindusthan Sugar will also report their quarterly results during the day.


Selan Exploration: Ace investor Dolly Khanna on Thursday bought over 1 lakh shares in Selan Exploration amounting to over Rs 2.5 crore, according to NSE data.


Nalco: National Aluminium Company (Nalco) posted a net profit of Rs 687 crore in the first quarter ending June 30, 2019 (Q1FY19), an over five-fold jump over Rs 129 crore in Q1FY18. The company’s revenues jumped to Rs 3035.42 crore in Q1FY19 against Rs 1997.43 crore in Q1FY18.


Punjab and Sind Bank: Public sector lender Punjab and Sind Bank reported lower losses during the quarter ended 30 June on the back of an increased income from interest. The New Delhi-based bank reported a net loss of Rs 398 crore, as compared to Rs 524.6 crore in the preceding quarter.


Indian Bank: The lender reported a net profit of Rs 209.31 crore for the quarter ended June 30. This was a fall of almost 44 per cent over the corresponding quarter last year.


Adani Enterprises: The flagship company of the Adani Group said its consolidated profit after tax (PAT) rose by 6 per cent to Rs 169 crore in the April-June quarter of 2018-19.


HPCL: State-owned Hindustan Petroleum Corporation (HPCL) has posted an 86 per cent rise in net profit for June quarter at Rs 1,719 crore backed by higher refining margins.


BPCL: Bharat Petroleum Corp (BPCL), the country’s second-largest fuel retailer, on Thursday posted a three-times jump in net profit for the quarter ended June at Rs 2,293 crore on the back of improved refining margins and increased sales.


Pidilite Industries: Adhesives and industrial chemicals manufacturer Pidilite Industries said it will invest $5,00,000 as equity capital contribution in US-based Pidilite Ventures LLC. 


Apollo Pipes: The company has posted net profit of Rs 8.79 crores for June quarter against Rs 3.16 crores for the 3 months period ended June 30, 2017. Net sales stood at Rs 103.55 crore against Rs 84.01 crores in the year-ago period.


ZEE: Subhash Chandra-promoted Zee Entertainment Enterprises (ZEE) has removed all its content from Mukesh Ambani-owned Reliance Jio, including 35 live TV channels and more than 2 lakh hours of video-on-demand content after failing to arrive at an agreement on price.


Siemens: The company reported 25.5 per cent rise in net profit at Rs 204.40 crore on 14.6 per cent increase in net sales at Rs 2,964.40 crore in Q3 June 2018 over Q3 June 2017. The result was announced after market hours on Thursday.

Till the time we are out of the election cycle, what has worked for last couple of years will continue to work, Gautam Duggad, Head of Research, Institutional 
  
  
  Equities, Motilal Oswal Financial Services, tells ET Now.Edited excerpts:

Light at the end of the tunnel now seems to be a reality. For the longest time, experts have argued that earnings recovery is round the corner and markets did not oblige. But for the first time, it looks like analysts are finally getting it right. There is reason to get optimistic about earnings recovery.
Yes, you put it right. The things seemed better this time compared to the last couple of quarters. Numbers are doing fine even though they are not surprising big time but at least they are not disappointing which we had gone used to. What one still needs to be circumspect about is that the downgrades have not stopped. 

When I look at my universe, we are still downgrading two companies for every upgrade that we are making. The upgrade to downgrade ratio is still 0.5. For the quarter at least, the numbers are in line. EBITDA across the board whether it is my universe or Nifty, is up 22-23% which is in line with expectations. 

Of course, as far as Nifty is concerned, there is some disappointment in profit because of the corporate banks where the provisions have been raised up, but markets will look beyond that because it is at least signalling that we are now nearing the end of that bad asset cycle. So yes, fingers are crossed. We are not having too much of an upside room as far as valuations are concerned on Nifty and midcaps are still trading at 20-22% premium to largecaps. That also is in a way in a rising bond yield environment and caps the valuation room for upside.


We cannot take our eyes off ICICI Bank. Within days, it has climbed up to 320 levels. Would you say that the worst is over for corporate banks and is ICICI Bank the go-to story here? Everything seems to be in its favour. 
Absolutely. This has been our preferred pick in the corporate banking space. It is part of our model portfolio since long and as you said clarity on the asset cycle, provisions have been raised further. Valuations are in its favour. Subsidiary valuations are also quite attractive. Things seems to be settling down for this bank. We will need to see a couple of more quarters whether these things are finally over and whether we can restart the new cycle as far as asset quality is concerned. 

But given the valuations, clearly the risk reward is very favourable and for the quarter also they have done pretty well. They have raised the provisioning estimates. To that extent, there was some miss on the bottom line front but the quality of earnings has turned better. The watch list has reduced significantly. Overall stressed assets have also come off and clearly subsidiaries are doing pretty okay. It continues to be a part of our model portfolio. It remains the best pick as far as corporate banking part of the portfolio is concerned.


We were talking about Eicher Motors earnings coming out later today. Do you think it is time to step away from the auto space like Maruti or Eicher Motors and start looking for that alpha play?
For this quarter, auto numbers across the board have been disappointing, save Ashok Leyland and for that matter, Maruti, Tata Motors, Bajaj Auto, Hero, TVS Motors also. The numbers were well below expectations from the profitability front even though volumes were in line. 

Clearly margin pressures are mounting and we are in a rising commodity cost environment. Wherever there is lack of pricing power, it will get reflected in the numbers going forward as well. We have cut earnings estimate for auto across the board, and I am not talking about Tata Motors only. 

The other secular stories have also seen earnings cut. This quarter will go down as a disappointment for auto names. What we like within the auto space for some time now has been Maruti and M&M. Our preference has clearly been towards the four-wheeler space because we feel the competitive intensity in that space is relatively more stable and the opportunities of volume growth continues to remain very high -- be it M&M or Maruti. Within two-wheelers, we have liked Bajaj Auto for some time now. We feel that valuations are now reasonable and the market to an extent has over reacted to the fears of price war.


This morning we are talking about oil cooling off and we have seen that the OMCs have reported a good set of numbers. Do you think that the oil and gas space which is plagued by concerns of higher oil prices, can be seen as an opportunity and is there value in OMCs?
Clearly there is a lot of value in OMCs whether oil is at $70 or $75. We had actually done a report talking about the value that current market prices are discounting and there is substantial undervaluation in the space. But the problem that we need to contain within the next couple of months is that we will be heading straight into the election cycle and that is where a lot of uncertainty will creep in. 

While numbers can be fine and oil prices could remain range-bound, the markets propensity to ascribe the multiple to those numbers will be constrained in my view. This will remain a trading bet till elections are out of the way and even yesterday’s number of both HPCL and BPCL on core GRM front has disappointed big time. The numbers which were reported obviously propped up the inventory gains. I will stay sideways on OMCs.


In the past, retail banks, retail NBFCs, consumer staples and consumer durables have worked. At a time when markets are looking at a rotation, if ICICI Bank is making a comeback, if Axis Bank is recovering, do you think what has worked in last three years as a pet theme may start taking a backseat? HDFC Bank may start underperforming or get into timewise correction. HUL and Britannia may not give you any returns. Maruti may slip into a timewise correction. Could there be a very stark rotation for next 12 to 18 months?
There is non-zero probability of that happening but my view is that till the time we are out of the election cycle, what has worked for last couple of years will continue to work. And the reason is very clear. Some of these corporate banks, some of the cyclicals have done well. But as a pack you cannot take a call based on one quarter of numbers. 

My view is that the same four-five sectors which is consumption, private banks, NBFCs, autos and to an extent IT will continue to do very well at least till election related uncertainties are out of the way. While micros have clearly improved, we have seen some deterioration in macros in the last four or five months on the inflation front, rate hike, bond yields, crude, the global trade war concerns. That will keep the market little bit on the tenterhooks as far as the broad cyclical or the value part of the equation is concerned. 

We prefer quality with earnings visibility plays and selectively wherever we find things to be getting better, we increasing the weights for those stocks in our model portfolio. ICICI Bank is part of our model portfolio. We have Yes Bank as another proxy to play the same corporate banking cycle. Broadly, I will still side with the quality plus earnings visibility theme which has worked well and will continue to work well even for the next 12 months.

Consumption has done well and you will see very strong recovery going forward as well. This has been our view for last 15 odd months. Even last three-four quarters including this quarter, the commentary that has been coming in from consumers -- whether it is stables or discretionary – is that things are picking up both on urban and rural front and my view is that for the next nine months this consumption recovery will gain further strength. While clearly there is no debate on valuations from a one year point of view, those valuations can remain irrational for some more time.


In light of this mega HDFC AMC IPO, what are you making of the AMC business? Could you see a shift out of the HDFC Bank into HDFC AMC?
As far as AMC business is concerned, clearly, we are in the midst of a very important and structural shift in favour of financial assets as far as saving is concerned. So financialisation of savings which has been talked about for some time now remains a big theme to play in the next couple of years, maybe even five years, 10 years. 

But whether investors will shift from HDFC Bank to HDFC AMC looks a little improbable because of the size of the companies that we are talking about; also secondly, AMCs remain a cyclical business whereas private bank if far more structural and there is far stronger value migration away from the PSU banking set and there the opportunity is still humungous because 70% of the system is still with PSU banks. 

While on an absolutely basis people will play the AMC scheme, people will play the theme of brokerages, insurance which is a broad spectrum of financialization of savings but I do not think there is a possibility of people moving assets from the banks or NBFCs towards this. We have 40% weightage for financials already in the index and it looks like this could inch up a bit higher because we still do not have representations of the non-bank, non-NBFC space in the bigger indices. So that theme will continue to play and it looks very solid, just that as you mentioned about HDFC AMC has had a stellar listing. So, maybe from a near term point of view, there is obviously some cap on the upside that one can make but if somebody has a medium to long-term view. clearly this is a theme to play.


Themes for Value Migration

If you have to summarise one big trend for the next three to five to 10 years, where you see a strong earnings visibility and a big migration of value, where could that be? 
Just two months back, we had come out with a sequel report on value migration where we looked back to what exactly has happened in the last 12 months since our first report came out. We found that there are two areas where the pace of value migration has accelerated; one is clearly PSU to private banking or even insurance place because this is a theme which will continue to play out for the next five, ten years and I have no hesitation in admitting that even at these prices, I will not be too concerned if I am overweight on private retail banks. 

The second theme which we have highlighted is the jewellery space. Titan has been our top India consumer discretionary bet for the last two years now. Even at this price, I will be very positive there. Titan can easily compound earnings at more than 25% for the next three years. What has happened in the jewellery space is that even before GST, demonetisation itself has started the migration away from unorganised to organised. 

GST has just come in and helped and that space is big, $55 billion of jewellery industry we talk about, almost 800-900 tons per annum of gold consumption and hardly one player standing out there which has a pan India footprint and a very strong brand equity which is gaining share every single day. So, I will be very positive on that space.

Then of course, there is a broad set of consumption categories -- consumer electrical, adhesives, diagnostic space -- where the room for growth by sheer shift from unorganised to organised base trade exists for a long time. It has not materialised yet barring one or two categories, because we are still in the early days as far as GST is concerned. It is hardly one year but these are things where from a 3-5-year point of view, there can be many compounding opportunities.

NEW DELHI: The BSE Auto index was trading 0.21 per cent up at 24,243 around 02:25 pm on Thursday, with a mixed set of components. 

Shares of Ashok Leyland (up 2.35 per cent), Tata Motors (up 1.39 per cent) and Mahindra & Mahindra (M&M) (up 0.84 per cent) were the top gainers in the index.

Balkrishna Industries (up 0.74 per cent), Eicher Motors (up 0.53 per cent) and Bajaj Auto (up 0.41 per cent) too were trading up.

However, Cummins India (down 3.89 per cent) and Bharat Forge (down 2.02 per cent) were incurring losses.

Bosch (down 0.43 per cent), MRF (down 0.30 per cent), Motherson Sumi Systems (down 0.29 per cent), Apollo Tyres (down 0.24 per cent) and Maruti Suzuki India (down 0.23 per cent) too were among the losers.

Shares of Hero MotoCorp (up 0.06 per cent), Exide Industries (down 0.02 per cent) and TVS Motor Company (down 0.01 per cent) were flat around that time. 

Market continued to be in the positive zone on gains in heavyweights, including ICICI Bank, Infosys and Axis Bank. 

The BSE Sensex was up 140 points at 38,028, while the NSE Nifty50 index was up 24 points at 11,474. 

Among the 50 stocks in the Nifty index, 23 were trading in the green, while 27 were in the red. 

ICICI Bank, Axis Bank, State Bank of India and Coal India were leading among Sensex scrips.

On the other hand, Bharti Airtel, ONGC, HDFC Bank, Kotak Mahindra Bank and IndusInd Bank were the top losers in the Sensex kitty of stocks.

New Delhi: Eicher Motors today reported its best consolidated net profit in a quarter at Rs 576 crore in the April-June period, driven by robust motorcycle sales.

The company posted 25.36 per cent rise in net profit in the first quarter ended June 30 from Rs 460 crore in April-June period of 2017-18.

Consolidated total revenue from operations stood at Rs 2,548 crore for the quarter under review, the company's highest ever so far in a quarter. It stood at Rs 2,255 crore in the year-ago period.

During the period under review, the maker of niche Royal Enfield bikes sold 2,25,286 units, registering a growth of 23 per cent over 1,83,731 units in the same period of last year.

"We continue to make significant progress on all the targets that we have set for ourselves and are happy to report strong financials quarter on quarter," Eicher Motors Managing Director and CEO Siddhartha Lal said in a statement.

To better cater to demand, the company has commenced work on second phase of its Vallam Vadagal manufacturing facility and should begin production by mid of FY20, he added.

Besides, Chennai Technology Centre is on track and the company plans to complete the installation of all testing and validation equipment by October this year, Lal said.

He added that the company will start bookings for twins -- Interceptor 650 and Continental GT 650 -- in a phased manner starting from the third quarter of this financial year, across geographies.

Volvo Eicher Commercial Vehicles (VECV), the company's joint-venture with Sweden's AB Volvo, saw revenue from operations increase by 45 per cent to Rs 2,609 crore in the first quarter from Rs 1,803 crore in the same period of last year.

Profit after tax rose by 78 per cent to Rs 118 crore from Rs 67 crore in April-June quarter of last year.

The S&P BSE Sensex closed above 38,000 level for the first time at 38,024, up 0.36 per cent, while the broader Nifty50 gained 21 points, or 0.18 per cent, to settle at 11,471.

Global brokerage firm Morgan Stanley feels the stock could rally as much as 100 per cent in two years as the narrative shifts to growth from bad loans. But there will be stock volatility for 2-3 quarters, the brokerage cautioned. The stock ended 4.64 per cent higher at Rs 332.95 apiece on BSE.

This apart, the company posted 12.2 per cent rise in its consolidated net profit at Rs 25.2 crore. Shares of the company closed at Rs 2.41 per cent lower at Rs 3,650 apiece on BSE.

NEW DELHI: After two straight sessions of record highs, equity benchmark Sensex retreated on Friday owing to profit-booking in recent gainers, including Reliance Industries, State Bank of India and ICICI Bank amid weak global cues.

It was Nifty's first fall after five straight sessions. 

The domestic market experienced the heat of weakness in global stocks, following a new round of US sanctions on Russia. Plunging Turkish lira too weighed on European markets as most of them fell more than 1 per cent on Friday.

However, Chinese stocks showed some resilience. As per media reports, gains in technology stocks made Chinese market post its best week in a month. 

Sensex took a beating of 155 points, or 0.41 per cent, settling at 37,869, whereas Nifty fell for 41 points, or 0.36 per cent, to close the day at 11,430.

In the Nifty index, 19 stocks remained in the green, compared with 31 in the red, while Sensex saw 12 stocks advancing and 19 declining.

For the week, the Sensex rose by 0.83 per cent and the NSE counterpart Nifty inched up by 0.60 per cent. 

State Bank of India, Reliance Industries and ICICI Bank contributed the most to Sensex losses.

Hero MotoCorp, Mahindra & Mahindra, Tata Consultancy Services, ITC and Kotak Mahindra Bank were the top five gainers in the Sensex index.

State Bank of India, Sun Pharma, Vedanta, Tata Motors and Power Grid Corporation stood as the top five Sensex losers. 

BSE Midcap and Smallcap indices underperformed Sensex on Friday, falling 0.80 per cent and 0.78 per cent, respectively.

Gail (India) declined 3.40 per cent even as the oil and gas major on Friday reported 22.8 per cent year-on-year (YoY) rise in standalone profit at Rs 1,259.25 crore for June quarter, in line with Rs 1,262 crore PAT projected by analysts in an ETNow poll. 

Shares of Hindalco Industries also suffered losses of 2.22 per cent, despite the company on Friday posted 42.84 per cent year-on-year (YoY) rise in profit at Rs 413.53 crore for the quarter ended June 30. It had posted a net profit of Rs 289.51 crore in the corresponding quarter last year.

State Bank of India (SBI) on Friday reported a standalone net loss of Rs 4,875.85 crore for June quarter, which fell way short of Rs 242 crore profit projected by analysts in an ETNow poll. This was the third straight quarter of losses for the largest domestic lender in terms of assets. The stocks settled 3.79 per cent down on BSE.

Jet Airways (India) Jet Airways tanked 8.39 per cent after the airline deferred the consideration of unaudited financial results for the first quarter of the current financial year 2018-19.

Royal Enfield maker Eicher Motors rallied 5.55 per cent today as the company on Thursday reported its best quarterly consolidated net profit at Rs 576 crore in April-June, driven by robust motorcycle sales. 

Sectoral indices on BSE settled mixed. BSE Metal fell over 2 per cent, leading among the sectoral losers.

State Bank of India (11.15 crore), Jaiprakash Associates (8.77 crore), Punjab National Bank (5.10 crore), PC Jeweller (4.21 crore), Adani Power (3.92 crore) and ICICI Bank (3.63 crore) also featured among the most traded stocks.

On the other hand, State Bank of India (Rs 3,493.52 crore) led the pack of most active stocks in value terms.

The correction is a a wonderful opportunity to ignore the so-called highest quality largecaps and come to the mid and smallcaps, Porinju Veliyath, Founder & CEO, 
Equity Intelligence India, tells ET Now.Edited excerpts:

Last time we spoke, there was a carnage, a messy selloff in mid and smallcap stocks. Do you think that sharp summer correction is behind us?
I strongly believe so. That was a very big selloff and some correction was definitely due because of the small and midcaps space had been overheated. There had been four-five years of rally in that space while the blue-chips underperformed in general. When the correction came, it was overdone.

I feel this is an ideal time to explore value among the small and midcap companies. When we say midcap companies, according to the new definition even companies at Rs 28,000-30,000 crore valuation are midcaps. There are wonderful companies and some of them are industry leaders with a relevant business model. Some people say do not buy those things, buy only the highest quality companies today at 100 PE, 80 and 70 PE. I do not agree with that. It is a cycle. Everything has its cycle and opportunity. Those who underperformed in last five years are performing over last six months, which does not necessarily mean that this is the strategy to adopt. Maybe this is the peak of the strategy if you are buying a Lever, a Nestle, a Britannia, a or Page or an Eicher -- very high quality companies with 70-80-100 PEs. A lot of people are doing that today. But that will be like buying the midcaps in November-December last year.


Looking at Nifty and Sensex, we can see that it is only a handful of stocks that have taken us to the top. But you believe that the market is going to get a little more broad-based and it is not going to be those select few 15-10 odd stocks which are going to move, and the rest of the index stocks would play catch-up. What makes you think so?
There is a herd mentality that works in the market. Smallcaps and midcaps are moving down now and the largecap blue-chips are moving up. So, everybody jumps into that band wagon and makes it a dirty place. This is what is happening today. There are very high quality companies which in the past 10 years have done exceeding well. Their best of times are going on and the best of earnings happening and the best of margin, the least competition and those are the companies that are quoting at 100 PE at today’s EPS. I do not understand that. Expecting these companies to grow at 20-25% for next 100 years is utter nonsense. It does not work. 



There is a disruptive world out there. Competition can come from nowhere. But all said and done, I am strongly bullish on Indian markets, Indian economy. I still believe in changing India and improving corporate governance. I still believe this is the best theme to continue to play for Indian markets. That does not mean just go and buy any chor (fraud) company. What I am saying is provided there is a very relevant business model and high business value in the company, then only we should bet on improving corporate governance if that was the reason for lack of wealth creation in the past. 

There are clear symptoms that India is changing, structural economy is changing. We had been talking about this change from unorganised economy to organised, from black to white. This has a long-term positive impact on a lot of companies. The former promoter of Bhushan Steel was arrested yesterday. All these things are very important. There would not be any incentive to remain unprofessional and it is happening in many companies. 

My own experience also says that there may be a few companies doing badly and that is what is being projected today in the social media but there are companies doing wonderfully as well. I have a smallcap bought one year ago. It is a five-bagger today and it is at an all-time high. This promoters were not considered to be very professional but today they are becoming professionals, they are showing profits, they are ready to pay tax. These changes provide one-time opportunity in India since independence.


At an index level we are talking at 11,500-12,000 for the Nifty. I know you track the midcaps more but their midcap and smallcap portfolios are not reflecting that euphoria. What would you say to viewers and investors who are feeling a bit confused in the market?
Nifty and Sensex definitely represent Indian equity markets today. I am not saying that investing in blue-chips is bad. But if you buy the top quality 10 companies in India at today’s PE and valuations, it may give you 5% to 10% CAGR for next five years or ten years because these companies are doing the best in terms of margins and lack of competition. With above normalised earnings, they are giving very high PE. Investors should think twice on earnings or return when they invest. Otherwise they are going to be disappointed in next five years’ time. 

There will be some companies still giving you 20% CAGR. If you make a portfolio of the top 15-20 companies, you are going to get 5% to 10% CAGR in next five years. Whereas if you look at opportunities in the mid and smallcaps, especially after the sharp correction, you are going to make maybe 30-35% CAGR for next five years. However, that does not mean you go and buy and fraud companies, dying companies, irrelevant businesses. You should look at medium quality companies with relevant business model and which are futuristic going forward among the mid and smallcaps. In these places, after selloff you are getting maybe 10 or 15 PE. Some of them maybe in single digit PE but there are not too many of these companies. 

The opportunities are not like 2013 or 2014. Maybe it has come down by 75% but India has only 1,000 investable quality companies. You have to choose 15-20 companies from them. That is called stock picking. I think this is a wonderful opportunity to ignore the so-called highest quality largecaps and come to the mid and smallcaps. Today companies with Rs 5000-6000 crores market cap are also considered to be smallcaps. For me, they are midcaps. 

I feel the opportunities are immense and the general market continues to be good. Any further move in the market will be broad based. Last week, there are signs of a greater participation happening and we will see broad-based market move in coming days.


Next Cycle is Starting for Investible Quality in Midcaps and Smallcaps


For long term investing, is banking still a good sector? Considering the turnaround which seems to be hinted at, should one look outside private banking names?
Yes, I still feel if somebody is interested in banking that makes a lot of sense. There are small microfinance companies quoting at high valuations, five times, ten times the book value because of the growth happening. And India has definitely lot more growth prospects in that sector, especially in the consumer finance in the retail finance so this is going to grow in a big way in India. We are so much under-banked or under-financed in that segment. 

I would still prefer something like and IDFC plus Capital First is going to merge, maybe a Federal Bank kind of bank. We have exposure in Federal Bank, of course, recently we have bought after the big selloff. Maybe a JM Finance kind of stock in the capital market related activity too. So there can be similar kind of midcaps and of course, the smallcaps which have got less NPAs, more visibility and good people managing.

I feel IDFC Bank plus Capital First can be a stock to watch if somebody is looking for next five years. There is more safety and more growth prospects in long term investing. Also, it is too early to write off some of the old generation private banks which are improving their efficiencies, have got a control over NPAs. The next three quarters are very important also. They will give you much more visibility. But once that visibility happens, the stock price could be doubled and maybe you have to take some chance before the full visibility comes if you buy it at a bargain price.


What is the future of speciality chemicals, especially dyes and dye intermediaries?
I do not follow this space much because it was too much fancied and valuations have gone through the roof. They had a great time in earnings. I do not have knowledge how this industry will look going forward in the next 1-3 years. The Indian companies in speciality chemicals segment were all in a sweet spot. We even made money in a company called Balaji Amines. We used to buy it at two-digit prices a few years ago. But we have exited it. 

Some of the companies have gone up five and ten times. Graphite Electrodes people have been after that. We have a habit of ignoring the current fancy or too much fancied segments and we always look for sober valuations in the mid and smallcaps. At the same time, in our PMS, we have also got ITC. It is not that we are always into smallcap companies. We have got high quality companies also like TTK Pharma or Hawkins as well.

I consider that is a very high quality company, we have a large exposure. I am not recommending these stocks, what I am trying to tell you is look at high quality, high PE stocks and also the value stocks with medium quality . This is the game now, which one you want.


Do you think you need to have a slightly greater weightage towards largecaps and megacaps because the four-year one sided bull market in those stocks is coming to an end. Earlier, 99% of the small and midcap stocks went higher and good investors like you were able to identify stocks which have done much better than the benchmark. Do you think it is time to get very selective?
I see it slightly differently. I feel the next cycle is starting for the investible quality in mid and smallcaps. It has started last week or maybe in the last two, three weeks. So another cycle is coming up in that and people will be not very happy with the kind of return that a Hindustan Lever or a Britannia or a Page and Eicher kind of stocks may give. They are wonderful companies, the best of companies. They have created great wealth and the promoters should be congratulated.

Remember Sun Pharma, Lupin in 2015. People were saying you the best companies are infallible, they can never disappoint you. At Rs 1200, Sun Pharma was the best company in the country and today after three years it is still below half the price. So, do not think everything is so evident in the companies. There can be problems in many sectors. Many of these high quality, high PE companies which created wealth in the last five, 10 years, are going to face competition going forward. 

Today the world is becoming smarter, entrepreneurs are becoming smarter, many of the family promoted and unprofessionally managed companies or traditionally managed companies are getting into a new growth orbit. They are understanding the benefit of growing the market cap, creating wealth through the market capitalisation. They are also going to be advised by the best of the talent in this country and they will create competition for the good players today. 

Certain companies were in a sweet spot and had very high margins and growth prospects in the last five, 10 years. That need not be repeated for the next five, 10 years. New people may come up. These companies that we are mentioning were all smallcaps years ago. Page Industries was only a Rs 500-crore market cap or Rs 300 crore in the beginning. People say do not buy smallcaps. What does it mean? That means you should not have bought Page Industries at Rs 500 crore?


You are of the view that there is serious money to be made in the small and the midcap space and one should not look at equities in a linear manner. Why don’t you clarify that viewpoint? Everybody thinks that equities are like fixed deposits, badhta hi rahega (will keep on growing)?
See, India has everything. Our economic structure is like that. Large global brands have an advantage. They will continue to be there. But that does not mean you buy a high quality company at any price. That is the simple thing I am telling you because if you stay overpriced, then there can be two, three sometimes five years of stagnation. This happened in Reliance. In last 10 years, Reliance did not create any wealth because people overpaid at that point of time and then they had to wait 10 years from where the stock went up by some 150%.

Even even I identified the stock and recommended below Rs 1,000. Now the stock is more than 100% up. So, this can happen to the best of companies in this country. We do not know. Do you have that kind of visibility for TCS for the next five, 10 years? I do not think, TCS management will be confidently telling you we can grow at this rate for the next 10 years. Things can change. So this is applicable also to the highest quality, most fancied companies today.

Royal Enfield maker Eicher Motors rallied 3 per cent on Friday as the company came up with its best ever quarterly show. 

On Thursday, the bike maker reported its best quarterly consolidated net profit at Rs 576 crore in April-June, driven by robust motorcycle sales.

The company registered 25.36 per cent growth in net profit for the first quarter to June, from Rs 460 crore in Q1 of 2017-18.

Consolidated total revenue from operations stood at Rs 2,548 crore for the quarter under review, the company's highest ever so far in a quarter. It stood at Rs 2,255 crore in the year-ago period.

The scrip added 3.02 per cent at Rs 28,315 at around 10.22 am. The BSE Sensex came down by 95 points, or 0.25 per cent, at 37,930 at around the same time.

Global brokerage firm Macquarie maintained ‘Outperform’ rating on Eicher Motors with a price target of Rs 37,000. 

“June quarter’s operating income was ahead of estimates. Despite rise in volume, market share is still low in large states. We expect Eicher’s growth momentum to continue and expect compounded annual growth rate of 22 per cent in net profit over FY18-21. Royal Enfield sales volumes and margin improvement would aid growth,” Macquarie said.

CLSA retained ‘Buy’ rating for Eicher Motors, but cut the price target to Rs 36,150 from Rs 39,300 earlier. “June quarter’s operating income was in line with estimates. Royal Enfield margins expand despite commodity price pressures. Royal Enfield waiting list comfort has faded, but structural story is intact. We cut FY19-20 EPS by 4 per cent factoring in slightly lower margins and financial income,” CLSA stated.

Kunal Bothra, independent market analyst, gives a buy on M&M and a sell call on Tata Motors. Bothra was talking to ET Now.Edited excerpts: 
  
  
  


How would you read into Friday’s move on the index? Does the fact that we fell in line with global cues worry you because the market is bloated and elevated at these levels?
I believe that it is going to be difficult to cross 11,500 mark and that is going to be one of the key hurdles which is going to test the mettle of this bull market. There are a couple of data points which transpired on Friday and also the entire last week. For a good part of the week, the market breadth remained on the positive side except for Friday. 

There was one important factor which gave the markets a bit of a concern and that was the rise of the dollar index. For the first time in last 12 months, we saw the dollar index rising above 96 mark. 

Also, if you look at the terms of the composition of stocks which were going up, a large part of the private sector banking names like HDFC Bank, IndusInd Bank etc, were the ones which are now consolidating. L&T is still below its 200-day moving average and that is a big concern for the overall market structure as well. The 11500 call on the Nifty has the highest amount of open interest and even in the last week of rise, that open interest did not recede.

In fact, it just about increased on the higher side. All in all, you could be in for a bit if volatility, maybe a bit of retracement on the indices. 11,500 is the major resistance and on the support side, 11,200 is the point where we could try and test the support over the next couple of days.


What do you think is next in store for ICICI Bank which has had a stellar move and SBI after that bit of volatility on Friday, once the street was trying to digest the numbers and then that huge rebound that played out as well?
SBI ran slightly ahead of the results. Expectations were on the positive side and the stock had run up 15-16% in the last one and a half weeks odd of price performance. Post the results, we saw SBI correcting and in that process, formed a bearish engulfing kind of a pattern. I believe that over the next ouple of days at least, from a very near term view, the stock can retrace back to that Rs 300 mark. If it settles around this 200-day moving average which is around Rs 300 mark, the selling pressure could abate. 

As regards for ICICI Bank, the stock should consolidate for at least a week or two odd around this Rs 330 odd mark. The run-up has been very sharp and swift and the indicators have entered into the overbought territory. I believe ICICI Bank should consolidate in the near term.


How would you read into the rebound in Eicher Motors which played out on Friday? Is it going to continue or is it just a flash in the pan?
This could be a false rebound. On monthly charts, it has given a breakdown of a nine-year range in terms of couple of indicators. Rarely I have seen that the stock gives you a false breakout of a nine-year kind of range and such kind of breakdowns on the indicators result into the stock going to a multi- month, multi-quarter downtrend.

I believe that could be largely the pattern for Eicher Motors. These kind of rallies in terms of trading opportunities should be used for shorting cases and at 29,000-29,250 there are ample amount of resistances. I categorically believe that another 200-400 points rally on the stock and it should come back into a good shorting opportunity.


What can we trade on Monday morning?
Again it is a mixed kind of trading ideas which I am giving. The first one is a buy on M&M. It is an interesting chart not just because of the kind of breakouts the stock has seen but over the last six months as well, it has been one of the few stocks which has not shown any kind of volatility and that is I think a positive aspect. 

If you expect the index to become volatile, M&M could continue to ride higher from that angle as well. It is a buy and Rs 980 is a one week target and stop loss is closer to Rs 920-925 zone. 

And the second one would be a sell on Tata Motors. I believe that on daily charts the stock has once again broken a crucial support of 250 mark, it has shown signs of weakness trading below its long term as well as 50 DMA and I believe it could continue to drag lower so that is also a sell, targets of at least 235, stop loss 260.

Edelweiss Financial Services has a buy call on Eicher Motors with a target price of Rs 35,731.

The current market price of Eicher Motors is Rs 28,442.30.

Time period given by the brokerage is one year when Eicher Motors price can reach the defined target. 


View of Edelweiss Financial Services on the company:
Eicher Motors’ (EIM) Q1FY19 consolidated EBITDA at Rs 8.1bn came in line with estimate despite higher-than-expected commodity pressure. While the waiting list has dipped to less than a month, demand outlook remains strong for premium products—higher demand for rear disc brake options (refer, Gun Metal Grey: Gunning for growth) and faster growth for >350cc segment (4MYTDFY19 growth at 35% YoY versus 17% for 350cc models). EIM is also expanding presence in low-penetration states, which should bolster growth despite the fact that in a few states (Maharashtra, Karnataka) RE demand is synchronising with industry trend. 650cc twins will be launched in September end and delivery will commence from December. Maintain ‘BUY’ with target price of Rs 35,731.

ET Intelligence Group: After a gap of almost five years, the Eicher Motors stock may emerge as a ‘value’ play for investors who had missed buying into the Bullet-maker when business had moved to the premium end of the road.

Now, the gap in valuations between mass-market two-wheeler companies such as Hero MotoCorp and Bajaj Auto on one hand and Eicher Motors on the other is narrowing. Still, the upside could be limited due to consistent moderation in volume growth in Maharashtra and Karnataka, unless new markets or products compensate the shortfall in the rate of expansion.

In the past five years, Eicher Motors has been viewed as a ‘growth’ story, a differentiated bike maker in a segment having low single-digit market share but high latency in demand. Consequently, the waiting period of the most selling bike Classic 350 rose to 12-15 months.

With the certainty of high volume visibility due to the waiting period, the Street was ascribing price-earnings multiple of more than 40 times until two years ago.

Eicher then increased its installed capacity to meet the market demand. The combination of incremental capacity and saturation in some markets has caused the waiting period to disappear.

Consequently, the volume growth of Royal Enfield has started moderating. Simultaneously, the PE multiple assigned to Eicher has started falling. The P/E multiple has fallen to 22 times one-year forward from 45 times two years ago.

Interestingly, the stock is back on the radar for investors looking for ‘value’ plays as the P/E premium between mass market twowheeler makers and Eicher has dropped to just 20 per cent.



Eicher’s stock deserves to trade at higher valuation given its presence in the premium market, which is having low risk of competition in the medium term. The company is also a key beneficiary of the shift toward premium bikes from the large pool of commuter bikes.

Credit Suisse has upgraded its rating to ‘neutral’ from ‘underperformer’ after the June quarter, citing that valuations are reasonable at 22 times and deserve a premium over other two-wheeler makers.

Furthermore, the company’s management in the June earnings conference call maintained its production guidance of 950,000 units (implies 15 per cent YoY) at the end of FY19. The Street has been pricing in volume growth of 15 per cent and 10 per cent, respectively, for the current and next fiscal years.

Volume growth will be entirely dependent on how the company performs in Uttar Pradesh, Bihar, Rajasthan, and West Bengal as these markets have been the biggest contributor to incremental sales.

The premium bike market in these four geographies is less than 4per cent, compared with the all-India average of 6.4per cent, thus providing enough room to expand.

In the first quarter of the current fiscal, these four markets accounted for about 23 per cent of the total sales volumes and grew in the range of 40-70 per cent, while unit sales in Maharashtra and Karnataka fell 15 per cent and 11per cent, respectively.
