That is a call that we have been giving and should potentially do. If there is M&A activity, consumption story continues to remain strong and cash generation is quite robust. Some of these companies. we would certainly look at but we want to see that the expensive valuation is because of a good corporate governance standards and strong promoters and not merely because there is a potential growth ahead which is overestimated.

Consumer spending is holding up in a big way. Even the hotel segment is looking rosy, says Kaustubh Belapurkar, Director, Fund Research, Morningstar Investment. He spoke to ETNow. Edited excerpts:


How are you looking at the market positioning?

There is a shift in the way managers are looking at it. Clearly, large cap stocks are the focus of the market not just because money has come into it but also because managers are largely shifting towards some of these large cap names. That is a trend we expect will continue at least for some time. Just take some defensive positioning or get into the most steady names. 

At a more sectoral level, we have seen some breakout from the previous years where we saw why financials got some money, but it was not as broad based as it has been before. Select banks continue to get money, some with turnaround sort of stories like your ICICI, Axis. The trend has changed.



Do they continue to see buying though ICICI Bank?

Absolutely. We still see. Even in December, we have seen a fair bit of buying. Axis continues to see buying. These are definitely somewhere managers have added on positions.



What about IT because you saw 2018 was great and 2019 is not going to be the same and look how TCS or even Infosys for that matter has completely negated that opinion. They are confidently saying we are here and we are here to stay and we continue to see the kind of growth. And look at the move on Infosys?

Yes, absolutely. Again, IT is kind of a tiered approach. If we clearly look at TCS and Infy -- the two favourites -- TCS actually added a lot of positions by managers simply because it has been so underowned as a stock. Infy continues to add positions, but beyond that we do not really see too much traction from managers. 

There has been selling in Wipro and Tech M. Maybe, we have some buying in a couple of IT names, but otherwise it is largely the two largest companies that are there in terms of additions on the portfolio.


Any midcap IT names which have seen buying or some acute selling?

Some sporadic buying in the likes of MindTree, probably Hexaware, but not something that will really trigger off their chance.

Yes Bank was very institutionally held. I do not know what you have picked up on Yes Bank. I do not see that as part of your list anywhere.

Yes Bank has been largely a play reasonably underowned. I do not think that is really changing. We have not seen people pulling out too much from a domestic mutual fund perspective or coming back into that stock really.

You are saying this even prior to the last six months when that whole issue started?

That is right.


So, it was never really heavy...

Not one of the heavily owned. I would not even say it is in the top five banking stocks that were being held.


I want to talk about HDFC Bank because just this morning one of our chartists said that in the long term chart pattern, HDFC has really come to the divergence point, it is going to be a big move either this way or that and HDFC Bank would shake off the market. Are holdings still intact for HDFC Bank?

Absolutely. We are going to only see incremental additions. I would not say it is a very aggressive addition. Everyone has kind of topped up on that, but everyone is holding steady on their positions. I mean it is about Rs 60,000 crore odd of exposure from domestic mutual funds managers to HDFC Bank. That is a pretty sizeable chunk. It is the largest holding by a long shot.


Auto has continued to suffer, be it an Eicher or even Maruti. Are there significant exits out of auto or even for a Maruti?
That is one trend we have actually witnessed over the last six months. Clearly there is a selloff in auto. Maruti is a classic case in point. We have seen selling in Hero MotoCorp, in some of the other names. Auto's and auto component’s exposure is coming down in terms of an overall exposure, for sure.


Do you see more build-up in Reliance Industries? Is it one of your top MF buys?

Yes, that actually continues and they have really built steam in the second half. It was largely ignored in the first half and when the price action started happening, a lot of the managers were trying to probably catch up. If I just look at aggregate 2018 numbers, Reliance Industries was the largest quantum of purchase by managers.


What about pharma because you are seeing some traction there as well and I am surprised to see how Sun Pharma is among your top MF buys, given all the overhangs?

Yes, Sun Pharma has been in and out to be honest, but among pharma names, that is probably one of the names that has still kind of held steady. After the dip with all the overhangs, managers still thought that valuations are probably better than what they would want them to be. That is where we have seen some buying in December and we have had some positive flow of news come in regarding a patent infringement case and some approvals coming through FDA. They are looking at valuations and some positive news flow.


What else have been your observations, anything peculiar which stood out in midcap or small cap positioning?

The way the market is structured, we have seen very-very limited buying in midcaps in 2018. I would say about 85-90 per cent of the money of the aggregate buying has gone towards large caps and the remaining towards mid and smallcaps. But the one trend we have seen is the consumer spending play which still looks strong. We have seen buying in the hotels segment though not very large. That is one play really playing out strongly for managers.


Do you expect more volatility? I mean there is a broader question because of the election risk. What is your sense on flows into the first half of the year?

So yes, there is. Even December was a classic case where we have seen a little bit of slowdown of flows on the domestic front. We speak about the steady state of the SIP book that continues to grow albeit at a slower pace, but the lump sum money is actually coming off. In fact it has gone into the negative zone now. 

We are at about Rs 6,000 crore versus a usual run rate of about Rs 8,000-9,000 crore in the market. We suspect that is going to be a little bit here and there depending on the way the markets go for the next six, nine months. That will be something of an overhang for sure.

NEW DELHI: Around 32 stocks fell to touch their 52-week lows on NSE in Thursday's morning session.

Among the stocks that touched their 52-week lows were The Byke Hospitality, FDC, Igarashi Motors India, Khadim India and Kalyani Investment.

Mask Investments, Shriram Pistons & Rings, Sun Pharma Advanced Research, TPL Plastech and Vivimed Labs also featured among the stocks that touched their 52-week lows on NSE.

On the other hand, Apollo Hospitals, Golden Tobacco, Punjab Chemicals & Crop Protection and The Western India Plywoods were the stocks that hit their fresh 52-week highs today.

Domestic benchmark index NSE Nifty was trading 19.60 points up at 10,909.90 while the BSE Sensex was trading 69.79 points up at 36,391.08. 

In the Nifty 50 index, HPCL, GAIL, Indian Oil Corp, M&M and Bharti Infratel were among the top gainers on the NSE. 

However, YES Bank, Zee Ent., Bajaj Finance, Hindalco Inds. and Eicher Motors were among the top losers in the index.

The confluence of local and global cycle picking up together should play out in the agri input side and we prefer 
  
  
  agrochemicals over other inputs, Ravi Dharamshi, CIO, ValueQuest, tells Nikunj Dalmia of ET Now in an exclusive interview. There are good set of companies where significant returns can be made over the next two-three year period, says Dharamshi. Edited excerpts:


Well begun is half done or is this just beginners’ luck in 2019?
No. First of all, our tribute to John Bogle. There is a lot of contribution to the fund management industry and one has to recognise that. Coming back to 2019, we really went through a rough period in 2018, especially if you are somebody managing a midcap concentrated strategy focussed on Indian midcaps and smallcaps. 

Valuations are now in our favour and some of the things that were really bothering like crude or the interest rates going higher, have now fallen in place. We can be a little more sanguine about the prospects of interest rate hardening as well as the crude going up. That bodes well for the Indian midcaps and they are relatively more reasonably valued today. So 2019 will definitely augur well, much better than 2018. 


We had a global scare in the last leg of 2018. There was a scary selloff in Dow, a huge meltdown in the hallowed FAANG stocks. So far, we have managed to survive the first storm. But if this is a recurring or long unwinding, emerging markets like India will also get hit hard.
It is surprising definitely but I would say 2019 is going to be more a year of mean reversion than anything else. Since the 2009 bottom, American markets have had a huge outperformance to the world market. The global market cap moved from $25 trillion to $85 trillion over a span of a decade and the biggest contributor to that was from the US market.

Relatively speaking, emerging markets have underperformed significantly and this gap between developed market and emerging markets had reached a high point sometime last year and that I think is reversing. So that is one of the reason why we did not see a selloff even though nearly a trillion dollars were wiped off just from the FAANG stocks in the US. Since FIIs have been sellers in our market over last two years, it is not a phenomenon of last three or six months.

We are constantly being going down in weightage. Our market cap probably peaked at around 2.5 trillion and came down to 1.8 trillion. We have also seen quite a bit of wealth erosion and that is why today I am much less worried about global crisis setting off or some kind of contagion which can make our markets collapse. I do not think we are facing that kind of scenario today.


In markets we have to look forward but I will look back for last two years. 2017 was the big year for fund managers and smallcap investors. 80% of the market went higher. In 2018, 18% of the market either went lower or remains stable. What is in store for 2019?
You are right. One of our studies showed that in 2018, more than 50% of the stocks fell more than 50%. In that kind of a scenario, your portfolio cannot be too much different. But enter 2019 and there are many opportunities to invest and those risks where there are unreasonable valuations or unreasonable expectations those have been taken out of the market. Now there are good set of companies where significant returns can be made over the next two-three year period. It might not be immediately in 2019 because some of the concerns are real. The stocks have not come off without a reason. There are good reasons. But that is where the opportunity lies. But opportunity is dressed in overalls and looks like hard work. 


Are you able to find enough businesses which can give a potential earnings growth of 20% to 25% for next two or three years? Are those businesses available at reasonable levels now?
There is an opportunity in the market today in the kind of buckets that we have. What we look for is good business, reasonable valuation and a business tailwind. Now it is very difficult to find a combination of all these three things. So it is definitely very miniscule. But at the same time, if you were to take in a little bit of a cyclical headwind in the business or there are some with structural headwind, then there is a bucket of and a pool of companies available where you can make good money if you stretch your horizon into three and five years of investment. But you will have to live through next 12 months when the problems will still be in the transition phase of turning around. 

For example, PSU banks or real estate developers are going through some real tough times. Those are structural issues. But valuations are not an issue over there. It is only an issue of whether and if the sentiment will revive. If the sentiment revives, the business tailwinds will come back. There is a going to be a big supply crunch for sure. The number of players are going to be whittled down dramatically in real estate. So that is a positive.


Do you own a real estate stock?
No, I do not own any and only thing I am saying is that that is a bucket which requires more than five years’ horizon. If you look at something that has more cyclical business headwinds, then over there, your horizon can be three to five years and you can still make good money. Managing public funds, sometimes we face challenges of having a 10-year horizon. So, we have to look at three to five years. I would be more willing to buy a company which has some cyclical headwind going on and which can be corrected by say the raw material prices coming down or some amount of stimulus being given to the economy. Those kind of situations provide more clear and present opportunity for us today.



So if we talk about your portfolio positioning in Jan 2018 versus January 2019, how many stocks have vanished, how many stocks have entered and in terms of an aggregate approach is there anything new and different or is it an extension of the same?
The last time we spoke, there were stocks priced to perfection and especially some of them were on the consumption side. Now, we are out of stocks that are priced to perfection with a business tailwind. Everything is going in favour but there is no room for error. High quality, high performance, highly valued. The money has been chasing very few ideas in this market and those few ideas have become really outpriced now. As long as the business tailwind continues, the valuations can sustain but I think there is a real risk of a significant underperformance with a three-year point of view.


We have seen that in Eicher, we have started seeing that in a Page. , I think you are referring to the same obvious stocks?
Yes that is the pool of companies that I am referring to, no one particular name but that is the kind of thing. Whether it is Page or Eicher or even Britannia or VIP.


Raamdeo Agrawal told me one thing which is that mehanga roye ek baar sasta roye bar-bar, we are always trying to find something very cheap but it does not work?
No, no, we are not going down the junk road but at the same time Infosys can have 10 years of underperformance, Hindustan Unilever can have 10 years of underperformance. So, you better be clear about what you are buying and I think the risks are real in terms of underperformance over the next three to five years. Any long-term investors’ horizon is also a risk.


You have been bullish on private sector banks, select chemical names and select retail/fashion names. Have those themes extended themselves for 2019?
 In private sector banks, definitely the theme continues but probably now some of the larger or the retail banks are not the ones to be focussed on. Corporate banks are better placed and that is where a surprise possibility is there in terms or earnings as well as a comfort in valuation. 

Larger private corporate banks or even smaller private regional banks provide a very good risk to reward with a five-year point of view if the capex cycle was to revive and that should revive sometimes within next six and 18 months. That is a fertile area to look at.


You do not think corporate banks are becoming a consensus trade? 
Consensus or not, you have to look at how much of the ownership is with the institutions and if you believe that price performance has been fantastic, then the performance has not even started ye. Honestly speaking, they are still available. These banks are doing sub 1% ROA. Over the next three to four years, the ROAs will move from 0.7-0.8 to 1.2-1.3 and with some bit of leverage, the ROEs can move beyond 15%. 

In that kind of a scenario where all these banks that are quoting between 1 and 2 can quote anywhere between 2 and 3. We are at the beginning of the story, we should not be worried about consensus at this point of time. It is a large pool, FIIs have been selling and I do not see us being in an overcrowded trade by any stretch of imagination.


You have this reputation of being the pharma expert on the stock market. When you see an experience like Sun Pharma in 2018, it just shakes you that corporate governance issues have been raises at this bluest of the blue chip company, Debt is not a problem for pharma though growth may be challenging. What does that speak for the sector?
This does not speak for the sector per se, it is a company specific issue. The sector issues were definitely more on the FDA front and those are behind us. The corporate governance issues were not completely unknown to the market. It is only that they are out in the public domain today and they probably did not matter when you were a small company but today when you have trillions of rupees of market cap, they matter a lot more because all the global FIIs have taken an exposure to your stock. There is no choice but to get your act together, clean up the books. 

And you are right, they do not have net debt but that cash in US and the debt in India are not matching. They will have to probably get out of this mess in some way but it reflects more on the company.


We started with John Bogel but let us go back to our favourite investor Warren Buffett. We love to quote him. I wonder if he has to start charging IPs for his quotes...
Yes he should charge a royalty.


 ...he will be a richer man by a billion dollars at least.
For sure.


He pretty much is alluding to what you referred to that you have to buy good businesses when there is a temporary slowdown or news is bad. Where else do you see this kind of a thesis getting played out?
So one space where three-four years of bad period is coming to an end I believe is agri inputs side. Agri has been in a distress and it is more because of agri prices being down than anything else. The global cycle also was on a slowdown since the last three years and over here there is a very good possibility that over the next one to two years there will be a pickup.


Despite what data we are getting from rural India?
No, because there is so much distress that is when governments will be forced to take action and when government take action it will have impact You want to be positioned for it today.


Focus on where the buck is going to move?
Correct. Because there is distress today there is no choice but the agri prices to move up over the next 12 to 18 months and finally this is a cycle. If a farmer is not getting good realisation for his crop he will move to another crop that gives him better realisation and that will eventually create shortage in the other crop and that will make the prices move up. 

Cyclically, from agri prices point of view we are close to a bottom and we should move up in the next 12 to 24 months and that is the local cycle but even globally also, the commentary or the large chemical companies has now started being positive and they have started witnessing growth which had come down to close to zero, now they are talking about 5-7% kind of growth. 

So the confluence of local and global cycle picking up together should play out in the agri input side and we prefer agrochemicals over other inputs.

The elections matter a lot to a speculator. For us, it is a question of offering an opportunity to enter or exit, says Ravi Dharamshi, CIO, ValueQuest, told ETNow's Nikunj Dalmia. Edited excerpts: 



Well begun is half done, or this is just the beginner's luck.

No, I think first of all our tribute to John Bogle. His contribution to the fund management industry is a lot and one has to recognise that. 

Coming back to 2019, we really went through a rough period in 2018, especially if you are somebody managing a midcap concentrated strategy focussed on Indian midcaps and smallcaps. Valuations are now in your favour. 

Some of the things that were really bothering like crude and the interest rates going higher have now fallen into place. We can be a little more sanguine about the prospects of interest rate hardening as well as crude going up. That augurs well for Indian midcaps and they are way better valued today and way more reasonable. 2019 will definitely augur well, much better than 2018. 

In 2018, especially the late leg of 2018, we saw a global scare and it was a scary selloff in Dow, a huge meltdown in some of the so-called hallowed stocks, the FAANG stocks. So far, we managed to survive the first hit, the first storm, but if this is a recurring unwinding and a long unwinding, emerging markets like India will also get hit hard.

It is surprising definitely, but I would say 2019 is going to be more a year of mean reversion than anything else. Since 2009 bottom, American markets have had a huge outperformance to the world market. Global market cap moved from $25 trillion to $85 trillion over a span of a decade and the biggest contributor to that was the US market.

Emerging market actually relatively underperformed significantly and this gap between developed market to emerging markets had reached a really really wide point sometime last year and that is reversing. 

So that is one of the reasons why we did not see a selloff even though nearly a trillion dollars were wiped off just from the FAANG stocks in the US. FIIs have been sellers in our market for the last two years, it is not a phenomenon of last three months, six months or something like that. We have been constantly going down in weightage. 

Our market cap probably peaked at around $2.5 trillion and came down to $1.8 trillion. We have also seen quite a bit of wealth erosion and that is why today I am much less worried about global crisis setting off some kind of contagion which can make our markets collapse. I do not think we are facing that kind of scenario today.


In markets we have to look forward, but I will look back and not look back for last one year, but last two years. 2017 was the big year for fund managers, the big year for small cap investors, 80 per cent of the market went higher, 2018, 18 per cent of the market either went lower or it remains stable. What is in store for 2019?

You said it right. In 2018, one of the studies we did showed more than 50 per cent of the stocks fell more than 50 per cent. In that kind of scenario, I do not think your portfolio can be too much different than that. But enter 2019, there are many opportunities available for you to invest and those risks with unreasonable valuations or expectations have been taken out of the market. 

And now, there are a good set of companies available where there can be significant returns made over the next 2-3 years. It might not be immediately in 2019 because some of the concerns are real. It is not like without a reason that the stocks have come off. There are good reasons. But that is where the opportunity lies. But opportunity is dressed in overalls and looks like it's hard work. 


Are you able to find enough businesses which can give a potential earnings growth of 20-25 per cent for the next 2-3 years and are those businesses available reasonably now?

The kind of buckets that we have, is there an opportunity in the market today? There is an opportunity. What are the kinds of opportunities available? What we look for is a good business, good valuation, reasonable valuation and a business tailwind. It is very difficult to find a combination of all these three things present. So, that definitely is very, very minuscule. 

At the same time, there is a little bit of a cyclical headwind in the business or there are some with structural headwinds also. If you are willing to look at those companies, then there is a bucket and a pool of companies where you can stretch your horizon into three and five years of investment and then make good money over there. But you will have to live through next 12 months where the problems are still in the transition phase of turning around. 

For example, even if I just want to put some context to it, PSU banks or real estate developers are going through some real tough times. Those are structural issues, but valuations are not an issue over there. 

It is only an issue of whether and if sentiment will revive. Business tailwinds will come back, there is a going to be a big supply crunch, for sure. The number of players is going to whittle down dramatically in real estate. That is the positive.


Are you happy to buy real estate stocks, do you own a real estate scrip?

No, I do not own any and the only thing I am saying is that is a bucket which requires more than five years of horizon. If you look at something, that has more cyclical business headwinds. Over there, your horizon can be 3-5 years and you can still make good kind of money.

In managing public funds, sometimes we face challenges having a 10-year kind of horizon. We have to look at 3-5 years. Over there, I would be more willing to buy a company which has some cyclical headwind going on and which can be corrected by, say, raw material prices coming down or some amount of stimulus being given to the economy.

Those kinds of situations are more clear and present opportunity for us today.


If we talk about your portfolio positioning in January 2018 versus January 2019, how many stocks have vanished, how many stocks are entry points? In terms of an aggregate approach, is there anything new and different or is it extension of same?

If you remember, we spoke about it last time. There are stocks which are priced to perfection and especially, some of them are on the consumption side. We are out of stocks that were priced to perfection. They are fantastic companies, business tailwinds, everything is going in favour, but there is no room for error. 

So, money has been chasing very, very few ideas in this market. Those few ideas have been really really out-priced now. Now as long as the business tailwind continues, the valuations can sustain. But there is a real risk over there of a significant underperformance with a 3-year point of view.


We have seen that in Eicher. We have started seeing that in a Page. You are referring to pretty much the same obvious stocks?

Yes that is the pool of companies I am referring to, no one particular name but that is the kind of thing, whether it is Page or Eicher or even for that matter Britannia or VIP.


Raamdeo Agrawal told me one thing which is that mehanga roye ek baar sasta roye bar-bar, we are always trying to find something very cheap but it does not work?

No, no, we are not going down the junk road but at the same time Infosys can have 10 years of underperformance, Hindustan Unilever can have 10 years of underperformance. You better be clear about what you are buying and I think the risks are real in terms of underperformance over the next 3-5 years.


You have been bullish on private banks, you have been bullish on select chemical names and you have been bullish on select retail/fashion names. Have those themes extended themselves for 2019?
Private sector banks definitely as a theme continue. But probably now, some of the larger or retail banks are not the ones to be focussed on, corporate banks are better placed. That is where there is a surprise possibility in terms or earnings as well as comfort in terms of valuation. Larger private corporate banks or even for that matter smaller private regional banks provide a very good risk to reward with a five-year point of view if the capex and corporate cycle was to revive.

That should revive whether it is in the next six months or 18 months. That is definitely a fertile area to look at.


You do not think corporate banks is becoming like a consensus trade or maybe I am speaking to all the smart guys who are bullish on corporate banks. I do not know what is this, is this a coincidence or is this a consensus trade now?

Consensus or not, you have to look at how much of the ownership is with the institutions and if you believe that price performance has been fantastic, the performance has not even started yet. Honestly speaking, they are still available. These banks are doing sub-1 per cent ROA. Over the next 3-4 years, the ROAs will move from 0.7-0.8 per cent to 1.2-1.3 per cent and with some bit of leverage, the ROEs can move beyond 15 per cent. 

In that kind of a scenario, all these banks that are quoting between 1-2 per cent can quote anywhere between 2-3 per cent. We are at the beginning of the story, we should not be worried about consensus at this point of time. It is a large pool, FIIs have been selling and I do not see us being in an overcrowded trade by any stretch of imagination.


You own this reputation of being the pharma expert on the stock market when it comes to pharma. We look up to you, we look for your thoughts, when you see an experience like Sun Pharma in 2018, it just shakes you. 


It shakes you that here is the bluest of the blue chip company where corporate governance standards have been raised for a sector and for industry where debt is not a problem, growth may be challenging. But they have never had a debt problem, what does that speak for the sector?

This does not speak for the sector per se. It is a company specific issue, the sector issues were definitely more on the FDA front and I think those are behind us. The corporate governance issues I do not think were completely unknown to the market, it is only that they are out in the public domain today.

They probably did not matter when you were a small company, but today when you are in trillions of rupees of market cap, they matter a lot more because all the global FIIs have taken an exposure to your stock. There is no choice but to get your act together, clean up the books. And you are right. They have an issue... They have a unique situation where they will have to probably get out of this mess in some way, but I do not think it reflects on the sector per se, it reflects more on the company.


We started with John Bogle, but let us go back to our favourite investor Warren Buffett. We love to quote him, we love to talk about him, I wonder if he has to start charging IPs for his quotes...

Yes, he should charge a royalty.


...he will be a richer man by a billion dollar at least.

For sure.

He is pretty much alluding to what you referred to buying good businesses when there is a temporary slowdown or news is bad. Where else do you see this kind of a thesis getting played out?

One space where three-four years of bad period is coming to an end and I believe is agri inputs side. Agri has been in a distress ant it is more because of agri prices being down than anything else. The global cycle also was on a slowdown for the last three years. 


What data are we getting from rural India?

Because there is so much distress that governments will be forced to take action. You want to be positioned for it today.


Focus on where the puck is going to move?

Correct. Because there is distress today, there is no choice but the agri prices to move up over the next 12-18 months. Finally, this is a cycle if a farmer is not getting good realisation for his crop, he will move to another crop that gives him better realisation.

That will eventually create shortage in the other crop and that will make the prices move up. Cyclically, from agri prices point of view, we are close to a bottom and we should move up in the next 12-24 months and that is the local cycle. 

Even globally also, the commentary on large chemical companies has now started being positive and they have started witnessing growth which had come down to close to zero. Now they are talking about 5-7 per cent kind of growth. The confluence of local and global cycle picking up together should play out in agri inputs and we prefer agrochemicals over other inputs.


The thesis of cyclical recovery, the thesis of attractive valuations or reasonable valuations is no longer there in consumers or retail banks or for that matter some of the other obvious names. Some of these opportunities are there in the B2B space, but the challenge with B2B space is that you will not see a huge PE expansion and you will not see a huge margin expansion. I am sure you are aware of that?

So, you are absolutely right, on the consumer front getting a good business at a reasonable valuation is the biggest challenge and even though as a theme, we are really bullish on it. On the B2B consumer side, there is a possibility, I mean I slightly disagree with you over there that PE expansion cannot happen and markets have done funnier things. It is not like it is my base case to bet on a PE rerating over there, but if an upcycle over there extends beyond what the market can imagine right now, they will move to a higher plane in terms of rating. 

So consistency and performance is the most important thing. 


We spoke about a niche pocket which you like within the finance space and that was the small finance bank (SFB). Now the RBI ruling has just acted like a sledgehammer for some names there. Are you still bullish on those names with the RBI red line?

Absolutely. See, they are small in size with Rs 2,000-3,000 crore kind of a loan book size and a similar kind of market cap that is number one. Second, we have to realise they are not NBFCs anymore, they are banks. They have gone through the pain of taking over the cost of the banks, they have started providing SLR, CRR and the cost of converting their branches into a bank branch going from a second floor to a ground floor. 

Those costs are in the numbers. MFI still remains a very-very profitable product while there is a non-MFI SFB also. I am not talking only about MFI SFB. And the SME space is the most lucrative space in terms of lending, you need to have your processes right, you need to do your lending right. 

But they have a platform available from where they can grow 20-25 per cent for a decade. That is the kind of runway available to them. Can these Rs 4,000-5,000 crore loan book become Rs 25,000, Rs 50,000 crore? Sure, it can become, there is no reason why it should not. They have a licence to do that. The ultimate aim is to become a universal bank, SFB is only a stepping stone and some of the vetting is done by RBI for us, they have given licence only to the 10 most deserving guys. 

So out of those 10, I am sure at least two or three will emerge to become far larger and much better banks.


You own the two or three obvious names there, the ones which have just got licence from becoming a microfinance to a small bank. Is that the way to approach it, buy all three, four whatever is available?

Yes, we do own a couple of those names.


Okay, that is the best way to buy them because you do not know eventually which one would be the winner?

No. You go through their history, you see which one survived the crisis best and which one is building its liability franchisee properly, which is the one that is diversifying in its product and geography and you take a call based on that. Still that does not guarantee you success, but at least you know what you are getting into.


What would you say is the outsized bet for this year?

As for outsized bet for this year, we run a concentrated portfolio and each and every bet for us is outsized. I will not say that there is any new stock that we have bet on in a big way, but I think just coming back to the earlier theme, corporate banks and within that small regional banks, there is a real good risk reward available over there.


Autos have corrected and there is a fear that there is a slowdown but if economy comes back, the rural demand comes back, Bajaj Autos and the Eichers and the Mahindra & Mahindra’s of the world will make a comeback. The way you invest, can you spot an opportunity there or this is not the alley where you want to walk? 

No, I am not very keen on looking for opportunities immediately. I believe that the EMI-led growth or leverage led growth is going to witness a slowdown over the next 6-12 months, all this growth was led by the NBFCs and the NBFCs have tightened their purse strings by choice or maybe not by choice. 

Because of that, growth will slow down over there. I would rather go to where the end consumer is buying out of his own pocket instead of taking loans for that.


The NBFCs have avoided a cannon ball, but the cruel fact is that look there was an asset liability mismatch, they were borrowing short and they were lending long. This setup has broken, this created opportunity for good players to gain market share. Are you looking at buying something in the NBFC space?

Again, no. It is not...


But that is the place you would be hunting right now, right?

No, I think the problems have just started. 


Even in HFCs?

Maybe not in HFCs. In some of the HFCs, the asset liability mismatch is not such a big issue. Even though you sell 25-year payment but those are actually seven, eight year products and some amount of ALM mismatch is necessary for you to make your ROE over there. 

I am not buying any HFCs at the moment, but I do not think the extent of problem in some of the HFCs will be as big as some of the other NBFCs that are let us say developer loans or any such thing. I think there is a decently chunky real estate developer portfolio which is coming up and it will be recognised as an NPA over the next 12 to 24 months and the conditions are not going to get any easier in terms of funding for the NBFCs. 

I would wait, it is a situation which is in flux, I would wait to see which are the players that are going to survive, which are the players that are going to get hit and I will wait for a year or so before I can say now the NBFC crisis is well and truly behind us and we can place our bets over here.


In 2013, when we met you said if I get a million dollars right now, I would invest it right away. I can see and smell that kind of an opportunity in the market. If you get a million dollars from a client after this interview, do you have the conviction to invest it right away in your set of stocks or will you wait? 

Investing is not an issue, managing the expectation is an issue... I will invest only when there is a crisis in the market or I will invest only when I get the best combination of opportunity, entrepreneur and valuation. 

For that kind of a money, there are very few opportunities in the market but if you are somebody who has a compulsion to look for opportunities and if there is no crisis, ex of crisis I think the valuations are okay, what we need is some revival in growth going forward. 

If that is the case, a reasonable expectation of return can be met. Let us not get carried away, can I make 10x return or something like that in four, five years, surely but probably I would be more comfortable maybe three months, six months down the line where more water has flown under the bridge. 

But investing and deploying in the equities is not an issue. In fact, we are fully invested, we will probably go fully invested into the elections and we will not change our strategy just because there is an event. That can have a big impact on the market, we are planning to live through it.


The way you manage money, the election would be just one of the events?

Yes, I mean, it matters a lot to a speculator and for an investor who has a longer term horizon. I have to only see whether it is going to provide an opportunity to enter or is it going to provide me an opportunity to exit.

Combined with the upcoming budget and seasonality around that, looks like a higher probability of that to happen soon, Nifty to soon cross 10950-11000 levels, Rishi Kohli, CEO, ProAlpha Advisors, tells ET Now.Edited excerpts: 

What is that you think the market is pencilling in with regards to what may happen with the Interim Budget?

The runup to the budget has been positive many times in the past few years and this time it looks no exception to that. In the near run, the technical patterns that are formed on the Nifty, Bank Nifty indices point to a bit more upside in the near term. 

Last time on the show, I had mentioned that Nifty looks like it could go to 11250 or so. Right now it is struggling to cross 10950-11000 levels. But the way the triangle pattern has formed, it is hitting on the upside multiple times. It looks like it will break out soon and that combined with the upcoming budget and seasonality around that, looks like a higher probability of that to happen soon.


What are you making of the strong move in Reliance -- Rs 100 move in just the last two trading sessions? The fact that digital as well as retail is posting good EBIT and the oil and gas business is going to be at best in line, was something which one would assume was already in the price. Why this fresh enthusiasm on Reliance then?
We have seen many times that in the runup to the results, one thing happens and then post results, that pent up buying or selling continues to happen. This time, the stock had consolidated for a bit and overall things are being minorly positive on the results front. This has led to the fresh upmove. Technically, again it looks like it should head back to previous highs which are about 100 bucks from here or may be slightly lesser now given today’s move. 

That should happen but how it handles that region combined with how further quarters shape up, will give rise to whether it is a long-term trend or not.


A couple of months ago when we spoke there was Eicher and Lupin in that portfolio. Are they are still there?
Yes, yes.


Eicher still. How much money have you lost?
So yes, Eicher is down about 15-20% from the last time we talked. Obviously, there has been disappointment in the stock due to lower sales coming in, margins tapering off a bit, plant shutdowns and strikes. It was trading at high PE multiples. The September-October decline in the markets had a hard hit on the high PE stocks. 

The price behaviour is not that out of line with how all this news has developed. Having said that, the underlying fundamentals and the underlying things at the company level still continue to be positive because there are some new launches happening, there is some new capacity coming up.

All of that, as it fructifies into whatever further developments are there, should give a fillip to the stock bouncing back. And currently from a technical standpoint, 20,000 levels are very strong supports. Ideally, it could go into a slight sideways patch before really shooting high like past few years, but from 20,000 a bounce till 24,000 or so is easily possible and one should at least wait there and see what further developments are happening before taking a call to either trim or add or something like that.


Where else do you believe that we could see negative surprises in the earnings season? Would you believe that be it a Hero MotorCorp, a Bajaj or a TVS for that matter, the negative is already baked in the price?
I would largely think so. Two-wheelers and even a lot of the four wheelers like Maruti and all have been disappointing for a long time. Tata Motors has its own issues. A lot of these are interesting plays more from a value and a long term perspective because finally some of these are growth stocks but they have disappointed and therefore taken the hit.

The underlying very strong fundamental thesis on which they have grown over time has not really changed. There are things which obviously have upset the move for one or two years here or there. There’s a similarity in a lot of fronts across these kind of stocks. 


Sun Pharma, Yes Bank, Jet Airways will you buy any of them?
I would not.


Why? If you wait for robin, spring is going to be over.
Which is why some of the other stocks which so far have been underperformers in my portfolios are still there because the underlying themes for which they were bought have not been disturbed too much beyond a point.


Why have you bought Sterlite Tech because my understanding is that prices of broadband fibre which they make, have collapsed 30% internationally and there is a problem with the China telecom order. The thesis for Sterlite Tech is broken according to me.
There is a very large data network opportunity in Sterlite Tech. They are one of the only ones placed for it. The long-term ROCEs are moving higher or are already high. So a business which could sustain greater than 25-30% ROCEs, high ROEs, reasonable earnings growth like FY20, profits could be double of FY18 despite some of the hiccups.


Are you counting for the cancellation of the China order? The management is admitting that there is a decline. The guidance numbers have not been changed. Are you accounting for this virtual 30-35% drop?
Yes. But we are expecting some of these profits and earning numbers to almost double and I can adjust for this a little bit as well. There are other positives also coming in. In terms of the underlying tailwinds in the industry, there may be 10% here or there but it will still amount to some very good numbers and technically again it is at the bottom. Very long-term supports are there, it is at lot of different channels and patterns supports.That also gives additional comfort because it is basically low risk high reward.


Is there trade in IT? Infosys has done exceptionally well but TCS has done extremely poorly?
That sort of a mean reversion is happening from last year because TCS had done very well and Infosys had not and for a lot of people are looking at relative value trades, this was an attractive trade to get out of TCS and get into Infosys, which I have just started playing out now. But having said that, within the IT sector, I had introduced Tech Mahindra in the portfolio and I would bet more on that because it is cheaper than most other stocks in the sector. 

The underlying segments telecom enterprise, some of those things which were down for many years, have started turning around. Numbers have started coming in and on the price charts, it is breaking out on the verge of a breakout.

It is again hitting resistances so many times and consolidating around there, that it is virtually sure to break out. That would give relatively better returns over next year. It could easily give you 30-40% kind of return over the next year whereas Infosys from a long-term channel perspective on technical, is at the higher end of the long-term channels that it typically trades in. Apart from some short-term bounces, here and there, it would end up giving a bit of a struggle in the six month to one-year perspective. I would bet on Tech Mahindra.

Net profit is a widely used metric to evaluate the performance of companies. It is also integral to valuation tools such as earnings per share (EPS) and price-to-earnings (PE ) ratio. However, net profit does not reveal the actual cash position of the company. A company may do business on credit and show revenue and net profit in its income statement even before customers actually pay the money. So, despite the net profit in the income statement, the company may actually have a cash shortage, which may affect its working capital management. Relying only on net profit, therefore, may not provide the true picture of the solvency and financial strength of a company.Free cash flow (FCF), which shows the amount of cash a company has at its disposal, provides a more accurate picture of a company’s profitability compared to its net profit. It is the discretionary cash which a company can use to reduce its debt, pay dividends and employ for growth. FCF is determined by subtracting a company’s capital expenditure from its operating cash flow. Capital expenditure is the money spent by a firm to maintain its fixed assets such as plants, machinery and other equipment.Like net profit, FCF should also be evaluated over a period of time to identify the financial health of a company. Rising FCF is a good sign as it indicates that the company is generating excess cash that can be re-invested in the business. Negative FCF indicates that the company is not able to generate sufficient cash to support its business. However, negative FCF is not always bad as it could imply that the company is making large investments that could generate good returns in the long run. However, a consistently negative FCF over the years should be thoroughly evaluated as it could indicate potential solvency risks.We analysed more than 900 companies with market-cap greater than Rs 500 crore and their FCF per share were extracted for the past five years, starting 2013-14. Companies whose FCFs per share were the highest in 2017-18 compared to past four years were sorted out. Then companies whose FCFs per share in 2017-18 were more than the past four years’ average FCF per share were filtered out. Out of these, only companies with consistently rising FCFs per share in the past five years were considered. The final filter looked at companies with only positive FCFs per share in the all the past five years.Only 11 companies passed all our filters. These companies have delivered -3.05%,94.5% and 664.6% average point-to-point returns in the past one, three and five years, respectively. Comparatively, BSE500 index delivered -5.4%, 40.5% and 87.2% point-to-point returns in the past one, three and five years, respectively, ending 8 January 2019. Companies with rising FCFs per share have substantially outperformed the index across time frames.Let us look at four of the 11 companies with rising FCFs per share with favourable analyst recommendations. These stocks also promise substantial price growth over the next one year, according to Bloomberg consensus estimates.Eicher MotorsThe company manufactures automobile products and related components and owns the iconic Royal Enfield motorcycle business— leader in India’s premium motorcycle segment. Ambit Capital believes that the company’s improved pricing power in export markets, rising scale, and local production of components will aid its operating margin. Moreover, under-control systemic inventory and seasonal strength of the fourth quarter will help revive retail demand. NEW DELHI: Auto shares were trading in the green in Friday's morning session.

Shares of Maruti Suzuki India (up 0.94 per cent), Eicher Motors (up 0.87 per cent), Motherson Sumi Systems (up 0.81 per cent) and Bharat Forge (up 0.75 per cent) were the top gainers in the index.

Tata Motors (up 0.71 per cent), MRF (up 0.56 per cent) and Apollo Tyres (up 0.51 per cent) too were trading with gains. 

The Nifty Auto index was trading 0.22 per cent up at 8556.15 around 10:06 am. 

Benchmark NSE Nifty50 index was up 75.60 points at 10,925.40 while the BSE Sensex was up 266.47 points at 36,461.57. 

Among the 50 stocks in the Nifty index, 41 were trading in the green, while 8 were in the red. 

Shares of YES Bank, ICICI Bank, Bharti Infratel, Ashok Leyland, Biocon, Sun Pharma, Tata Motors, RIL, ITC, Axis Bank, SBI, Bank of Baroda, Wipro, BHEL and Indiabulls Housing Finance were among the most traded shares on the NSE.

NEW DELHI: Around 225 stocks fell to touch their 52-week lows on NSE in Tuesday's morning session.

Among the stocks that touched their 52-week lows were Aditya Birla Capital, Alicon Castalloy, Balkrishna Industries, Bharat Forge,Bharat Rasayan, Cadila Healthcare and Cipla.

Cyient, Dilip Buildcon, DHFL, Hero MotoCorp, Hinduja Ventures, ICRA, KEC International and Kirloskar Industries also featured among the stocks that touched their 52-week lows on NSE.

On the other hand, Odisha Cement and International Constructions were the stocks that hit their fresh 52-week highs today.

Domestic benchmark index NSE Nifty was trading 7.35 points down at 10,654.20 while the BSE Sensex was trading 52.50 points down at 35,604.20. 

In the Nifty 50 index, Adani Ports SEZ, Bharti Infratel, Sun Pharma, Zee Ent. and Dr. Reddys Lab were among the top gainers on the NSE. 

However, Indiabulls Housing Finance, Eicher Motors, YES Bank, Infosys and PowerGrid were among the top losers.

NEW DELHI: Auto shares were trading on a mixed note in Tuesday's morning session. 

Shares of TVS Motor Company (up 2.66 per cent), Hero MotoCorp (up 1.40 per cent), Tata Motors (DVR) (up 0.79 per cent) and Tata Motors (up 0.78 per cent) were the top performers in the index. 

Motherson Sumi Systems (down 2.89 per cent), Apollo Tyres (down 2.29 per cent), Bharat Forge (down 1.06 per cent) and Eicher Motors (down 0.86 per cent) were trading with losses. 

The Nifty Auto index was trading 0.01 per cent up at 8144.15 around 10:24 am. 

Benchmark NSE Nifty50 index was down 9.55 points at 10,652 while the BSE Sensex was down 44.42 points at 35,612.28. 

Among the 50 stocks in the Nifty index, 28 were trading in the green, while 22 were in the red. 

Shares of YES Bank, Zee Entertainment, Ashok Leyland, Vodafone Idea, ICICI Bank, Indiabulls Housing Finance, Bank of Baroda, Adani Ports SEZ, SBI, PowerGrid, BHEL, Motherson Sumi, Sun Pharma, Axis Bank, ONGC and RIL were among the most traded shares on the NSE.

Domestic equity benchmarks Sensex and Nifty slipped for the third straight session on Tuesday, as market sentiment turned cautious ahead of Union Budget 2019 amid subdued global cues. There are expectations that the Finance Minister may announce some populist measures on Friday.

The 30-share Sensex closed 64.20 points, or 0.18 per cent, down at 35,592, while NSE’s Nifty settled 9.35 points, or 0.09 per cent, lower at 10,652.

“The market opened on a negative note due to uncertainties surrounding global markets and the forthcoming US Fed policy. However, towards the closing, market managed to recoup some of the losses supported by a strengthening rupee and short covering ahead of F&O expiry. The market is not completely out of the woods, as volatility may rise in the coming days due to the interim budget and election-led uncertainty,” said Vinod Nair, Head of Research, Geojit Financial Services.


Let’s a look at the key highlights of Tuesday's session: 

Cobra bites DHFLShares of NBFC player Dewan Housing Finance Corporation (DHFL) closed 8 per cent down at Rs 170. Earlier in the day, the portal known for investigative journalism alleged the company had siphoned off Rs 31,000 crore into promoter companies to create private wealth through a network of shell companies. The scam has been pulled off mainly by sanctioning and disbursing astronomical amounts in secured and unsecured loans to dubious shell/pass-through companies, related to DHFL’s own primary stakeholders Kapil Wadhawan, Aruna Wadhawan and Dheeraj Wadhawan through their proxies and associates, which have in turn passed on the money to companies controlled by the Wadhawans, the web portal alleged. “The money was used to buy shares/equity and other private assets in India and abroad, including in countries like the UK, Dubai, Sri Lanka and Mauritius,” the news portal said on its website.


FACT drops on doubts over networth Shares of Fertilizers & Chemicals Travancore (FACT) plunged over 4 per cent after the auditor said the company’s net worth has been fully eroded. The company reported a net loss of Rs 49.77 crore for the quarter ended December 31, 2018 against a net loss of Rs 4.41 crore in the corresponding quarter last year. The scrip settled 4.45 per cent down at Rs 38.65.


Adani Gas rallies 5%Shares of Adani Gas rallied over 5 per cent after reports that the Supreme Court ruled in favour of the company in connection with two city gas networks and said the petroleum regulator should issue free orders to Adani Gas. The scrip settled 5.08 per cent higher at Rs 93.


HDFC slips on drop in profitHDFC, the country’s biggest mortgage lender, reported a net profit of Rs 2,113.80 crore on the standalone basis for the third quarter ended December 31, 2018 against Rs 5,300 crore profit reported for the year-ago quarter. The scrip settled 1.53 per cent down at Rs 1918.80.


Bajaj Finance rises 3% on good Q3The company posted 54 per cent rise in consolidated net at Rs 1,060 crore, the highest-ever quarterly profit, for December quarter against Rs 690 crore reported for the same period last year. Shares of the company closed 2.27 per cent higher at Rs 2,511 on BSE.


40 stocks signal weaknessMomentum indicator moving average convergence divergence, or MACD, showed bearish crossovers on 40 counters on NSE. Among them were Biocon, Aurobindo Pharma, ITI, Castrol India and Sequent Scientific. On the other hand, Sun Pharma, Bharti Infratel, Jindal Saw, Talwalkars Better and Care Ratings were among 12 stocks that showed positive crossovers on NSE.


BSE telecom index top sectoral gainerSectorwise, the BSE Telecom index (up 0.98 per cent) emerged the top gainer among the sectoral indices. It was followed by healthcare (up 0.75 per cent), TECk (up 0.73 per cent) and IT (0.65 per cent). On the other hand, BSE Energy and Capital Goods index slipped over 1 per cent on Tuesday.


Spurt in OIBank of India, with a 68.86 per cent change in open interest, led the pack of stocks that witnessed the biggest spurt in OI on NSE. It was followed by MGL (60.85 per cent), Nestle India (51.07 per cent), Motherson Sumi (48.45 per cent) and Bata India (48.23 per cent). 


Fresh 52-week highs & lowsAs many as 264 stocks on NSE scaled fresh 52-week lows on Tuesday. Stocks on the list included Aban Offshore, Aditya Birla Capital, ABG Shipyard, Bharat Forge, Avanti Feeds, Dewan Housing Finance Corporation, Eicher Motors, Graphite India and HEG. On the other hand, Odhisha Cement and International Constructions scaled fresh 52-week highs during the day.


Escorts tanks over 4%Shares of farm equipment and engineering major Escorts slumped 4.49 per cent after the company management lowered volume growth guidance for the domestic tractor industry for FY19 to 10-12 per cent due to monsoon deficit in southern and western regions.

I would give a couple of quarters before starting to build positions in midcaps, Prasanth Prabhakaran, Group 
  
  
  president & CEO, Yes Securities, tells ET Now. If you have cash, you are going to be king and you will end up getting a portfolio which will give you returns over the next 12 to 24 months, said Prabhakaran.
Edited excerpts:


What do you make of the kind of volatility that we are seeing overall in the markets? Do you believe that this sort of consolidation to sideways move is the order of the day?
A sideways move with a downward bias is what I will be a little more comfortable with. But the fact remains that we had expected a downward move, anywhere between 10,000 and 10,400, where a position can be built. We expect to see those levels very soon.

The reasons are simple. There is a mixed bag of results that have come about which basically means that financials that we had been expecting did not come out as strongly as we would have liked to. Very few sectors are holding up the segment or the overall markets. The good news is that most of the midcaps have been brought down to valuation which looks attractive but I would still give it a couple of quarters before I start building positions once the ambiguity is over. 

It is a market to sit and wait by the sides. If you have cash, you are going to be king and you will end up getting a portfolio which will give you returns over the next 12 to 24 months. In the short run, at least in the current calendar year, it is going to be see mid level returns in single digits which is going to be the norm.


Bajaj Finance’s Q3 performance has managed to exceed expectations on all counts. The problem is that it is that one stock within NBFCs that everyone is chasing and the high valuation, What do you think new investors should be doing?
Every stocks has a price at which you should buy and sell it and we believe that we are at the upper end. The risk to return ratio for Bajaj Finance, irrespective of the fact that they have shown fairly decent growth in an otherwise tough environment for raising money. 

It still has valuation which is even costlier than HDFC Ltd which has pedigree in raising and running NBFC business for decades together. You have to understand that even in their business model, around 36% of their loans come in from consumer financing segment which is traditionally equivalent to giving loans against consumer durables. This is prone toward defaults. Another 16% odd is into SME financing which is again going through a lot of stress. 

So I would prefer to book my profits out and end up putting it into sectors and segments which will be a lot more stable in the times to come by. If I am holding Bajaj Finance, I would definitely end up looking to move into a cheaper stock with better fundamentals.


What is the outlook in terms of individual sectors benefiting in terms of budget announcements. What is the expectation from a sector and stock market point of view?
The fiscal maths is going to go out of shape. Our expectation of the 3.3% fiscal deficit is definitely going to be moving up to the upper end of 3.5-3.6% which is not very uncomfortable considering the fact that it is an election year.

But the fact remains that the focus is going to be ensuring that the defeats of the last three state elections are covered which basically means that they are going to go after rural with a strong focus area. They will go after the small businessmen who have suffered because of various implementations that have happened during this period of time. 

Lastly, they will get into the middle income group or regular citizens of India where they would end up putting a lot more focus into affordable housing.

These three areas will be the immediate focus of the government because that is the only way you will end up having a chance to swing votes in your favour. And that is where you should look if you want to build up a portfolio in the short run. 

In the long run, fundamentals of stocks hold good and that is what you will end up looking at when you build up a long term portfolio. For the next three to six months, look at these three sectors and find out which can be used to build a portfolio for yourself.


Eicher has hit a fresh 26-month low today. We have all seen how Maruti has gotten battered after its earnings. Escorts has felt the monsoon impact as well. There is weakness across the sector. Where would you find opportunities to invest in autos or should one wait it out because the pain is not quite over?
It is time to wait it out. As I said, cash is going to be king over the next two quarters. You are going to get a lot of these stocks far cheaper than what it is at this point of time because the economic cycle is supposed to have turned. There was expectation of earnings growth in the range of 20 plus. There is a clear mismatch that has happened in the earnings growth that was expected. 

In the commercial vehicles segment, around 55-60% of the vehicles sold are financed through NBFCs and they have gone through a bad patch over the last quarter. It will continue for the next two quarters because most of them are trying to raise money now. Even the regular four-wheeler and two-wheeler segment has a good 35% penetration by NBFCs where they end up having large loan books.

All these segments will show a slowdown because of the simple fact that there is no money available to push the discretionary spend. All these are feel good stories. You will buy a car when you are in a happy mood, when you have extra money in your hand and you have easy credit available. If any of these factors goes out of shape, you will have a slowdown in that sector and that is what auto is going through. 

You should end up looking at the market leaders -- a Maruti or a Hero -- but not today and maybe in next two quarters when you will see the lowest end of this cycle panning out. It is a wait and watch period for stock pickers.

By Chandan Taparia
Nifty50 had a volatile session on Tuesday as it fell towards the 10,583 mark but recovered sharply from lower levels in the last hour of trade. The index managed to recover most of its intraday losses and formed a candle similar to a Dragon Fly Doji, as it closed near its opening level on the daily scale.

The index has been making lower lows from last six sessions and has been holding below its 50-day EMA, as it hit the lowest level for this month. Now it has to hold above 10,650 and cross the 10,700 mark to form a short-term reversal pattern. Else, the market could continue to show weakness.

If Nifty manages to hold above 10,690 level, then a bounceback could be seen towards 10,777 and then 10,820 levels, while on the downside, support exists at 10,580 and then 10,535 levels.

On the options front, maximum Put open interest was at 10,500 followed by 10,600 level while maximum Call OI was at 11,000 followed by 10,900 level. Call unwinding was seen at 10,900 followed by 11,000 levels, while there was Put unwinding at 10,800 followed by 10,900 levels. The option band signified a shift in the lower trading range to 10,550-10,777 zone.

India VIX fell 2.50 per cent to 18.42, as overall higher volatility restricted the upside.

Bank Nifty continued its weakness towards the 26,440 mark and it has been forming lower lows for last six sessions. It recently broke its rising support trend line and held below its 50-day EMA. As long as it holds below 27,000 level, it can continue selling pressure towards 26,400 and then 26,250 levels, while on the upside, a medium-term hurdle is seen at 27,150 level.

Nifty futures closed positive at 10699 level with a gain of 0.21 per cent. Long buildup was seen in Bank of India, PVR, Bharti Infratel and Sun Pharma while shorts were seen in TechM, Motherson Sumi, Eicher Motors and Indiabulls Housing Finance.


(Chandan Taparia is Technical & Derivative Analyst at MOFSL. Investors are advised to consult financial advisers before taking an investment calls based on these observations)

Liquidity could get bit a more tight going forward. If the government is not able to meet fiscal deficit numbers
  
  
  , that would put further pressure on bond yields and that does not augur well for credit markets, Dipan Mehta, Founder Director, Elixir Equities, tells ET Now. Edited excerpts: 


What is your view on rural plays? There could be some budget linked announcements and there are a lot of sectors and specific stocks that could stand to benefit. What is your expectation and what is the general trend?
Every time the budget comes, we talk about rural themes and some amount of trading bounce takes place in these companies. Thereafter, real benefit does not flow through in terms of higher revenues or profits and eventually investors in those companies get disappointed. Over last four years, companies in the seed business, fertiliser business and irrigation business have given low returns despite much impetus being given to the rural sector. 

I am not that hopeful that a long-term change in dynamics for rural focused companies should take place. If the government does end up announcing a minimum support scheme or a minimum income scheme or additional flow into the pocket of the average rural citizen, then consumption- oriented stocks will benefit the most. FMCG, automobiles and building material companies are the ones which one could consider targeting.

Even a marginal increase in the top line for such companies, results in unusually larger increases in net profits because of operating leverages. Our focus is more on consumption-oriented stocks rather than direct rural plays such as seed companies, fertiliser companies or irrigation companies.


What is the outlook on IT? How are you looking at the overall digital outlook for some of these IT companies? What kind of revenue growth are you pencilling in for the sector as a whole?
By and large, largecap IT companies have reported good numbers and it could be because of the base effect or seasonal or cyclical reasons. But broadly, none of the IT companies are factoring or guiding in significantly higher growth rates going forward, prime example being HCL Technologies, which despite coming out with a decent set of numbers is still guiding towards low double digit or high single digit type of top line growth.

This is the kind of growth rate which the sector, at least the largecap IT sector should factor in, going forward. From an investment perspective. you want to buy into a company which is growing at least at 15-16% top line and about 20% bottom line and IT at best can grow at low double digit, high single digit. Although they are slightly cheap, the lower growth rates have already got priced in. 

So, I am not that optimistic on the IT sector as a whole, but there could be selective companies within that -- a TCS which has got the capacity to grow faster than the industry or IP-based companies like Intellect Design or Majesco which have a differentiated business models. Also, there are very specific niche companies like L&T Technology or Tata Elxsi which focus on design and are in the right space or right verticals and they may do well going forward. 

One has to be extremely selective within the IT space and need to buy into a basket of IT stocks because there is a certain degree of volatility in IT earnings which was not there earlier. One cannot assume that growth rates will be secular going forward. 


Given the high exposure of mutual funds to Essel Group’s debt, there are liquidity concerns in the market. Going further, could one could tighter liquidity conditions for NBFCs?
Yes, absolutely. There is a certain amount of nervousness in the debt markets and not only surrounding Essel Group. The DHFL story also has broken and in any case, there is a huge delay in solving the bankruptcy cases which have already been taken up. On the whole, the entire debt market seems to be in a bit of a wait-and-watch mode at this point of time. 

Liquidity could get bit a more tight going forward. Also if the government decides to be profligate and not able to meet their fiscal deficit numbers, then that would be further pressure on bond yields and that does not augur well for credit markets. 

So, it is one of the biggest threats at least in the near term for the debt market and the likelihood of defaults or delays in interest payments and subsequent problems which may arise because of specific cases. The overall sentiment within that market also is quite downbeat.


Some of quality names are falling off. Yesterday, you saw HDFC fall after its numbers, HDFC Bank as well has been cooling off. Reliance as well is down 1.5% or so. In the last 300-400 point decline of the index, some of these quality names have come off. Should we buy them in this decline or with the market fall, are these stocks also going to fall further?
That’s difficult question to answer. The market remains pretty much range bound and we have not discussed the big gorilla in the room which is political uncertainty. That is keeping a complete cap on our equities and indices at this point of time. 

This sort of scenario could remain for many more months, at least till we are closer to the election. Then may be, depending on what the opinion polls say, markets could react either ways. We are in for a very tough few months till June-July and the results thereafter of the election results would determine the market trend.

We have an RBI policy which is going to be extremely important for the RBI governor and explain what their stance is as far as liquidity and as far as interest rates are concerned. On the whole, we are in a confused situation and given that situation, it is best the market remains within a range. Selectively, you will see stocks going up and also sharp corrections depending upon numbers or stock specific situation. 
There is no doubt that the terrain over the next few weeks and months could be quite difficult for the investor and the trader. 


Are cement companies in a position to hike prices? 
I do not understand the PE multiples at which cement companies are trading. They are excessively high given the underlying fundamentals can justify only a high single digit or at best low double digit type of growth rate. 

The numbers which have come from the cement companies so far, have been disappointing by and large and there is a degree of volatility also in their earnings. Sometimes they are able to pass on input cost increases such as power, fuel and petcoke and sometimes they are not able to do that. It is not a complete sector which investors can buy with deep conviction and you could have selective holdings in cement. But it is a sector where investors should remain underweight in. 

New capacities are coming up, there is intense competition, increasing prices is not as easy as it was earlier after the Competition Commission came down hard on the industry. Going forward, demand will remain around about the GDP growth rates about 7-8% or thereabout. 

My view on cement is negative and investors should remain underweight. Some stocks could do well, like UltraTech, which is getting the benefit of consolidation and now they are taking over the cement plants of Century and some amount of internal restructuring could boost earnings. 


Is it time to buy the pain in auto stocks just yet? 
You have to take a very long-term view in auto companies at this point of time. These are great businesses -- be it Maruti, be it Eicher or some of the other two-wheeler companies -- and they have had a great track record. At some point of time the auto industry will turn and will go back to double-digit type of volume growth which we have seen in the past many years. 

There is considerable headroom for growth domestically as well as in exports and also input prices have now cooled off significantly and that would provide them with some amount of cushion as far as the cost and margins are concerned. 

But volumes may remain tepid for three four more months and we may see another disappointing quarter or two from the sector which is why I say that investors need to have a longer-term perspective in these companies. I am pretty certain that two, three years from now, most auto companies led by Eicher and Maruti which are our top picks within the sector will be 40-50% higher in terms of values.
Given the kind of market conditions these days and the mood of the traders and investors, if there is a minor disappointment in numbers, they want to en masse exit and sell off. There is just no patience for companies with disappointing numbers. In Godrej Consumer, we saw a massive selloff because of a disappointing and it is true across many companies which have failed to deliver results which are better than street expectations. 

We have this kind of a mood and thinking one should be prepared for further hits as far as the auto companies are concerned. I am convinced that it is a growth sector over a three-year period.
