'These 2 stocks could turn out to be next Eicher & Bajaj Finance'


MACROS


EPFO recommends hiking interest rate to 8.65%The Central Board of Trustees of the Employees' Provident Fund Organisation (EPFO) has recommended increasing the interest rate on Employees' Provident Fund for 2018-19 to 8.65% against 8.55% in the preceding year. The move, once approved by the finance ministry will benefit six crore EPFO subscribers.



RBI's MPC minutes show pro-growth tiltIndia needs to take steps to boost economic growth as the inflation outlook remains low, the Reserve Bank of India’s monetary policy committee (MPC) said in minutes released on Thursday. Most of the six-member MPC were in favour of spurring growth in Asia’s third largest economy amid a soft inflation outlook on a sustained fall in food prices, the minutes of the February monetary policy meeting showed. The MPC delivered a surprise repo rate cut in a 4-2 split vote this month.



India to stop water share from flowing into PakistanIndia on Thursday said it will no longer allow its share of river waters to flow into Pakistan, signalling that it was taking a close look at punitive measures it can take as an upper riparian country following the Pulwama terror attack in which 40 soldiers were killed. Water resources minister Nitin Gadkari announced on Twitter: “Our government has decided to stop our share of water which used to flow to Pakistan. We will divert water from eastern rivers and supply it to our people in Jammu and Kashmir and Punjab.”



Govt offers sops to boost oil & gas outputThe government has rolled out major incentives in royalty rates to attract investments into oil and gas exploration and maximise production. The petroleum ministry will soon notify these policy announcements following which the government hopes there will be renewed interest among private players. Concessional royalty at the rate of 10%, 20% and 30% has been proposed for category-I, II and III basins respectively, reports ET.



Govt asks ONGC, OIL to sell 66 fields to pvt firmsThe government has asked state-owned Oil and Natural Gas Corporation (ONGC) and Oil India Ltd (OIL) to sell out 66 of their small oil and gas fields to private firms as it brought in a new policy to boost domestic production and cut imports, Petroleum Minister Dharmendra Pradhan said Thursday.



Cement workers' pay to rise by Rs 5,000/monthThe Cement Manufacturers' Association (CMA) has signed with major trade unions a new wage settlement pact, which would increase the gross monthly pay of cement employees by Rs 5,000. The move is likely to benefit around 20,000 employees in the Indian cement industry, the CMA said in a statement here on Thursday.



Ordinance bans illegal deposit takingPresident Ram Nath Kovind Thursday promulgated the Banning of Unregulated Deposit Scheme Ordinance which seek to curb the menace of ponzi schemes and make such unregulated deposit scheme punishable. The Ordinance will help put a check on illicit deposit taking activities like Saradha scam and Rose Valley chit fund scam.



US capital goods orders fall in DecemberThe US Commerce Department said orders for non-defense capital goods excluding aircraft, a closely watched proxy for business spending plans, dropped 0.7 per cent. Data for November was revised down to show these so-called core capital goods orders falling 1.0 per cent instead of declining 0.6 per cent as previously reported.



RBI seeks info from NBFCs on moratoriumAmid a controversy on loans against shares, the Reserve Bank of India has asked non-banking finance companies (NBFCs) to disclose the moratorium or grace period given to borrowers. Besides mutual funds (MFs), NBFCs are large lenders against shares — often funding promoters to diversify and raise stake through creeping acquisition. There are more than 11,000 NBFCs of which 218 are systemically important, having total assets of Rs 25 lakh crore.

NEW DELHI: Following the crowd usually takes you nowhere in the stock market. True!

But what do you make of the stocks that figure in portfolios of one after another mutual fund scheme? At the end of January, there were 78 stocks that were part of the portfolios of at least 100 mutual fund schemes, including ETFs, data from Ace Mutual Fund showed.

Don’t forget domestic institutional investors have become one of the key market drivers in recent years, having managed to cushion severe corrections every time there has been a big selloff by the overseas portfolio investors. 

Foreign portfolio investors have been net sellers in Indian market, having offloaded shares worth over Rs 34,000 crore since January 2018. DIIs poured in some Rs 1,15,000 crore in the same period.

Not surprisingly, the list of 78 stocks includes the usual suspects. HDFC Bank is part of at least 535 mutual fund schemes; ICICI Bank 528 schemes, State Bank of India 465 schemes and Axis Bank 450 schemes.

State Bank of India recently posted a net profit of Rs 3,955 crore year-on-year for December quarter against a net loss of Rs 2,416 crore posted for the corresponding quarter last year. Some 412 schemes held the stock at the end of January, 2018 and 452 at the end of December, 2018. 

Global brokerages Jefferies and Nomura have ‘buy’ rating on SBI with price targets of Rs 365 and Rs 375, respectively.

Anand Rathi Financial Services is bullish on HDFC Bank with a target price of Rs 2,420. “Considering the opportunistic macro conditions, healthy balance sheet growth and superior asset quality and management, we believe the bank is well poised to deliver consistently with margin leadership and robust return ratios. We continue to be positive on the company from a medium to long-term perspective,” the brokerage said.

Among others, IT major Infosys, FMCG giant ITC and engineering conglomerate L&T were owned by more than 400 schemes as of January 2019.

Goldman Sachs is bullish on L&T with a target price of Rs 1,570. The brokerage believes domestic economic fundamentals will favour the company in the medium term. However, elections can have a temporary slowdown impact. Major sectors are anticipating capex growth going forward, it added. 

Also on the list are Maruti Suzuki, Reliance Industries, Kotak Mahindra Bank, HDFC, Mahindra & Mahindra, Tata Consultancy Services, Sun Pharmaceuticals, Bharti Airtel, NTPC, Bajaj Finance and HUL, which were held by over 250 schemes.

Corporate banks, IT and consumer sectors delivered strong performance in December quarter, while auto and cement sectors disappointed the market.

Brokerage Motilal Oswal is positive on Maruti Suzuki and Kotak Mahindra Bank with price targets of Rs 8,131 and Rs 1,350, respectively. The brokerage has also increased weightage of Maruti Suzuki and Axis Bank in its model portfolio.

The mutual fund industry’s asset under management (AUM) stood at Rs 23.40 lakh crore in January 2019 compared with Rs 22.41 lakh crore in the same month last year. However, equity and equity-linked saving schemes saw Rs 6,158 crore inflow in January 2019, compared with a Rs 15,390 crore inflow in the year-ago month.

The slowdown in inflows has been attributed to uncertainty about the outcome of the forthcoming general elections and a prolonged depression in domestic stocks.

Despite the fall in inflows, equity fund managers stayed put on stocks like HCL Technologies, Asian Paints, Tech Mahindra, Tata Steel, Vedanta, IndusInd Bank, Titan, GAIL (India), Tata Motors and Aurobindo Pharma. There stocks featured in the portfolios of more than 200 schemes as of January 2019.

Among others, Coal India, Power Grid, Hero MotoCorp, Dr Reddy’s Laboratories, Cipla, Motherson Sumi, Cummins India, Petronet LNG, Britannia Industries, Grasim, Bajaj Finserv, M&M Financial Services, Hindalco, YES Bank, UltraTech Cement, ONGC, Bank of Baroda, The Federal Bank, Dabur India, MRF, ACC, Exide, Eicher Motors and UPL were other companies that were owned by at least 100 mutual fund schemes as of January 2019.


OthersSource: Ace Mutual Fund

Tata Motors’ Rs 26,993 crore loss in December quarter caused non-BFSI Nifty companies’ aggregate profit to drop on a year-on-year basis for the first time since June 2017. BFSI stands for banking, financial services and insurance.

Cumulative profit of 40 non-BFSI firms fell 36 per cent year-on-year after growing 18.37 per cent in the same quarter last year. Net sales increased 22.13 per cent YoY during the quarter against a 12.02 per cent rise in the year-ago period.

During the quarter, India Inc witnessed headwinds in the form of liquidity tightening, rupee volatility, slowdown in government spending (with onset of elections) and global trade issues.

“Some companies recorded decent revenue growth with volume support from the consumption space, while a weak rupee aided incremental revenues in certain sectors (IT). Some other companies (in non-BFSI) reported lower profitability on account of margin pressure owing to currency volatility, higher costs and commodity prices along with slower-than-expected revenue growth,” Centrum Broking said in a report.

Besides Tata Motors, oil marketing companies IndianOil (IOC), HPCL and BPCL too had a depressed quarter, which resulted in a drop in profitability for the non-BFSI Nifty pack.

Brokerage Motilal Oswal has 'buy' ratings on Nifty stocks ONGC, Mahindra & Mahindra, YES Bank, Hindustan Unilever and Tech Mahindra, with price targets of Rs 181 and Rs 840, Rs 270, Rs 2,120 and Rs 860, respectively.

While the performance of OMCs continued to be impacted by lower gross refining margins (GRMs) and inventory losses, auto companies suffered due to subdued consumer sentiment leading to higher discounts and also higher raw material and advertising costs.

Brokerage Prabhudas Lilladher is cautious on the OMCs. It has a 'hold' rating on HPCL with a target price of Rs 225.

BPCL posted 77 per cent YoY drop in profit for the quarter, while HPCL saw profit shrink 87 per cent and IOC 91 per cent.

Among auto firms, bottom lines declined 1.03 per cent for Bajaj Auto, 7.85 per cent for Hero MotoCorp, 3.09 per cent for Maruti Suzuki and 3.05 per cent for Eicher Motors.

If Tata Motors and OMCs are left out from the list of 40 companies, then net profit of the remaining 36 firms grew 17 per cent YoY on a 24 per cent rise in net sales.

In the non-BFSI segment, Reliance Industries emerged the best-performing company in terms of sales growth (up 56 per cent), while Sun Pharmaceuticals came out on top in terms of profit growth (up 286 per cent YoY). Vedanta was worst performer in terms of net sales (down 2.84 per cent), while telecom major Bharti Airtel reported a 72 per cent drop in profit.

JM Financial has a 'buy' rating on Sun Pharma with a price target of Rs 575. “Post multiple false dawns, Sun Pharma returned to a normalised earnings trajectory in 3QFY19 with various elements of a diversified earnings engine on display. There was incremental comfort on concerns including terminal decline of US generics, domestic pharma growth being slower than historical trends, slower than anticipated ramp-up of key specialty assets, discomfort around certain corporate transactions and structures and capital allocation discipline,” the brokerage said.

Tata Motors continued to face challenges given the weak performance by its subsidiary Jaguar Land Rover owing to market conditions in China. Ambit Capital has a ‘sell’ rating on Tata Motors.

Tata Motors’ consolidated bottom line was hit in Q3 due to Rs 27,838 crore asset impairment in its British arm Jaguar Land Rover (JLR).

“JLR lost share in China’s premium car market from 9 per cent at the beginning of 2018 to 4 per cent now. JLR’s volumes declined around 27 per cent last year and are now contracting by 40 per cent YoY per month. Note that the Chinese premium car market didn’t shrink YoY even a single month in 2018, implying JLR’s underperformance was caused by Audi’s 400 bps share gain in the second half (H2) of 2018 over H1,” Ambit said in report.

Nifty’s BFSI companies, on the other hand, posted over 35 per cent year-on-year rise in net profit for the quarter. Axis Bank posted 131 per cent growth in profit at Rs 1,680.90 crore. Bajaj Finance, HDFC Bank, Kotak Mahindra Bank and IndusInd Bank posted 48 per cent, 20 per cent, 13.53 per cent and 5.21 per cent YoY rise in profit.

On the other hand, State Bank of India reported a net profit of Rs 3,954.80 crore for the quarter against a net loss of Rs 2,416.40 crore in the same quarter last year. Indiabulls Housing Finance, YES Bank and ICICI Bank posted 60.12 per cent, 13.73 per cent, 6.97 per cent and 2.75 per cent YoY drop in profit.

HDFC posted a net profit of Rs 2,113.80 crore on a standalone basis against Rs 5,300 crore profit for the year-ago quarter. However, the numbers are not comparable as the mortgage lender had a one-time gain from its insurance arm IPO last year.

Of the 50 Nifty companies, 16 (32 per cent) posted earnings above expectation, 15 (30 per cent) had them in line with expectations, 10 (20 per cent) reported a mixed set of numbers and nine (18 per cent) reported numbers below estimates, Centrum Broking said.

“The earnings season has been a mixed bag. Incrementally, in FY19, we are pencilling in about 9-10 per cent earnings growth for Nifty, but we see an improving trajectory going into FY20 where we are looking at 16-18 per cent earnings growth,” said Shibani Sircar Kurian, Kotak Mahindra AMC

Kurian said if earnings growth does play out as per expectations, a lot of the valuation concerns that are there, especially in the minds of some of the FII investors when they are looking at India vis-à-vis the emerging markets pack, would start getting corrected. From here on, she expects to see improvement in the earnings growth trajectory and that, she said, should start playing out post elections.

In next three-four months, if one tries to be aggressive, precious resources and capital may get eroded. That is 
  
  
  the worst possible outcome, says Jagannadham Thunuguntla, Senior Vice President and Head of Research, Centrum Broking, in an interview with ET Now.Edited excerpts:


How are you looking at the market direction? We managed to see that sort of a bounce back. Is the euphoria here to stay?
Markets are in a no-man’s land. It is one of those awkward cricket pitches where it is difficult to play on the front foot as well as on the back foot. Overall, the setup of the Nifty around 10,700-10,800 levels is giving the impression that it is still very close to the psychological 11,000 marks and has not corrected sufficiently for new money to aggressively come into the market. 

That is preventing the huge inflows -- be it at the HNI level or at the retail level -- to pump in money. But the correction at the midcap and smallcap level is intense enough to appear as a classic bear market. 

Now two things can happen; a) the largecaps -- the seven, eight stocks which have been defying the gravity and are staying at high levels -- even they will give up and the entire market will correct to a point where fresh money and the strategic money will come in, so that the fresh rally can happen from there. 

b) Nifty will consolidate at the 10,500 or 11000 levels and then the midcaps and smallcaps will start catching up. It is very difficult to form an opinion at this moment whether the first scenario will play out or the second one. 

Whichever way one looks at it, it is one of those moments where you neither go on front foot aggressively nor on the back foot, but it is very important to preserve the resources. I am sure there are enough events lined up where the volatility will give opportunities in next three to four months to build up for the next three to four years. 

In next three-four months, if one tries to be aggressive, the challenge is that precious resources and the capital may get eroded. That is the worst possible outcome.

So, preserve the resources and be patient and you will get an opportunity to be in the frontline companies with no pledged shares by promoters and which have low or zero debt. Also, companies which are consistently showing good results despite ongoing economic slowdown and the currency and the crude oil volatility. 


Consumption is a very narrow space and within that also the outperformance can be seen in a select few. Everyone on the street is of the view that these are expensive stocks. Bata, Titan have got PE multiples which are nearing 40 plus now.
Absolutely. No matter whether we like the market condition, that is how most of the investors will keep betting on consumption stocks, especially institutional investors. On top of that it is a very narrow theme. At best, four-five themes are playing out. 

There used to be a time when names like say Page Industries used to be the hot favourite of the industry and everybody used to keep buying but now after the damage that we have seen in Page Industries, both in terms of price as well as sentiment, a new wave of consumption names are popping up for fund managers and investors. Bata and Titan are sort of fitting the bill. 

Of course, after this deposit schemes related development, we have to see how this gold deposit related angle will play out on Titan. As you said, the consumption names are definitely getting disproportionately higher allocation from fund managers and that too very select names. 

The only thing is as we had seen with names likes Eicher and Page, once these highly-valued stocks get hammered, the corrections are quite steep. So the investors, while putting in money, should be ready for an awkward outcome as well. There’s nothing wrong in playing the momentum as long as it is with due understanding of the risks involved. 


Why is Wipro hitting a 52-week high on a daily basis?
Two things; one, it was a huge underperformer in the entire IT pack consistently for the last one year or so and now some catchup is happening. Understandably, there is bonus angel to it, 1:3 bonus and we are towards the financial year-end. 

Some bonus-related anticipated buying also happening. Also, though the company had talked about buyback program and giving the money back to the shareholders, they have not officially announced it in the board meeting. That means in the next one or two board meeting, there is a chance that they may announce a buyback also. 

It is a perfect combo of the current ongoing bonus related buying as well as upcoming anticipated buyback in the next one to two quarters. 

Currently, IT is more of a stable play, It is no longer the super growth sector of yester-years but at the same time, in the current environment when there is so much damage on corporate governance as well as default risks, the global money and the local money are both chasing IT as it fits the bill in terms of the quality of corporate governance, almost zero debt levels and perfect play on the rupee weakness and very high cash generation capability. 

The entire IT has rallied. Wipro is a clear outperformer thanks its underperformance during the previous year.

NEW DELHI: Headline indices Sensex and Nifty opened with deep cuts on Tuesday, as escalating tension between India and Pakistan spooked investors on Dalal Street.

Nearly two weeks after a terror strike at Pulwama, Indian Air Force is claimed to have carried out aerial strikes on terror camps early Tuesday.

Indian Air Force on Tuesday carried out aerial strikes at major terror camps in Pakistan occupied Kashmir, completely destroying them, 12 days after the ghastly terror attack in Pulwama, ANI reported.

Pakistan has claimed that the Indian Air Force violated the Line of Control (LoC).

Experts say, the move may aggravate the already simmering tension between the two neighboring countries and may have other geopolitical ramifications.

Sensex plunged nearly 500 points in opening deals and Nifty slipped below the 10,740 level. The volatility index India VIX surged 17 per cent, logging its biggest intraday jump this year.

However, market recovered from day's low. At around 12:10 pm, the BSE Sensex was 198 points, or 0.55 per cent, down at 36,016, while the NSE Nifty was 53 points, or 0.49 per cent, down at 10,827. BSE Midcap and Smallcap indices were 0.46 per cent and 0.87 per cent down, respectively, at that time. 

Rupee also pared some losses, following dollar's weakness and a fall in the global crude oil prices. However, it was still trading 9 paise lower.

Asian markets also showed bearish trend. Asian shares lost steam on Tuesday after scaling a five-month high as investors waited to see if Washington and Beijing can clinch a trade deal, while the pound advanced on hopes UK Prime Minister Theresa May will delay a Brexit deadline, Reuters reported. 

In the 30-share Sensex index, 24 were in the red. Shares of Tata Motors, TCS, Coal India and Bajaj Auto were trading with gains. .

NTPC, ICICI Bank, HDFC, State Bank of India and Infosys were among the top losers in the Sensex kitty.

All sectoral indices on BSE, except auto, were in the red. Gains in shares of Tata Motors, Motherson Sumi, Bharat Forge, Eicher Motors and Bajaj Auto were keeping the BSE Auto pack up.

Over the next four to six weeks, the bank index is probably going to be the first mainline index to hit new lifetime 
  
  
  highs and we are recommending our clients strongly to be heavyweight in this sector, said Gautam Shah, Associate Director & Technical Analyst, JM Financial, in an interview with ET Now. It would be the banks, capital good, oil and gas stocks and possibly the IT stocks that Shah would continue to buy and hold. Edited excerpts:


Who would have thought in 24 hours we were back at 10,900. Does it look sustainable because simmering tensions with ET Now continues?
The market has not just seen resilience in the last couple of days but that has been the case for the last two and a half months now. Nifty has been trading in the band of about 400 points, moving like a pendulum around the 10,800 pivot level and there have been four or five occasions wherein the market had news flow or an excuse to actually breakdown and collapse below levels of 10,600. 

We have had almost four or five failed attempts on the downside. The market has only got stronger and having digested all possible negative news flow, whether it is on the geopolitical front, on the local economic front or the global front. This market is looking much stronger. The problem is because we have been in a range, you could not have extrapolated because every time you felt that after a patch of good days, the market is setting up for a breakout, it just did not happen. 

But this attempt that you are seeing right now is possibly the strongest and possibly the most genuine attempt at a possible breakout at about 11,000. For the first time in two and a half months, Nifty is getting support from the broader markets. In the past too we have traded around 10,900-10,950 but the midcap index and the small cap index have been in bad shape. They have never moved in sync with the mainline indices, but this recovery from the lows in the last three days looks a lot more broad-based and has a lot more backing in terms of volumes.

I am tempted to believe that the next attempt above 11,000 is likely to be genuine and once that confirmation happens, you could see the Nifty move towards 11,350 and over the next few months, you could even be trading at 11,700. The bigger picture view remains positive and 10,600 has really become a strong floor for the indices, given that from a risk-reward perspective, it still makes a lot of sense to buy a 10,900. The global setup is helping the indices because global equities have got much more stable, crude has got into a range. 

The currency is pretty much range-bound around the 71 mark. All of these factors suggest that Indian markets are likely to see much better days ahead.


My only concern is given how narrow the rally has been for many months now, what do you think is going to happen? Will newer names participate or will it be just those four-five candidates pushing the Nifty forward from here?
Well that has been the complain. Just top five-ten stocks are doing well and it is showing you that the Nifty is at 11,000 but the overall market was pretty much at levels as low as 9000-9500. But as I said what has really changed in the last one, one and a half weeks is that the broader market is getting better. I thought that the CNX midcap 100 index has bottomed out at that long term support of 16,000. If that is the case, then there is a huge scope for recovery for the midcap 100 index. 

You could actually see a 1000-point recovery for the midcap index from these levels and if that were to transpire, then it will rub off on the mainline indices and then you could see a genuine breakout. 

But I must highlight the banking space because this is one index that has single-handedly helped the markets sustain above support levels in the last four to six weeks. As we speak the index is still trading above 27,000 and if it is just 5% away from lifetime highs. Over the next four to six weeks, this is probably going to be the first mainline index to hit new lifetime highs and we are recommending our clients strongly to be heavyweight in this sector because I think it is going to do very well whether it is private names or the PSU names.


What exactly is driving this conviction in banks and when do you think that we could see this kind of euphoria or optimism?
Well you know when markets go through a difficult phase -- and last three or four months have been extremely difficult given the carnage that we have seen in midcaps and smallcaps -- relative strength is a very important tool. 

All those stocks which have done better than the midcap index or which have done better than the mainline indices are the ones that are likely to see a lot of strength. The FMCG index, the banking space, the oil and gas index are the names which have stayed sideways while the fall happened.

I believe that these are the names that will do exceedingly well once the Nifty gets past that threshold level of about 11000. So relative strength is something that we are watching very closely in the midcaps and small caps, I cannot discuss names but even in the midcap space all those stocks which turned sideways in the last four to six weeks, are the ones that are likely to give you supernormal returns to the extent of 20-50% over the next four to six months.


Do you have the same thesis when it comes to oil and gas and cement?
Cement looks very interesting. Fundamental analysts were telling me that on the ground, the scene is picking up quite a bit on the cement front and when I coincide that with my chart setup, I get a lot of conviction that cement could actually be the dark horse for the next three to six months. 

Most of the frontline cement names have done exceedingly well in the last two, two and a half weeks and today as you see the markets picking up some strength you are seeing cement stocks buzzing and many of them are actually broken out of important bases. 

This is one space I would recommend not only from a trading but from an investment perspective. 

Oil and gas, as a space has been an outperformer. We love the top names in the segment from a six to 12-month perspective. Oil marketing companies, which have been a big drag on the sector and on the market are now looking up. A bottom has been formed out there as well. So yes, both of these spaces look very interesting along with sugar and auto where I think the worst is over as well.


Interesting that you mentioned auto. What about a non-performer like Tata Motors, or a Maruti and an Eicher which have really gotten beaten down? Is time to buy these stocks too?
I would only recommend a very small weightage in auto stocks. I there are much better bets in the market where the risk reward is far more justified and the fact that they have shown relative strength in the bad times. Auto, looks interesting to us only because it is highly oversold. 

The BSE Auto Index itself it has lost about 30% in the last few months and it is approaching that important support of 10,000. From around that level, you are likely to see a recovery of about 10%. 

Talking about Tata Motors, it just cannot get more pessimistic. Auto can be played from a rebound perspective. It is more of a trading idea but if you ask me what I would buy and hold, it would still be the banks, it would still be the capital good stocks, the oil and gas stocks and possibly the IT stocks.

Key stock indices extended their losses for the third straight session on Thursday as market participants squared off their positions on February derivatives expiry amid simmering tensions between India and Pakistan.

NSE's Nifty closed lower 14 points, or 0.13 per cent, at 10,792.50. The BSE Sensex too settled marginally down by 38 points, or 0.11 per cent, at 35,867.

“Market continued to see a range bound movement due to F&O expiry while mid and smallcaps outperformed as investors believe that border tensions won’t continue for long. Additionally, focus is likely to shift to economic data and possibility of pre-election rally while FII inflow is picking up and the rupee is gaining strength," said Vinod Nair, Head of Research, Geojit Financial Services. 

We run you through the highlights of Thursday's session.


A volatile day for Jet Airways
Shares of Jet Airways declined over 6 per cent intraday after the company said seven more aircraft have been grounded due to non-payment of lease rentals. However, the scrip recovered smartly and closed 0.91 per cent higher at Rs 222.80 on the BSE.


Future Retail gets foreign hand
Stock of Future Retail gained over 3.50 per cent after the company said its unit SHME Food Brands signed a master franchise agreement with US-based 7-Eleven Inc to operate its stores in India, marking the convenience retailer's entry into the country.


Vascon Engineers gains on order win
EPC player Vascon Engineers gained as much as 14.35 per cent, their biggest intraday percentage gain since December 21, 2017. The scrip gained momentum after it informed bourses that the company has received order worth Rs 83.52 crore from the Airports Authority of India. However, the scrip closed 9.41 per cent higher at Rs 15.70.


Top Nifty losers and gainers
As many as 26 stocks of the Nifty index closed the day in the red, with TCS falling the most by 3.62 per cent, followed by Eicher Motors (down 2.87 per cent), UltraTech Cement (down 2.03 per cent and Maruti Suzuki (down 1.96 per cent). On the other hand, share price of ONGC, Vedanta, Coal India and BPCL gained up to 5.43 per cent.


32 stocks ready to rise
Momentum indicator, moving average convergence divergence, or MACD, showed bullish crossovers on 32 counters on the BSE, signalling that these stocks may rise in coming sessions. Among the stocks that saw bullish crossovers were Nalco, Oriental Bank, Future Retail, Equitas Holdings and Rashtriya Chemicals. On the flip side, 14 issues, including Hero MotoCorp, MCX, ABB India, Motilal Oswal Financial Services, Sonata Software and Teamlease, showed bearish crossover.


Buyers pile into these 175 stocks
As many as 175 stocks hit their upper circuit on the BSE even as 193 counters hit the lower circuit. Those that hit upper circuits included PG Electroplast, Zodiac Clothing, Sankshya Infotech, Max Altert Systems and Rama Steel Tubes. Darjeeling Ropeway Company, Himachal Fibres, Capital Trust and Intellivate Capital Ventures were among the ones that plumbed lower circuits.


Stocks that saw spurt in OI
With a change of 50.24 per cent, Nestle India led the pack of stocks that witnessed the biggest spurt in open interest (OI) on the NSE. It was followed by Can Fin Homes (50.12 per cent), HDFC (55.07 per cent), MGL (42.56 per cent), Kajaria Ceramics (40.71 per cent), IOC (39.63 per cent) and Hero Moto (39.10 per cent).


Mid and smallcaps outperform
BSE Midcap and Smallcap indices, however, managed to buck the trend and closed 0.49 per cent and 0.86 per cent higher, respectively.


Most active securities
Axis Bank, TCS, RIL, L&T and ITC stood out in the most active stock bloc on the NSE in terms of value while Reliance Communications, Suzlon, Nalco and IOC turned most active in terms of volume on the exchange.

If you find a stock where the company enjoys a competitive advantage, has a moat and has been reporting steady earnings growth, lap it up.

There have been instances of stocks with such traits delivering mouth-watering returns! In one case, an investment of just Rs 10,000 grew to Rs 1.50 crore in 10 years.

In the case of Westlife Development, the master franchisee of McDonald’s restaurants in West and South India, an investment of Rs 10,000 in March 2009 has grown to Rs 1.45 crore as of today, delivering a whopping 1,449 times return.

A little-known stock in 2009, Westlife Developments became the market’s darling during 2012-13 when McDonald's franchisee Hardcastle Restaurants became its direct subsidiary. The stock climbed to Rs 372 on December 31, 2013 from Rs 0.20 in March 2009. From 2013 onwards, the scrip has traded in the Rs 160-400 range. Progressive Share Brokers is bullish on Westlife Development with a price target of Rs 425.

Bajaj Finance has been another big compounder. Since March 2009, an investment of Rs 10,000 in this stock would have grown to Rs 57 lakh, growing exponentially at 88 per cent annually. A similar investment in leading shrimp feeds manufacturer Avanti Feeds would have made you Rs 33.30 lakh.

Astral PolyTechnik, Ajanta Pharma, Vinati Organics, LA Opala RG, Mayur Uniquoters, Eicher Motors and Poly Medicure are other such stocks which have grown an investment of Rs 10,000 into Rs 8-33 lakh during this period. 

Global brokerage Macquarie recently maintained an ‘outperform’ rating on Eicher Motors with a price target of Rs 24,000. The foreign brokerage said structural demand drivers remained intact for the company. However, sales of Royal Enfield (RE) were impacted by large price hikes in the recent past. “RE sales growth should pick up in the coming months,” it said.

Stock returns do not come so easily and it’s not easy to spot such stocks. An investor should devote time to do the research on prospective investment opportunities to increase the chances of spotting such big compounders.

Some basic traits like good leadership, clean balance sheet, revenue visibility, scalability and sustainability usually are first signs that differentiate the wheat from the chaff.

The price at which a stock is bought is also important, as are other parameters such as reasonable to no debt, strong parentage, high return on equity (RoE) or return on capital employed (RoCE) and consistent earnings, even in a weak macro environment. 

Top line and operating profit are two other major components that can give a clear picture of a company’s operating performance. The operating performance should reflect in valuations. 

Companies whose share prices have grown over 5,000 per cent in last 10 years include TTK Prestige, Stylam Industries, Balkrishna Industries, Natco Pharma, Havells India, VIP Industries, Gruh Finance, Supreme Industries, Whirlpool of India, IndusInd Bank, Aarti Industries, Minda Industries and KPR Mill. 

ICICIdirect has a hold rating on TTK Prestige with a price target of Rs 8,800. Religare Broking is positive on VIP Industries with a price target of Rs 551.


Others

But the bad apples can erode your wealth even faster. Shares of companies like Educomp Solutions, IVRCL, ABG Shipyard, Punj Lloyd, Videocon Industries, Reliance Communications, Unitech, MMTC, Religare Enterprises, Bilcare, Shriram EPC and Bombay Royon Fashion have dipped up to 90 per cent in last 10 years.

Others

The rural segment has reported healthy double digit growth for both passenger vehicle and two
  
  
  -wheeler segments, said Mitul Shah, V-P, Research, Reliance Securities, in an interview with ET Now. Edited excerpts: 


Do you believe that autos will continue to remain in the slow lane, when is to your mind could we see an uptick in the overall demand?
We believe that automobile will continue to report muted volume performance in February as well and the trend has continued since last two-three months after the monsoon got over and we came to know that few districts and few regions of the south and western and parts of the rural witnessed lower monsoon. All that has impacted the rural demand. This will continue at least for next few months and going forward next year’s monsoon will decide the volume performance. 

So, there won’t be any recovery before mid of FY20. Right now the volumes will remain muted but of course Street has considered this type of slowdown and that is why we believe that it will not be highly disappointing number and stock price reaction would not be a big negative considering the volume performance.


Do you believe that maybe we could see recovery coming in in certain segments like two-wheelers or passenger vehicles?
Rural play has very important role for passenger vehicles as well as two-wheelers in past three-four years. In fact, the rural segment has reported healthy double digit growth for both passenger vehicle and two-wheeler segments.

Moreover, we are hearing that a few players have restricted their dispatches to the border area in last 15 days, considering the Indo-Pak tension. This will also have some negative impact on the wholesale number reported by the companies. 

We believe that recovery is still at least a few months away from now and on the other side, inventory level with all the two-wheeler players are reasonably high. 

Again ABS, CBS becoming mandatory from 1st April and so they would be in a hurry to reduce as much inventories as possible. In this situation, reported numbers for February as well as March would not be very great. 


Would you like to take that on board with respect to Eicher?
We do not have coverage on the Eicher but in general in terms of two-wheeler sales, as I mentioned that inventory level is reasonably high and again the Royal Enfield being a speciality motorcycle, the base reaching close to 70,000 itself is reasonably high. 

Recording growth on this base is definitely a challenge and as we have seen in past two-three months, numbers would remain subdued for the Royal Enfield in February also.

Autos are going through a couple of quarters of challenges but they will bounce back again next year, said Nitin Raheja, Co-Founder, AQF Advisors, in an interview with ET Now.Edited excerpts:


When we talk about assets that are up for sale, there are names like Zee, Dewan Housing, CG Power and a lot of other various good assets, maybe Jet as well. How do you see the scenario panning out?
Let us not forget that India is a growing economy and all these assets are in industries which are growing. But due to either mismanagement on account of the existing promoters or because of excessive debt, they have got into temporary problems. Do not forget that when you talk about a stock like DHFL, they have actually sold assets in the affordable housing subsidiary, Aadhaar Housing, they have put their education loan company on the block as well. 

Similarly, we are seeing this with Jet also. The airline business is getting consolidated. There are these three, four large players and it is really a question of mismanagement on the part of the existing promoters which has caused them to be where they are. I am pretty sure that you will see interest, clearly a case in point being a lot of these assets which were in the restructuring in the IBA. Look at the interest that they have found from other large Indian entities who have been willing to step in.

That is a big story which is going to play out. In the whole restructuring, there are going to be a plenty of opportunities within this whole scheme of things because some of these assets are really selling and hence every day you hear about some international entity tying up with an Indian entity, whether it was Kotak on one day, or JM the other day, for setting up distressed asset funds. That is a very interesting opportunity. A lot of value is going to be created.


Maruti, Ashok Leyland again are seeing de-growth on a month-on-month basis. M&M tractor sales have disappointed. The only silver lining so far are the numbers for Eicher CV sales which have seen a pick up. Do you think for some more time we will see a slump in the auto sales?
We all know that there is a liquidity crunch as far as the economy is concerned. NBFCs, which were very strong lenders in this segment, are finding it difficult a) to raise capital and b) a lot of them are actually shoring up their balance sheet and hence constricting growth themselves. 

Also, the government talked about infusing some liquidity as we get into the advance tax season this month. So there is a liquidity crunch and that is having an impact as far as all the autos are concerned. 

Clearly, from the next quarter onwards, you will start seeing liquidity coming back into the economy. You are going to see some pre-monsoon based buying. Post monsoon, you are going to see demand pickup in CV segment ahead of the changing regulatory norms that will come into play from 2020. 

Autos are going through a couple of quarters of challenges but they will bounce back again next year. I would not be surprised if you start seeing a number of companies like Mahindra & Mahindra introduce new models as far as their UVs and SUVs are concerned which are starting to show up in terms of growth numbers albeit in a small way but you will start seeing that acceleration. 


Do you think we have already seen the worst of the stock prices? Are all the negatives already baked in and can one start buying into the weakness in the auto stocks?
I clearly think so. Whether you take the price of Ashok Leyland or Mahindra & Mahindra, a lot of these stocks are trading at multiple-year lows. Ultimately, there is intrinsic value in all of these companies. When you adjust for some of them, their subsidiary holdings and so on and so forth, a lot of them are coming into single digit PEs adjusted for subsidiary valuation. I clearly see value in this pack.


When we look at the markets, you could say that it polarised into two sections; a) one where there is earnings visibility -- the likes of HUL, Nestle, etc, where the valuations do not really dip. b) The other is the area people do not want to touch. How should one allocate or look at the strategy in this space?
Nitin Raheja: The markets are at this point in a complete risk-off mode and hence you are seeing companies with leverage, companies where working capital is high, companies where shares are pledged are being avoided. People are no longer looking at the P&L growth. They are looking more at balance sheet at this present moment and this normally happens in such markets and it is a cycle that the markets go through. 

If one wanted to invest in this market, one has to look through the noise that we are seeing in the short term, whether it is with respect to the political tension that we are seeing or the uncertainty of the elections as such. One has to really focus on individual stocks and stories. Look at companies with strong balance sheets. 

The GDP growth the numbers disappointed yesterday and that can only get better from here and stock prices especially the mid and smallcaps have corrected immensely -- anywhere from 70-80% to 20%. If you look at the entire index, hardly about 15% or 20% of the index is in positive zone and the rest 80% is negative. 

Some of them have come down to levels especially in the recent past backed by this whole fear over share pledges and promoter selling to levels where clearly value is emanating and you have seen them bounce back silently without you noticing them. Some of them have move up almost 10-15%. You could keep waiting for the election and election results to decide what you want to do or you could decide that you could start dipping in a particular company, given its intrinsic value and cheap valuation.

Many stocks both in the midcap and otherwise neglected part of largecaps have started moving up, said Sudip Bandyopadhyay, Group Chairman, Inditrade Capital, in an interview with ET Now.
Edited excerpts: 

Do you think large banks will continue to report good numbers -- the likes of ICICI, Axis and maybe SBI?
They will continue to report good numbers on the back of the fact that the asset quality issues are by and large over. What is going to happen is NCLT process is gathering momentum and some amount of recoveries will start happening which will help them improve their profit on the back of the fact that most of these assets were written off earlier.

Also, the NBFC or liquidity crisis, which started from the IL&FS fiasco, pretty much ensured that the rates of interest at which they have been lending have stabilised or gone up marginally. This is in spite of the fact that RBI is trying to bring down the rates, but the real rate at which they are lending or people are borrowing is marginally higher than what it was prior to let us say September. 

On the back of these two things, the performance of large corporate facing banks are definitely going to improve in the coming days and we have been bullish on ICICI, Axis, Federal Bank, City Union Bank, South Indian Bank and a whole lot of other corporate facing banks. You have to be careful at what price you are entering the stocks because that will be a key factor


What do you make of Airtel and their fund-raising plans?
The verdict is out in the market. With the kind of valuation at which they are making the issuance leads to a significant dilution, obviously the market is not liking it. That is why the stock is being punished and Airtel is completely out of sync with today’s market mood. 

But having said that, companies in this particular sector have very little option but to build a war chest to ensure that they are able to effectively compete with the other big boys in the space. So, there are very few options as far as Airtel is concerned but again the market is punishing the stock because this kind of dilution will definitely erode the investor value per share. So yes, there is a matter of concern but it is a catch-22 situation as far as the telecom space goes. 


NBFCs were the market favourites same time last year. Do you still believe that this sort of correction is the time to buy in good NBFCs with great capital and great processes?
Yes absolutely. NBFCs definitely have a space in Indian economy. The segment of the market which NBFCs have been catering to were not serviced by the banks and large institutions. That was the rationale and that was the reason why NBFCs came into existence and grew so rapidly. 

In last four-six years, they have exponentially grown on the back of the miseries of large corporate facing banks and particularly the PSU banks. The niche they occupy is not yet being serviced by banks. These are the niches which large banks will also not endeavour to service in the near future. They have a role to play and if they have a role to play, the government and the system will definitely find ways and means to meet their funding requirements. 

The challenge is not their systems, processes or people. The challenge is meeting their funding requirements and so a good set of NBFCs with good set of systems, processes, people will get fund. 

We are seeing it getting played out in the market today. There is little bit of stress on the weaker NBFCs but the NBFCs which have a strong balance sheet are doing well or would have started performing very well once again. They are getting their supply of funds and there is no fundamental worry. As far as the markets are concerned, valuation-wise, they have taken a hit but it is a matter of time before it starts recovering once again.


What interests you within the broader markets?
For quite some time, we have been saying that one should look at the broader universe. The Nifty was moving on the back of the movement in a few largecap stocks. After a long time, today is probably an exception. We are seeing many stocks both in the midcap and otherwise neglected part of largecaps also moving up. Today is a different day but otherwise that has been the trend. 

Coming back to the stocks or pockets which one can look at, I have been mentioning that consumption is a theme which is evergreen as far as India is concerned. We will have elections and GDPs moving up and down, but the fact remains that consumption and the consumption related theme will continue to sell in India. 

In that particular space, ITC Ltd looks good at current levels as it is definitely cheaper compared to its peer group. The performance of tobacco has been solid as usual. There are concerns about volume growth but there is absolutely no problem with overall profitability. The real interesting part is the other businesses which were a drag on the profitability, have started showing signs of stability and improvement that is going to pay rich dividend going forward. 

Apart from that, one can look at some of the automobile stocks that really look beaten down. So, a Maruti and even Ashok Leyland at current level look good for an investor with one year plus time horizon. 


You like some of the midcap IT names – NIIT Tech and Mindtree. What about largeccaps and why Mindtree and NIIT Tech?
Mindtree and NIIT Tech are on the back of the corporate action which is being envisaged for some and there is rationale and certainty to the corporate action. It is a matter of time when it happens and considering the valuation at which these stocks are quoting currently, we believe that an open offer is bound to happen post the corporate action and that will definitely unlock significant value from here on as well. 

So for an aggressive investor, these two are good bets even at current levels. As far as large IT companies are concerned, both TCS and Infosys are definitely steady stocks. Their performance has been stable but it is a question of how much incremental money you will make entering at current levels. If somebody has limited resources, I will say let us play through midcap IT but if somebody wishes to have steady stable return over a period of time, even now TCS and Infosys at current levels looks good.


You talked about Ashok Leyland and I just want to highlight what the monthly auto sales are looking like. Barring what Eicher’s commercial vehicle segment has done in February, it has been disappointing all across. Do you now believe that maybe all the negatives are baked in when it comes to autos and one can look at buying the likes of an Eicher Motors or perhaps even a Maruti?
I completely agree with that line of thought. You mentioned Eicher Motors. Look at the Bajaj Auto numbers. They took a conscious call on the export front quite some time back and that is paying them rich dividend today. They also took a conscious call a few quarters back on getting into a price war model for domestic market and again that is paying them handsomely. 

Bajaj Auto numbers have been pretty good, yes the stock took a beating today but the fact remains that the numbers were good as far as Bajaj is concerned. 

As far as the overall recovery of the space is concerned, commercial vehicle sales probably will recover ahead of passenger vehicle sales as soon as the liquidity situation eases and the GDP shows signs on definite upward movement. We will see the commercial vehicle space moving up. Of course, passenger vehicle also will move and Maruti with significant presence across the country including vehicles which work well in the rural market will be a beneficiary. 


How would you look at the pharma sector?
Well I have been bullish on the pharma sector, particularly in the midcap pharma space and there are enough opportunities. Earlier there was a huge pricing pressure on US generics and that was taking a toll on many Indian companies. 

The second was the regulatory issues which were kind of facing these companies. I think on both counts significant positive developments have happened; regulatory issues by and large are behind most of our companies and US pricing pressure is ebbing so that is good news for Indian pharma. 

In the midcap space, Natco Pharma and Aurobindo Pharma are our favourites and we kind of are recommending investors to buy into both these. Apart from solid US business where the pricing has stabilised, Natco also has a significantly large domestic business. Aurobindo has a domestic as well as business spread across other geographies. Overall, considering the valuation at which these are quoting, these are interesting from an investment point of view.

NEW DELHI: Headline indices Sensex and Nifty reversed the losing run of three sessions on Friday, spurred by healthy gains in bank, financial, IT and auto stocks, as investors cheered de-escalation of tensions between India and Pakistan.

Speculators raised their bets across sectors on the first day of March futures and options contracts. A rally in emerging markets also influenced mood. 

Chinese stocks jumped after MSCI raised their weight in its global benchmarks. 

Concerns over weak macroeconomic data eased as investors saw a silver lining in subdued GDP and infrastructure output numbers. They hoped that the signs of slowdown in the economy may push RBI to cut interest rate at its next meet. 

The Sensex jumped 196 points, or 0.55 per cent, to close the day at 36,063.81. IndusInd bank stole the show, advancing 2.94 per cent, followed by Yes Bank and Vedanta. 

The decliners included Bharti Airtel, Asian Paints, Bajaj Auto, Axis Bank, Reliance Industries and HCL Tech, sliding up to 3.43 per cent. 

Midcaps and smallcaps stayed ahead of the Sensex, with solid gains, rising up to 2.13 per cent.

NSE's Nifty50 settled higher 71 points, or 0.66 per cent, at 10,863.50.

For the week, Sensex inched up by 192 points or 0.54 per cent, while the Nifty added 72 points or 0.67 per cent.

Let's take a look at highlights of Friday's session.


Rs 1.41 lakh crore added to investor kitty
Friday's rally in the market made BSE investors richer by Rs 1.41 lakh crore as the overall market capitalisation of listed firms on the BSE jumped to Rs 1,41,82,750.99 crore from Rs 1,40,41,530.33 crore on Thursday.


Spurt in open interest
Reliance Power, with a change of 82.35 per cent, emerged at the top among the stocks that witnessed the biggest spurt in open interest on the NSE. It was followed by Arvind (71.83 per cent), Reliance Infrastructure (48.36 per cent), Just Dial (44.64 per cent), Oriental Bank of Commerce (38.76 per cent) and Bharti Airtel (35.14 per cent).


Over 200 stocks hit upper circuits
As many as 202 BSE stocks, including SML Isuzu, Religare Enterprises, Shreyans Industries, Star Paper Mills, Forbes & Company and Indiabulls Integrated Services, hit their upper circuits. On the flip side, Weizmann, Atlas Jewellery India, Optiemus Infracom and Darshan Orna were among the 162 stocks that hit their lower circuits. 


115 stocks signal upside
Momentum indicator moving average convergence divergence, or MACD, showed bullish crossovers on 115 counters on the BSE, indicating that they may climb in coming sessions. Among the stocks that saw bullish crossovers were Engineers India, ITI, Dabur India, Lupin, Repco Home Finance, Mindtree, Dr Reddy's Labs, JSW Energy and Karur Vysya Bank. On the other hand, Tech Mahindra, Eicher Motors, Asian Hotels (West) and Orient Beverages were among the 22 stocks that showed bearish crossovers. 


New CEO takes charge, YES Bank jumps 3%
Shares of YES Bank closed 2.68 per cent higher at Rs 237.40 after Ravneet Gill took charge as Managing Director and CEO of the bank. His tenure as approved by RBI is 3 years from the date of his joining, i.e. March 1, 2019 to February 28, 2022. 


Sugar stocks turn sweeter
Most sugar stocks jumped higher, a day after India's Cabinet approved a plan to spend up to Rs 1,054 crore to pay interest on loans to the sugar industry for a year, in a bid to help sugar mills clear their dues to farmers. Dharani Sugars & Chemicals (up 9.99 per cent), Sakthi Sugars (up 6.06 per cent), Triveni Engineering & Industries (up 5.18 per cent), Indian Sucrose (up 4.69 per cent) and Thiru Arooran Sugars (up 4.97 per cent) were among top gainers in the sugar space. 


Airtel falls on EPS worry
Markets reacted negatively to the fund-raising plan of Bharti Airtel as the shares of the company fell 3.43 per cent to close at Rs 307.05. Analysts say the raised funds will help the company pare its debt, but is not enough for its capex and opex plans. Also, the deep discount given for the right issue will hit the company's investors view for further fund-raising and increase worries on EPS estimates.


SBI Life Insurance gains 5%
Shares of SBI Life Insurance Company settled at Rs 612.25, up 5.47 per cent, after CA Emerald Investments, an affiliated entity of a Carlyle Group fund, bought 9 per cent stake in the firm. Separately, BNP Paribas Cardif SA cut its stake in the insurer by 9.23 per cent to 12.77 per cent, the company said. 


Jet Airways jumps 5%
Shares of Jet Airways closed 5.32 per cent higher at Rs 234.65 on reports that founder Naresh Goyal had agreed to step down as chairman. Reuters said Goyal also agreed to reduce his 51 per cent stake in the airline but would continue to be part of the company in some capacity even after stepping down as chairman.


Auto sales
SML Isuzu sold 1,282 vehicles in February 2019 against 965 vehicles in the same month a year ago. The stock closed 20 per cent up at Rs 682.55. 

Domestic sales of Mahindra & Mahindra stood at 52,915 vehicles, compared with 48,473 units during February 2018. Shares closed the day 0.43 per cent up at Rs 649.35.

Maruti Suzuki India saw a marginal decline in total sales at 1,48,682 units. The company had sold 1,49,824 units in February last year. The scrip closed 1.48 per cent up at Rs 6,933.20. 

Ashok Leyland saw an increase of 1 per cent in its domestic sales at 17,352 units. Shares of the company closed 0.23 per cent up at Rs 86.55.

Total trucks and buses sales of Eicher Motors came in at 6,268 units against 6,796 units a year ago. The scrip settled 0.19 per cent up at Rs 19,938.25. 

Escorts reported a 12 per cent increase in tractor sales at 7,240 units against 6,462 units in February 2018. Its shares closed 2.35 per cent up at Rs 674.30. 

Bajaj Auto reported a 10 per cent increase in total sales at 3,93,089 units against 3,57,883 units in the same month last year. The stock fell 1.16 per cent to close at Rs 2,862.90.

Abhimanyu Sofat, VP-Research, IIFL, is optimistic about midcap stocks which he says remain quite stable in the face of falling GDP numbers. He expects technology and private bank stocks to gain further traction. He was speaking to ETNow.

Edited excerpts:


What is the screen telling you? Irrespective of the rising geopolitical concerns, the Nifty has really put on a show of resilience. What was good to see in the week gone by was that the broader markets as well began to participate. Would you say this is just a temporary phase because that big overhang of elections is still not done or would you say, we are sort of out of the woods?

We are not clearly out of the woods, it has more to do with the fact that year to date, we have one of the underperforming countries relative to what is happening whether in the developed market or even other countries. Take the case of China, which had gone up significantly because of lowering of tensions between the US and China. 

As for the Indian market, clearly that overhang of election continues. People are still sitting on the sidelines. They still do not have full conviction in terms of adding positions and the geopolitical tensions which are there with Pakistan clearly are adding to that. 

But what one realises is there are certain pockets of the markets, say IT, which have done pretty well over the last couple of days. That market is unlikely to get impacted by whatever happens on the geopolitical side. And for that reason, we are clearly seeing that some of the sectors which are not dependent on what happens on the border are clearly seeing traction in terms of market performance.


The start has been very slow, we had the February auto sales numbers come in. When it comes to Maruti, you have had slow sales. When it comes to Ashok Leyland, the muted movement continues for the fourth consecutive month now. This is irrespective of some hefty discounts from most motown majors. That has been unable to really lift volumes and kick in demand. Do you think that all the negatives are in the price and maybe at the dips one can nibble at for the likes of an Eicher Motors which is struggling at a 52-week low or for that matter, a Maruti which has fallen quite considerably from the top?

It is all about risk reward, which is especially so when we are seeing that the overall industry momentum for auto is not that great. Considering from a risk reward perspective, something like a Bajaj Auto which is trading close to around 15x is something we would be comfortable on. 

Overall, for the sector, we are not that bullish in terms of growth, going forward. Maruti at the right price would be a good buy, a lot of positives for the next two years are already there in the price. If you see the growth numbers, the compact sales growth number was higher, but that was partially due to the fact that the Wagon R category has changed and that was the reason why we saw an 11 per cent kind of growth in that particular segment. 

The numbers continue to disappoint and we would be cautious on the sector as well from here now.


Any particular trend or new piece that you would particularly think would impact the market in the near term?

Yes, obviously the geopolitical front is something that one needs to clearly look at. However, the heartening thing we have seen is that despite falling GDP numbers, we see the midcap stocks continuing to remain quite stable. 

If we see some amount of improvement over the next couple of days in terms of midcap stocks going up, then clearly one would see that some amount of buying interest could come back to the stocks. Overall, consumption and gross capital formation are the kinds of things that one needs to look at. Based on that, something like Titan, which is enjoying more from the gold price going up over the last 2-3 months looks quite interesting to us. 

From the technology pack, a lot of companies whether it is HCL or Tech Mahindra, those look quite interesting to us. These are the companies in addition to the private banks where we now see the slippages to fall. We expect the stocks to do pretty well.

ET Intelligence Group: The Bullet, it appears, is just not firing on all cylinders at the moment.

Royal Enfield (RE) sales are rather soft, and state-wise volume statistics furnished by industry body SIAM show that the bike that defines panache for motorcycle enthusiasts in India is riding through a rather rough patch. Eight states that make up three of every five RE bikes sold locally have reported deceleration.

Maharashtra and Karnataka together account for 13 per cent of RE volumes, and these two states have seen a drop in 6-7 quarters of the past nine.

Kerala, the largest market of RE, has witnessed volume drops of 13 per cent and 23 per cent in the September and December quarters, respectively. The September decline is attributed to floods. But declines in the December quarter have put the lens on underlying demand. To be sure, volumes at leading carmaker Maruti Suzuki, a proxy for consumer discretionary spending, rose 9 per cent in Kerala in December after declining 25 per cent in the previous quarter.



RE volumes in Kerala dropped 5 per cent in the first nine months of FY19, while it grew 24 per cent in the same period last fiscal. Bike sales in Tamil Nadu saw a fall of 37 per cent in the December quarter.

Industry volume growth of twowheelers in south India was 9.5 per cent in the first nine months, up from 5.6 per cent in the previous year. However, RE’s sales volume growth in the Southern states has been underwhelming.

The Street has been pencilling in volume growth on the assumption that Uttar Pradesh, a less penetrated market, would help offset tepid demand elsewhere. But UP sales climbed 7 per cent in the December quarter. With the base becoming larger in UP, volume growth is likely to be weak. Similarly, among north India states, Punjab sales grew 14 per cent, but remained lower than the industry growth of 28 per cent.

The RE management has given production guidance of 8.7-8.8 lakh units for the current fiscal year. However, it is unlikely to be met. Average monthly run-rate of RE in the first 11months of FY19 stood at 69,569 units. To achieve the stated guidance, the company needs to produce 1.04 lakh vehicles in March. This appears to be quite a daunting task given the weak demand cycle.

The Street is factoring in volume growth of 10 per cent for FY20, which could be trimmed due to about 3 per cent growth in FY19. The Eicher Motors stock fell 30 per cent in the past year following constant negative surprises on the volume front. The stock is trading at 21 times FY20 earnings, compared with the long-term average of 30 times.

NEW DELHI: Equity benchmarks Sensex and Nifty logged strong gains on Tuesday on healthy buying in bank, financial, auto, oil & gas and metal stocks.

Investors’ risk appetite got a boost after crude oil prices softened further, the rupee gained strength against the US dollar and analysts projected improved prospects for Prime Minister Modi in the forthcoming general elections.

Expectations for an increase in the US crude inventories dragged oil price down towards the $65 a barrel mark. Resumption of Libya's biggest oilfield added more pressure on the commodity price.

Sensex closed the day 379 points, or 1.05 per cent, higher at 36,442, with 24 stocks ending in the green and seven in the red. Nifty50 settled 124 points, or 1.14 per cent, higher at 10,987, with 39 stocks advancing and 11 declining.

Midcaps and smallcaps outperformed Sensex with wider margins; the BSE Midcap index rose 2.01 per cent and the BSE Smallcap index 3.11 per cent. 


Let's take a look at the key highlights of Tuesday's session:

Investors gained Rs 2.45 lakh cr a single day!Tuesday's rally made investors richer by Rs 2.45 lakh crore, as the total market capitalisation of BSE-listed firms shot up to Rs 1,44,27,254.47 crore from Rs 1,41,81,544.79 crore on Friday. 


304 BSE stocks hit upper circuitsAs many as 304 stocks, including Tata Steel, Graphite India, Vakrangee, Reliance Naval and Engineering, Shankara Building Products and IL&FS Transportation Networks, hit upper circuit limits. However, Jaypee Infratech, Gyscoal Alloys, Industrial Investment Trust, Eurotex Industries & Exports and Oasis Tradelink were among the 177 stocks that touched their lower circuits. 


Spurt in OIRepco Home Finance, with a change of 84 per cent, led a pack of stocks that witnessed the biggest spurt in open interest (OI) on NSE. RBI slaps Rs 1 crore fine on YES Bank The Reserve Bank of India has slapped a fine of Rs 1 crore on YES Bank for non-compliance of directions on the Swift messaging software, the global messaging software used for transactions by the financial entities. The Rs 14,000 crore fraud at the PNB was a case of misuse of this massaging software. Shares of YES Bank closed 0.04 per cent down at Rs 237.30.


Cadila climbs on USFDA nod Shares of Cadila Healthcare closed 2.48 per cent up at Rs 331.20 after it received the USFDA approval to market Rivastigmine Transdermal System, marking its first approval for a transdermal product in the US.

Aurobindo climbs on new product acquisition Shares of Aurobindo Pharma climbed 1.73 per cent to settle at Rs 735.90 after the company said it completed the acquisition of seven marketed oncology injectable products from Spectrum Pharmaceuticals Inc.

PNB, IOC, NMDC above 200-DMAsPunjab National Bank (PNB), Indian Oil Corporation (IOC), NCC, BPCL, HDIL, Blue Star, NMDC, JSW Energy, Bosch and Bank of India were among the stocks that witnessed positive breakouts and traded above their 200-DMAs.
