For the last four weeks, we consistently saw positive FII inflows and that seems to suggest that there is some 
  
  
  interest coming back into the broader market, said Siddhartha Khemka, VP - Head of Research (Retail), MOSL, in an interview with ET Now.Edited excerpts:

How do you read into the buoyancy in the markets in the afternoon despite some indications of a soft start this morning from the global end of the market? Is this sort of move where we are ignoring what is going across the globe likely to continue especially with what is happening with the broader end of the market?
We had seen in the market that the global rally was taking place. We were not participating because of a host of domestic factors. Now the market is well past that event. The geopolitical issues look likely to have resolved. Other factors like the US-China trade talks seems to getting resolved. Also the pressure from the crude side seems to be stabilising. 

Having said that, the boarder market was oversold. A lot of stocks were hammered and the positive factor that started supporting the market was the positive FII figures. For the last four weeks, we consistently saw positive FII inflows and that seems to suggest that there is some interest coming back into the broader market.


Recently Mark Mobius alluded to the fact that with developments on the geopolitical front, BJP’s chances of winning the 2019 polls have turned brighter. He believes that PM Modi’s popularity for the second term is only going to grow and that our prospects compared to other markets like China are very strong. What do you believe is the sentiment in the runup to the big event?
Yes, definitely there are positive sentiments across the board which is being reflected not only from the domestic side but from the global FII perspective as well. While I am not a political analysts to suggest what the outcome may be, the events that have unfolded has definitely led to positive sentiments towards the current government and especially the Modi-led government where the Street is now talking about a sharp increase in the number of seats that they could win from what they were talking about just before this event unfolded. 

So that is a positive. If the current government continues for the next term, that will definitely be positive for the broader markets which is where we are seeing the interest coming back in the market.


Is Eicher at a good level to be bought into and are all the negatives and decline in the RE sales, priced in?
Yes. Eicher had a lot of issues apart from the volume decline. They had issues with regards to strike at their factories and that also impacted some of the volumes. Compared to the historical past, the valuations were comfortable and that gives some upside to the stock. However, in the near term, we do not see very high growth in the volumes. 

If I were to explain that while the absolute volumes looks like bottoming out, on a YoY basis, we would not see much of a growth and generally we try and track the growth in the two-wheeler or the overall auto sector. It is valued for the high growth that the sector gives which is still some time away. 

Right now, more of value buying is there, which helped investors from a long-term perspective and can definitely have a look given the good portfolio and the niche segment that Eicher caters to. However, in the short-term, I do not think we need to see whether this buying get sustained but in terms of volumes and numbers, I do not see much upside in the near term.


You say there is a decent asset quality improvement in corporate banks now. Which are these banks where you are seeing asset quality improvement and are you restricting yourself only to private sector or are there some PSU names?
Generally, the bulk of the corporate facing banks which includes some of the PSUs are seeing a good improvement in asset quality. Slippages have bottomed out, provisions are getting lowered, because of which even if you see the latest quarter Q3 numbers, most of them reported healthy improvement in earnings. 

But if you see private companies, for an Axis Bank, so far NII grew almost 18% while the PAT growth was much higher because of lower slippages and lower provisioning. The entire corporate facing banks because of the NCLT resolution and because of new NPAs not coming in, are seeing good improvement in the overall asset quality. 

However, in terms of growth potential, I will restrict myself to the top three corporate facing banks which is your ICICI, Axis and one PSU that is again doing well -- SBI. All three are in the same league and are expected to do well going forward. These are the preferred picks in the overall banking space, specifically the corporate facing ones. 


If I have to go a one notch below and compromise a bit on quality, then which are the two or three names which attract your attention?
Some of the banks where I would not want to get into are tier two or tier three PSBs. But you can get into the private space. For example, look at RBL Bank, which is a mix of SME, retail as well as corporate book and has done consistently well. That is a bank which we prefer among our top picks. 

Apart from that, if you wanted to take some risk, Yes Bank is another corporate facing banks which should do well. The quarterly numbers have been pretty good. The new management now is in place. We have also got clearance from RBI saying that there has been no divergence in the latest annual numbers. That baggage is now behind us and that should continue to do well.

Overall, there is a slowdown but at the same time, it is not much of a concern in the medium to long term, said Vinod Aggarwal, MD & CEO, VECV, in an interview with ET Now. Edited excerpts: 
Most of the reports that we are reading seem to indicate that the Indian CV industry is entering a downturn. What exactly is the sense that you are getting? Is the slowdown of the last few months structural or cyclical in nature, according to you?
There has been slowdown in last four months starting from November, But at the same time, we should not forget that the last year, the January to March quarter was a bumper quarter and this year due to that large base effect, the numbers are less as compared to the last quarter’s.

But the numbers are still good. For example, in February, the heavy duty trucks industry was still 25,000 plus and 5-15 ton trucks industry was still 10,500 which are good numbers. So, overall, there is some slowdown but at the same time, it is not much of a concern in the medium to long term.


Would you attribute it to only high base effect or is it something else?
No, definitely there is liquidity crunch. After November, there has been some problem with respect to the financing by NBFCs. To that extent, there is liquidity crunch. Some retail customers are not able to get the financing as easily as it was earlier. Similarly, the interest rates have gone up a little bit. At the same time, there has been some impact of the axle load norms which were changed last year and due to that, higher capacity is also available. 

Then the replacements are required but at the same time, the fleet operators are still waiting and watching because there is a lot of uncertainty. I am sure once the elections are over, we should get into regular demand and there would be a very strong replacement cycle that is coming in and then at the same time you will have the pre-buying impact due to BS VI norms that is going to kick in. 

Another positive for the industry is infrastructure investments. The infrastructure sector is doing very well and as a result of that, even if the overall industry was looking down as compared to the same quarter (Jan to March) last year, the construction trucks -- tippers -- have grown even in February and YTD, the growth in tippers market is 50%. That is a huge growth in the construction trucks. I would say infrastructure is continuing to be very strong. Apart from that, the e-commerce segment is continuing to lead to a lot of demands,. There are these positives which are in sectors which are leading to good prospects for the industry in medium to long term.


Do you see the liquidity situation improve any time soon? Are the headwinds that you just highlighted, going to sustain in the near to medium term as well?
No. The liquidity crunch will get over because I have seen lots of steps being taken by NBFCs to raise the medium to long term finance. They are taking steps to substitute the short-term borrowing which they were doing, through commercial papers. They are coming out with more and more medium-term papers and at the same time, there is more support coming in from the banks. Banks have also started giving loans to NBFCs. I am confident that the NBFCs’ liquidity crunch should be over in next three to six months.


What is the current inventory level at present? Is there slump in demand in heavy duty segment or is it going to be more broad-based?
As far as the inventory is concerned, it is absolutely normal as far as we are concerned. I am not sure about the inventory of the competition but as far as Volvo Eicher is concerned, our inventory is absolutely normal and then we were growing. 

In the YTD basis, we have grown by 14%. If you look at the industry also, on YTD basis, it is still growing handsomely and we are going to new peaks in all the segments like heavy duty trucks which will touch sales of close to 300,000 and light and medium duty (5-15 tonne) truck sales will go up to 1,10,000 to 1,15,00. The earlier peak was 1,03,000 in 2011-12. Buses sales should be around 65,000 to 75,000. 

So, for the overall industry this year, we will see good growth and even in sub 5-ton segment, there is a growth of more than 20%. Overall CV industry will fare very well this despite facing some headwinds in last few months. 


OEMs, according to you, are still doling out discounts in order to push sales. What exactly is the outlook on that front? Do you think that sort of a trend is going to continue?
Discounts are still continuing. They are on deal-to-deal basis. If there is a bulk deal, the discount maybe higher. If there is a retail deal, discounts maybe less. So the discounts are continuing. Of course, you can say it is a factor of demand and supply. Capacity is available with the industry and as a result, discounts are still high.


What is the likely impact on margins given the discounting trend and the decline that one has seen in the heavy and the medium segment so far?
In first nine months, we are maintaining the margins at around 8-9%. Of course, beyond a point, we have a very clear policy that we will not run after the market share, we will not sell the trucks at any cost. So, we have put an upper limit beyond which we will not give the discounting beyond a point. Each company has its policy on the same and as far as we are concerned, we are very clear that we will not go beyond a point.

NEW DELHI: NSE barometer Nifty50 kicked off March derivatives series on a solid note, settling last week a tad above its 200-day moving average. In the process, 74 stocks formed bullish crossovers on NSE, as suggested by momentum indicator moving average convergence divergence, or MACD. Technically, this signals more upside for these stocks. 

The fact that many of these stocks have also been witnessing strong trading volumes of late is adding credibility to the emerging trend.

Engineers India looks set to rally. The technical indicator has signalled an upward crossover, meaning a bullish signal, on the counter. Dabur India, Lupin, Mindtree, Repco Home, TVS Motor, Sequent Scientific, Network18 Media and MCX are some on other stocks that look positive on the technical charts. The list also includes Hero MotoCorp, Dr Reddy's Labs, MOIL, Karur Vysya Bank, ABB India and CESC. 




The MACD is known for signalling trend reversal in traded securities or indices. It is the difference between the 26-day and 12-day exponential moving averages. A nine-day exponential moving average, called the signal line, is plotted on top of the MACD to reflect 'buy' or 'sell' opportunities.

When the MACD crosses above the signal line, it gives a bullish signal, indicating that the price of the security may see an upward movement and vice versa.

Meanwhile, 12 stocks showed bearish crossovers on the daily charts, indicating that these stocks may see downsides in the days ahead. They included Eicher Motors, Tourism Finance Corporation, Endurance Technologies, Asian Hotels (West) and Aditya Birla Nuvo. 



The MACD indicator should not be seen in isolation, as it may not be sufficient to take a trading call, just the way a fundamental analyst cannot give a 'buy' or 'sell' call using a single valuation ratio.

Traders should make use of other indicators such as Relative Strength Index (RSI), Bollinger Bands, Fibonacci Series, candlestick patterns and Stochastic to confirm an emerging trend.

In case of Nifty50, it has clearly formed a 'double bottom' on the daily chart, said IIFL Securities. 

It has also surged and tested its critical zone of 10,870-10,900, which is the confluence of the resistance area. "A break above the resistance would lift Nifty higher towards the 11,000 level, with the 10,800 mark being a key support," the brokerage said in a weekly note. 

ICICIdirect sees a resolve in Nifty50 to move out of the upper band of its consolidation range (10,900), unfolding the next leg of upward move towards 11,400 level in the coming months. 

"Volatility would remain high in the runup to the elections, which should be capitalised as an incremental buying opportunity in the 10,750-10,600 range," it said.


UNDERSTANDING MACD
 
A close look at the stock chart of Engineers India shows whenever the MACD line has breached above the signal line, the stock showed an upward momentum and vice versa.

Private banks and cement companies are where money would flow in said, Gurmeet Chadha, Co-Founder, 
Complete Circle Consultants, in an interview with ET Now. Also, one can be selective in consumption and tactical in OMCs, says Chadha. Edited excerpts: 


What is it that the market is pricing in? It seems this is a pre-election cheer which is coming in a tad too early?
It is a little early to call it pre-election cheers but what has happened is that while the entire market continues to focus on the geopolitical risk, a lot of other risks which the market was concerned about have abated a little bit. 

2018 was a year when we had some central banks hiking rates like in US and some of the emerging markets like India and Indonesia. There were some central bankers who were more accommodative. Probably this year you will see all central bankers being more accommodative. US is already indicating a pause in balance sheet contraction. India has already had a rate cut. China has now guided for lower end of the GDP at 6%. You could see both monetary and fiscal stimulus there. 

You will probably have a synchronised central bank accommodative stance this year which is positive for EMs. Also the threat of a full-blown trade war seems to have abated a little bit. Also India has really underperformed the EM basket. The emerging market index is up 11-12%. China is almost 18-20% up and we had underperformed. So. it could be a bit of catching up as well.


Which are those names which you would like to be part of your portfolio? Any particular segment within housing finance companies where you are more optimistic?
In the housing finance space, we have to differentiate the balance sheets. It looks to be a homogenous space, but it is not. A lot of the names have been under pressure -- the likes of Edelweiss or Repco or even Motilal because of their Aspire incurring losses. 

In case of L&T Finance, 60-65% of the book is mortgaged. The balance is developer loans and LAP. Also, NHP does not regulate HFCs as strongly as RBI does for some of the others in terms of banks. I also expect more regulation to come in once this crisis is fully taken care of. 

Within the HFC space, one safe bet is HDFC Limited. They have about six million homes which they have financed. They have a right combination of consumer and institutional book. Even if you see the institutional book, they are more focussed. The growth is coming from the lease rental discounting and construction finance and not much from the corporate loans to developers. We are a little selective here. I would consider something like a Can Fin in HFCs, where 80% of the book are linked to the salaried class, which again are mostly government employees. 

We have to watch out on the liability side. It should be more granular and on the lending side, the exposure to developer loans and the LAP should be a little lower. On consumer finance, the obvious position which I have been maintaining for long is Bajaj Finance. 


You seem to be betting on NCC. What kind of potential do you see over here? What is the long-term target price and do you believe now is a good time to enter?
We are positive on three fronts. They have a order book of more than Rs 34,000 crore, even in last quarter, they had a good EBIT with 12% margin. Most of these orders are government PSU backed. It is one of the largest construction companies right now. 

The only concern is the working capital days which is about the highest in the industry. Their receivable days are about 200 vis-à-vis about 120 for the industry. The safer bet could be L&T in the largecap space which is not necessarily construction, but the entire engineering construction -- the ECC space. In Q4, they have guided for almost Rs 40,000-50,000 crore of order book and in the first nine months, they were at about Rs 1.2 lakh crore.

If they have a Rs 40,000-50,000-crore order book, they will be on course to hit about 10% to 12% growth in orders and the good part is that there is improvement across the metrics. It is not only in terms of the diversification of orders. There are orders from hydrocarbons and refineries because the oil prices have been a little better. There are airports, water supply and they have this time re-categorised the orders into broadly four categories -- which is significant, large, major and mega. I am not really talking about the small orders which are Rs 1,000 crore. There is improvement in working capital cycle as well. So, in this space, we are fairly positive on largecap L&T and midcap NCC.


Tata Motors clocked it is best single day gain in about three years’ time. Do you think Tata Son’s business rejig to cut costs, the fact that they have assured that JLR turnaround is round the corner and the kind of rebound that we have seen in the Feb auto sales would that give you conviction to be a medium or long-term buyer in Tata Motors?
It is interestingly placed. If you see its sales breakup, the passenger cars actually grew 2% in Feb where the CV and the overall business was down. In case of JLR also, the US sales were up about 29%. If you add Germany, Italy and US and put together as a cluster minus China, it grew about 16%. 

There is lot of action in terms of ramping up their I-PACE model. There are couple of more SUV models on the Range Rover platform. So it will be an interesting space to watch out and I think Tata Motors has been attractive sub-200 for a long, long time. 

I think what has happened is that every quarter you had some disappointment or the other. I would like to watch out for Brexit and the China factor because that is where the high margin because US is mostly low margin sales. China is where they have the higher margin as well as volumes sales coming up. So, maybe with news of China cutting 3% VAT on manufacturing, there could be a slight improvement in their China sales.

In domestic business, the response to Harrier and some of the new SUVs which they are coming is quite good in terms of their dealer checks we have done. So it is an interesting one. If you want to buy it right now, maybe 20% now and then wait for a quarter and then maybe gradually accumulate.


Would you buy into Eicher sub Rs 20,000? The stock has recovered much from there and seeing a big move today?
A lot of pain was in the price when the stock was at around Rs 19,000 and sub 19,000. The numbers of February were also a little disappointing as it was approximately 64,000 units versus 70,000 which this fleet was expecting. If you look at it, the strike in one of their plants meant a loss of 3,000 units. So, it is a larger trend which is playing out here. I will not be a buyer right now on Eicher. I will try to wait and watch because I like to see two trends here, one is their new models which are at the 650 cc which is the Interceptor and the Terminator.

Also often not discussed is the commercial vehicle segment and they have some good technology in the medium weight commercial vehicles. We probably will have to see whether the CV cycle is on the downturn or it is a temporary phase. But it is good to add on dips. You can wait and watch for now on some of these auto names, but as I said lot of pain is in the price.


How are you playing the consumption theme? Do you believe that within the consumption space, you would tend to be very selective?
I would be. Every election in India is like a mini QE (quantitative easing). You see the cash in circulation goes up. It has already gone above the pre-DeMo level and a lot of the parallel side of the economy comes into the mainstream with the kind of spending we see.

We are already seeing government transferring about Rs 28,000 crore to the farmers which is part of the basic income support. There will be more loan waivers and as you get closer to election, there will be probably a lot of spending by the political parties. So. that makes me positive. 

There are two-three spaces I like here. The FMCG packs stands out, I like Nestle and HUL in the staples. Nestle is likely to launch about 13 t0 15 new products, you could have a topline growth of 15% after a long, long time and followed by a margin expansion or may be 80 to 100 bps. So, that looks attractive. 

HUL has come off a little bit in the last previous trading sessions. The food and the beverage segment after the acquisition would give them the distribution reach to add on to those gains so positive there. 

I also like some niche consumption plays which are like the pressure cooker and the kitchenware makers like a TTK prestige the market itself will probably grow 3 to 4x as rural areas are only 20-30% penetrated. 

I also like some of the while we have spoke about Info Edge right and Zomato probably the unlisted space has an advantage on the food aggregator side but I like Jubilant for the fact that there has been a good price correction. They are cutting down on their Dunkin Donuts outlets which did not pan out well. They have already cut down from 70 to about 35. The same store growth is about 20-21% and they are now venturing into the Chinese Kitchen which will probably give them some variety to take on to these food aggregator so those are some of the ideas in the space.


How would you approach not just OMCs but also some of the other names like ONGC and some of the gas names like MGL, IGL?
There are two parts to the portfolio. One is buy to hold which is your HDFC and Bajaj Finance and Asian Paints of the world and one is buy to sell. A lot of these OMCs, some of the PSU names you spoke about possibly fall there. One has to be a little tactical in OMCs. HPCL for example at sub-200 was a good buy. It was almost book value. 

Also we have to look at the marketing infrastructure. Some of these are virtually oligopolies. There are chances of obvious government regulating through tinkering with excise duties and subsidies. HPCL, in particular, is one of the largest lube based refineries in India. If I were to be a little tactical here, I will probably pick up HPCL. 

You are right about the city gas distributors. MGL looks very, very good. We are already seeing three-wheeler sales turning positive for most of the auto makers even in February. So domestic connections, increasing three wheelers moving to the CNG and slightly lesser regulation in the gas space compared to petrol and diesel, gives them an edge. 

But again you have to be more tactical here. Some of the other PSU names where you can be a little tactical is NTPC. It is trading at about 11 times. It has a good dividend yield. The coal production is up by almost 7% after a long time. The dispatches are up about 3%. It is a virtual monopoly play. This is almost like 7-8% dividend yield on it. So maybe that part of the portfolio could be looked at, but as I said tactically.


In the next leg of the rally, where do you think the contribution is going to come in from sectorally?
If you see the overall report which has come last year on the entire banking sector, the private corporate banks are getting the bulk of the flows. If you look at for example current accounts, the share of PSU bank has even fallen from 58% last year to 54%. In deposits, they are losing market share and by deposits I mean saving, current and term deposits. 

Once you lose current account share, it basically means that cash management is being handed over to the private banks. The corporate loan fund are going to the private banks which affects the PSU banks’ trade, their fx income and it has a cascading impact on their overall fee and interest income. 

So they will continue to gain market share and bankex typically grows one and a half times GDP. If private banks can gain market share, probably they will grow at 15% to 18% as a category. Also, the credit cost is likely to come off by 100 bps for private banks largely led by ICICI and Axis. Now on a large base, a 1% reduction in credit cost would translate to Rs 5,000-7,000 crore of bottom line movement. That is one space which is looking very good. 

Some of the construction names we have discussed in the capital goods space looks good. Cement valuations look very, very attractive. There have been a price hike of Rs 50 to Rs 60 on an average in south, about Rs 30-40 in other parts of the country. Good picks here could be Shree Cement which is largely north based and ACC as well because the stock has been a little under pressure due to having older splant and some of the clinker capacities are not really coming through. So, these are the broad sectors, which liquidity would chase.

Dr CK Narayan of Chart Advise has a buy call on Eicher Motors Ltd. with a target price of Rs 21850. The current market price of Eicher Motors Ltd. is Rs 21507.7. Time period given by the analyst is Intra Day when Eicher Motors Ltd. price can reach defined target. Dr CK Narayan recommended to keep stoploss at Rs 21250. Eicher Motors Ltd., incorporated in 1982, is a largecap company with a market cap of Rs 58680.48 crore.

 Eicher Motors Ltd. key Products/Revenue Segments include Automobile - 2 Wheelers which contributed Rs 8314.17 Crore to Sales Value (90.25 % of Total Sales), Spare Parts & Components which contributed Rs 853.56 Crore to Sales Value (9.26 % of Total Sales), Scrap which contributed Rs 22.15 Crore to Sales Value (0.24 % of Total Sales), Export Incentives which contributed Rs 17.58 Crore to Sales Value (0.19 % of Total Sales) and Other Operating Revenue which contributed Rs 4.35 Crore to Sales Value (0.04 % of Total Sales)for the year ending 31-Mar-2018. 

 For the quarter ended 31-12-2018, the company has reported a Consolidated sales of Rs 2328.25 Crore, down -2.80 % from last quarter Sales of Rs 2395.22 Crore and up 3.45 % from last year same quarter Sales of Rs 2250.65 Crore Company has reported net profit after tax of Rs 491.48 Crore in latest quarter. The company’s top management includes Mr.Inder Mohan Singh, Mr.S Sandilya, Mr.Siddhartha Lal, Ms.Manvi Sinha. Company has S R Batliboi & Co. LLP as its auditoRs As on 31-12-2018, the company has a total of 27,275,653 shares outstanding.

The markets will probably gyrate and the volatility might continue though the positive bias might stay, said 
Mayuresh Joshi, Fund Manager, Angel Broking, in an interview with ET Now.Edited excerpts:


The setup is looking fairly healthy at the moment. The broader end of the market is participating and the flows are fairly encouraging. Are we going to see a prolonged move on the upside or is this a flash in the pan move right now?
The FIIs have probably reposed confidence in our markets and the domestic buying is justifying the move that we are seeing. The rally that we witnessed yesterday was really broad-based. A lot of stocks and sectors probably moved, but my own sense is certain headwinds are still left for the markets to counter. 

On the global scale, we have discussed about it time and again in terms of what happens with Brexit, the US-China contours of negotiations on the trade war and what probably happens with oil. The volatility on these aspects will probably keep currencies probably a little bit on the tighter side. Then we have the general elections over the next few months. So yes, the markets probably were stuck in the range but very close to the upper end of the range.

The markets will probably gyrate and the volatility might continue though the positive bias might stay. I am adopting a stock specific approach in markets like this. 


What is the sense that you are getting when it comes to IT? Do you believe that it will continue to outperform?Ticking off the positive elements that the sector has probably gone through, you could be right. The digital investments as a percentage of top line has increased significantly whether for the top-tier players or mid-tier players. Anywhere between 30-40% is where the digital percentage of revenues are which is a high margin business. 

The second element obviously is in terms of onsite staffing. There was a significant amount of hit that a lot of these players have taken to recalibrate their entire business model and the wage hikes that typically happen in the first two quarters. The EBIT margins which probably got affected have gestated to a large extent, the kind of impact that one probably sees from these factors. 

The third element obviously is the order book and the order book takes off because of the wins that they are probably getting, specifically in key areas like BFSI, retail, manufacturing, life sciences that holds them in good stead. 

The fourth element obviously is utilisation levels. The utilisation levels have started picking up, but attribution levels for a few players are still on the elevated side. As the bench strength starts getting improved and as the execution starts improving, you are probably going to see the earnings traction happen both in the constant currency and dollar terms. 

The risk-off factor probably is slower than expected discretionary spending from US corporates in the event of a slowdown that one probably talks about. BFSI which is very critical for a large number of players, is one sector to be closely monitored. 

The second element obviously is in terms of the slowdown where you are probably going to see lower utilisation levels and higher onsite costs. Having said that, the top tier names is something that investors can hold at. We hold Infosys within the top tier names and HCL Tech in our portfolios. 


What is your outlook on autos? Which are the stocks you prefer?
The slowdown is here to stay for at least next few months, a) they are working on a very high base, b) you are probably looking across the spectrum of the auto universe -- two-wheelers, four-wheelers and even the MHCV players. 

There is high inventory level in the system at this point of time. Over the next few weeks, the liquidation of this inventory is going to be very critical and liquidation of inventory will obviously happen at a discount. Add to that, if we talk about two-wheelers, the entry level segment is where the heavy discounting and undercutting is still continuing to probably have a foothold in terms of market share gains. 

The premium bikes have witnessed certain amount of slowdown pressures as well because of ownership cost moving higher due to higher insurance cost as well as costlier fuel cost in the quarter gone by. There were delayed purchases from the buyer end. 

On the PV side, the competition is hotting up and for volumes to normalise, it will take a few months. It is not going to be a V-shaped recovery in terms of volumes that one can really expect from the auto universe. 

It is a very slow and gradual recovery process that will happen. Even on the MHCV part he LCV market has held up pretty well, the HCV part is probably still languishing because of concerns on what probably happens through in view of axle load norms. 

Again as pre-buying will starting taking place in the second half we will see traction coming but there will be price hikes in the last quarter as well. I am being very, very selective. Eicher Motors is something that we own the two-wheeler space. It has gone through a lot of pressure points but the new twin 650 cc launches that they have done has seen good response. The export market is holding up for them as well. 

Maruti probably looks very interesting. Though the correction has been very sharp, the recovery will be very gradual but valuations probably look very attractive at this point of time. 


I always find this argument rather silly that you should do defensive buying when markets are uncertain and buy staples and auto stocks because they will not fall?

Mayuresh Joshi: So to a certain extent I think a) one must really look at how the earnings recovery and the earnings trajectory is going to pan out. Cyclical sectors go through volatile times and in these volatile times you are going to see these sectors getting beaten down. But there is a huge amount of impact that can also come through in terms of strong earnings recovery. How do you position yourself specifically in terms of the sector allocation that you are probably expected to do with the expectations of strong earnings growth and earnings recovery is something to be seen. 

Financials that you are probably alluding to have probably gone through the worst possible patch. They have also moved up quite sharply. But as credit growth starts picking up in the system, a large part of recognition has probably happened on the book. The valuations probably can get rerated even from the current level. You are talking about specific NBFCs. They have got beaten down out of shape because of liquidity concerns. But the well-capitalised, less-leveraged NBFCs will recover the most as the recovery process starts coming into play. One really needs to understand the dynamics in terms of which sectors might do well. 

Consumption, again is a large basket, but within consumption, there are sectors which can get played out. Our sense is we are probably looking at the paper sector which in our opinion can do really well over the next few quarters and even certain stocks within the hotel industry.

NEW DELHI: High growth days in India’s auto sector seem to be over till a new story, say electric vehicles, comes into play .

Automobile makers reported another month of tepid sales in February. Analysts say even the forthcoming wedding season and the general elections may not help lift passenger vehicle volumes, while two-wheeler sales could see a boost in the medium term.

That said, analysts are still showing a preference for passenger vehicle makers to two-wheeler makers due to relatively less competition, with Maruti Suzuki being the top pick from the segments. Among two-wheeler manufacturers, Bajaj Auto remains the favourite pick.

Most analysts say the commercial vehicle segment will continue to disappoint Dalal Street in the coming months. There has been a buildup of unsold inventory, as RBI rate cut has failed to lift buyers’ sentiment. Looming general elections is another concern.

Centrum Broking says auto demand will continue to remain volatile, but the two-wheeler segment may gain momentum due to recent pro-rural Budget announcements.

”High cost of ownership continues to dent passenger vehicle (PV) volumes. The upcoming marriage and festive seasons could support sales. The CV and tractor cycle seems to have peaked, but pre-buying in H2FY20 could help grow the numbers,” it said in a note.

Nomura sees downside risk for most auto makers, except for Bajaj Auto. The foreign brokerage sees high inventory and rising cost pressure to weigh in going ahead.

“Wholesale volumes are likely to remain subdued despite some improvement in retail sales in March due to the marriage season,” it said. The brokerage maintains a 9 per cent YoY industry growth estimate for FY20.” It said Maruti Suzuki is the best play from the sector.

Maruti posted a set of subdued numbers for February, with domestic volumes rising 0.2 per cent. Unlisted peer Hyundai saw sales drop 3.1 per cent. SUV maker M&M showed strong growth at 16.6 per cent.

Motilal Oswal prefers PV players over CV and two-wheeler makers due to a relatively stable competitive environment. This brokerage prefers Maruti Suzuki among the largecaps.

Analysts said while volume growth for passenger vehicle makers has been tepid, new product launches might offer some respite going ahead.

The two-wheeler space proved a mixed bag. Bajaj Auto logged double-digit growth at 10.2 per cent on attractive product pricing, but Hero Moto Corp registering a 2 per cent decline as it faced challenges in retail sales. Higher cost of ownership and intense competition added to Hero’s woes.

Eicher Motor’s Royal Enfield sales dropped 14.3 per cent. TVS Motor posted 1.7 per cent sales growth.

In the commercial vehicles segment, sluggishness was visible all over due to the lag effect of the implementation of revised axle load norms. Ashok Leyland reported flat volume growth at 0.4 per cent. Eicher Motors also saw a 6.7 per cent decline.

Analyst expect pain for CVs to continue in the coming months. Tractor volume growth slowed down in February to 3.3 per cent YoY, owing to a high base and muted farm sentiment in key markets. Escorts continued to report strong 12 per cent YoY growth, while M&M’s volumes declined 7 per cent YoY.

Analysts expect 10 per cent growth in tractor volumes in FY19, followed by 5 per cent YoY drop in FY20, as the cycle peaks out.

In the two-wheeler segment, Bajaj Auto with 40 per cent exposure to export markets is the top bet in domestic as well as overseas markets, said Centrum Broking.

In all, the PV segment is expected to grow at 7 per cent, while the two-wheeler segment will witness a 6 per cent growth over FY20/FY21, said CLSA. The foreign brokerage expects truck makers to log only 2 per cent growth in FY20, followed by a 12 per cent decline in FY21.

The outlook going forward in terms of growth is getting better. It was only a matter of time before buying emerged from lower
  
  
  levels. What surprised most people was the speed of the rally, said Vivek Mavani, Independent Investment Advisor, in an interview with ET Now. SBI, Bank of Baroda or even some of the tier two or tier three banks like Union Bank are appearing attractive, says Mavani.Edited excerpts: 


 Are we seeing a short-term rebound in the market?
At this point of time, it seems to be a short-term rebound. But it could sustain for a while. Let us put things in perspective. Last six months, some of the largecaps and more of the small and midcaps got hammered. A price erosion of 30-40% seemed quite common. Stocks had been beaten down 60-70% off their highs exactly a year back. We are talking of January-February of last year. Some of them deserved to be beaten but a lot of them had sound fundamentals with short-term concerns or pains.

They were whacked out of shape and at lower levels, value buying at some point of time would have emerged. The key indicator of value buying was that a large number of promoters, entities linked to the promoters buying their own stock or accumulating their own stock via creeping acquisition at lower levels. That is a very convincing sign that things are not so bad or have sort of bottomed out. 

Technically also, the indicator seemed to be giving us hints that the worst seems to be over as far as price is concerned. In last two-three quarters quarterly results, a large number of companies in spite of 30-40-50% correction have still delivered quite reasonably on their earnings front.

The outlook going forward in terms of growth is getting better. It was only a matter of time before buying emerged from lower levels. What surprised most people was the speed of the rally. In less than two weeks, stocks have rallied anywhere from 20% to 50%. That probably is surprising everybody and hence I would say that this seems to be like a missing out feeling that most market participants had last week or even yesterday. Before you missed out on the opportunity, you need to jump on the bandwagon, before it starts to move.

Now is that likely to continue? Perhaps yes, because the NBFC crisis was real, but the crisis did not hit everybody but everybody got hammered as a result. You had even an Edelweiss correcting 60% which probably was undeserved in that sense because when you really scratch the surface and see where Edelweiss has a problem, you are likely to see that Edelweiss really does not have a problem. I am just giving an example and you could extend that same to several other stocks as well. 

If they have been rallying from the bottom, quite rightly they should be. Will this sustain? My sense says it will. Whether it will be stock specific? It will. Are we headed for 12,000? I have no comments on that but individual stocks certainly have bottomed out.


When you say individual stocks have bottomed out, let us say talk about weaker pockets. We have seen Maruti, Eicher Motors. Irrespective of all the news flow on them, Eicher has seen sales dip in February. Is the negative is all baked in and is it time to start buying these stocks? 
I do not think so. Eicher particularly, I do not think so because in Eicher, sometime last year also, valuations had gone quite out of line with its own historical multiples that it has traded in or even with auto companies. Not just in India, but it is globally number one. The kind of growth rates Eicher was clocking month after month, quarter after quarter seemed difficult to sustain and we have been seeing the pain points in the last six months. Not only is sales in Royal Enfield, which was a growth driver, slowing down, now it is probably the third month when sales have actually dipped. 

In case of Eicher, that huge expansion of multiples contracting because of earnings growth is not there, at least in the foreseeable future. So Eicher probably may not bounce back as much. Eicher has not participated in the rally in the last two weeks where large number of or most midcaps have participated. 

In case of Maruti also, there is growth problem in terms of system inventory levels, likely production cuts and so on and so forth but Maruti was never trading at euphoric valuations in the first place. Maruti also has not participated in the rally and I do not see a very serious downside in Maruti either, maybe another 10% downside is all I would sense in a panic situation as far as Maruti is concerned. 

But as far as other auto stocks are concerned -- Mahindra & Mahindra or Bajaj Auto or Hero MotoCorp -- all are at quite attractive levels for value buying. 


 There is reassuring words coming in from Tata Motors Chairman and the management saying that they are looking at turning around JLR. With Feb sales showing that bit of an uptick, would you buy into the story at all?
I would buy into the story not so much for the statements that the senior management or the chairman or officials from Tata Sons make. But a clear indicator for confidence in the management of any company is are the insiders buying and Tata Sons in the last couple of weeks has bought close to 1.5 crore shares. So 1.5 crore shares is almost Rs 300 crore plus investment. Tata Sons is actually putting their money where their mouth is. I can believe that more than what statements they make. The sign of confidence is they are putting their own money in the stock at these beaten down levels.


They also bought when Tata Motors was trading at Rs 350 also.
True, I am only referring to a certain sign of confidence. See for Tata I do not think they need to really make that statement that they will turn around. They have no choice but to turn it around. Otherwise, in a way Tata Motors is too big to fail given the size of their balance sheet. More importantly, from a perspective of pride, Tata Group cannot allow Tata Motors to go down the drain. Nobody is going to forget this in a hurry, not to say the kind of repercussions it would have on the banking and financial system not just in India, are going to be quite serious. 

Any call on Tata Motors has to be not less than two to three or five years, unless one is willing to take that kind of a view. It will be very difficult for anybody to be making those kind of forecasts or projections as to how soon or in with what intensity will JLR turnar ound. I can only wish them all the best. There is value in the company at these prices sooner than later. The problem will get sorted out and perhaps a couple of years down the line, the stock price certainly will be higher than what it is right now.


Are the banks still sitting out of this bounce back?
As far as the private banks are concerned, the banks which really had no concerns per se -- HDFC Bank, Kotak bank, IndusInd Bank -- had not corrected meaningfully in the first place and things are fine for them.

Two or three banks which stand out -- ICICI Bank, Axis and Yes Bank -- supposedly had some problems over the last two-three years as regards their balance sheet issues, governance issues and with corrective action taken in the last six months or so. 

After almost a three or four year of underperformance, ICICI Bank and Axis Bank have come back roaring. So ICICI Bank probably in the last one year has returned almost 50% or at least 40% returns. Axis Bank has also shown similar kind of returns in the last one year/

A lot of the underperformance between 2015 and 2018 has been made up. Yes Bank has yet to make up but if things go fine with the new CEO coming in and cleaning up, Yes Bank should also bounce back. 

As far as PSU banks are concerned, there too the worst seems to be over as regards their bad loan problem but somehow the market is not fully convinced. That is what the price seems to suggest. SBI at Rs 276? In the last two years or last three years, SBI has been range-bound at 250-260 on the lower side and may be 300-310 on the higher side. It could have shot up by few rupees beyond that but certainly they have value from a I would say if the worst in case of the balance sheet issues and bad loans is behind us most PSU banks on a price to book multiple are quite attractive. 

From here on, we would see growth returning and which is where the capital expenditure and the corporate side lending activity has to come back in double digits otherwise from current levels, there is not much of downside. But from a medium to long-term, very attractive bets are SBI, Bank of Baroda or even some of the tier two or tier three banks like Union Bank.


 What are you making of Edelweiss because it seems like maybe value unlocking is the way to go forward. We will see these separate entities under Edelweiss get listed at some point in time but just going by the valuations of the ECL Finance deal at Rs 9500 crore, that is sizable. Would you still buy into Edelweiss at the current levels?
Oh certainly. I would buy into Edelweiss from not just from one-year perspective but even from a longer term perspective. You put any number up to next 10 years, I would be a buyer in Edelweiss at these levels simply on the macro theme of financialisation of the economy and financialisation of the savings.

Number two, as far as maturity of the financial markets as regards asset reconstruction, wealth management, private lending or individual lending spaces are concerned, NBFCs have done a reasonably good job where banks are not present. 

In all of that, Edelweiss is quite well placed that is number one. To answer your question about value unlocking, that is the way to go and that would actually apply not just to Edelweiss but to Kotak Bank as well. HDFC has shown the way. 

HDFC and ICICI have shown the way where ICICI has got two insurance companies already listed. HDFC has got the life insurance and the AMC business listed. Reliance Capital also has shown the way with listing of home finance business and the AMC business. Perhaps some other subsidiary is also likely to go public. It is a clearly template laid out and every bank or every NBFC is at some point of time going to do that in terms of value unlocking the subsidiary whether it is by listing or by having a strategic investor does not matter.


Now there are so many subsidiaries or so many companies, sum of part valuation. Which company you would value more?
The NBFC would have the highest value simply because of the size. Today, when we look at Edelweiss as a consolidated entity, simply the NBFC by virtue of its size in the total is going to have the highest value. Next will be the wealth management and brokerage business. 

Today in terms of sum of parts, it is the size of the business and contribution to the consolidated revenues but that not necessarily may hold true in future because some of the smaller businesses may catch up much faster.

India will either move up or emerging markets correct, whichever way, my guess is that India will move up, said 
Sridhar Sivaram, Investment Director, Enam Holdings, in an interview with ET Now. Edited excerpts: 


Given the fact that we are seeing the evidence of a slowdown in China, are we better placed when it comes to the macros?
To start with, we have significantly underperformed the emerging markets. If you see year to date, emerging markets have had a flying start. They are almost up 11-12%. China is up almost 15-16%. There has been a significant underperformance for India and maybe for the right reasons. We have had our own issues with NBFCs and HFCs, plus there has been uncertainty with elections coming up. But this underperformance will not last too long and our view is that we will see the underperformance bridge. India will either move up or emerging markets correct, whichever way, my guess is that India will move up. 


What gives you this conviction?
Because there is nothing globally to suggest that there is any major scar right now. The US-China tantrum trade war is going on and we keep getting news flows on that but barring that, we are seeing a benign liquidity situation. Even the Fed has given a benign outlook. Given all this and the fact that India has significantly underperformed, majority -- barring a group of five or six stocks -- were beaten down much more than required. 

Not necessarily earnings are catching up but the valuations of many of them have started looking attractive. We will see a catch up in the Indian market to at least closer to the emerging market…


We may have underperformed since the beginning of 2019 but we outperformed in 2018. So, some would argue that we are simply aligning with the reality. 
The outperformance was a mirage. Take any average FII emerging market fund or India dedicated fund…


You did not say that in 2018, did you? Did you use the word mirage?
No, I am just saying that it is just those 5-10 stocks that actually performed the broader market and even the portfolios of average fund managers. I am saying the FII fund managers underperformed by 500 to 700 bps in 2018. So, it was not as if the portfolios did well. We had 5-6 stocks which held the market up but we all know broadly that the market was in pain. It was not as if the market was giving a positive return, the portfolios were not showing that and I think that is what is getting corrected now.


Zee, Vedanta and a lot of promoter groups got exposed because of cross holdings, large debt at promoter holding or capital allocation. Does that worry a classic long-term investor like you? 
100% because when promoters are doing well in one business, they tend to extrapolate and think that they can do well in others too. He had a missed out feeling that infra is doing well or roads are doing well or something else is doing well. Telecom is doing well, I want to get in there and how do I get in if I do not have money? I pledge my shares or do whatever else to get the equity. But what we have seen now is that there is core competence for all promoters. They are good at doing something. I may not be good at doing everything and that results in minority shareholders interest being compromised. That is what we are seeing right and I am happy that this has come to fore.

In many cases we did not even know that they were pledged because the structure was so complicated that they did not have disclosed it as pledged because it is some structured finance and stuff like that. I think that has to be cleaned up and minority shareholder interest has to be kept at the top. I am happy that many of the promoters now have to sell their crown jewel to pay their debts. It is a good sign, it will clean up the market. 


Report after report this morning or start of the week till now and the chorus is only getting louder for a broader market recovery. Does it seem like the worst is behind us after a hiatus of almost a year and a half or underperformance? The worst may not be behind us and I can come to that later, but for the broader market, the valuations of many of these stocks have come down so much that I would want to believe that the broader market will rally. We have been meeting consumer companies not necessarily FMCG, trading at below one time sales; paper-related companies trading at two or three times earnings. Many of these were quite shocking and with adjusted dividend, yields were unbelievable. So, there was a disbelief in the market that these will rally. 

Also, there was the entire PMS issue which came up. 2017 was such a great year for any investor. People thought they were better than Warren Buffett because any stock that they bought, went up! So you think investing is so easy and then 2018 was the reality check. Many of these fund managers have not seen cycles. So I am not saying as if we have not made mistakes, everybody makes mistakes but it is just that understanding that there is cycle and that has resulted in this situation. PMS have caused more damage to midcaps and small caps. 


So you do believe that there is value within mid and small caps and that is beginning to be realised.
Yes correct.


What did you think went wrong? What did you assess which is proving out to be a wrong?
Last year, we were bearish for a long period of time, we started getting comfortable sometime middle of last year and then we had this IL&FS issue which was not in our calculations because prior to that, most companies were giving sort of bullish outlook that festive season may be very good this year and you are starting to get that sort of a feel. 

Once IL&FS happened everything sort of collapsed because many of these NBFCs and HFCs were also funding consumption in many ways and there was second derivative impact where projects stopped, real estate construction stopped and all of that had a significant impact on earnings on the sentiment. Some of that is now reducing. I would not say those issues are completely over but a lot of that is now looking priced in. But as I have said in the past also, I still do not believe that the problems for NBFCs, HFCs are over.


Are there going to be more skeletons coming out of the closet -- anything as big as IL&FS?
It is very difficult to say whether that will happen or not but HFCs have been very vocal on this that their books are not the best because on an average, in HFCs, about 40% is builder loan and a LAP combined. Mortgage is only about 60% and HFCs can restructure the loan and not disclose anything to the minority shareholders because that is how the NHB regulations are. So, it is not as if they are doing anything wrong! It is high time that we had an AQR for HFCs because you cannot remember any large builder NPA for any HFC.

Recently there was a presentation by one of the sort of a company which tracks real estate that NBFC funding to real estate has gone up in the last six years from 35% to 65% . Incrementally, real estate has been funded predominantly by NBFCs in the last four-five years and yet we have not seen any NPAs whereas banks are declaring NPAs. But that is not possible and so, I think there is lot that needs to be done. The process of NPA detection for of HFCs and the corporate facing NBFCs has not even started. That process has to happen.


Stories yet to unfold there.
Yes, that is my broad view.


My only fear with that assumption is that because that wheel is going to stop, that pipe is going to get caught, that will throw a cog in liquidity. If the housing sector does not do well, then there is a problem for cement, for steel and then there is a problem for the economy. I hope our assessment is not right.

Yes, what you are saying is right but my prediction is that many of these promoters will realise that their funding has stopped because their main source of funding is either the banking system or the mutual funds. Mutual funds have already stopped. Now it is only the banking system where they have to beg and cry and may be do some selling of their assets to get some money. This cannot last for too long and so they will sell out the business. 

In my view, if the NPAs are between 5% and 10%, then the bond market is safe because the equity holder has to take a haircut. The bond market is safe which is broadly fine and if that happens, equity guys are anyway taking the risk. You should understand that there is risk here! If you are taking risk, that is a reward but there is also pain. 

As long as the bond market and the banking system does not face the crisis, this crisis can be resolved and one of the steps that NHB has now suggested is higher capital adequacy, a step in the right direction. and increasing the capital adequacy is only that much leverage that you can take. So, I think these are steps in the right direction. They need to ensure that restructured assets are disclosed to minority shareholders and that is very important because only then can investors assess between the good, bad and the ugly. I am not saying all HFCs are in the same basket, but the point is many HFCs may be hiding behind the easy regulation that NHB has.


What about autos, more pain?
There could be pain but it is a cyclical sector and you make money when you buy at the bottom of the cycle. I have not seen especially two-wheelers trading at 12-13 times PE for a very long time. Our view is that consumer discretionary will improve as we enter into election season and beyond because once the NBFC issues get resolved a lot of them are also funding many of the two-wheelers and discretionary spending in general. 

Our view is this is a good sector to bet now because it is a cyclical stock, you do not buy it at the top of the cycle, you buy when things are really bad and given that India’s penetration, many of these can still improve. There is a scope to play on this. I would look at autos. Everything will not fall in place but two-wheelers look very interesting.


Is not the two-wheeler space very competitive? Bajaj Auto has set the cat amongst the pigeons by saying we do not care about margins, we care about market share. What happens when the dynamics change?
I agree. The company should have done this a long time back. They lost 10% market share in seven, eight years but they will reach a saturation point where they cannot get more because they do not have one entire segment -- which is scooters -- also moving up. Given where the valuations are, things will settle down, even they have to make money at the end of the day for their minority shareholders. 

There is a risk reward play here, if everything was perfect then you would not get these stocks at these valuations. You make a risk reward assessment of the sector and you feel that if I look at the 10-year, 15-year history, these are valuations where it troughs out. That makes the probability of making money high. It could go wrong if they completely go the other way round but that is the risk you take.


What about Maruti? Is the worst in the price?
Yes, I will not comment on individual stocks but if you ask me I am more comfortable with the two-wheelers than passenger vehicles.


When you say two-wheelers, what about others like Eicher? Is the Royal Enfield fad over? Would Eicher have a fair case to bounce back?
That was the issue with autos, especially two-wheelers. We were giving them consumer valuations and not discretionary valuations and once you realise that these are actually cyclical stocks and you cannot give them consumer valuations, you would be fine. 

As the valuations have corrected more to discretionary levels, your risk reward is better. When a consumer discretionary get priced at staples or consumer FMCG valuation that is when you know you have trouble. That is why I said the risk reward is looking better for this pack in general.


Classic investors have always taught me that any stock which gives you a dividend yield of 4.5-5%, becomes an attractive value buy. There are half a dozen stocks in the Nifty which give you this proposition.
Many more actually if you go down the curve.


NTPC, Vedanta, Coal India, Nalco, HPCL, BPCL, would you buy these stocks?
I will not individually comment on this.


PSUs in general, non banking PSUs?
PSUs in general, I would avoid but some of the banking PSUs are looking more interesting.


That is not because of dividend yield you like the business side?
Correct, I like the business side but if I want to play dividend yield. I will also want to see if I have business certainty. Many of the private sector companies where I am seeing dividend yield also have good business prospects. I am getting a combination of both. 

I am only playing for dividend yield and I do not know what the government will do. I would like PSUs for dividend yield but there are many private sector companies which are trading at attractive dividend yields. In fact, we have been suggesting to them that instead dividend they should go for buybacks because that way they structurally reduce the total dividend outflow for the company over a longer period of time. Plus, it is more tax efficient.


That is Rs 10 lakh plus. How many minority shareholders will be getting Rs 10 lakh or dividend?
No, no, it is better for the shareholder also. Forget the Rs 10 lakhs. Even as a normal shareholder you are better off because everything helps, once your shareholding comes down, you have to service that much lesser plus the dividend outflow for the company is reduced for perpetuity.

With prospects of a NDA victory at 2019 general elections brightening, the money waiting in the sidelines is now 
  
  
  getting into the market and we are seeing much better liquidity flows into small and midcap stocks, said Dipan Mehta, Founder Director, Elixir Equities, in an interview with ET Now.Edited excerpts:


The ride to 11000 has been great. Broader markets have also participated. Do you think it is only flattering to deceive us or is it going to be more sustainable this time?
The trading range is gradually moving up and that has more do with the fact that recent events which have taken place in the border state has perhaps improved the chances of NDA coming back to power. The money waiting in the sidelines is now getting into the market and we are seeing much better liquidity flows into the broader market -- the small and midcap stocks. 

Maybe this trend could continue for a few more weeks or so but the ultimate test will be when the May election results are out and perhaps even before that when the opinion polls gave a bit of an insight into who the next government is going to be. While we can play this trading rally, one has to be extremely cautious because an adverse election result would dampen the sentiment! There could be a great deal of volatility somewhere in the middle of May when the actual numbers are known. 


How are you playing the banking space as a whole? Also, do you think that Lakshmi Vilas Bank’s deal with Indiabulls would be a win-win for both the parties?
Yes, absolutely. The recent crisis in the NBFC space have made two things extremely clear; one is that you need to have a strong liability franchise. NBFCs with good retail support in terms of deposits or which are part of a bank or are a business group, were largely unaffected in raising resources for lending. That is one trend. 

Secondly, size does matter and bigger the company, the better is it able to manage all the volatility and uncertainties within the industry. For NBFCs, getting merged or getting access to a banking licence is very positive and we have seen many such instances. There has been the Equitas-Ujjivan deal, which after initial teething troubles, has seen numbers turning decent over the last couple of quarters. 

Their prospects going forward are significantly better. Any amalgamation or corporate action between NBFC and a bank will be definitely viewed positively by the street. 

Another example which comes to mind is IDFC First Bank which got merged with Capital First and that also has been doing pretty well these days because of better prospects and the fact that the retail franchise business of Capital First is getting good synergy from the wholesale and the banking platform of IDFC Bank. 

So there are many such examples which have turned out to be quite favourable for investors and any such action between Lakshmi Vilas and Indiabulls will be viewed positively by the street. 


How are you looking at the housing finance sector? Recently, we had NHB planning stronger capital norms for housing finance companies. How do you think all these changes will impact the overall ROE and leverage in coming times? Whatever steps the NHB is taking will be positive for the housing finance companies and the stronger housing finance companies should have no problem in meeting those norms. But it is a sector which is highly competitive and has a fair degree of maturity and until the real estate condition really improves, it is going to be a challenge to grow the volumes for HFCs. 

Nonetheless, there is adequate headroom for growth but growth is likely to be muted going forward, until the housing market picks up. The better way to play the NBFCs would be through consumer finance companies or through vehicle finance companies or pure retail lenders like say microfinance or gold finance.

Those NBFCs would have higher growth rates than housing finance companies and there are many exciting companies within the space like Bajaj Finance which is more consumer-oriented finance or L&T Finance for that matter which has got microfinance as well as equipment finance and other many such other divisions.

Within the gold finance business, there is Mannapuram and Muthoot which have shown good performance in the past two, three quarters and going forward also are quite confident of their growth rate.

Then come a whole host of microfinance companies like Equitus or Ujjivan or AU Small Finance Bank. There are many smaller NBFCs which are focussed on consumer lending other than housing finance and those would offer higher returns for investors than pure play housing finance companies. 


Does it make sense to stick to HDFC Ltd?
Yes. If you want to buy housing finance companies, then HDFC and LIC Housing also merits a mention. LIC Housing came out with a good set of numbers for the December quarter, which was better than what the street was expecting. 

But almost all the so-called retail finance companies, NBFCs have got housing divisions -- be it Bajaj Finance or L&T Finance for that matter and some of the other companies as well. Either they have got it as a division or as a subsidiary company. When you want to play the housing finance story, I still feel it is better to play it through the non HFCs. 

The non pure play HFCs and NBFCs have got several divisions and housing finance is one of them. If you want to buy a pure play HFC, the best two companies still remain HDFC and LIC Housing. They have got a fantastic track record. They have got a good liability franchise, they are able to raise loans at extremely attractive valuations and good brand value in terms of attracting customers for lending as well and excellent risk management systems as well. 


What is your perspective on Bharti and Idea? Are people now willing to bet in on oversold names like Bharti and Idea?
A trading bounce definitely is possible in Idea as well as Bharti. The fact that promoters are reposing so much of faith in the business and investing their own funds even at these levels despite extremely challenging scenario does show that the long-term prospects of the industry are great. But one needs to keep in mind that the way the promoters think and the way the investors think are different. The promoters have a much longer timeframe than the average investor bet it institutional or retail and my sense is that while the long-term prospects may be great for the industry, when there is actual consolidation and gradual increases in the yields for the industry as a whole, from a retail perspective, the next few quarters will remain extremely challenging. You may not get the kind of growth in earnings that the street is expecting.

I would say that if any positive news flow such as right issue announcements would lead to a trading rally, then investors who are stuck in the stock could look at exiting out of these companies depending upon what the news flow is. 

Broadly, I am not that confident of the short or medium-term prospects of the industry and over the longer term, there is too much disruption. There is 5G also which is coming and that will entail more capex for these companies. 

It is easier said than done to try and increase the yields as far as the services which they are offering are concerned. I am not that optimistic on the sector as a whole but still say a trading bounce is likely. Since they have been beaten down, short positions are there within that sector and short covering could lead to a rally but whether you should participate in the rally on the long side is questionable. It is an opportunity to exit out of the stocks rather than build fresh positions. 


What is the outlook when it comes to Tata Motors? It has been an acute underperformer of late. 
This is a great opportunity for investors to exit out of Tata Motors and this view could be wrong only if the company decides to sell off Jaguar Land Rover completely. That would change the dynamics for the company per se but until that event takes place -- and one is not sure that it will take place at all -- the rally in Tata Motors is a great exit opportunity. 

There are far better automobile companies to get into which also have been quite beaten down like say Maruti, Eicher or TVS Motor. Those companies will give a significantly higher return than Tata Motors. Tata Motors has just too much of volatility in their earnings because of JLR and even though the domestic business is a very small portion of the bottom line, there is a fair degree of volatility and they have achieved limited success whether it comes to commercial vehicles or passenger vehicles for that matter. 

Our view on Tata Motors is not positive. This is a perfect opportunity to cut the losses and move on into some of the stronger automobile names which could be auto ancillaries also. Those may give higher returns than Tata Motors over the medium to long term.


What do you like out of the auto ancillaries?
Within the auto ancillaries, Motherson Sumi is looking quite attractive. Here’s the disclosure that we and our clients are invested in it. The valuations are reasonable, the company has been reducing its debt levels and all the capex which has taken place over the past couple of years should start contributing to the top line and bottom line. 

Apart from that, the likes of Minda Corporation and Minda Industries also are quite interesting, given the kind of specific products that they are into and they are also amalgamating their subsidiary and joint venture companies and those should start contributing to the top line and bottom line. 

Apart from that, the tyre companies also are quite interesting at this point of time. We have seen a steep correction over there and raw material prices impacted their earnings over the past couple of quarters or so. As and when these pricing pressure, input cost pressures reduce, you will see good earnings coming back into the tyre companies as well. 

Broadly, these are the two, three companies and the space that we are looking at as far as the auto ancillaries are concerned. Within the OEM space, top picks still remain Maruti and Eicher and TVS Motors. Maruti’s numbers for February were quite interesting and if you exclude the low contribution product -- the compact cars, the UVs -- it had decent growth rates. 

We are seeing a gradual turnaround as far as Maruti’s monthly sales numbers are concerned. Do not get fooled by the overall number for the company but if you go deeper, the products which matter, have got higher margins. Growth has come back over there at least it is high single digit or low double digit.

NEW DELHI: Around 16 stocks rose to touch their 52-week highs on NSE in Friday's session.

Among the stocks that touched their 52-week highs were Agro Phos India, Allahabad Bank, The Anup Engineering, Arvind Fashions and Cantabil Retail India.

Gujarat Fluorochemicals, HeidelbergCement India, Mahamaya Steel Industries, Muthoot Finance and Seamec also featured among the stocks that touched their 52-week highs on NSE.

On the other hand, Jaihind Projects, Mask Investments, Raj Rayon Industries, Sathavahana Ispat and Visesh Infotecnics were the stocks that hit their fresh 52-week lows today.

Benchmark NSE Nifty index was trading 11.30 points down at 11,046.90 while the BSE Sensex was trading 8.53 points down at 36,716.89.

Overall, 20 shares were trading in the green in Nifty50 index, while 30 were trading in the red. 

In the Nifty 50 index, NTPC, Eicher Motors, Bajaj Auto, Titan Company and TCS were among the top gainers. 

While Wipro, Indian Oil Corp, Tata Motors, Hindalco Industries and Coal India Ltd were trading in the red.

NEW DELHI: Equity benchmarks Sensex and Nifty50 were trading lower in Friday's session.

NEW DELHI: Nifty futures on the Singapore Exchange were trading 15 points, or 0.4 per cent, lower at 11,043, indicating a negative start for the Nifty50. Here are a few stocks, which may buzz the most in today’s trade: 


Sadbhav Infa: Canada’s largest pension fund manager Canada Pension Plan Investment Board (CPPIB) is in advanced talks to acquire 12 operating road assets of Sadbhav Infrastructure Project Ltd (SIPL), in a deal worth $400-500 million (Rs 3,000 crore).


Alok Industries: The NCLT’s Ahmedabad bench has approved the Rs 5,050-crore resolution plan submitted jointly by RIL and JM Financial,with immediate effect.


IDBI Bank: The lender has put on the block its insurance and mutual fund businesses as it seeks to increase the capital base after Life Insurance Corporation acquired over 51% stake in the bank.


Delta Corp: A subsidiary Gaussian Software has entered into an agreement to subscribe to 1 crore equity shares of Jalesh Cruises (JCML) for a total consideration of $10 million. The company is expected to hold over 25 per cent stake in JCML. 


DLF: Realty major DLF plans to raise an estimated Rs 3,000 crore through the sale of equity shares to qualified institutional investors.


GMR Infrastructure: A subsidiary of GMR Infra has bagged contract to manage Nagpur airport from MIHAN India.


Reliance Industries: Global pension and sovereign wealth funds and long-only infrastructure-focussed financial investors have been sounded out as Reliance Jio Infocomm’s efforts to monetise its pan-India optic fibre assets to deleverage its balance sheet gather momentum.


Suven Life Sciences: The company said it will create a wholly-owned subsidiary in the US and will infuse USD 75 million (about Rs 525 crore) in its new business.


Varun Beverages: PepsiCo India's bottling partner Varun Beverages has set up a Rs 800 crore facility in Pathankot that is expected to generate 5,000 direct and indirect jobs.


IOL Chemicals: The drug maker said it will expand its existing unit at Barnala and also set up an ancillary facility at Raikot in Punjab with a cumulative investment of Rs 347 crore.


Dredging Corporation: The government said it has executed share purchase pact with four ports with regard to the strategic sale of its stake in Dredging Corporation of India (DCI), mobilising a total amount of Rs 1,049 crore by this strategic sale.


Indian Overseas Bank: State-owned Indian Overseas Bank said it has reduced the MCLR across all tenors, except overnight and one month, with effect from Sunday.


Magma Fincorp: The Mumbai-based asset finance company \expects to close the outgoing fiscal year with a 20 percent growth in disbursals as it comes out of the liquidity crunch that hit the shadow banking sector after IL&FS went belly up last September.


Apollo Tyres: The company expects returns to start accruing from 2021 for the investments it has put in over the last few years across its operations in India and Europe, a top company official said.


Syndicate Bank: The state-owned bank said it has reduced its marginal cost of funds-based lending rate (MCLR) by 0.10 per cent for various tenors.


Board meetings
 

Analyst calls
• IIFL has retained reduce rating on Eicher Motors with a target price of ₹18,400. The brokerage has cut FY20-21 EPS estimates by 5-6% due to continued weakness in volumes. The cumulative EPS cut in the past six months stands at around 20%, said IIFL.

 • CLSA has maintained outperform rating on Ambuja Cements with a target price of ₹250. Ambuja should benefit from the better pricing environment which should drive strong earnings growth, said CLSA. There is near-term concern on further market share losses, but this should reverse as new capacity comes on-stream in CY20, the brokerage said. 

• Kotak Institutional Equities has downgraded Maruti Suzuki India to add from buy and reduced fair value to ₹7,500 from Rs 7,600. The domestic passenger vehicle industry is likely to grow in low single digit due to increase in costs related to stricter safety and emission regulations, it said. 

 • Antique Stock Broking has maintained buy rating on Gujarat Gas with a target price of ₹180. Stars appear to align well for Gujarat Gas, as company stands to benefit from favourable NGT ruling and benign LNG prices environment, said Antique.

 • Emkay Global has a buy rating on ICICI Bank with a target price of ₹465. The brokerage believes that ICICI Bank is gradually transforming itself with its uncompromising focus on quality, profitability, accountability, governance and customer-centricity, which were not seen in the past.
