By Chandan Taparia
NEW DELHI: The Nifty50 index opened positive on Monday and headed towards its 26-week high of 11,180 zone. It has been making higher top and higher bottom formation and supports are gradually shifting higher with medium term support at 10,985.

The index formed a bullish candle on the daily scale and needs to hold above 11,118 to extend gains towards 11,200, and then 11,250-11,333 zone.

Overall setup and momentum is positive and a hold of recent zones could extend rally, while support exists at 11,118 and then 11,050 levels.

On the options front, maximum Put OI stood at at 11,000 followed by 10,800 strike, while maximum Call OI was at 11,500 followed by 11,400 strike. Meaningful Put writing was seen at 11,100 followed by 11,000 strike while Call writing was seen at 11,400 strike.

Option band signifies a shift in higher trading range between 10,985 and 11,300 levels.

India VIX fell 0.30 per cent to 14.89 level. The index has been falling from last seven trading sessions and lower volatility is providing the comfort to bulls zones to extend its momentum.

Bank Nifty has been making higher lows from the last seven sessions and is headed towards 28,000 level. It recently surpassed its multiple hurdle of 27,750 and is now looking for its life time high of 28,388 level. Now, the index has to continue to hold above 27,750 to extend momentum towards 28,388 while on the downside, support exists at 27,750 and then 27,500.

Nifty futures gained 1.22 per cent to 11,211 level. Built-up of long positions were seen in HPCL, NTPC, Bajaj Auto and Eicher Motors, while shorts were seen in Nalco, Hexaware and Kajaria Ceramics.


(Chandan Taparia is Technical & Derivative Analyst at MOFSL. Investors are advised to consult financial advisers before taking an investment calls based on these observations)

Aditya Agarwala of YES Securities has a buy call on Eicher Motors with a target price of Rs 25,450.

The current market price of Eicher Motors is Rs 22,415. 

Time period given by the analyst is two weeks when Eicher Motors price can reach the defined target. 

Aditya Agarwala recommended keeping a stop loss at Rs 20,700.

"On the weekly chart, Eicher Motors is on the verge of a breakout from a sideways consolidation pattern placed at Rs 21,900. Sustained trade above Rs 21,900 will trigger a bullish breakout which may extend to levels of Rs 23,800-25,450. It has also formed a bullish harmonic pattern, indicating that the downtrend is losing steam which can lead to the start of a fresh bull trend. Moreover, the correction in the stock took the shape of a 5-wave correction and has completed the 5th corrective wave, indicating that the downtrend can be arrested soon. RSI has also turned upwards after taking support at the lower end of the bull zone i.e. 40-level and has formed a positive reversal on the daily chart, suggesting bullishness in the stock," said Agarwala.

HDFC Mutual Fund’s chief investment officer Prashant Jain has become the first Indian fund manager to complete 25 years managing a single fund. He achieved this in 2019 with HDFC Balanced Advantage Fund which has generated an alpha of 9.54 per cent over the Sensex since 1994, Morningstar Direct data show.

HDFC Balanced Advantage Fund (the erstwhile HDFC Prudence Fund), launched in February 1994, is the largest equity-oriented fund in India with assets of Rs 37,395 crore as of February 2019. The fund, now categorised as dynamic asset allocation (equity can be 0 per cent to 100 per cent), in its earlier avatar as HDFC Prudence Fund (a balanced fund). Data from Morningstar Direct show that when compared to other global funds managed by a single fund manager for 25 years and above, Jain’s fund has generated an alpha of 9.54 per cent over the Sensex, second only to legendary Peter Lynch who managed Fidelity Magellan till 1977, generating an alpha of 10.92 per cent.


Anthony Bolton managed Fidelity Special Situations from December 17, 1979 to December 31, 2007 and generated an alpha of 9.2 per cent. HDFC Balanced has returned an annualised 18.48 per cent since inception.

Financial planners point out that one of the main reason for Jain’s success is his ability to identify market cycles ahead of time and ride through cycles. For example, he made the most of the IT-driven rally between 1995 and 2000 by buying Infosys that multiplied 113 times. Between December 2000 and December 2017, Jain was quick to spot the capex/banking and commodity stock rally identifying stocks like BHEL which rose 35x, L&T 33x, Reliance 19x and Tata Steel 16x and SBI 14x. In the next cycle between December 2007 and December 2017, where FMCG and pharma stocks rallied he bought HUL which rose 8x, ITC 5x, Lupin 8x and HDFC Bank 6x.

Currently, Jain is betting on corporate banks, utilities and capex with stocks like Infosys, ICICI Bank, SBI, L&T and NTPC being the top holdings in his portfolio. Jain has had his shares of misses as well. He missed multi-baggers like Kotak Bank, IndusInd Bank, Eicher Motors and Asian Paints. Then there are a number of stocks where he exited early. Though he was quick to spot Shree Cement and made 10 fold returns, he sold off early at Rs 700. Similarly, he sold out Page Industries early on at Rs 7,000.

“Jain has a sharp ability to spot cycles ahead of time. He adopts a long-term approach to stock picking, sticks to his investment mandate and is not worried about underperformance in the short term,” says Himanshu Srivastava, senior research analyst at Morningstar India.

While Jain’s strategy has worked in the long term, it has also tested investor patience in the short term. “The transition years, where he books profits and identifies stocks to ride the next cycle have been the most difficult for Jain, as returns lag those of peers in the short term. However, if you consider block of 3 or 5 years the returns are good,” says Deepak Chhabria, CEO, Axiom Financial Services.

PUNE: A fast growing middle class and burgeoning consumption will bolster growth in the commercial vehicles space in India going forward and the biggest beneficiary will be the light commercial vehicles (LCV) segment, industry stakeholders said.

“Going forward, increase in urbanisation and consumption will lead to shifts in market segments,” said Satyakam Arya, chief executive, Daimler India Commercial Vehicles, while speaking at the ETAuto CV and Logistics Conclave, on Friday. “We are seeing light commercial vehicles segment growing fast for lastmile connectivity.”

Globally, LCVs account for 75% of commercial vehicles sales, said Nitin Seth, president of LCV business at Ashok Leyland. “In India, it is only 62%. So, 62% to 75% is still a long way to go,” he said.

But there are three big challenges the industry needs to overcome to realise this sales potential, said Seth. These are lack of availability of finance due to liquidity crunch at nonbanking finance companies, the upcoming BS-VI emission norms and a lack of drivers.

“With the introduction of BSVI, the cost hike will be much higher than the prediction of 5%-7%. We are trying to cover a 10-year journey (of evolving regulations) in three years. The industry is in for a shock,” he said. Calling the rush to BSVI ‘haphazard’, Arya said by next year India will be the only country to have BS-VI emission norms compliant trucks based on cowl architecture, which is deemed to be less safe than a trailer truck.

In the future, keys to growth will be reducing time taken to bring new models to the market, making vehicle platforms more flexible and dynamic, and staying abreast of the changing needs of the customer, said Rajinder Singh Sachdeva, chief of operations and head of R&D at Volvo Eicher Commercial Vehicles.

On the technology front, Sachdeva said that electric and autonomous vehicles are an inevitable future.

Speaking about vehicle propulsion technologies of the future, Daimler India Commercial Vehicles’ Arya said the industry will have to be ready with multiple technologies. “LCV will go more towards full electrification,” he said.

As cab aggregating services like Ola and Uber have brought a disruption in the passenger vehicles space, we are seeing the beginning of “uberisation” of the CV industry, said Rajeev Singh, partner at consultancy firm Deloitte India. He said another promising technology is predictive analysis that can help manufacturers reliably calculate the life expectancy of different components for different regions, seasons and climates.

Over next three to six months, deploy money in a systemic manner, because risk-reward of investing in Indian 
  
  
  markets are very well in place, said Vikas Khemani, Founder, Carnelian Capital Advisors, in an interview with ET Now. Edited excerpts:



What a comeback by bulls! They have surprised everyone.
If you remember our conversation, one of the things which I had highlighted was that the market will always come back sharply when nobody expects and in that kind of market, the idea is to keep on deploying over a period time because risk reward was very well placed. But obviously nobody can time the catalyst to the turnaround and that is what has happened! 

Two or three things have changed over last couple of weeks. One, the global scenario has changed especially around the Fed turning dovish around the liquidity scenario and is very important from a global sentiment perspective

Second, general election is one of the biggest events ahead of us which most people were worried about. All kinds of speculations were being made. All of us in the market expect continuity of the government or at least there is a greater chance of it.

Third, with the global clue that the interest rate environment has started falling in place, the new RBI Governor has done a great job in calming down the whole system in the aftermath of the IL&FS fiasco. For a long period of time, it was getting worse and worse. In my opinion, the new leadership has done a great job in settling down and these two-three things in my opinion coupled with the flows towards the emerging market, have helped our revival. This kind of environment is always sharp because there are lots of shorts which are waiting to be cut. There is always a little bit of buying, backed by short covering. So this is not the first time that we have seen this. The market environment sentiment has definitely changed and this is a good situation to be.


Would you be in a long only mood in the runup to the election, or has the party just about started or is it time to take 10% chips off the table? 
I do not know how to play in short term in the run-up to elections because I think it is a very binary kind of event. My personal view is that the present government will be coming back to power, but anyway you can never take a call. You can only manage your portfolio at your own risk. I have been long believer that you should deploy money over next three to six months in a systemic manner, because risk-reward of investing in Indian markets are very well in place. 

I do believe the Indian economy is very well on right track. A lot of structural reforms have been done and we will start seeing fruits of that coming through soon. Secondly, if you believe that the India story is good, you remain an optimist and pick up good businesses and stay invested even if it disappoints you short term and you have take a hit or for some macro reasons, markets come back. 

I will continue to believe that India is a great story. We have a much better future ahead of us and we have just begun. Next five to seven years are very good. We had a very bad sort of setback in the recent past that has reset a lot on the basis that it has cleared the froth. The market is much better placed than what it was before. Of course, people have taken a knock on their portfolios and their wealth but there is no point in living in the past. You have to rebase, restart and as I look forward, next four-five years look very interesting.


We are seeing a lot of leadership coming in from banks. What is your stance on the overall growth outlook for banks?
BFSI as a segment accounts for a large part of the market cap. Secondly, it is very very critical for economic growth and I believe it will continue to deliver. You cannot aspire for 7%-9% growth and make money from Indian capital markets and not include banks. That is not possible. It will be a leading sector. 

Also for revival of the credit cycle, banks’ confidence is very important so I think I am glad that markets are reposing faith and banks would lead the rally. There is no doubt on that. Of course it is not only banks, it’s the entire financial segment and in last two-three years, we have seen the market diversifying with BFSI space to many more players and you will continue to see that happening over next five-seven years.

I have no doubt in my mind that being almost 30-35% of the market cap, the banking sector BFSI’s entire basket will do well and even if you take 7-8% growth adjusted for the inflation and shift of market share from PSU to public this sector can grow at 18%-20% growth in a reasonable long period of time. So I think that gives me confidence that this will probably one of the big sector which given what reforms have been done in the past in form of IBC, RERA, GST I think this sector benefits the most from all the reforms which has been done and hence my confidence in the segment would continue to remain very high.


IT has had a solid move it lasted as over a year now but do you think because of the currency move, that trade could get challenged and it is best to take your profits off the table then?
I would say that the risk-reward in moving out has started falling into place. Other sectors like banks, industrials and consumer, would probably outperform over next couple of years for the simple reason that global growth is slowing down. While current outlook and order book of IT companies look good, the market typically tends to look forward. If you start looking forward, the market might start hypothesising a little bit of slowdown on the demand outlook as the global growth slows down. 

That could vary and secondly rupee is also going to create a little bit of impact on the margin. What was working as a tailwind over last two-three years probably could turn little bit of a mild headwind. I would not say that sector is going to do decently well but given the valuations, given the little bit of mild headwinds, you would be better placed in some of the domestic-oriented stories. IT will be more of a defensive portfolio but risk-rewards are definitely shifting in favour of domestic plays.


Would you buy autos in this downturn?
Auto is coming from a significantly high growth background and a very high base. What we are seeing in Maruti and some of the cases is a result of that. The IL&FS crisis added a little bit more to it because of the credit squeeze to this segment.

Auto is a sector which gets impacted more from the availability and cost of capital. Along with the high base, both has impacted the segment and that is the reason you are seeing the reactions you have seen. 

Maruti and Eicher grew very rapidly. That has got corrected. Auto will remain a sector which will do well but when to pick is the question. I would say wait for a few more quarters because the stocks are still not cheap. They are reasonably valued, they are good companies but market’s faith will not come back immediately from revival perspective till the time you see the volume growth coming back.

Probably you will have to wait over the next three, four quarters and pick the right time for the revival to be around the corner. But in CV space, players like Ashok Leyland can do very well. As credit supply eases out and interest rates come down, that segment will get impacted first from positivity perspective then cars.


IOC has gained over 5%, the most since 22nd February. What is fuelling this fire for OMCs?
Honestly, I have not been tracking much of that but the only intelligent guess is maybe this is because of dividend yields which are around the corner. Most of them are high dividend yield story but honestly I have not really tracked in terms of what is driving or fuelling this particular sub segment.


What did you purchase in this downturn that happened in Jan and March? A lot of midcap stocks were down 10-15-20%, what did you buy in that leg of decline?
There are lots of interesting stories in the midcap space. One of the sectors that I have always believed in is building materials. It came down very sharply and you could buy a lot of stocks there which were earlier sought after and corrected almost 40-50% in the last seven, eight months. 

Chemicals as a sector did not correct much but the stocks were available at reasonably good price which have already pushed up. Within the NBFC space, some of the NBFCs which were well capitalised, diversified owned by corporate houses because those business models are very robust and sustainable, remain very interesting plays to look at. 

There is a very wide variety of stocks, sectors you could look at in my opinion in the midcap space. We are looking at some of these three, four sub very aggressively.

The next 200 points could see some volatility or range -bound behaviour, but overall the trend is pretty clearly 
  
  
  on the upside, said Rishi Kohli, CEO, ProAlpha Advisors, in an interview with ETNOW.Edited excerpts: 

We have seen a fantastic runup and the word is that despite the profit-booking or tapering that we have seen in today’s trade, the momentum is building right now. Would you agree?
Yes I do agree. I have been pretty positive on markets while there was a lot of volatility going on and the view was very clear that 11,250 is very much on the cards in the near term and that zone has been broken through with a lot of momentum.

Given that the last 500 points upmove on the Nifty has been pretty much non-stop, obviously there could be a halt for a week or two, especially on the Nifty. If you look at Nifty futures, then 11,550 to 11,650 is a short-term resistance zone and then you have the 793 kind of levels which are the previous highs. 

The next 200 points could see some volatility or range -bound behaviour, but overall the trend is pretty clearly on the upside and while the lower levels were defended in the earlier decline in September-October and the range bound movement after that, it seems very clear that 12,000 is on the cards in a couple of months. That is the overall view for the next few months. Short-term volatility should be taken advantage of that view.


 I am curious about the view on the IT space because you seem to have increased allocation on Tech Mahindra. Since the rupee is moving from strength to strength, is that a worry when it comes to the overall margin?
Overall yes, but the rupee has been depreciating continuously for so long and obviously we had the sharp spike from 72 to almost 75, 74.5 or whatever and from there it has appreciated right now to about 68.5. But I think going below 67.5-68, will be very difficult for the rupee. At best it will remain in a sort of range between 68 and 70-71 zone and from there, over the next few years, there would be a depreciation because that is related more to macro.

I do not think there is any case for a very sharp appreciation which is long-term in nature. There can be short-term movements here and there. From that perspective, I am not worried and coming to Tech Mahindra specifically, there is technically a very strong long-term cup and handle formation which looks to be on the verge of a break-out, which with the break to new highs will get confirmed. That has happened in the last one month and the minor decline seen after the strong breakout has taken support at previous highs. 

It is very copy-book pattern and giving a target of 1100 which even from a fundamental perspective PEs and all, looks like a reasonable target. Otherwise, business has been doing well.

Earlier bottoming out of the telecom sector and other things that we have spoken of in the past seems to be happening in line with expectations. Given that the fundamental picture is in line with expectations, rupee in the long run will not be a worry for this stock. The technical strong picture seems to have a target of 1100 and that could happen in like six to nine months. A 30-35% upside is clearly warranted in the portfolio.


What is your take on auto? On one hand we have had so much to talk about the consumption story but in the immediate term, it still looks like that pressure is really mounting on some of the auto majors?
Yes, and that has been the case over last year. Almost the entire auto segment has been weak and whether it is two-wheelers or four-wheelers, everything has been underperforming. I have had Eicher in the portfolio and we have discussed multiple times on this show if that looks interesting or not and why.

The last time around, it was hovering around Rs 20,000 levels and I was clear that let it be short term for now because obviously it looks like some things can get extended but a bounce from Rs 20,000 to Rs 24,000 looked to be on the cards. I had held on to it for that. 

It did bounce up to around 23,000 levels and then consolidated between 22,000 and 23,000. I do feel that 24000 will come and then either some trimming or some rebalancing can happen. So that is regarding the portfolio, but otherwise I think stocks like Maruti, Tata Motors, Mahindra still need some time to recover. 

But having said that, the downsides from here on seem limited so in a staggered way, one could enter it from a medium to long-term perspective. One interesting stock in that segment is Bajaj Auto. It was doing nothing for a long time and recently at least on the technical long term charts, it started turning around and broken out of long-term resistance trendlines. That is one I would focus on.


The plans to buy this large stake in MindTree to a certain extent has led to a fall in the value of the software services arm of L&T. CCD is also in focus. The latest news says the co-founder has said this is going to be a hostile bid which he wants to prevent. What is your outlook on the news flow so far?
The news is pretty much out there. The synergies was discussed apparently but I would still go with Mindtree because the stock per se is fundamentally good. In such kind of a hostile takeover situation, the minority shareholders will gain because if it gets messy, then both sides will bid higher to protect their stake. This is a very simplistic analysis but I have seen in many cases in the past even globally how that works. Given the underlying positivity on the fundamental side, there is no downside on that approach. I would go with that view and hold the stock.


Let us talk about OMCs. Would you add them to your basket?
Yes, I would. Last month’s move was very strong after the decline. On any dips from here on, I would get into it. The medium term signals have gone into positive from negative. From a six-nine month view, I would be long that but I would wait for a slightly lower levels to get into some of them.

Waiting for a relief rally in a bear market to sell the stocks you own and waiting for a correction to buy the stocks 
  
  
  you want to buy in a very strong bull market does not pay off, said Amit Jeswani, CIO, Stallion Asset, in an interview with ETNOW.Edited excerpts: 


Sanjay Dutt from Quantum Securities believes that Reliance Home Finance and Reliance Capital among ADA Group companies still have fundamental value. Would you go with any of the ADAG names?
You play Reliance Capital, Reliance Home when the bull market is at the end phase. We are at the start of a major rally and you want to be in quality stocks that will grow at 25-30%. You need certainty of returns now. Typically, play these low-quality stocks when you are at the last phase of the bull market. Now is the time to be with leaders, strong growth companies, good ROCE and so we are positioned that way.


Where do you see that leadership within the banking space?
Banking and consumer are the two sectors. ICICI Bank had 10% NPA till last year, even then this stock is hitting life-time high. Financials and consumers are one space which keeps getting better with size. There are times when you want to be long on gold finance companies, We are very bullish on microfinance as a space right now. We have been adding stocks out there like small SFBs. A lot of stocks in financials look good. Axis Bank is there. 

Private financial space gives you beta and consumer stocks would not lose money if the market goes down. So if anyone has a portfolio of private financials and consumers, the financials will do very well in a bull market. In a bear market, the consumer stocks will save you. A typical portfolio of these two sectors would do extremely well throughout market cycles. 

The horses keep changing in financials. In the 2013-2017 bull market, it was the housing companies (HFCs). This time, it is going to be private financials again. At some point of time, PSUs will also join the rally. We do not have any positions in government stocks. We do not buy government stocks but it looks like that stage is getting built up because NBFCs are not able to grow and NBFCs are 25% of the market. 

Some delta trade can happen in PSU banks but you have to have Kotaks, HDFCs in your portfolio. There is a large opportunity size and these guys are getting better with size. Only a few business models get better with size. Most companies, including construction companies, airline companies, steel companies get worse with size but a financial services company like HDFC or Kotak or those kind of stocks get better with size, as does Bajaj Finance. We always have those kind of stocks in our core portfolio. 


We are seeing a big roar in Union Bank, PNB, Bank of India. You have already said the rally is going to spread to PSBs. Are they worth investing in?
Humans imagine and markets discount. Today everyone wants to buy on dip, but the dip is not coming. Waiting for a relief rally in a bear market to sell the stocks you own and waiting for a correction to buy the stocks you want to buy in a very strong bull market does not pay off really well. 

Markets have now started discounting and till the end of May, they will keep going higher. The stocks will keep churning. Now the rupee has given a breakdown below the 69 level. So, the rally will slowly move towards smallcaps and midcaps which can go up 10% next month. That is how strong this wave will be. It is going to go from extreme oversold to extreme overbought. As long as the rupee stays below 69.20, that is the whole idea here. 

All the small banks, PSUs, kachra stocks can do well for the next month or two. It might be a buy on rumour and sell on news kind of a market. 

So, by May, you have to go back to your top 20-30 stocks you can do all the kind of trading you want to in this kind of bull market, but after May, markets are going to chase quality, growth and the same things; high ROE, leadership.

These two months you can trade PSU banks, Bank of India, PNB whatever but after that you have to get back to your HDFCs and your Kotaks and the quality names where you can make and retain money. 

A lot of smallcap investors made money 2017 but they had to give it back. Money does not get retained in smallcaps. You have to trade them in and out. After May we will get back to your Dow Jones, your MSCI emerging markets and all those things. Till that time, it is a very strong rally and let us just enjoy this rally. 


You have been fairly bullish on sectors like steel, real estate in the past. We are starting to see a resurgence in some of these extremely beaten down pockets of the market. Are you still bullish on these trends?
Absolutely. Real estate is an extreme long-term trade for us. Right now, Godrej is like Rs 1,000-1,500 crore a month sales and this is a downcycle. You need to buy the leaders here, I am not bullish on real estate overall, 90% of builders will go bankrupt but the 10% builders become really large. I am just giving you an example, we might have vested interest. 

Godrej Properties is doing Rs 1,000-1,500 crore of sales in a down market. When the up market comes, these companies can actually scale up to a lot larger companies and it is a negative working capital cycle business and brand is the thing that is working now. So a Mohan Builder or Shyam Builder, Ram Builder those builders cannot pre-sell, it is going to be the Godrej kind of companies that will pre sell. Godrej knows how to create market cap. They created Rs 70,000-80,000 crore market cap out of killing mosquitoes on Godrej Consumer. 

They are into hair care and all other things as well, but Godrej knows how to scale up a business. Those are the companies you want to bet for long term and this will do extremely well for the next three, four, five, 10 years. It is a very long-term trade in real estate, but we are very bullish on it. 


There has been a lot of debate on whether or not certain names in the market are underperforming versus whether or not earnings growth can genuinely catch up in the runup to elections. Which side of the fence would you sit on?
I am very bullish till elections and after that, the same old 20-25 stocks will do well. The high growth, high return on equity leaders are the stocks you buy. Other stocks do not make you money. 


Do you have any contra bet or a space that you like for the long haul? It could be agri, fertiliser, tea companies or something like that?
We have nothing like that in our portfolio. We are looking at auto again. The markets are pricing auto according to growth rate. Let us take Hero Honda. Hero Honda will grow at 5% and markets have priced Hero Honda at let us say 15 PE multiple. Markets were expecting Maruti to grow at 15% and were pricing it at 33 PE multiple. 

Of course, in the last few months, growth has been extremely poor. In fact, they are de-growing at 8-10%. At some point of time, these stocks will have to come to like 20 PE or something like. At 20 PE, the expected sustainable growth rate for the market for Maruti or an Eicher Motor would be somewhere around 8-9%. Basically, those are the kind of bets we can look at if I want to be a contrarian. But we are actually not contrarian. We buy companies that are growing fast and showing good price action. For now, we are buying financials and consumer and some real estate. We already have some infrastructure but we do not recommend that. But those are the four broad sectors that we are invested in.

After election, you want to be more into quality and not into the midcaps because we will start following the MSCI EM again. Look at the price action in Reliance. There is 30-40% growth in Reliance. The stock is hitting new highs. The management knows how to scale up a business. They are growing retail business at 100%. Jio is growing extremely fast and it is a next gen business. 

These companies can be leaders of the bull market and they might do 30-35% kind of compounding. Let us see how we play but for now, I am going to come back to your show and tell you if I am going to select a sector. But for now, it is just consumers and financials. 


Where exactly are you seeing the market headed in terms of the election? Do you have any particular targets in mind?
Till the time, rupee is below 69, you might see a surprise 66 kind of move towards the dollar. Basically, the dollar will hedge towards 66. It is going to be very fast. It is basically a repeat of what happened in 2014. What are the sectors to buy? It is going to be the same stocks. You look at stocks which are going to grow at 30% plus. There are only 30-40 names and good quality management which will grow at 20-30%.

The FIIs love financials and I do not know why but 75% of FII investments are there in financials and the FIIs are the biggest buyers. Financials might do well in the run-up to the elections. After that, we might see what to do but for now it is the same old things.

Samsung, Tata Motors, Apple, Hero MotoCorp and Nike are the top-five consumer-focused brands in the country, according to a study by TRA.

The study, titled 'India's Most Consumer-Focused Brands 2019', measures brands on their increase in buying propensity index over the previous year.

"Samsung showed an upward movement of eight ranks to secure the top position on the list of this year. The South Korean conglomerate dominates the Indian market by displaying its determined supremacy through complete consumer focus, thus dominating their mind and perception," TRA said in a statement.

Life Insurance Corporation, LG, HDFC Bank, Bajaj Pulsar and Vivo took the sixth, seventh, eight, ninth and tenth place, respectively.

Category-wise, Tata Motors secured first position in four-wheeler manufacturer category, while Eicher topped in the commercial vehicle category.

Budweiser won the title of India's most consumer-focused alcoholic beverage brand. Chennai-based Otto was ranked number one in the apparel-menswear category.

India's most consumer-focused brands is an exclusive list of only those brands that have managed to improve their buying propensity over two successive years.

From among 11,000 brands studied, only 500 brands were able to improve their buying propensity over the previous year.

NEW DELHI: Nifty futures on the Singapore Exchange were trading 63 points, or 0.55 per cent, lower at 11,407, indicating a gap-down start for the Nifty50. Here are a few stocks, which may buzz the most in today’s trade:


Mindtree: Independent directors at Mindtree have voiced their concerns about the board not having a “collective and informed stand” on what is seen as a hostile takeover attempt by L&T. The IT company’s board will discuss seeking a meeting with the engineering conglomerate.


Tech Mahindra: The Rs 1,956-crore share buyback by Tech Mahindra will open for subscription on Monday. The IT major intends to buy back up to 2.06 crore shares at Rs 950 a share. The offer will close on April 5.


Dr Reddy’s Laboratories: The drug maker said the USFDA has completed inspection at research and development facility of Aurigene Discovery Technologies and issued no form 483. 


Jet Airways: As lenders moved in to take charge of cash-strapped Jet Airways, lead banker SBI may ask a retired senior banker to head the airline and guide it out of the financial mess.


Tata Motors: Automobile major 
Tata
Motors will increase prices of its passenger vehicles range by up to Rs 25,000 starting April 2019.


Finolex Cables: Finolex group’s Chahbria family feud has worsened with Prakash Chhabria, son of late Prahlad Chhabria, founder of the Pune-based Rs 15,000 crore Finolex group, moving the Bombay High Court, questioning the continuance of Deepak Chhabria as executive chairman of Finolex Cables.


Reliance Infra: The promoter group entity of Reliance Infrastructure has pledged 1.56 per cent of the company's shares, according to a regulatory filing. Reliance Project Ventures and Management had on March 6 pledged 41 lakh shares.


RCom: Reliance Communications has pledged 4.52 per cent of its holding in Reliance Communications (RCom) amounting to 12.50 crore shares with IndusInd Bank Ltd, according to a regulatory filing.


Jyoti Structures: The National Company Law Appellate Tribunal (NCLAT) has set aside the order to liquidate Jyoti Structures and asked the Mumbai bench of NCLT to consider the Rs 4,000-crore resolution plan submitted by Sharad Sanghi and others.


Reliance Industries: The operator of the world's largest oil refining complex, on Friday said in a statement it was not breaching US sanctions against Venezuela.


Karnataka Bank: The bank said it has reported to regulator RBI about a fraud amounting to Rs 13.26 crore in the fund-based working capital facility extended to SRS Finance.


Power Grid: State-owned Power Grid Corporation said Friday that it has paid Rs 1,629.62 crore as interim dividend for 2018-19 to the central government.


Alkem Laboratories: Drug firm Alkem Laboratories said it has received a letter from the US health regulator asking not to manufacture a particular product at its St Louis facility till a final decision is taken.


Board meetings





ADRS/GDRs
ADRs of Tata Motors plunged 5.26 per cent on Friday. They were followed by Dr Reddy's Labs, Vedanta, ICICI Bank, Wipro and Infosys, which fell up to 3 per cent. 


Analyst calls

• Emkay Global has a sell rating on Eicher Motors with a target price of Rs 18,000. Royal Enfield volumes suffered a 10 per cent year-on-year decline over November 2018 and February 2019 despite the absence of negative one-off factors such as production losses due to labor strikes, said Emkay. 

• Citigroup has a neutral rating on Info Edge (India) with a target price of Rs 1,715. Info Edge reported muted EBITDA growth in the third quarter owing to elevated ad spends across recruitment, property and matrimonial businesses, said Citi. 

 • Kotak Securities has downgraded KNR Constructions to add from buy and revised target price to Rs 282 from Rs 239. The company has bagged around Rs 10 billion worth of new projects in the last one month and is on track to meet its guidance of adding Rs 20 billion of new orders in 3-6 months timeline, said Kotak Securities. 

• HSBC has initiated coverage on Aster DM Healthcare with buy rating and target price of Rs 205. Aster is among the largest healthcare providers in the Gulf Cooperation Council and India through its hospitals, clinics and pharmacies, said HSBC. The firm has estimated Aster’s GCC EBITDA to double in five years despite the current macro weakness in the region. 

• CLSA has a buy rating on Sadbhav Engineering with a target price of Rs 340. While the stock is up 45 per cent in the last one month led by risk on rally, CLSA sees more legs to the stock. One of the key catalysts is potential divestiture of 9/11 of 12 operating NHs in favour of a global strategic investor, said CLSA.

In an interview with ETNOW, Nitin Raheja, Co-Founder, AQF Advisors says there is value in financials., city gas
  
  
  distribution companies, chemicals and auto companies.Edited excerpts:


Would you be willing to put your penny on Jet Airways just yet?
No, absolutely not. Overall external environment is so uncertain, you are entering the election phase and you are seeing the US growth rates slowing. At such point of time, we would rather stick to stories where business models are well defined. There is visibility on earnings. We would just not want to play stocks which are more like a punt in terms of it could go either way.


When we are looking at the markets right now and looking at the upmove building again. Where would you find value? What are the segments that you are looking at?
We like the financial space because post the scare that we saw in the September-October last year, things have started to stabilise. Liquidity post the swap programmes that the RBI inculcated was just one of the measures that the government and the RBI are taking to bring liquidity back into the markets. Financials continue to look good and we are seeing that the demand for credit has outstripped deposit growth. 

That tells you there is healthy demand on the ground. That is one space that we are fairly confident about. We like the city gas distribution space. Those businesses have huge visibility as far as earnings grow. We like the chemical space. Chemical companies, after seeing a sharp runup, saw a fair bit of correction, came back and now they are starting to pick themselves up again. 

These companies have a good deal of visibility. We see a lot of value in the auto sector. It is a contrarian bet. Right now, the last two months’ figures have not been great. There has been inventory build up. But if you are talking of the economy starting to rebound, post elections, a lot of auto companies are trading at extremely attractive valuations. From a longer term perspective, that is another area where we would look at.


Where within autos do you find value? Is it going to be the beaten-down ones like an Eicher or a Maruti or something like Bajaj Auto where you have protection because 30% of revenue is coming in from exports?
We like the two-wheeler space and within that, it is again stock specific. Bajaj probably stands out there. We like the passenger vehicle cum UV space. We think valuations of something like Mahindra & Mahindra are very attractive, trading close to historic lows. 

They have had a good rollout in terms of new models which have seen a good amount of demand. Again it is function of where these companies are getting valuation because ultimately in the market, value of a stock acts also as one of your biggest safety nets. You might not have immediate quarter visibility on growth but clearly if you are buying them close to historic valuations and the economy upcycle with interest rates getting cut, start showing strength in the next three-six months, these are the stocks where you are going to make money.


In the larger energy basket, we have got a variety of different trades going on. Would you be looking at any play basis on what we are seeing on crude or the currency or any of these factors that would affect what you are looking at in the market?
I have no view in terms of where crude is going to go. It is all over the place. It is an egg on the face for analysts on both sides, just the sharp moves that we have seen in last six months as far as crude is concerned or even the currency is concerned. 

As I mentioned, in such an uncertain environment and also in an industry which is so heavily regulated, we do not really like the OMCs as such. If you were to play the energy space, city gas distribution companies is where we are more comfortable. It is more of a quasi B2C play. It is a play where the environmental norms are pushing you towards cleaner fuels and there is a government push in terms of just the sheer number of areas that are being thrown open there.


Looking at areas that have been beaten down in the market, would metal stocks be a pocket? Any select names there?
Steel seems to be panning out well. If I go by the reports that we keep hearing and some anecdotal evidence when talking to managements, it seems if you take the next couple of years, you are going to see a demand-supply tightening in that space. Again, we would like the companies which have access to iron ore because that is the space where we are seeing a tightening of supply. So, integrated companies as far as steel is concerned. 

For the rest of the metal pack, we are looking for companies with high visibility. A lot of these metal pack companies are difficult to play because of the way prices have yo-yoed through the year. We are not traders, but are investors with a longer-term tenure and I believe these companies do not give us that amount of visibility.


What is the sense that you are getting on the currency math and how do you see margins for some of the IT companies shape up? Do you have any favourites?
The short-term price movement of IT companies is high correlated to the way the rupee behaves. The strength that we have seen in the rupee in the short term is of course, affecting the prices. But from a business point, almost all the IT companies are finding good visibility as far as their business is concerned.

The whole move is towards digital and every single company that you talk about talks to you about what percentage of their revenue and order book is coming from digital. 

Clearly, there is an opportunity out there from a longer-term perspective. These are quality businesses. They throw out cash and they have been among the businesses at the forefront of buybacks in recent years. Whether you take an Infosys, a Wipro, a TCS or a Tech Mahindra, all these businesses have been throwing out cash and continue to have robust economics. 

As far as the rupee is concerned, as long as you are going to have a trade deficit, you are going to have an inflation difference and long-term depreciation of the rupee will continue in the range of 3-5%. 
Short-term, I do not know where the rupee will go given the way things have been in the last six months but longer term, the trend of the rupee is clearly towards depreciating and annualised at that rate although in lumps, the business has visibility. IT is a good place to be. Companies which are on the telecom side such as Tech Mahindra will benefit completely from the 5G rollout and that should add to visibility.


What are your thoughts on the media space? Do you sense a scenario similar to telecom space could play out for media and OTT players as well?
There is a huge disruption that is happening as far as the cable guys or even the satellite guys are concerned with the advent of OTT and broadband coming in. It is great from the consumer perspective, not so great from an investor perspective. 

Whenever the scenario is murky, it is very difficult for you to make money. Where regulations are changing, it is like shifting sands. If you were to be in the media space this year, print media is where you should be. All the print media companies so far have not seen the huge move away from print media to electronic media in terms of internet. Their businesses are generating cash at the present moment, also this year being an election year, should be good for these companies in terms of ad spend that will come their way. The next couple of quarters should be good for print media companies.

If you are a long-term patient investor, autos, consumer oriented stocks, even FMCG, appliances are great contra 
  
  
  bets at this point of time, said Dipan Mehta, Founder Director, Elixir Equities, in an interview with ETNOW.Edited excerpts:

The Bank Nifty managed to close above 30,000 for the first time ever and from the January lows, has recovered nearly 15%. Is this kind of momentum here to stay? How are you looking at the overall credit growth backdrop? Also, what do you think is driving so much optimism in banks?
Banks have always been the leaders in this bull market so far and now that they have resumed their upswing, we can expect the broader indices also to move up. The underlying forces behind banks is that going forward, the entire industry will face lower credit cost. Some of the PSU and corporate banks may have writebacks of interest or write-backs of provisions as many of the NPA cases get resolved, that is the first reason. 

Second, they are sensitive to interest rates and as interest rates start to move lower liquidity improves, their volumes also tend to go up and that also should drive earnings going forward. 

Lastly, it is one sector where we are seeing a structural and secular growth momentum for the past several years and given the headroom for growth, given how under-banked India is and the demand for credit especially at retail and low- ticket loans, there is considerable growth opportunity for most of the banks, especially the ones which are well capitalised have managed their NPAs better, have good lending practices and have a nice distribution and brand. 

There are many positive factors going for banks and NBFCs and this trend should continue and they would remain leaders over the next few years as far as any bull market is concerned. 


You are not really a fan of aviation. Would you look at Jet right now amidst all this turmoil?
There is an opportunity for Jet shareholders. If the banks are able to get a strong strategic investor in the company, then there is a potential to turn around Jet Airways. It still has a very strong brand. It has got all the slots at the various airports, it has got the aircraft, it has got all the ingredients required to run a successful aviation company. Some amount of mis-management and lack of control over costs have resulted in the mess that Jet Airways is. 

And if a strategic investor is able to bring discipline into the operations of the company and reduce debt, then even at these levels, Jet may be quite attractive as a solid turnaround story. We already have witnessed one turnaround story in the aviation industry in case of SpiceJet after the change of owners.The kind of wealth that company has created, makes one optimistic about Jet Airways and also positive on the aviation sector.

But one should expect volatility in their earnings depending on the competitive intensity and fuel prices. One thing is certain that a certain amount of pricing discipline has come back to the sector and airlines are not just chasing volumes. They are having a very sharp look at the yields as well and that will augur very well for the sector. 

I am not too concerned about the single digit passenger growth because end of the day, the yields are 40-50% higher than what they were a year ago and that should certainly give a big boost to the profitability of the entire sector. 


What would you look at within autos?There is another downgrade on Tata Motors coming from S&P with regards to JLR. Would you bet on indigenous players or would you rather hedge with a player like Bajaj Auto whose revenue has 30% export content?
I would like to go with the leaders and in the auto industry. Maruti has been the leader. They have an exceptionally high market share and as and when the passenger vehicle growth starts to pick up, you will see Maruti stock also doing pretty well. 

There are issues with discounting and high level of inventories but then the industry has gone through much in the past and came out only stronger. What is plaguing Maruti at this point of time is new model launches and that certainly will be addressed over the next few quarters or so. Having said that, another company which comes to mind within the two-wheeler space is Eicher Motors see. 

The best returns are given by Bajaj Auto. If you had bought it when it was really down and out and losing market share and was not able to display strong monthly sales figures, you would have got it comparatively cheap. Then the management took action and you are seeing the result at this point of time. A similar story will play out in Eicher Motors as well where because of declining or flat monthly sales and perhaps a poor quarterly performance, the stock is available at these levels but as and when sales pick up and management will take necessary action -- be it is exports or domestic or new product launches -- and you will see turnaround in the performance of this company as well. 

As I said, in the case of consumer-oriented or consumer-focussed companies, it is better to buy these companies when they are really down and out and where sales are flagging and there are certain industry or stock specific issues because as and when those get addressed, you see a great alpha as far as their profitability is concerned. 

Bajaj Auto has already delivered great returns and from this point forward one could not expect exceptional returns but except say an Eicher Motors or a TVS Motors, over a two-three year period, provide outperformance versus the sector as a whole and perhaps even Bajaj Auto.


Some consumer staple companies and auto companies are telling us that the demand trend in the next coming months will be south bound. What does that mean for a) staples and b) autos?
There are many great companies in the sector. They have been great wealth creators in the past be it in auto, be it in staples, appliances or typically consumer facing companies. There are many great companies over there and they have very strong moats around their business as well. 

It is just that there is a mild cyclical slowdown within the sector and it is not going to last forever and conventional wisdom is that you buy stocks when they are down, when there are specific company or industry related issues which are transient in nature and that is the reason why these stocks are available at a lower valuation and attractive price levels, there is a certain amount of margin of safety built in. 

If you just hold on to these companies for two, three years or so these demand adjustments take place, pent up demand comes into play, base effect comes into play, consumer spending also does come back and eventually you will see that these companies again starting to report exceptionally good earnings and that is when the stock prices start to skyrocket because essentially there is a scarcity of their equity considering that these are low capital intensive businesses and there is not much dilution of equity. 

If you are a long-term patient investor, autos, consumer oriented stocks, even FMCG, appliances are great contra bets at this point of time and end of the day there is not much downside for these companies. The entire India story and the demographics and the consumption trends, will come back eventually and when they come back into that high single, low double digit, you will see even operating leverages come into play for these companies.

I would not be too negative over the longer term. But that is easier said than done. You may have to see disappointing quarterly numbers and maybe somewhat flat to declining stock prices as well. If you hold on to them for a longer period of time, these could be great stories in terms of delivering exceptional index beating returns as well. 


How are you reading into the overall consumption theme as a whole? You seem to be fairly bullish on the sector. You also like infrastructure. What makes you optimistic here?
After many years, we are seeing all construction companies, especially infrastructure construction companies with bulging order book position. What is more impressive is these order books are at healthy margin of profit and some of the mistakes that these companies made in the past have been addressed. Whatever order book they are sitting on just now will be margin accretive and there is a high degree of visibility as far as their billings are concerned. The next two-three years could be great for these companies starting from L&T to Dilip Buildcon and most of the other smaller companies like NCC.

The next two-three years could see 15% to 35% earnings growth and that means these stocks will always remain in focus and would be favoured by the investors, so they could have some amount of outperformance over there. 

Whichever new government comes into play they will certainly keep the momentum going as far as infrastructure is concerned. Thus medium to long term prospects are also good for the companies. Coming to the consumption theme, one needs to have a slightly differentiated strategy and look for specific pockets of growth like media, entertainment, aviation and also appliance companies are doing quite well, as are liquor companies after some disruption.

As far as elections are concerned, there are still enough pockets of outperformance within the consumption space. Considering that is a very wide sector, investors need to have select exposure within the overall consumption basket and that access is a good hedge towards any kind of disruption in the markets considering that these have been greatly placed as far as safety is concerned.


Is there money to be made in cement?
There is no money to be lost in cement either. These are mature businesses with restricted type of growth rates going forward. There is price discipline but there are also cost increases and there are pockets in the country where, from time to time, companies will make a good sales and profitability but the long-term trends have to be in the low to high single digit, irrespective of whether real estate or infrastructure does well. 

Capacity utilisation is at fair levels and valuations for cement companies are on the higher side. The entire cement picture appears to be quite cloudy on a long-term basis. But in short term, from time to time, you could see a good trading bounce taking place in select cement companies. UltraTech is still awaiting corporate action as far as merger of Century Cement business is concerned and that could provide a fillip to the earnings of the company.

So, there could be select opportunities within the cement space but broadly I do not want to be overweight in cement at this point of time, given that the long-term growth trends are in low to high single digits. Typically, when you are looking to buy into businesses, you are looking for at least 15% earnings growth over a long-term trajectory. That does not seem to be possible in cement companies.

NEW DELHI: Nifty futures on the Singapore Exchange were trading 28 points, or 0.24 per cent, lower at 11,418.50, indicating a negative start for the Nifty50. Here are a few stocks which may buzz the most in today’s trade:

Tata Motors: S&P said it had downgraded its credit rating on Jaguar Land Rover (JLR), and its owner Tata Motors, even deeper into junk and put it on review for a possible further downgrade due to the growing risks of a no-deal Brexit and US import tariffs. 


Vedanta: Mining baron Anil Agarwal-led Vedanta on Wednesday announced an oil discovery in its Krishna Godavari basin block in the Bay of Bengal. The block previously had a gas discovery in the very first well drilled. 


MT Educare: The company, which runs Mahesh Tutorials and Lakshya coaching brands, is in talks with a clutch of institutional investors to raise funds, sources close to the development told ET.


NBCC: The company has bagged new works for various infrastructure projects.The total estimated costs of these projects are Rs 1,003 crore. 


PNB: Sebi exempted the government from making an open offer for the shareholders of Punjab National Bank but directed reduction in non-public shareholding in the lender post capital infusion.


Tata Power: The company said the state electricity regulator MERC has approved the power purchase agreement signed between its distribution and generation businesses to supply 700 MW power for the next five years. 


Bank of Baroda: State-owned Bank of Baroda is set to raise up to $1 billion by selling bonds overseas to solidify its capital position ahead of a likely jump in credit demand. The bank has just concluded roadshows across the world.


Jain Irrigation Systems: Deutsche Bank said Jain Irrigation Systems is caught in a debt trap as working capital and interest payments have been eating into operating cash flows, leaving negligible amounts for debt repayments.


Maruti Suzuki: India’s largest carmaker has extended the tenure of its managing director Kenichi Ayukawa by another three years starting April 1, 2019, ensuring continuity in operation ahead of the critical regulatory changes in 2020.


ICICI Prudential Life Insurance Company: The two-day offer for sale by the company received strong response from both retail and institutional investors. Analysts said at the floor price of Rs 300 in the OFS, the stock was undervalued compared to its peers.


United Breweries: Indian authorities probing the fugitive economic offender Vijay Mallya realised Rs 1,008 crore on Wednesday by selling his shares. A PMLA court had on Tuesday turned down United Breweries Holdings’ plea to stay the sale of shares of its erstwhile subsidiary United Breweries. 


Strides Pharma: The drug firm said it has received approval from the US health regulator, USFDA, for its oral dosage facility in Singapore.


Sheela Foam: The two-day OFS saw non-retail investors subscribing 2.26 times the total issue size.This was 2.78 times the base size.


GMR Infra: The GMR Group-run Delhi international airport (DIAL) has raised close to Rs 2,000 crore from real estate monetisation, which will help its on-going expansion plan, as the airport is set to handle over 70 million passenger this fiscal, a senior executive said on Wednesday. 


Larsen & Toubro: L&T is being unfairly doubted for its alleged role in a bribery case against Cognizant without evidence of its involvement, CEO SN Subrahmanyan said. 


Coal India: The Centre wants Coal India to increase its output and sales target to 655 million tonnes (MT) in 2019-20, 7.4% more than the current fiscal.


Tata Global Beverages: The company said its board has reappointed Ajoy Kumar Misra as its Managing Director and CEO for a period of one year.


NTPC: State-run power giant NTPC Wednesday said it has raised USD 450 million (about Rs 3,105 crore) through five-year bond offering in the international market under its USD 6 billion (about Rs 41,400 crore) medium term notes (MTN) programme.


Eicher Motors: Niche bike maker Royal Enfield Wednesday said it has launched all new Bullet Trials Works Replica range in India. The Bullet Trials 500 is priced at Rs 2.07 lakh, while Bullet Trials 350 is tagged at Rs 1.62 lakh (ex-showroom).


BSE: The leading stock exchange said it has received approvals to launch interest rates futures on overnight MIBOR (Mumbai Inter-Bank Offer Rate).In this regard, the bourse has got clearance from the Sebi and the RBI, according to a release.


Board meetings





Analyst calls 
• IIFL has maintained buy rating on Vardhman Textiles with a target price of Rs 1,220. The brokerage said its interaction with industry/channel partners points to healthy demand across the domestic yarn and fabric segments, as liquidity constraints have eased. Further, ebbing of China yarn inventory destocking pressures has aided yarn demand, said IIFL. 

• Reliance Securities has maintained buy rating on Kalpataru Power Transmission with a target price of Rs 544. Looking ahead, the brokerage expects expect Kalpataru Power Transmission to be one of the key beneficiaries of strong transmission capex in both domestic and global markets. 

 • Motilal Oswal has retained buy rating on Alkem Laboratories with a target price of Rs 2,170. The price correction in the last six months provides a good buying opportunity in Alkem Laboratories. With compliance in place and ANDA filings/ approvals proceeding at a healthy rate, the brokerage expects Alkem to post revenue CAGR of 16% over FY19-FY21 and improve profitability from US generics. 

 • IDBI Capital has initiated coverage on Federal Bank with a buy rating and target price of Rs 120. While the bank remains in a dominant position in Kerala, incremental growth will be driven from Non-Kerala geographies. Asset quality challenges are behind and bank is well placed to capitalize on likely economic recovery, it added.

ET Intelligence Group: In 2019, the shock absorbers of India’s two-wheeler industry have been tested on rather rough roads, but Bajaj Auto has held firm – at least until now. But that outperformance may not sustain in a business climate that doesn’t look too promising for bikes, and investors in the stock shouldn’t expect outsized returns relative to Bajaj Auto’s peers.

It’s true that Bajaj Auto has returned 8 per cent since the beginning of the year. By contrast, Hero MotoCorp, TVS Motor and Eicher Motor have posted negative 8-18 per cent returns. And that’s where the positive divergence begins to look rather shaky.

Bajaj Auto is trading at a premium compared with its long-term average, although industry growth is moderating. It is the only company in the listed two-wheelers space trading at a premium - at 17.4 times FY20 projected earnings compared with 16.4 times of the five-year average. The industry has seen flat growth in the past two months, compared with 14 per cent growth in the first nine months of FY19. Inventory levels reached 80-90 days in February compared with the normal metric of 30-45 days.

Bloomberg

Bajaj Auto’s domestic motorcycle growth rate plunged in January and February, compared with 34.3 per cent in the first nine months of FY19. The entry-level segment—more than 75cc and less than 125 cc bikes—has given significant market share gains. This segment has seen moderate growth.

The Street has been ascribing higher multiples to Bajaj Auto following its aggressive pricing strategy to gain market share. The Street was expecting that the company’s pricing stance would hurt the margins of Hero Moto-Corp more than of Bajaj Auto as the entry-level segment constitutes 15 per cent of the total domestic volumes of the Pune company, compared with 60 per cent at Hero. Still, the margins at Bajaj Auto continue to be under pressure. Operating margins fell 370 basis points YoY to 15.6 per cent in December quarter, the lowest in about nine years.

Analysts are penciling in volume growth of 6-7 per cent for the next fiscal year, compared with an expectation of 25 per cent in the current fiscal for the domestic market business of Bajaj Auto.

The pressure on margins could increase due to the inability to pass on the entire cost of regulatory changes effective April 2019. The government has mandated putting Anti-Braking System (ABS) in all bikes above 125 cc from April, and this feature is likely to increase unit prices by .Rs 5,000-6,000.

Bikes more than 125 cc constituted more than 40 per cent of the domestic sales at Bajaj Auto. Therefore, the impact of increased vehicle prices due to ABS is likely to be more on Bajaj Auto than on its peers. According to Bloomberg, consensus EBITDA margins for FY19 and FY20 are 16.6 per cent and 16.8 per cent, respectively. Hence, mounting margin pressure could result in profitability slippages.

NEW DELHI: Vodafone Idea with over 0.99 crore shares changing hands was leading among the most traded stocks on NSE on Friday.

Global funds are making a beeline for India big time. Their growing interest, along with expectations of Narendra Modi taking power again and forecast of plentiful rains ahead, gave the bulls enough will power to stay in-charge for the sixth straight week on Dalal Street. 

The Sensex rose 1.33 per cent, or 508 points, to 38,673 for the week to March 30. NSE's Nifty jumped 1.46 per cent, or 167 points, to 11,624. 

The finance ministry said liquidity in the economy is comfortable and will improve further with the central bank’s move to infuse Rs 35,000 crore through the rupee-dollar swap auction. That was good enough to stoke investment appetite.

“Hopes of a stable government took the Sensex higher by almost 8 per cent this month. Buying has been mainly led by FIIs who have put in around Rs 45,000 core into domestic markets. We believe that any rate cuts in developed markets such as the US or Europe may result in steady inflows for emerging markets (EMs),” said Hemang Jani, Head-Advisory, Sharekhan by BNP Paribas. 

All eyes are on national elections starting next month, which will keep domestic markets volatile in the short term. The results are due on May 23. 

In the long term, corporate earnings growth and revival in private capex remain crucial for further market upside, say experts.

How did major stocks and sectors play up the whole week? There we go.


The IPO update


Rail Vikas Nigam: The initial public offer (IPO) of state-owned Rail Vikas Nigam got subscribed 9 per cent on the first day of the bidding on Friday. The Rs 481-crore offering received bids for 2,19,01,620 shares against the total issue size of 25,34,57,280, NSE data showed.


MSTC: State-owned MSTC made a weak market debut on Friday and settled over 5 per cent down compared with the issue price of Rs 120 per share. The stock opened the day at Rs 111, down 7.5 per cent against the issue price on the BSE. Intra-day, it touched a high of Rs 116.55 and a low of Rs 110.05. However, it settle the day at Rs 114.20, 4.83 per cent lower.


Top Nifty movers
With a rally of 18 per cent, Indiabulls Housing Finance emerged as the leader of the Nifty pack. It was followed by YES Bank (up 8.91 per cent), State Bank of India (up 7.62 per cent), Bajaj Finance (up 6.64 per cent) and HCL Technologies (up 6.11 per cent). 
On the other hand, Eicher Motors, Wipro, Hero MotoCorp, Hindalco, Tech Mahindra and Bajaj Auto slipped 1.30-4.19 per cent.


Jet Airways flies higher
Shares of Jet Airways rallied nearly 19 per cent after founder Naresh Goyal on Monday quit as a board member, with the lenders taking control and deciding to infuse Rs 1,500 crore immediately into the ailing airline. The scrip settled the week at Rs 268.80 against Rs 226.10 on March 22.


DHFL takes spotlight
Dewan Housing Finance Corporation Ltd (DHFL) soared over 12 per cent during the week amid reports that Piramal Group and Baring Private Equity (PE) are in talks to acquire a majority stake in the company. The scrip advanced 12.34 per cent to Rs 150.30 during the week.


Britannia replaces HPCL on Nifty
FMCG firm Britannia Industries replaced OMC major Hindustan Petroleum Corporation on the Nifty50 on Friday. The stock closed 0.19 per cent down at Rs 3,081.95 on March 29 while HPCL settled 3.83 per cent up at Rs 283.50.


WABCO India drives up
Shares of WABCO India rallied nearly 5 per cent on Friday after the company clinched a definitive merger deal with ZF Friedrichshafen AG, a privately-held global leader in driveline and chassis technologies.


Stocks @ new all-time highs
As many as 25 stocks of the BSE500 index hit their fresh record highs during the week. The list included stocks such as ICICI Lombard General Insurance, Varun Beverages, RBL Bank, Future Lifestyle, Muthoot Finance, Ipca Labs, PI Industries, UPL, ICICI Bank, SKF India, Pidilite Industries, Torrent Pharma and Merck.


The sectoral scene
Among BSE sectoral indices, Consumer Durables rallied the most -- 3.09 per cent -- for the week under review. It was followed by Oil & Gas (up 3.08 per cent), Bankex (up 2.99 per cent), Metal (up 1.82 per cent) and Power (1.68 per cent). BSE Telecom (down 0.42 per cent) was the only loser.


Titan m-cap tops Rs 1 lakh cr 
The market capitalisation (m-cap) of Titan surpassed Rs 1 lakh crore for the first time ever. With a rally of over 3.50 per cent, m-cap of the company jumped to Rs 1,00,985.70 crore on Friday, from Rs 98,073.70 on March 22. Before closing 0.69 per cent up at Rs 1,137.50, the scrip scaled its all-time high of Rs 1,146 on Friday.

In order to propel Royal Enfield as a global motorcycling brand, Eicher Motors Ltd (EML) today announced the appointment of Vinod K. Dasari as the Chief Executive Officer of Royal Enfield, a unit of EML. 

Dasari will also join the Board of Eicher Motors Ltd as an Executive Director with immediate effect. 

Vinod Dasari takes over from Siddhartha Lal who will continue as the Managing Director of Eicher Motors Ltd. At Royal Enfield, Siddhartha will continue to support Vinod and the team on product and brand related areas, said the statement issued by the company to Bombay Stock 

Speaking on the appointment, Mr. Siddhartha Lal, Managing Director, Eicher Motors Ltd. said, 
“After a phenomenal success story in the last decade, Royal Enfield is now building the foundations of its next level of growth. As we commence another exciting chapter, I believe, there is no better person than Vinod Dasari to lead Royal Enfield into its next phase of evolution to a global brand. Vinod is a proven leader who combines business vision and people skills. He has been a catalyst in 
reviving the fortunes of his previous company and re-shaping the dynamics of a hitherto slow moving industry.”

“Vinod’s fearless entrepreneurial leadership, experience of managing complex businesses globally, deep understanding of customers and his vision of how digital technology will be used and experienced around the world are precisely the qualities that Royal Enfield needs as it aspires to lead and catalyse the global motorcycling industry towards middle weights (250-750cc)”, Siddhartha added. 

Prior to joining Royal Enfield, Vinod Dasari was the CEO & Managing Director of Ashok Leyland, a position he held since 2011. He joined Ashok Leyland as the Chief Operating Officer in 2005.

Vinod Dasari has held several leadership positions at Cummins India Limited and Timken Company where he went on to become the President of its Global Railroad business in the USA. He started his career with General Electric in 1986. 

Speaking about his new role, Mr Vinod Dasari, CEO, Royal Enfield said, “Royal Enfield is an 
inspiring story and I am very excited to be part of such a fantastic brand. Personally for me, working with a consumer brand will be a tremendous learning opportunity, and professionally, I am looking forward to the challenge of creating a global consumer brand from India.”

Dasari has also served as the President of the Society of Indian Automobile Manufacturers 
(SIAM) from 2015 to 2017 and as President of Automotive Research Association of India (ARAI), from 2013 to 2015. 

Dasari holds a Masters degree in Engineering Management from the McCormick School of Engineering and a Masters in Business Administration (MBA), from the Kellogg School of Management. He earned a Bachelor’s degree in Engineering from University of Louisville in 1988.

SBI Caps Securities chooses to give a wide berth to the two-wheeler space even as auto sales numbers for March trickle in. 

The industry continues to battle headwinds, given structural weakness coupled with a lot of regulatory issues concerning safety and emission norms.

“We have been recommending a cautious view on the two-wheeler space, especially with a negative view on Eicher Motors and TVS,” Chirag Jain, auto analyst at SBI Caps, told ETNow.

Jain said the brokerage still keeps a buy on Maruti Suzuki India.

Maruti saw a 1.6 per cent decline in total sales at 1,58,076 units for March. While domestic sales fell a paltry 0.7 per cent at 147,613 units, exports saw a sharp decline of 12.9 per cent at 10,463 units.

“Clearly, the numbers have been on expected lines for Maruti for this month. I think the slowdown in demand has been fairly known and accepted. What needs to be seen is obviously recovery. Our dealer checks indicate that the consumer intent remains quite strong with respect to consumer enquiries, which still is in the positive zone,” Jain said.

“Even the used car market is growing quite strongly. So, there is definitely an interest to buy cars. It is just that there are multiple uncertainties, especially ahead of elections. There are liquidity issues and stuff like that, which are delaying car demand. So, it is just a matter of time when there is clarity with respect to macroeconomic environment,” added Jain. 

Once the elections are out of the way, there could be recovery in demand, but near-term demand is quite weak, according to Jain. 

Maruti's franchise value keeps the stock going and it's the weakness in macros that's impacting the volume growth, he said.

On Tata Motors, Jain said the commercial vehicle (CV) and passenger vehicle (PV) segments are under stress as well. 

“It is more about how the JLR performance pans out, and as far as domestic (sales) are concerned yes, the expectations are by and large flat growth. No major volumes, but yes more than that I think how the retail performance pans out in the last few months and especially March is something that needs to be seen rather than just the wholesale numbers,” said Jain.

On tractor sales, it is almost a third year of upcycle running. Despite the strong first half, last couple of quarters have been a disappointment. 

“There are certain players like Escorts which are still doing well and mainly because they are largely present in the northern and central parts of the market, which are growing ahead of the entire industry. By and large, even on the tractor front, we have seen momentum slowing, probably because obviously it is a cyclical industry,” said Jain.
