NEW DELHI: A host of triggers are likely to help benchmark indices move out of rangebound trading next week. While quarterly earnings will drive stock-specific actions, economic data such as March factory output and manufacturing growth prints, fifth phase of elections and progress of US-China trade talks will be keenly followed. 

Oil prices, rupee-dollar exchange rate and foreign flow trend will also be tracked keenly. 

For the week gone by, BSE Sensex fell 104.07 points, or 0.27 per cent, to 38,963, while NSE’s Nifty50 fell 42.40 points, or 0.6 per cent, to 11,712. 


Here are key factors to watch out for next week: 


US-China trade deal
A Chinese delegation will arrive in Washington on Wednesday (May 8) to discuss the proposed trade deal. Donald Trump on Friday said the trade negotiations with China were going on pretty well. The comment by the US President came after White House’s chief of staff Mick Mulvaney earlier this week said the trade dispute with Beijing will likely be resolved “one way or the other” within the next two weeks. A report by CNBC quoting sources suggested that a trade deal could be announced by Friday this week. 


Q4 earnings
A total of 216 companies will report March quarter earnings in the coming week, BSE data suggests. Bharti Airtel, ICICI Bank and Marico will declare results on Monday, Vedanta, Escorts and CEAT on Tuesday, Titan Company and Dhanlaxmi Bank on Wednesday, HCL Tech and Apollo Tyres on Thursday and SBI, L&T, Eicher Motors and Allahabad Bank on Friday.


IIP, manufacturing growth data 
On Friday, investors would like to know whether the industrial output growth improved in March from a 20-month low of 0.1 per cent hit in February. The factory output last month was hurt mainly due to a contraction in the manufacturing sector. Therefore, the numbers on manufacturing output to be released the same day will also be watched. Meanwhile, Nikkei India PMI Services data for April will be released on Monday. The three data prints will give cues on the state of the economy. 


5th phase of elections
The fifth phase of voting in the general elections will take place on Monday. Voting will happen in 51 Lok Sabha constituencies across seven different states. After four phases of elections, the voting percentage stood at 67 per cent, comparable with 67.6 per cent reported in 2014. Equirus Securities said flattish turnout has historically proved to be good for an incumbent party. 


Global economic releases
Among global cues, investor will watch Euro zone’s retail sales figures on Monday, China’s foreign reserves data on Tuesday, its trade data on Wednesday and CPI and PPI data on Thursday, and US’ CPI numbers and Baker Hughes oil rig count on Friday will be watched keenly.


Oil, rupee movement
Investors are keenly waiting to see if the recent fall in crude oil prices was temporary. A drop in crude prices will help the rupee appreciate or vice versa. Data suggests Brent crude futures settled at $70.85 a barrel on Friday, down 2.6 per cent for the week, snapping a five-week rising streak. US crude futures on the other hand fell around 3 per cent for the week to $61.94 a barrel.


Foreign flows
Foreign flows into India were pretty strong at Rs 72,394 in the last three months. That said, inflows in April at Rs 21,193 crore were down 37 per cent from March’s record flows of Rs 33,980 crore. In May so far, FPIs have pulled out Rs 367.30 crore from domestic equities.

NEW DELHI: Reliance Power with over 0.54 crore shares changing hands was leading among the most traded stocks on NSE on Monday.

Shares of Federal Bank (number of shares traded: 0.35 crore), Vodafone Idea (number of shares traded: 0.31 crore), YES Bank (number of shares traded: 0.28 crore), Ruchi Soya Industries (number of shares traded: 0.21 crore), Tata Motors (number of shares traded: 0.12 crore), SAIL (number of shares traded: 0.11 crore), Infibeam Avenues (number of shares traded: 0.09 crore), Uttam Value Steel (number of shares traded: 0.07 crore) and PC Jeweller (number of shares traded: 0.07 crore) also featured among the most traded stocks on the NSE.

YES Bank was leading the pack of most active stocks in value terms.

It was followed by RIL (Rs 49.07 crore), HDFC Bank (Rs 47.48 crore), Infosys (Rs 42.23 crore), Federal Bank (Rs 41.47 crore), Tata Steel (Rs 31.34 crore), Tata Motors (Rs 30.53 crore), TCS (Rs 24.62 crore), Indiabulls Housing Finance (Rs 23.79 crore) and Hindustan Unilever (Rs 20.51 crore).

The NSE Nifty index was trading 115.45 points down at 11,596.8 while the BSE Sensex was down 403 points at 38,560.26 around 09:17 am. 

In the Nifty index, Power Grid Corporation of India (up 0.21 per cent), Eicher Motors (up 0.09 per cent) and Bharat Petroleum Corporation (up 0.09 per cent) were among the top gainers. 

While Tata Motors (down 3.70 per cent), JSW Steel (down 3.56 per cent), YES Bank (down 3.27 per cent), Hindalco Industries (down 2.80 per cent) and Tata Steel (down 2.67 per cent) were the top losers in the index.

If somebody has Reliance share in the portfolio, it is a hold. But it is a difficult call to take whether it is a buy at this point of time, said Devang Mehta, Head-Equity Advisory, Centrum India, in an interview with ETNOW.Edited excerpts: 


The largecaps have taken quite a beating and Reliance Industries definitely merits a mention given the selling pressure. Now, Morgan Stanley is also rather circumspect and have downgraded the stock saying that the upside is going to be limited. What are you advising on RIL?
The markets have been extremely polarised in the last few months and the rally has been led by five or six businesses including Reliance, Bajaj Finance, Bajaj Finserv and TCS. Unless the broader market starts participating in the rally, a crack in stocks which were doing extremely well, would cap the rally. 

The correction that we are seeing is more FII driven and that is clearly notable. They have overweight positions in the stocks which I have mentioned earlier. Reliance also is getting a bit of its correction because it has been a dream rally for the stock. I do not see a big challenge in the business as such people knew the earnings of petchem as well as the core business of oil and gas has been slowing down in the last two-three quarters.




But still, the stock was making new highs and this can be a natural correction -- probably 5% more from here as the market ,corrects led by heavyweights. I do not see a big problem emerging. If somebody has it in the portfolio, it is a hold. Whether it is a buy, it is a difficult call to take at this point but it is a good hold in the portfolio.


 The world is migrating towards corporate banks but looking at Yes Bank, Axis Bank and ICICI Bank numbers, would you say the long crowded trade in corporate banks is getting challenged?
There were different set of numbers from different banks. Yes Bank faces a typically different type of problem. There was a kitchen-sinking done after the stock performed very well in the earlier couple of quarter. One quarter is mirroring what Axis Bank or a Yes Bank, ICICI Bank did two-three four quarters back, but there are not many compelling trades in the market in the banking sector. Of course, HDFC Bank commands a premium as a retail bank but clearly if somebody still needs to buy on dips, a better candidate where ROE expansion is going to happen is Axis Bank. The management is talking about 8% ROE getting into an 18% league in another three years.

After the clean-up, there is a lot of scope for these banks to give if not 25-30%, at least 15, 18, 20% type of return CAGR for the next two-three years, particularly for Axis Bank. 

So, yes the cream is out of the rally. The 40-50% return has already been made but it is back to 15-18% boring returns that can be made out of Axis or ICICI.


What is going on with some of these pledged share scenarios like the Essel Group? The fact that Reliance Mutual Fund sold it had created a lot of nervousness in the markets. What is your take?
It is better to avoid the space, where there is a lot of pledged share issue. In last two-three months, there has been bouts of volatility. A lot of these companies have good businesses and good pipeline as well. The numbers also are good for a lot of these companies, but the overhang on these type of stocks have always been the promoter pledge or the debt on the books which is very difficult to manage, during these types of market where on one side, there is polarisation and on the other, market breadth has been very weak. 

So, fundamental has taken a back stage for this type of businesses. It is better to stay away from these types of businesses. If you have to buy at all, go for a screaming buy or place your bet on the valuation side. That way, you do not suffer in the shorter term but over a longer period, you make good returns but yes, refrain from buying into companies where there are pledged shares.


We are gathering that there is going to be a steep hike in cement prices, the second one in the last two months. Your view?
In the last couple of quarters, we have started hunting for such businesses. Generally we refrain from buying more cyclical businesses as we are more into high market share or market leading businesses where there is pricing power. But cement in the last couple of quarters, have been showing a bit of traction. The last quarterly numbers of a lot of companies like UltraTech also see that the demand scenario coming back plus a bit of pricing power with price hikes. 

After a long time, probably the demand for cement is coming back and may be monsoon would be subdued. But for somebody with a one-one-and-a-half-year type of a view, cement presents a good opportunity. Cyclicals is one space where with select capital goods or cement, you can start constructing a portfolio and post election results, if a stable government is in place, the construction demand, infra demand and a bit of housing demand could come back. Cement can act as a proxy play for this type of construction activity.


Do you think one should just get more realistic rather than following a predefined template of buying good companies and great businesses? One should acknowledge that these companies are nowhere available at levels at which they warrant a buy?
There is a clear distinction between a great business, a good business and also a third category which IS classified by Warren Buffett as gruesome business. You do not want to buy any gruesome business in the portfolio at any type of valuation. May be it is a value or a value trap. We do not know any business so gruesome you have to stay away. A good business is probably about some cyclicals you have to time as and when you feel that this is the right price or the cycle is changing. Of course it is very difficult to say but cement and capital goods probably qualify as some of these companies have good business. 

Great businesses are some of the businesses like a Britannia or may be Dabur or HUL. These are types of businesses you do not want to sell or either you want to buy in distress. These are distressed times and probably after a 5% or 10% correction, the price may be right. But Page Industries from Rs 35,000 to Rs 32,000 or Rs 28,000 was probably overvalued. A couple of bad numbers brought it to Rs 22,000 right. Probably you need to time your bets -- that this is a time when you buy some consumption businesses like Page Industries or take a contra call like Eicher Motors which people will not find favour with right now at Rs 20,000. But at Rs 18,000 it would a screaming buy.

So, rather than adventuring into companies which you do not know, get into plain vanilla businesses where you know that the high market share and market leadership would come and help you in good times and which would not shatter you in bad times. So keep your bets ready, keep your list ready and these are the businesses in India which you need to buy. There are 100-150 good businesses where you can make money in a simpler way rather than adventuring out of the 500 stocks that present itself.

HDFC Asset Management, the country’s largest mutual fund house by assets, lightened its largecap holdings and bought additional shares of select midcap and smallcap companies in April, when the benchmark equity indices advanced 1 per cent. 

The money manager more than doubled its holding in select aviation, NBFC, cement and consumer durables plays in April, even as it sold stake in industry leaders Maruti Suzuki, Reliance Industries, Infosys, Asian Paints and ICICI Bank. 

The fund house added more shares in as many as 61 companies, while reduced its holdings in as many as 84. NSE’s Nifty index rose nearly 8 per cent during the January-April period, while Nifty Midcap100 and Nifty Smallcap100 shed up to 2 per cent each.

Brokerage Elara Capital says midcaps continue their underperformance against largecaps. “Relative valuations are plunging towards -1 standard deviation levels, making midcaps very attractive. A negative SD shows the price to equity ratio has slipped to the lower end of average valuations.

Stocks where the top fund manager raised its holding in April included in InterGlobe Aviation, where its holding has gone up to a whooping 1,94,200 shares as of April 30 from 15,600 on March 31. Likewise, it increased stake in Indiabulls Housing Finance (from 99,238 shares to 3,72,605), ACC (from 8,000 to 27,200) and Bajaj Electricals (from 8,65,300 to 24,60,000).

According to Stewart & Mackertich, improved pricing power, lower ATF coupled with rupee appreciation should aid an improvement in profitability of domestic airlines. With the global ban on Boeing 737 Max 8 planes coming into force from March, capacity is not likely to rise at the expected pace, thus demand should outpace supply in the near future. This means the prospects for yields would be encouraging, the brokerage said. 

“We expect IndiGo to outperform, as it has a deep domestic network with over 43 per cent market share, availability of slots, lowest cost structure and a healthy cash balance to fuel the airline,” the brokerage said.

ACC has been demonstrating sustained ability to improve sales volume since Q1CY17, which had remained stagnant through CY11-CY16. While its CY18 volume growth stood at 8.7 per cent YoY, capacity utilisation came in 85 per cent, Ashika Stock Broking said in a report. 

“We expect ACC to deliver improved RoE backed by better pricing and lower operating expenditure,” the brokerage said.

HDFC AMC also developed fancy for select power plays. Data shows the fund house bought over 1 crore additional shares in NTPC and BHEL during the month. It held 35.75 crore shares of NTPC and 2.04 crore shares of BHEL as of April 30, 2019.

Antique Stock Broking prefers utilities firm like NTPC over equipment makers like BHEL. “In the short run, for a year or two, demand in power equipment and projects is unlikely to grow. Policy makers are consolidating and streamlining the existing 68GW of projects under construction. Plus, in the near term, the focus is on making good of the 175GW renewable target. This is visible in subdued order pipeline for BHEL, a state-owned power-equipment manufacturer. However, with commissioning pace of thermal plants are inching up,” it said

Tiles firm Kajaria Ceramics, telecom major Bharti Airtel as well as private sector bank Karur Vysya Bank also drew interest of HDFC AMC, which added 13,000 shares of Kajaria, 43.65 lakh shares of Karur and 16.77 lakh shares of Airtel during the month.

Coal India, Bank of Baroda, Apollo Tyres, GAIL India, Sadbhav Engineering, Bharat Electronics, Tata Steel, Bharat Dynamics, Jagran Prakashan, Chambal Fertiliser, Power Finance Corporation, Firstsource Solution, REC, Redington, REC, Kalpataru Power, KEC International, Axis Bank, Indian Hotel, BPCL, Gabriel India, SBI, Cipla, ITC, ICICI Prudential, Zee Entertainment and HDFC were among other stocks where the fund house raised its stake during the month.

On the other hand, it offloaded more than 13 lakh shares in Infosys, ICICI Bank and Reliance Industries. It also sold over 50,000 shares in Maruti Suzuki, Adani Enterprises, HPCL, Britannia, Kotak Mahindra Bank, Allahabad Bank, Wipro and NBCC, among others.

Brokerage firm YES Securities recently gave a ‘sell’ rating to Maruti Suzuki with a price target of Rs 5,850. “Maruti Suzuki (MSIL) reported a weak performance in Q4FY19 with Ebidta coming in 8 per cent below expectations,” said YES Securities.

In the Nifty50 pack, shares of companies like Reliance Industries, Tata Motors, Axis Bank, Wipro and HCL Technologies surged over 20 per cent in the first four months of 2019, while Hero Moto, Indiabulls Housing Finance, Vedanta, Mahindra & Mahindra, Eicher Motors and Maruti Suzuki declined over 10 per cent.

Average asset under management (AUM) of HDFC AMC stood at Rs 3.43 lakh crore as of March 31, 2019. It was followed by ICICI Prudential AMC (Rs 3.21 lakh crore) and SBI Fund Management (Rs 2.84 lakh crore) in terms of AUM.

Whichever government comes in, if growth is going to be the focus, then we should be more hopeful than despondent, said Ravi Dharamshi, CIO, ValueQuest Investment Advisors, in an interview with ETNOW. Edited excerpts:

On May 23, we will know who is going to form the government. What are your expectations from the new government? 
What is important from an investor’s point of view is what are the cards that the new government is going to be dealt with. In 2004, the UPA-1 government was dealt extremely favourable macro scenario globally as well as domestically and they reaped the benefits of that. The opposite was true for UPA-2, where they actually came in post the global financial crisis and we had a protracted slowdown, which has carried on till now. 

So for all practical purposes, it has been almost a decade of earnings lost. 

In that kind of backdrop, it is very important that whichever government comes in, should focus on growth. PM Modi said somewhere that the last five years went towards meeting the needs of the poor and the next five years are going to be focussing on their aspirations. 

Whichever government comes in, if growth is going to be the focus, then we should be more hopeful than despondent.


Before we talk about the five-year agenda, let us talk about 23rd of May. Markets will swing. It could be a 5% or a 10% swing. What scenario do you think is in the price?
The most likely scenario like everybody keeps saying is the return of NDA government, maybe with a reduced number of seats. That is the base case that the market is playing with. But there is unlikely to be a major move if that is the outcome. Unless there is a new government or if there is simple majority for the incumbent government, then and then only will the market movement be exaggerated. Otherwise, we will go back to focussing on the global backdrop and the domestic factors.




If the outcome is adverse, then what are markets betting on? Are we looking at a tsunami of selling or would the selling be contained and muted?
It has been 10 years of earnings slowdown and we have spent the last five years cleaning up the books -- whether it is at promoter level or the government forming regulations and framework to help the corporate India clean up their books. We are probably more than half way through that clean-up. Going forward, whichever government comes, over a five-year scenario again it will be a beneficial thing only. We have a platform ready. We have a billion consumers who are connected with mobile and we have GST. Now we are a one geography. 

We are the last standing consumer in the world. Everybody is looking at us with a lot of hope that we are going to take over the mantle of growth in the global economy when two big giants are probably facing a slowdown. In that kind of scenario, I do not think one can be negative on the Indian economy and Indian markets for too long. 

So barring the initial reaction of the disappointment of the incumbent government not coming in, we will go back to focussing on the factors and there are lots of small positive changes which the market is not focussing on right now, that will come into play. Also, right now, the valuations optically seem high but that is the top 25-30 stocks. If you look at the rest of the market, we are really at pre-2013 valuations. The world has changed for the better. Crude is in tolerable zone. Rupee is stable. Inflation rate is contained and RBI is cutting rates. We are in a rate cut cycle. So in that kind of scenario, I do not see us dropping dramatically beyond the initial knee-jerk reaction.


How are you approaching the market right now? Election will occupy everyone’s mind but the concern is with slowdown in autos and consumer sectors because of the NBFC crisis. There is no demand and production is being cut. What is going on?
Those are more important factors than elections from the economy point of view. The consumption slowdown is driven more by the NBFC crisis and less by Indian consumer facing some kind of pinch. If political stability comes back and BS-VI is triggered, down the line, there might be some pre-buying for passenger vehicles and commercial vehicles. That could lead to a revival sometime in the second half. 

Right now, even though it is looking dire, I still feel it is a cyclical slowdown and not a very structural issue, This slowdown is manifesting itself in EMI-based products.


Soaps and shampoos are coming down and that makes me wonder! Slowdown or no slowdown, EMI or no EMI, you do not stop having a bath or start rubbing a bar of soap?
That is never the case. It has to do with competitive intensity may be the rural economy is facing a little more issue right now. A lot of stimulus has been given. The pie is not shrinking, it is just that the penetration of that category has reached a level where growth is difficult.

Maybe some substitute products have come in for all we know. But having said that, rural economy has received a decent amount of stimulus which is yet to play itself out. For example, this PM Kisan Yojana -- Rs 2,000 that is going to be given thrice a year. Two instalments have already gone in. That can play a big role in reviving the rural sentiment. The farm loan waiver that has happened in the last one year and also the fact that whichever new government comes in, the priority will be for them to revive the farm sector.

In that kind of a scenario, even the rural revival is on the cusp. Maybe six months, 12 months down the line, we should have a revival. The cyclical slowdown will not prolong itself that is my opinion.


Where are you shopping? Where are you getting out? 
There have been very few places where one can find a clean story where the valuation as well as the tailwind is in your favour. One of the spaces is the corporate banks and that has played out to some extent.


Is it the only thing which has played out for investors?
Yes, but it is not over yet. The asset quality improvement that is going to drive the ROE still has some legs to go. Also, credit growth is finally picking up. The NBFC crisis is playing into the hands of the large private corporate banks who can actually buy these NBFC portfolios and that is very easy growth and easy pickings for them. 

Some amount of realignment from NBFCs back to banks is going to happen and it is in progress and it is happening. This trade will still last maybe 12 to 24 months going forward as well.


A lot of midcap stocks have sold off across the board and the common theme here is not business, not demand. It is promoter pledges. Are you picking something which can be called distress sale, where the selloff is technical and not fundamental?
In a perverse way, actually this is a very bullish sign. Usually this happens in the late stage of the cycle. So, who are the sellers? Either it is the lender that is selling or liquidating or desperate promoters are selling, trying to get some asset value out of their asset to repay their lenders. 

All these are desperate sellers and to some extent there are retail investors who are tired of not getting any kind of returns for the last 18-24 months. Their patience is wearing thin and that is giving rise to an opportunity. 

Coming to your question, we have not picked any such distressed asset but we are constantly and continuously monitoring, we will wait for the opportunity where we feel the asset value is dramatically more than whatever the market is reflecting right now. 


Would you buy autos in this sell-off or would you buy consumers because a stock like Eicher is down from Rs 35,000 to Rs 22,000-23,000. HUL is down 15-17% from its recent high?
If you put a gun to my head and I have to choose only between the two of them, I might actually not choose either of the two.


You will not buy autos also…
Yes, I would rather go for more secular stories than a cyclical on. But having said that, may be three months, six months down the line with more some price correction, I will start looking at auto but in consumer stocks like Lever, definitely valuations are more expensive. There are other companies within the FMCG pack where you can probably look. There is a large tobacco company which is available at much cheaper valuation. One can pick and choose within the sector. You do not need to go with the most expensive stock.


Are you buying risk or growth in your portfolio or it is time to take a safety shelter kind of an approach stick to stocks?
Growth is not visible in most of the companies at this point of time. Now, you have to go with the quality of the company and the valuations. You have to pick the company or stock where you believe they would not make the cardinal mistake of overleveraging or doing capex at the wrong time of the cycle and if market has punished them for the slowdown in growth.

 Growth is a temporary thing. It is more a balance sheet issue that cannot be resolved very easily and so if the problems are of P&L, I am more open to buying them. But if the problems are of balance sheet, then I am still a little wary of picking them up right now.


This is the fourth year where earnings estimates are going to be downgraded.
I think it is eight or ninth year.


The optimism had come back four years ago.
It is eight or nine years since estimates have been downgraded.


What does one do now?
Do not stop estimating because you are not getting it right at all. The estimates would be around 25% earnings growth, even if we do not end up showing a 25% kind of growth, we will end with somewhere close to 18%-20% growth which is good. It is not a bad year. What matters more is the quality of earnings growth. If it is just a mathematical increase in earnings because you have provided less, that does not excite me. 

Most of the earnings growth is going to come from the banks which have gone through the provision cycle and their provisions are tapering off and that is leading to an increase in profits but if that is the only reason, then I would be a little wary of the earnings cycle rebound. Looking more for where the growth is panning out and where some operating leverage is coming in, it is leading to an ROE improvement. Those kind of stories would attract me more.


Are there enough options where growth, valuation, operating leverage or financial leverage work together?
You have often said that good headlines and good valuations do not go together. Right now we are in a situation where there is bad headlines and along with that, comes good valuations. So, valuations and the quality of the company remains the core you have to focus on at this point of time. 

You have to focus on the broad opportunity and believe that whatever the slowdown is happening is temporary in nature and if your horizon is beyond one-two years, then those companies will provide you with fantastic returns over a three to five year horizon.

NEW DELHI: A drop in sales of Royal Enfield (RE) is all set to pinch Eicher Motors’ fourth quarter earnings on Friday. The auto maker is expected to report a double-digit drop in profit and at least 200 basis points (bps) contraction in margins on a year-on-year basis. Inventory update and clarity over RE production target of 9.5 lakh units for FY20 will be followed keenly.

Brokerage Motilal Oswal Securities expects the company report an adjusted profit after tax (PAT) of Rs 540 crore, down 16.3 per cent YoY or 1.9 per cent QoQ. Consolidated revenue is projected to fall 2.7 per cent YoY (up 5.1 per cent QoQ) to Rs 2,460 crore.

During the quarter, Royal Enfield reported a volume degrowth of 13.5 per cent YoY to 1.96 lakh units. Volvo Eicher Commercial Vehicles also reported 9.1 per cent YoY drop in units sold to 21,010 units largely on a high base.

HDFC Institutional Equities is factoring in a 4 per cent drop in sales. “Realisations will be higher due to price hikes taken through the year. Ebitda margin contraction 200 bps YoY to 29.5 per cent (up 50 bps QoQ). Profit may decline of 10 per cent YoY (up 9 per cent QoQ,” the brokerage said.

ICICI Securities projected sales at Rs 2,413 crore, down 4 per cent YoY estimates March quarter Ebitda at Rs 728 crore with corresponding Ebitda margins at 30 per cent, down 230 bps YoY.

“Ensuing PAT is expected at Rs 589 crore. PAT for the quarter also includes profit from VECV JV amounting to Rs 58 crore. At RE level, pureplay standalone PAT is expected at Rs 494 crore,” the brokerage said.

NEW DELHI: Indian domestic indices soon took a turn for the worse, after opening mildly higher in morning trade on Friday, after US hiked tariffs on Chinese goods. 

Other Asian markets traded mixed after the tariff hike. MSCI's broadest index of Asia-Pacific shares outside Japan was up 0.3 per cent, led by gains in Chinese shares. China markets were on midday break when the higher tariffs took effect. The Shanghai composite rose as much as 3.1 per cent early on Friday before paring much of that gain, leaving it up 1.5 per cent.

The BSE benchmark Sensex was down 28 poinst or 0.07 per cent at 37,531 whereas its NSE counterpart Nifty was trading at 11,294, down 7 poinst or 0.061 per cent.

"The index needs to hold key support of 11,200-11,250 and enter a base formation to see a pause in the ongoing correction. The recent consolidation breakdown area 11,550 would now act as stiff resistance, as per change of polarity concept earlier support would now act as resistance," said ICICI Direct in a note.

Reliance Industries was the biggest Sensex gainer, up around nearly 2 per cent, after Mukesh Ambani-led company acquired iconic British toy-maker Hamleys for around Rs 620 crore in an all-cash deal. 

Other gainers included -- ICICI Bank, Vedanta, Tata Motors, SBI and Tata Steel.

On the other hand, HCL Tech fell the most, down 4 per cent, following its March quarter numbers. The IT services major posted a 14.3 per cent rise in its consolidated net profit at Rs 2,550 crore for the March 2019 quarter and set an "aspirational" annual revenue target of more than USD 10-billion (about Rs 70,258 crore) in FY2019-20. 

Asian Paints, Kotak bank, Coal India, HUL and Power Grid joined HCL Tech on the loserboard.

On the BSE sectoral front, realty was the biggest gainer. Meanwhile, FMCG, telecom, consumer durables, oil & gas were among the sectoral losers.


BSE Midcap and BSE Smallcap traded marginally higher, up 0.02 per cent and 0.14 per cent respectively.

The markets would keep an eye on stocks such as the State Bank of India (SBI), Larsen & Toubro (L&T), Eicher Motors, Allahabad Bank, Canara Bank, PVR, Oberoi Realty, Syndicate Bank, Vakrangee and Venky’s which will report their March quarter results on Friday.

Markets look poised for a rally but a lot depends on how the next government takes some of these reforms forward, said Sridhar Sivaram, Investment Director, Enam Holdings, in an interview with ETNOW. Sivaram travelled in four states to find out the ground reality. Edited excerpts: 


How many kilometres have you travelled?
Almost 1,000 km over four weeks.


What is that one word you have come back with -- good, slowdown?
The consumption slowdown is there but different pockets had different sort of anecdotes. At least in Tamil Nadu, the TVS dealer mentioned that the demand in April has started to improve and in fact he was doing almost 20-25% growth for April, but it is very difficult to extrapolate that for the entire year or for a quarter. It could be because of the election effect. In certain other pockets like in UP, the slowdown was still there and there was inventory issue. The inventories were getting cleared so it was not like a clear view across the country. 




Is the slowdown cyclical or structural? Is this largely because of delay in decision making for funding, because of election or is this something which could be a prolonged two-three year slowdown because in the last five-seven years, we have not seen a marked slowdown in consumption. Is this the beginning of the slowdown cycle which we were fearing?
The sense that I got is this is more cyclical than structural because the funding issue is for real. When we spoke to people on the ground, it was very clear that they are getting this funding for two-wheelers or passenger vehicles very easily. Now the number of players available is much lesser and the credit criteria they are now asking for is much tighter. Plus GST related issues are not related to auto, but in other consumption sector, it still comes up that some of the smaller traders are still not very happy with the way GST is shaping up and the amount of filings that they have to do. 

A lot of it is cyclical because we have had a change of taxation structure and that takes about two-three years to stabilise. May be in another six months, whichever government comes, may end up benefiting from some of the reforms which have happened in the last two-three years which are having the teething issues right now, may stabilise and will benefit in six to 12 months time.


I notice you said whichever government comes to power... there is lots to read in between the lines…
I have no expertise as far as elections are concerned.


But at least you are not coming with a sure shot view after your entire roundtrip?

No, I mean it is very difficult to call and just doing four states or 1,000 km is hardly enough.


Four big states account for 50% of Lok Sabha seats -- Tamil Nadu, Uttar Pradesh, Bihar and Maharashtra.

 I can say that it looks like the market consensus may be right which is that the current regime will continue with a lower majority, but the big question mark is what happens to UP? There, depending on whom you spoke to, you got a range of 20 to 60 for BJP. It really was not very clear.


What is the market positioning one month ahead of the election? There is no euphoria this time unlike 2004 or 2014?
If you look at the broader market, that gives a better sentiment. If you leave out the 10 stocks and look at the broader market, it is clearly telling you that the positioning is very light. Nobody wants to go on 23rd with the heavy position. Even if you get a consensus view, my gut feel is that the market could rally a bit but keep in mind that there is also a slowdown. Eventually earnings have to come. If the earnings do not follow through that sort of a rally could be sold into. 

All I am trying to say is that fund managers, friends, nobody is sure of the outcome. We have seen in the past that election results could have volatile short-term movements and nobody wants to play that right now.


The US-China trade scenario has put the world under pressure. Tracking the US ten-year paper makes you feel like it is going to hit recession some time?
First my view on the tariff itself. I actually support US on the tariff. If I look at all the speeches of Trump, one of the phrases that he used is reciprocal, which is that if China is able to export so much to the US, then there should be a reciprocal arrangement for the US companies to do that also.


But they are inefficient, their wages are high. 
That is not true. You can allow Google and Facebook to start operation in China. None of the financial services companies are allowed to standalone, take a position or to operate in China. When it says reciprocal, it does not mean exactly in manufacturing itself. It could be services. Over the years, the US has a $500 billion trade deficit with China, which is unsustainable. I am surprised that the previous regimes have actually allowed it to go to this level. I have read some article saying only one mad man can handle another. Now I do not know what people are referring to here…


There are many of them out there.
I know. But I am just saying that you need some drastic steps to happen for this sort of equation to settle down. To that extent, I support what the US is doing. What happens to global trade in the interim? There will be turmoil but in the last 18 months, this trade talks has gone on. Market takes a knock for about a month or so and then they rallies back. 

The US is in a cycle where the Fed has completely turned from wanting to tighten to being open to a cut. If that is the global environment, then that is a great thing for emerging market. I will just add one more point here. UBS recently came out with the report and they have done a CEO survey of about five or seven countries including China and many of the ASEAN countries on this entire manufacturing and what happens? India has come out very highly on that as far as shift of manufacturing is concerned because China is becoming more and more expensive to manufacture. 

It is an opportunity for India, but not in the short term. This is a medium and long-term opportunity, provided India plays its cards well. The two ways of looking at it is in short term, there will be volatility and one has to brace for some volatile moves.


You are saying it is a justified move as of now at least…
 That is my personal view.


This ongoing economic slowdown is also appearing to affect the construction sector where activity has slowed down. How dangerous would that be for the overall economic growth? 

During my trip to Tamil Nadu, I found a different view. There cement demand grew more than 20% last year and cement dealer after dealer kept telling me that the demand is coming because of Pradhan Mantri Awas Yojana and that people are building houses there because there is a huge subsidy which the government is giving. The demand is not there in the big cities and towns, but it is there in the rural areas.

When speaking to some bureaucrats, the sense I got is that Tamil Nadu as a state has adopted central schemes very well irrespective of who is in the centre. If the scheme is very good for the state or for the people at large, they have adopted it very well and that is the sort of response I got. If other states are able to adopt, it is possible that cement demand could come up maybe in the next regime whoever comes and they take this forward. 

We could see demand come back as far as cement is concerned. But I agree that broadly there is a slowdown as far as the larger real estate is concerned and that remains a concern not only on the slowdown, but also on the way they have been funded. That is of concern for the market.


A very simple dipstick analysis tells us that NBFCs are not lending. There is going to be an asset liability mismatch. What happens if the entire NBFC wheel has already turned? 
My biggest concern for the market is actually the NBFCs and HFCs. I have been speaking about this for almost two years. Today my concern is not so much on the NBFCs especially the retail, my concern is more on the HFCs because of the way they are structured. Mortgage is only 60-65% of their book, rest is all builder and LAP. We do not know what is happening there because the regulation, because they come under NHB and it is a very weak regulator. We really do not know if the numbers being thrown out by some of these companies are true and fair. They are very similar to how the banks were three years back. 

None of us believe the NPA numbers. Today after what we see, most of us can say 90% of it is true. But for an HFC, a corporate facing or a body with large exposure to builders, we hardly see any NPA from builders. 

In my view there needs to be an AQR. People like Arvind Subramanian have also raised this point that there should be an AQR for HFCs and NBFCs. It is only then that confidence would return in this sector and funding will start. 

Incrementally, they are not getting funding. Maybe the top three-four are getting funding. The rest are not getting any funding. Barring the top three, mutual funds have shut shop for many of the other NBFCs. There is a trouble here. Whenever the new government comes, they, along with RBI have to figure out a way to resolve this mess. 


What are you buying which is looking distressed? Are you buying autos, consumers, metals because of the trade warfare?
So autos, yes, because as we think this is a cyclical slowdown and you are getting companies with brand, with cash flows, with no debt and at valuations which are fairly compelling right now.


Define what is attractive -- Eicher is 25 times, Maruti is 30 times, two-wheelers are teens?
You can look at the other two-wheelers also. I do not want to name companies but there are enough two-wheelers available which are...


Paanch to company hai total (there are five companies in total)?
That is for you to guess and the investors to guess. There is opportunity available there. I think that autos in general and auto ancillaries have corrected significantly. If auto were to come back, auto ancillaries will also come back. That is a space which looks quite interesting.


What about metals and consumption?
Metals are really stock-specific trades. I really cannot say that all of them will move together and we do have some exposure in metals, based on the past and we continue to hold many of them. 

On consumption, we are better off with discretionary than with staples. We prefer the discretionary consumption over staples because even through the stocks have corrected, but not significantly. Their earnings and volume growths have significantly corrected. If you see the last five, six results, volume growths have come off from double digits to single digit in some cases and low single digits,

That remains a concern and risk reward is not looking favourable right now there.


What about telecom? How do you approach this entire scenario now?
Normally, my view is when you have a pricing war between various players, you are better off being a consumer than a minority shareholder. I am enjoying all the data that I am getting right now.


Even with the leader?
Whether it is the leader or the follower, I am enjoying all the data that I am getting. I can watch anywhere, everywhere.


Not getting call drops?
That is the concern. When you have so much, your quality does go down but jokes apart, that is the broad view. It is very tough to take a call. 


There are sectors which have gone through serious pain; hotels, telecom, real estate. Will the leaders survive?
Of course.


There were 12 telecom players, now there are three. You can only buy two, one has got a bad balance sheet, one is still a formidable market leader. Does it make sense to take a slightly cyclical view?
Where the risk reward is good, it is worth it. I am not saying that we are completely away from telecom so that is an interesting sector where we know that maybe in a six to 12 months time things will change. This pricing war cannot continue for infinite time. The leader should be able to maintain his leadership position or at least profitability may come back. Those are risks one has to take as a fund manager. Some of them are reaching there from a value standpoint.


Sunil Mittal said in Davos his ambition is not to be the biggest but to be the most profitable telecom player and he actually quoted Kotak Mahindra Bank. What is your view?
Promoters have changed over the last 10 years. Ten years ago, most promoters wanted to diversify, get into a different country, do some other business. After the mayhem, better sense is prevailing and they are realising one is better off with core competency and small is fine. There is no point going into other businesses. But this awareness has come at the cost of a lot of pain to minority shareholders. 
I would say that it is good that sense is prevailing because even minority shareholders will make money in the long run. 


In the next two to three months, do you think all this euphoria around the election would settle down? The trade war would be in the price and the markets would be back to attempting a fresh high or not in such a hurry?
Honestly, it is a very tough to call to take in the short term because we have seen in the past that event risks have such volatile movements in the market that even if I want, I will not be able to make a constructive assessment of that. All I can say is that in the medium-term, India is poised and looks interesting. 

The tax to GDP could possibly go up because of the way GST is structured and we could see more collections as time goes by. I did meet the GST commissioner in Tamil Nadu and he was very happy with the GST collections and in fact he suggested that I do not even want to do any raids because collections are quite good.


So in six months it will all settle down?
Exactly. Once it settles down, we will see more people in the tax net and once GST settles down, people will be happy that they are getting offsets, they are getting more funding because they are coming under GST. Markets look poised for a rally but a lot depends on how the next government takes some of these reforms forward.

Quantum SecuritiesI will remain positive on capital goods and engineering and infrastructure space, said Neeraj Dewan, Director, Quantum Securities, in an interview with ETNOW. Edited excerpts:

US is going ahead with the tariff hikes against China. What will be the implications in terms of impact on equities?
What happens globally definitely has an impact on India though we are not directly impacted by the trade tariffs put up by US on China. Once this comes through, then there can be some pressure on global growth which will in turn have an impact on the flows which are coming to emerging markets. In the last few days, the FII flow figures have been negative. They have been selling again.

The renewed buying which we were hoping for may not come if the tariffs and reciprocal tariffs are imposed and global growth concerns come back, People will be more cautious and liquidity will not be that great. 

Domestically also, we have very important cues coming up, which is showing up in slowdown in FMCG stocks. One would like to be cautious for some more time.


Do you think the slowdown is priced in Eicher Motors? We are not going in with very gung-ho expectations. Where does Eicher go from here?
One good thing about the numbers that have been coming in from the auto pack is that we know what to expect. Expectations are low and the stock has already corrected from the high levels. The valuations are now more reasonable. Even if the numbers are muted as expected, unless and until there is a very significant downside on the numbers, the stock will not react in a big way on the negative side. The stock may in fact bounce back also because bad numbers are already priced in.


What about Reliance? Do you buy this decline or do you wait it out because of concerns with regard to the huge debt on the balance sheet and the core business not contributing as much?
I would wait it out because you are not getting that FII flow back. In the last couple of months, the market was doing well because FII money was chasing these four-five stocks, and they were becoming more expensive. Now because that buying has stopped or selling is back, these positions are getting reversed. 

More or less the concerns regarding their core business, oil and gas business, is also there in the stock. Though I am positive on the telecom and the retail front, I would be a buyer at some point but I would wait it out. The stock may not correct a lot but there can be some time correction in the stock.

.I will see when the circumstances are reflecting that you are getting a renewed buying coming back from institutions and then Reliance can again get back on the radar as far as buying is concerned from FIIs. 


Why do you feel FMCG could be a potential sector to look at?
There are concerns on the global front. There are concerns on the domestic growth front as well. We are not very sure of what is going to happen on the political front. So everything is negative and we are only looking at the negative part. 

But FMCG stocks, specifically staples, have actually been trading at very high valuations. And because of this slowdown, it is an opportunity where we are getting them at decent valuation. Stocks like Hindustan Lever, Dabur, Godrej Consumer, have corrected and their performance have been very great. 

There can be one or two quarters here and there but if you see a trend over the last three to five years, the CAGR growth have been tremendous and the volume growth is also picking up for most of these companies. These are the opportunities where we are getting these companies at decent valuations. We are getting these companies at 35 or less than 35 times next year earnings. That is the opportunity to buy some of these companies.


What about corporate banks? I understand that some of these corporate banks are longer-term plays but in the near term, the market is still a little nervous when it comes to financials?
Yes, the market is nervous because the liquidity crisis has again come back post September. We had this fear of liquidity crisis which we are going through now, plus a lot of these corporates have pledged shares and exposure to some of these corporate banks. So, that concern is there. 

But the major part of the concern is that a lot of these things have already again been priced in some of these corporate banks. One needs to be very selective when you are looking at corporate banks also. 

There will be the largecaps which have all again corrected, even a bank like State Bank of India. 

There are other parts of banks which are exposed to MSME lending. We like some of the stocks which were lending to MSMEs because MSME as a sector has come out of a lot of trouble in the last three, four years because of GST and demonetisation. 

Now that they are out of all that trouble, again that sector is picking up. Some corporate banks which are exposed to them have opportunities in that sector also. One needs to be selective but at this price also, there are opportunities even from a medium to long-term perspective. 


Looking at a liquidity squeeze coming up, would you be bullish on cyclicals, infra, capital goods pockets?
Yes, because there are two factors; one is that interest rates are still low and the order books are very healthy. So once you are out of this election period, you are going to get that capex cycle coming back again. It may have slowed down temporarily and the coming back may take a quarter or two, but I am positive looking at the order books and looking at the interest rate scenario because of low inflation in the country, it is bound to come back. 

A lot of the private sector also had held to their capex because of the liquidity crisis in the last quarter, last year plus because of the impending elections.

Capex also has to come back and though it may have got delayed by a quarter or two, it is very much on the cards and it should come in the next two, three quarters. I will remain positive on capital goods and engineering and infrastructure space.

Eicher Motors on Friday reported 18 per cent year-on-year rise in profit at Rs 544.84 crore for the quarter ended March 31. Analysts in an ET NOW poll had projected a profit of Rs 542 crore.

The company had posted a net of Rs 461.53 crore in the corresponding quarter last year.

Consolidated revenue from operations, however, fell to Rs 2,500.08 crore from Rs 2,528.01 crore in the corresponding period last year. Ebitda of the company declined 14 per cent YoY to Rs 685 crore.

The board of the company also recommended a final dividend aggregating Rs 341.03 crore (or Rs 125 per share) for the financial year ended March 31. The payout stood at Rs 299.93 crore, or Rs 110 per share last year.

The company announced its earnings post market hours. Earlier in the day, the scrip closed 0.23 per cent higher at Rs 20,329.25 apiece.

The company sold 1,97,567 Royal Enfield motorcycles during March quarter, registering a decline of 13 per cent from 2,26,907 units in the same period last year.

“The latter half of 2018 was a challenging period for the two-wheeler industry with factors such as revision in insurance cost, increase in prices on account of new safety norms, affected consumer sentiment. At Royal Enfield, we recorded flat sales volumes after several years of augmented sales growth. Despite a challenging fourth quarter, the trend of premiumisation continues to show significant potential,” said Siddhartha Lal, Managing Director of Eicher Motors.

In the commercial vehicles space, VE Commercial Vehicles (VECV) -- Eicher’s joint venture with Volvo -- was affected by the industry slowdown, especially in the later part of the year.

For the quarter ended March 31, VECV’s revenue from operations was 3 per cent lower at Rs 3,209 crore against Rs 3,317 crore in the same period last year.

The unit’s Ebitda declined 13 per cent to Rs 274 crore from Rs 315 crores in the same period last year. Profit after tax slipped 22 per cent to Rs 139 crore from Rs 177 crore on a yearly basis.

VECV sold 21,010 trucks and buses during the quarter, registering a decline of 9 per cent YoY.

On VECV’s performance, Siddhartha said: “While registering a decline in the fourth quarter, VECV finished the year at par with the industry growth of 12 per cent. The market conditions were adverse due to all-time high price discounting. VECV entered Indonesia and South Africa with Kuzer under the UD brand. We continue to believe that we can be the catalyst to drive modernisation of commercial transportation in India and other developing markets.”

NEW DELHI: Nifty futures on the Singapore Exchange were trading 8 points, or 0.07 per cent, lower at 11,3334, indicating a flat start for the Nifty50. Here are a few stocks, which may bizz the most in today’s trade:


SBI, L&T: State Bank of India (SBI), Larsen & Toubro (L&T), Eicher Motors, Allahabad Bank, Canara Bank, PVR, Oberoi Realty, Syndicate Bank, Vakrangee and Venky’s will be among a few companies, which will disclose their March quarter results today.


Reliance Industries: The Mukesh Ambani-led company said it will acquire iconic British toy-maker Hamleys for 67.96 million pounds (around Rs 620 crore) in an all-cash deal.


Tata Motors: The auto maker denied reports that said the company is in the process of selling its British arm Jaguar Land Rover (JLR) to French automotive major PSA Groupe.


HCL Technologies: The IT services major posted a 14.3 per cent rise in its consolidated net profit at Rs 2,550 crore for the March 2019 quarter and set an "aspirational" annual revenue target of more than USD 10-billion (about Rs 70,258 crore) in FY2019-20.


Mindtree: Larsen & Toubro, the country’s largest engineering and construction conglomerate, said it won’t increase its offer of Rs 980 per share to acquire control of Mindtree, having already built in an adequate premium over the fair value of the stock.


Jet Airways: Concluding that the transactions of Jet Airways are of 'suspicious' in nature and require a thorough probe, the Mumbai regional office of the Ministry of Corporate Affairs (MCA) last week submitted its report recommending a detailed investigation into the affairs of the company, source in the know told ET.


Sundram Fasteners: The company has set up a wholly owned subsidiary to tap the aerospace and defence segments. Sunfast TVS Ltd would focus on aerospace and defence sectors, the city-based TVS Group firm said in a release.


HCC: Hindustan Construction Company (HCC) posted a standalone loss of Rs 427.87 crore for the fourth quarter ended March 31, 2019.


Voltas: The Tata Group firm said its consolidated net profit has fallen a 27 per cent to Rs 141.74 crore for the fourth quarter ended March 2019.


PVR: Multiplex chain operator PVR Cinemas plans to add 35 screens to its premium portfolio in the next 18-20 months, a top company official said.


Kalptaru Power Transmission (KPTL): The company reported a 30 per cent rise in its standalone net profit to Rs 136.88 crore in the fourth quarter ended March 31, helped by higher income.


ICRA: The domestic rating agency reported 5.2 per cent decline in consolidated net profit at Rs 26.10 crore for March quarter. The company said it has hired an independent investigative agency to probe charges of meddling in the rating of the failed Infrastructure Leasing & Financial Services Ltd, without naming it. 


South Indian Bank: The private sector lender reported a fall of 38 per cent in net profit at Rs 70.51 crore for the March quarter due to a rise in bad loans.


JSW Steel: The company said its crude steel output grew two percent to 13.93 lakh tonne (LT) during April 2019.


Granules India: The company said its profit after tax for the quarter ended March 31 was up by 213 per cent to Rs 64 crore against Rs 20 crore.


Solar Industries: The company reported 11 percent increase in net profit for the quarter ended March 31 at Rs 75 crore as against Rs 68 crore in the corresponding period last fiscal and hopes to maintain the growth outlook at over 20 percent in FY20.

Analyst calls
• Edelweiss has maintained buy rating on KEC International with a target price of ₹350. KEC's fourth quarter numbers were a mixed bag-while revenue and EBITDA missed estimates, balance sheet improvement was encouraging, said Edelweiss. While order book and order pipeline are healthy, the management's 15-20% revenue guidance for FY20 looks a tad on the lower side, probably indicating persistence of a few domestic execution challenges, the brokerage said..

• Anand Rathi has maintained buy rating on Visaka Industries with a target price of ₹495. Higher selling and branding expenses along with losses due to a delay in the Jhajjar plant commencement and losses in ATUM resulted in Visaka’s restrained operating performance in the fourth quarter, said Anand Rathi. The yarn division’s better performance is another positive, said Anand Rathi. 

• CLSA has maintained sell rating on Shriram Transport Finance Company with a target price of ₹ 960. The brokerage expects a pick-up towards second half with 14%-15% growth in AUM in FY20-21. Asset quality showed some improvement with a fall in stage-3 loans to 8.4%, but the brokerage is concerned by aggressive growth in rural markets and business loans. Clarity on the group structure is awaited and may be a medium-term overhang, said CLSA. The stock ended up 0.29% at ₹1,030.85 on Thursday.

• Jefferies has maintained hold rating on Titan Company with a target price of ₹1,100. Titan continues to execute strongly in terms of design aspect, new customer acquisition and store expansion coupled with strong market share gains continuing since demonetisation given industry headwinds, said Jefferies. 

• Kotak Institutional Equities has maintained buy rating on Brigade Enterprises with a target price of ₹290. Brigade ended FY19 with a strong performance on the residential business, with 83% YoY growth in pre-sales at ₹16.5 billion and an exit quarter performance of ₹5.2 billion, aspiring for a 30% YoY increase in FY20 on the higher base, the brokerage said.

NEW DELHI: Nifty futures on the Singapore Exchange were trading 34 points, or 0.30 per cent, lower at 11,249.50, indicating a negative start for the Nifty50. Here are a few stocks, which may buzz the most in today’s trade:


HDFC, ITC: Idea Voda, HDFC, ITC, Karnataka Bank, MRPL, Oriental Bank, Just Dial, Inox Leisure, Andhra Bank and United Bank are a few companies which will announce their quarterly results on Monday.


Voda Idea, SBI Life: India’s three newly listed insurers — ICICI Lombard General Insurance, SBI Life Insurance, HDFC Life Insurance — and RBL Bank and Info Edge (India) could be included in MSCI India index in the upcoming re-balancing scheduled later this month. Vodafone Idea and Cadila Healthcare could exit.


L&T: Larsen & Toubro’s (L&T) March quarter earnings came in line with market expectations as the infra major reported a 7.91 per cent year-on-year rise in profit at Rs 3,418.24 crore. Analysts in an ET NOW poll had projected a profit of Rs 3,414 crore. The company maintained its revenue growth and order inflow guidance at 12-15 per cent and 10-12 per cent for FY20. 


Eicher Motors: Eicher Motorson reported 18 per cent year-on-year rise in profit at Rs 544.84 crore for the quarter ended March 31. Analysts in an ET NOW poll had projected a profit of Rs 542 crore. 


PC Jeweller: The company said its board has given approval for the demerger of the company's export division and amalgamation of the same with its wholly-owned subsidiary PCJ Gems & Jewellery.


NIIT Technologies: Hulst B V, which has signed a deal to acquire about 30 per cent stake in 
NIIT Technologies, has received approvals from anti-trust authorities in Germany and the US for the transaction, as per a regulatory filing on Friday.


SRF: Chemical engineering firm SRF has agreed to sell its engineering plastics business to Dutch conglomerate DSM for Rs 320 crore as part of a strategy to focus on core operation. The Gurugram-based company is a chemical based multi-business entity engaged in the manufacturing of industrial and specialty intermediates.


Era Infrastructure: The National Company Law Tribunal (NCLT) has rejected ICICI Bank’s plea to initiate insolvency proceedings against Era Infrastructure (India) on the grounds of “duplicacy” of claims.


Torrent Pharma: Drug firm Torrent Pharma Inc is recalling over 8.82 lakh bottles of Losartan Potassium tablets, used for the treatment of hypertension, from the US and Puerto Rico markets on account of deviations from the current good manufacturing norms, according to a report by the US health regulator.

NEW DELHI: Shares of Eicher Motors declined over 7 per cent in trade on Monday after the company on Friday reported an 18 per cent year-on-year rise in profit at Rs 544.84 crore for the quarter ended March 31. 

The board of the company also recommended a final dividend aggregating Rs 341.03 crore (or Rs 125 per share) for the financial year ended March 31. 

The numbers it seems have failed to excite the market. Brokerage HDFC Securities has maintained its sell recommendation on the stock with a target price of Rs 18,900. 

"We reiterate sell as Royal Enfield’s over 30 per cent margins are behind in our view. We are building in 27.7/27.5 per cent over FY20/21 for RE business, respectively," said the brokerage.

The brokerage sees the demand environment to be weak even as competition (Jawa) has commenced product deliveries. New product launches and foreign forays are time-consuming, with returns expected with a lag and earnings growth falling to single digit over FY19-21E, the brokerage said.

Edelweiss has maintained its buy recommendation on the stock but cut the target price to Rs 23,386 from Rs 23,781. "Our FY19–21E EPS CAGR of 21 per cent factors weak volume growth in FY20, followed by pick up in FY21 as the premiumisation trend sustains," said the brokerage.

Shares of Eicher Motors closed 7.69 per cent down at Rs 18,766.35 on BSE.

Very few good performing names of the earlier midcap cycle are continuing to do well in the next one. You have to wipe the slate clean and relook at the market, said Prateek Agarwal, Business Head & Chief Investment Officer, ASK Investment Manager, in an interview with ETNOW.Edited excerpts:

Last week, there was a 4% fall in the index. Considering US-China trade talks are still uncertain and in the run up to the election outcome back home, what do you expect from the market this week?
Yes, that would be a fair assessment. US-China trade talks on the margin may actually help other countries, including India. But while there is uncertainty about China being such a large part of the emerging market basket, when people pull out monies from the emerging market funds and if the fund manager sells across-the-board, then even India ends up selling. 

This is something where the short term and the medium term conflicts happen in the market. For some time, till the trade issues settle, we should be expecting continued selling. Moreover, political uncertainty will go in 10-odd days but then also, the result season has been lacklustre, the breadth of the good, nice, positive numbers are not there. We are seeing a slowdown and the market is reflecting that.


Are you sticking to Bajaj Finance, L&T, HDFC, HDFC Bank or do you think this is the time to start buying midcaps now?
We are sticking to the earlier names that you suggested. We do not believe this is the time to look at midcaps. Midcaps for the new cycle will emerge. The classic thing that one has to remember in midcaps is that very few good performing names of the earlier cycle are continuing to do well in the next one. You have to wipe the slate clean and relook at the market and time for that will come in the future. It is just not there as of now.


The traditional defensive plays are not really providing an opportunity apart from select names here and there. Where does one go and look for a safe haven in a market like this?
One area in the marketplace where you get a combination of some amount of valuation comfort and continued strong growth is financials. Apart from names in the NBFC and banking space, names in the insurance and mutual fund space interest us. Given the low penetration, these spaces can continue to grow very strongly for several years. We also like companies which are exposed to the microfinance space where the supply versus demand still is a very large gap. So this is one big area of interest.

While the consumption space lacks valuation comfort, certain niche companies in the jewellery space, are nicely positioned. We are looking for companies which are dominating the spaces which are growing well. In this space, Titan is very nicely positioned and is something that interests us for sure.


We are looking at earnings. Although L&T guidance, the order flow were impressive, the stock is down. Eicher Motors was a mixed bag. Margins were a dampener and the stock is sharply lower. Where within autos are you finding an opportunity?
In autos, you get monthly numbers and you are prepared for the quarterly numbers. Thus, quarterly numbers themselves will not impact the stock prices too much. What happens or is continuing to happen in terms of numbers on a monthly basis is what causes concerns and impacts. We believe that a period of slowdown will continue in autos. We have reduced our exposure to the space. 

We believe the slowdown will be there because of several reasons; one, cities still account for over 40% part of auto sales and in most cities, there is no place to drive, people are leaving cars home and taking public transport. So, where is the need to buy a new one? 

Two, the overall cost of ownership has gone up considerablly. It is not only fuel prices, parking prices have moved up sharply and in many parts, you have to own a parking. The parking may cost more than the car itself. 

Third, the electrical vehicles (EV) are coming in. Anything that you buy just now may just look fuddy-duddy over the next one or two years. Some people may be pausing for that as well, apart from the price increase and the taxation increase and the insurance led price increase. 

We believe there is some slowdown to be expected. We believe the biggest reason is the low ability to drive on roads. A the infrastructure gets built and roads get freer, we would again see a bump-up in car sales.


Are you sitting on cash or significantly higher cash in the runup to the election? Is it better to protect right now? This is a market which is reasonably priced and there is a marked slowdown in consumers. So, even if markets like the verdict, Nifty will not go to 15,000 very soon. What do you do in this kind of a scenario?
We stay fully invested, but I am sure our investors are keeping money on the sidelines. That is something that we are definitely feeling. Any large investor that we speak to, wants the election uncertainty to be over before committing their entire money. We continue to get flows but a large part of that flows are happening through systematic transfer plans. Not everything has been put into the market immediately. 

That said, we are also telling investors who have to invest into the equity markets -- people who can stay on the sidelines forever, it does not apply to them -- that invest on both the legs of the elections. I agree with you valuations are not cheap, just about defendable at this juncture. If the verdict is as per what the market desires, you would get 8%-9% kind of a bump-up quickly and then post elections, the ability to invest the entire money after elections would not be there. People will be worrying on the valuations much more than they are doing now. So, we are actually telling people to invest on both the legs of the election outcome.


We are watching out also for ITC today. Any kind of concern that is building up as you view these counters?
We understand that the NBFC slowdown or credit crunch is impacting FMCGs, which have a higher percentage of distributor-led sales. Companies like Levers. who are able to address or own most of their distribution network and do not rely so much on the distributor-led model, are less impacted, whereas other companies where this percentage is higher are more impacted because the NBFCs fund a lot of distributors and there may be a cash crunch. 

If distributors are unable to pick stuff from the wholesalers or from the company, the stuff is not getting pushed into the end shops. That is the reading that we have. It should get addressed as the liquidity position in the NBFC space gets addressed. We believe it will take some time so anybody who is looking at the space should be prepared for that. That said, elections are on and there will be a lot of spending post elections. With the money that people now have in the bank account on account of that Rs 6,000 the government is already sending to farmers, that should have some impact on the smaller category consumption items like small electrical, heaters, electric wires apart from FMCG stuff and that is a part we are focussed on.

Banking is where the cheer is and non-BFSI is probably where the real drag is at this moment, said Jagannadham Thunuguntla, Senior Vice President and Head of Research, Centrum Broking, in an interview with ETNOW.Edited excerpts:


Anything from the earnings this weekend that may have stood out for you besides L&T?
One should keep an eye on the overall Nifty 50 earnings. As we speak, 25 companies have posted the results and the BFSI numbers are appearing to be quite robust and probably can compensate for the slowdown that it is clearly witnessed in the non-BFSI space. The non-BFSI earnings have grown just 5% out of the 18 companies that they have posted. In the BFSI space, on the other hand, be it because of the low base effect or the losses that the banks have posted over the last few years and few quarters, banking is appearing to be a reasonably positioned. 

But by the end of the season, at least at the Nifty 50 level, we may have at best a stable or muted earning season. We have to live with it because Nifty had rallied so much to justify the valuations and to stay for the Nifty at the elevated levels. It may be a difficult place. There was a lot of damage at the midcap and smallcap related earning season, though all in all, we will have to wait for few more quarters for the uptick to take place. Banking is where the cheer is and non-BFSI is probably where the real drag is at this moment. 


Given that the market has been a little nervous about the squeeze with regards to NBFCs, and the corporate affairs secretary has talked about how we may see further turmoil there. On the other hand, earnings have been fairly stable for some key corporate banks. What is your take away?
In terms of the NBFC point, we firmly believe that the Capital First and IDFC transaction which went through and successfully created the merger, probably may not become the template for each and every transaction out there. I am sure RBI will go through each and every transaction on its merits. Many relatively not-so-strong banks are looking for merger so that they will have the NBFC platform and NBFCs are looking at an opportunity to enter into banking in an indirect manner. 

While there is credible win-win situation for both banks and NBFCs in this kind of arrangement, we have to ensure whether all the mergers will really make sense from the overall compliance and the overall banking industry positioning point of view. We have to take it very slowly. Investors will have to keep an eye on how RBI approaches the whole thing. 

I personally believe IDFC and Capital First was probably relatively easier decision for the RBI to take and for some of the other mergers that are on the table, probably RBI will take more thoughtful decisions in terms of how to go about. 

As for PSU related bankings and the earnings season, SBI because of the heavy provisioning that they have done in the previous quarters, turned into profit this time. That was good to see. But, as we speak, more and more commercial paper related and liquidity related issues keep coming almost on a daily basis. Till the time, that settles down, it will be difficult to believe whether the banking and especially the PSU banking related issues are out of the woods. 

As we speak, a lot of repair work has been done over the last two to three years and that is definitely working in favour of banking.


 How closely are you tracking some of the earnings that we have seen this time? What is your strategy on some of these names -- be it discretionary like auto or FMCG?
Even before the earning season started, the slowdown in the auto industry was quite evident and the best part is, the market entered the earning season expecting very muted earning season from the auto sector. But what came as clear surprise in the current earnings season is the stark slowdown on the consumption theme. 

It is right in the face and very difficult to ignore. Make no mistake, the India story has been clearly the consumption theme in the last four-five or may be 10 years or so. That entire story is coming under a big question mark and those stocks are not undervalued. In the consumption space, It is very difficult to find any stock below 40 times or 50 times price to earnings. Keeping that into account, if things do not improve soon, I think there is a very risk of de-rating on the consumption theme. 

Let us hope that post elections the confidence will be back and once the liquidity settles down, hopefully, consumption will come back. Else, we may be witnessing a de-rating of some of the popular consumption names. Whether we like it or not, they hold majority percentage holdings in many mutual funds and many large portfolios in India. The portfolios may start underperforming. The underperformance in Nifty can be quite stark if the consumption related stocks start doing badly. It is at a very critical crossroads. 


What did you make of Eicher’s numbers? Do you buy this decline in Eicher just yet?
The volume growth in Eicher Motors has been very slow for quite some time. That is likely to continue and as we discussed, the stock is by no means undervalued. Probably, some more pain may be evident. And that is true across the auto sector. 

In the case of Eicher Motors, because of heavy dependence on single brand and single model, that probably will speak more. So more time is needed for auto stocks to move aggressively.

But having said that, it is a clear contrarian theme at this juncture. Keep it more from the accumulation point of view as you will get your opportunities at much lower levels. There is no need to be aggressive there.
