By Chandan Taparia 
Nifty continued its weakness for the ninth consecutive session as every bounce got sold into in the market on Monday. The index formed a bearish candle on the daily scale and continued to form lower highs and lows for past six sessions, indicating weakness.

As long as it remains below 11,350 level, weakness could continue towards 11,088 and then 11,000 levels, while on the upside hurdles are seen in the 11,320 -11,350 zone.

On the options front, maximum Put open interest was at 11,000 followed by 10,500 levels, while maximum Call OI was at 12,000 followed by 11,800 level. There was Call writing at 11,500 followed by 11,700 levels, while minor put writing was seen at strike price 11,200. The Option band signified a shift in the lower trading range to 11,000-1600 zones.

India VIX moved up 3.09 per cent to 27.15 level. A higher VIX suggests volatile swings could continue in the market till the election outcome.

Bank Nifty consolidated for most part of the day but witnessed strong selling pressure in the last hour of the session. It formed a Bearish Candle on daily scale and failed to hold above 28,888 level, as it extended losses and headed towards 28,600 level. As long as it holds below 28,888, the index could continue its weakness towards 28,500 and then 28,388 levels, while on the upside, hurdles are seen at 29,000 and then 29,250 levels.

Nifty futures closed in the negative at 11,185 with a loss of 1.08 per cent. Long buildup was seen in Tata Global Beverages, Bata India, IndiGo and Titan while shorts were seen in Canara Bank, Indian Bank, STAR and Eicher Motors.

(Chandan Taparia is Technical & Derivative Analyst at MOFSL. Investors are advised to consult financial advisers before taking an investment calls based on these observations)

NEW DELHI: Marking its longest losing streak since 2011, equity benchmark Nifty closed with a deep cut for the ninth session in a row on Monday. 

Speculations over the US-China trade talks and uncertainty over the outcome of India's general election kept the market depressed.

“Investors are keeping themselves away, as there is ambiguity over US-China trade talks. Uncertainty over election results is another factor making investors nervous,” said Pankaj Pandey, Head of Research, ICICIdirect.

Sensex fell 372 points, or 0.99 per cent, to 37,090 while Nifty closed 131 points, or 1.16 per cent, lower at 11,148. In the last nine sessions, both Sensex and Nifty have plunged 5 per cent each.


We walk you through the highlights of Monday's session:

Rs 8.5 lakh crore gone so farIn the market fall in last nine sessions, investors have lost over Rs 8.5 lakh crore as overall market capitalisation has dropped to Rs 1,44,55,039.74 crore from Rs 1,53,08,828.49 crore on April 26. On Monday alone, investors lost nearly Rs 2.12 lakh crore.


300 stocks hit 52-week lowsMahindra & Mahindra, Sun Pharma, Bharat Forge, Biocon, Cadila Healthcare, CEAT, Eicher Motors, IDBI Bank, Wockhardt, Reliance Capital, Phillips Carbon Black and Motherson Sumi Systems were among the 289 stocks that hit 52-week lows on BSE. Meanwhile, DCM Shriram, Merck and MT Educare were among the 25 stocks that touched 52-week highs.


PSU bank, pharma pack tankWhile the selloff was widespread, PSU banks and pharma stocks were among the worst hit. Nifty PSU Bank index closed 5 per cent down, finishing the day as top sectoral loser. It was followed by Nifty Pharma index, which lost 4.37 per cent. The pharma pack as a whole reacted to reports of a lawsuit against Teva Pharma and 19 other generic companies in the US. Names of some Indian companies in the lawsuit spooked investors. 


HDFC shares rise on Q4 numbersShares of HDFC closed 1.06 per cent higher at Rs 1,951, ending as top gainer in the Sensex pack, as better-than-expected March quarter numbers buoyed investor sentiment. The company reported a 26.80 per cent year-on-year rise in standalone profit at Rs 2,861 crore, which was better than Rs 2,600 crore profit that analysts had estimated in an ETNow poll. 


Jet shares nosedive 8%Breaking the winning streak of the last three sessions, shares of Jet Airways closed 8.14 per cent down at Rs 139.45 after media reports said a buyout offer from Etihad Airways was non-binding and might not guarantee a deal for Jet.


ITC falls 3% after Q4 resultsShares of ITC closed 2.64 per cent down at Rs 289.85, extending losses into the fifth session, as the FMCG major reported an 18.73 per cent year-on-year (YoY) rise in profit at Rs 3,481.90 crore compared with Rs 2,932.71 crore net reported for the same quarter last year. 


L&T shares down 3%Shares of Larsen & Toubro (L&T) fell 2.81 per cent to close at Rs 1,317 after the company last Friday reported a 7.91 per cent year-on-year rise in profit (attributable to owners). Brokerages offered mixed views on the numbers and its growth prospects in FY20. YES Securities has downgraded the stock to ‘hold’ with a target price of Rs 1,469. 


Eicher Motors plunges 8%Shares of Eicher Motors ended 7.69 per cent down at Rs 18,766 after the company on Friday reported an 18 per cent year-on-year rise in profit at Rs 545 crore for the quarter ended March 31. The numbers failed to excite the market. Brokerage HDFC Securities has maintained its ‘sell’ recommendation on the stock with a target price of Rs 18,900. 


61 stocks ready to fallMomentum indicator moving average convergence divergence, or MACD, showed bearish crossovers on 61 counters on BSE, signalling that these stocks may fall in the coming sessions. Among them were CG Power, BPCL, Karur Vysya Bank, Hexaware Technologies, DCB Bank, Tata Chemicals and SBI Life Insurance. On the other hand, Vimta Labs, Mahindra CIE Auto, Apoorva Leasing Finance and Elnet Technologies were among the 32 stocks that showed bullish crossovers. 


ITC, L&T below 200-DMAsITC, Larsen & Toubro, India Cements, Aurobindo Pharm, Syndicate Bank, Indian Oil Corporation, BEML, Allahabad Bank, Indiabulls Real Estate, Canara Bank and Union Bank were among the stocks that witnessed negative breakouts and traded below their 200-DMAs on Monday.

ET Intelligence Group: The stock of Eicher Motors hit a 52-week low of Rs 18,600 on Monday after the maker of iconic motor bike Royal Enfield reported a nineyear low volume growth for FY19. The stock closed the session at Rs 18,766.4 on the BSE, 7.7 per cent lower than the previous day’s close.

The company has enjoyed premium price-earnings multiple over the past few years due to its pricing power, premium models and sustainable operating margin above 30 per cent, which were nearly double than the mass market bike makers. However, each of these factors now appears to be under threat.

The Royal Enfield volume fell by 14 per cent year-on-year to 1.9 lakh units in the March 2019 quarter, the second quarterly decline in a row. For the full year, it was measly 0.7 per cent higher at 8.26 lakh units, the lowest in at least nine years. The volume of the top-selling bike Classic 350, which accounts for nearly two-thirds of sales dropped by 5 per cent in FY19; a few years ago, the waiting time for its delivery was 8-10 weeks.

The volume growth in the last fiscal year was impacted due to higher cost of ownership on account of new safety norms and higher insurance cost. The pressure on volume is likely to persist in the medium term as demand in urban markets moves closer to the saturation point. In the post-earnings conference call, the company said for the first time inquiries in mature markets have declined. Royal Enfield added 90 dealers in the previous fiscal taking the total number to 915.

The company expects to grow production by 13 per cent to 9.5 lakh units for FY20. The street seems to have little belief in the guidance since most analysts expect flat to low-single-digit volume growth for the year. Kotak Institutional Equities and Nomura see projected volume of 8.1and 8.2 lakh units, respectively, for the current fiscal year, which implies a decline in volumes.

In response to rising costs due to regulatory measures, the company has increased prices of Classic 350 by 11-14 per cent since December 2017. The margin at EBITDA (operating margin before depreciation) level fell to 27.8 per cent in the March quarter from 32.3 per cent in the year-ago quarter. The company’s EBITDA margin remained in the range of 30-32 per cent over the past 10 quarters, and in the previous two quarters it fell below 30 per cent. The company expects margin between 25 per cent and 30 per cent in the coming quarters.

Given these factors, the stock has undergone major resetting of volume and margin expectations. The projected earnings per share for the current fiscal is revised downwards by 23 per cent in the past nine months. In June 2018, 71 per cent of the analysts tracking the stock had a ‘buy’ rating. The proportion has dropped to 41 per cent since then.

The stock has underperformed the benchmark indices by over 37 per cent in the past year, and the trend is unlikely to reverse in the nearterm. The stock traded at 20 times the 12-month projected earnings on Monday, a 36 per cent discount to the long-term average.

NEW DELHI: Equity benchmarks Sensex and Nifty broke a 9-day losing spell on Tuesday as global sentiment improved after the US and China agreed to continue talks to find a resolution to their trade dispute.

"Such rallies confirm that the market has come to terms with the fact that trade war is here to stay and even as the long-term impact can dent profitability of some of the Indian corporates, not much damage will be done to stock prices in the short term," said Umesh Mehta, Head of Research, Samco Securities. 

Besides, rupee's rise against the US dollar and softer crude oil prices also influenced investor sentiment, triggering a fresh spell of buying in afternoon trade. 

Heavyweights Reliance Industries, ICICI Bank, HDFC and ITC were the top contributors to the rise in Sensex index, in that order.


Let's take a look at the highlights of Tuesday's session:

333 stocks hit 52-week lowsEven as the market managed to close the day with decent gains, as many as 333 stocks hit 52-week lows on BSE. Among them were Hero MotoCorp, Vodafone Idea, Mahindra & Mahindra, Amara Raja Batteries, Apollo Tyres, Bharat Forge, Bosch, Cadila Healthcare, Eicher Motors, JK Tyre, Motherson Sumi Systems and Tata Elxsi. Meanwhile, Atul, DCB Bank, Merck and SRF were among the 24 stocks that hit 52-week highs.


Jet shares fall 7%Extending the losses into the second successive session, shares of Jet Airways ended 7.42 per cent down at Rs 129.10 after it said its Deputy Chief Executive and Chief Financial Officer Amit Agarwal has resigned due to personal reasons. Post market hours, the company said its CEO Vinay Dube has also resigned from the company. In the last two sessions, shares of the company have come off 15 per cent. 


Vodafone Idea down 3%Shares of Vodafone Idea closed 3.11 per cent lower at Rs 14 after global brokerage CLSA cut the target price on the stock to Rs 12.50 from Rs 27 while maintaining a ‘sell’ recommendation after the company's March quarter numbers. The brokerage said the company missed on revenues and its operating metrics look weak. 


HDFC shares extend gainsShares of HDFC logged gains for the third consecutive session, ending the day 1.10 per cent higher at Rs 1,973.25. The stock gained 3 per cent in the last three days. The company reported a 27 per cent increase in profit for the quarter ended March 201p which received a thumbs-up from brokerages. Global brokerage CLSA said HDFC is its top pick among NBFCs. 


Airtel shares jump 5%Shares of Bharti Airtel closed with a strong gain of 5.40 per cent at Rs 335.75 after, as per a PTI report, the company tweaked its post-paid plans, a move that involves gradual phasing out of offerings that are less than Rs 499 and retaining limited number of plans above it. The move is expected to help the company chase better realisation from mobile subscribers while improving its Average Revenue Per User (ARPU).


ITC snaps 5-day losing streakBreaking the losing streak of 5 successive sessions, shares of ITC settled 1.43 per cent up at Rs 294, a day after the FMCG firm reported Rs 3,481 crore profit in line with a Rs 3,201 crore profit estimate that analysts had made in an ET NOW poll. Macquarie and Credit Suisse have 'outperform' ratings on the stock with target prices of Rs 376 and 370, respectively. On the other hand, Morgan Stanley and JP Morgan have 'overweight' ratings with target prices of Rs 320 and 340, respectively.


Siemens shares rise after 6 daysAfter six successive sessions of losses, shares of Siemens rose 3.38 per cent to close at Rs 1,086, buoyed by its better-than-expected March quarter results. The company posted 27.6 per cent jump in net profit at Rs 280.3 crore for the March quarter 2019 mainly due to higher revenues. Net profit in March quarter 2018 stood at Rs 219.7 crore. 


43 stocks ready to riseMomentum indicator moving average convergence divergence, or MACD, showed bullish crossovers on 43 counters on BSE, signalling that these stocks may rise in the coming sessions. Among those stocks were Reliance Power, Alok Industries, DCB Bank, Titan Company, Hexaware Technologies, Usha Martin and Mahamaya Steel. On the other hand, FDC, Ess Dee Aluminium, Prima Plastics, Future Market Networks and Emami Paper Mills were among the 39 stocks that showed bearish crossovers.

ITC, HDFC, Ashok Leyland, Titan and UPL are the stocks where Sanjiv Bhasin, Executive Vice President, IIFL Securities, is bullish today. He was speaking to ETNOW.Edited excerpts: 


I do not know where to start.
Sell in May is an odd adage and it is held true to the date. Donald Trump and the election uncertainty and weak earnings have all played out. But believe me, this is a brilliant opportunity to buy. The second half of May will be a deceiver and a counter pullback rally is very much on the cards, maybe today or tomorrow, but there is a 600-point rally now waiting to come and the other elephant in the room will be the elections. 

Till then, there will be rumour mongering. But a large part of the fear element may have played out. We think the market will ignore most of the tweets because the damage is already done. But truly, this May has been rather unsettling and we still got the second half to go but I am relatively sanguine. Oversold conditions notwithstanding, we should see some smart pullback in select stocks and the index.


Foreigners were selling. DIIs were buying. The data is exactly the same. Thousand crores of net buying, thousand crores of net selling and yet markets capitulated yesterday.
You can see forward, the US futures and so on. People had an inkling of where this trade war was going. So smart money or the people who are on the trading side saw that weakness get sold into. By the way, data tells you that the 9th day consecutive fall is the first time in eight years. It is telling you how heavily oversold you are and like you mentioned, there is an equal amount of buying and selling just one crore of difference. Then why should you be down 150 points and that too in the last half an hour? . There is a lot of extreme shorts and extreme pessimism but it is not so on the numbers. We know that auto, discretionary, consumption has been a weak spot but look at the positives. If I can name them, cement, corporate banks, capex and construction all these seem to be in a very fine fettle.

It is a glass half full, half empty. I would say the second half of May and beyond should see smart pullback, a counter-trend rally and we will take it from there. The other event would be the elections. But most of the volatility may be in the price now.


What do you do with pharmaceuticals if you are an investor? I do not recall the last time you had Sun Pharma drop down 20 odd per cent in one given day! 9% was the fall yesterday. How do you approach this weakness? Do you buy on dips yet or is that like trying to catch a falling knife?
That’s a good point. It has been in the eye of the storm whether for corporate governance or some of the issues regarding some of the subsidiaries. Now, you are totally rumour driven. We do not know what the impact is but definitely yesterday was the day where the bears have hammered the stock. 

Fundamentally, numbers and some of the generic pricing pressures should ease. They have seen a lot of approvals on the FDA side. If you are a value picker, that whole basket of pharma looks good. We have to ignore the negatives that play out for some time just as President Trump tweets. We know that finally a deal will be reached with China. It is just that the volatility is hurting and same is the case with pharma. 

A lot of the stocks have gone through a lot of the tiring processes but the ones that stand out would be Dr Reddy’s, Lupin and Aurobindo where the price damage is giving you an opportunity. On Sun Pharma, a SIP would be ideal here for the next 16 weeks or 6 months because you could average out on a good stock just because of amalgamation of rumours and some downgrade maybe the cause of the price fall.


Give me a list of three stocks where you are a buyer today.
Not three, I will give you five stocks. It would be ITC, HDFC, Ashok Leyland, Titan and UPL. All five are in different sectors. All earnings are to be upgraded and the pessimism in ITC was overdone. Last week, I travelled to five cities in three states and saw the mood there. These are smaller cities -- some in Gujarat, some in Karnataka -- the mood is not BJP versus… it is Modiji versus the mahagathbandhan irrespective of the candidates.

So my call if I can stick my neck out is 240 to 250 on the BJP, 290 on the NDA and you will cross the mid line aaram se. I think the pessimism is overdone. Let me also specify to the retail investors that gold is no longer the new defensive. The new gold is SIP and that SIP is here to stay not for the next 6, 9, 12 months, for the next many years. So, please do not ignore your SIP, in fact up your exposure because SIP is the new gold for many, many years.


A year ago if I would have spoken about Eicher, before I finished the question, the response which I used to get from everyone was great company, buy the stock. Now it is don’t buy Eicher at Rs 20,000, buy it at Rs 17,000. Your view?
Good point and you have summed it up well. Siddhartha Lal is a visionary. He could look much well beyond. I used to drive the Bullet when I was in college and look at what the Bullet is now. He has transitioned the Bullet into a Harley Davidson concept in India. Pan India, there are 750 outlets and like you said, this is a cyclical slowdown rather than a structural one. I am very sure that Eicher should see volumes, margins all starting to bounce back maybe in the next two quarters. 

The undertone remains that auto is one of the lame ducks and we know a number of reasons, I would not go into that. But I think if you can see some of the CV players (a disclosure we think Ashok Leyland fits the bill), you are talking of 200 airports. You are talking of truck orders which have gone out after the Pulwama attack and for that, Ashok Leyland will stand out heads over others. We think their foray into CIS countries is another modification of their geographical area. I can put my money on Ashok Leyland, Eicher and Bajaj Auto in that order.

ICICI Prudential Asset Management, the country’s second-largest money manager by assets, was busy all through April lapping up beaten down stocks, when the BSE benchmark Sensex advanced around 1 per cent.

The fund house increased exposure to select stocks such as Vodafone Idea, Lakshmi Vilas Bank, Avanti Feeds, Bharat Electronics and NBCC, that have plunged 45-72 per cent since January 2018. 

S Naren, ED and CIO, ICICI Prudential AMC said, “The market currently is fairly priced. The strategy in such market condition is to adopt a stock-specific approach. There are several pockets of opportunities across sectors and market capitalisations, where scrips are available at attractive valuations.”

Power, auto ancillaries, metal and telecom looks attractive to Naren.

Vodafone Idea recently concluded a Rs 25,000 crore rights issue, which was oversubscribed nearly 1.08 times. Ace Mutual Fund data base showed ICICI Prudential was holding 46 crore Vodafone Idea shares as of April 30 against 8.77 crore a month earlier, hinting that the fund house subscribed to the rights issue.



Besides, the fund house bought additional shares of IT majors Infosys (1.30 crore) and Tata Consultancy Services (4 lakh). Infosys last month posted a 10.5 per cent rise in consolidated profit for March quarter at Rs 4,078 crore, and gave a guidance for 7.5-9.5 per cent revenue growth in FY 2019-20. 

TCS reported 17.7 per cent year-on-year growth in March quarter net income at Rs 8,126 crore and Rs 6,904 crore profit. The IT major last Friday once again became India’s most valued firm by market valuation, surpassing Reliance Industries. 

Brokerage Prabhudas Lilladher has an ‘accumulate’ rating on Infosys with a price target of Rs 782 and a ‘buy’ call on TCS with a price target of Rs 2,312.

ICICI Prudential AMC also added shares of auto players Eicher Motors (5,484 shares), TVS Motor (13 lakh) and Mahindra & Mahindra (4.15 lakh). Financial majors Kotak Mahindra Bank and HDFC Bank also manage to draw the fund house. 

In the power sector, ICICI Prudential purchased additional 2.83 crore shares of NTPC, followed by Power Finance Corporation (40 lakh), REC (36 lakh) and Adani Power (1.34 lakh). Antique Stock Broking has ‘buy’ rating on NTPC with a price target of Rs 161.

“With improvement in commissioning and commercialisation, NTPC should see an uptick in operational performance. Further, capacity addition in the next five years will sustain the momentum. We foresee 5-6 per cent capacity addition CAGR,” the brokerage said.

The fund manager also bought auto ancillary shares like Apollo Tyre, Exide Batteries, Motherson Sumi Systems and Amara Raja Batteries.

“I will be a little contrarian on auto and auto ancillaries at this point. Although lead indicators suggest a bit of consumption slowdown, two-wheelers should start looking better. I would probably be a buyer on dips starting with two-wheelers and also in some of the auto components and auto ancillaries. There has been a reasonable price correction because of the overall slowdown,” Gurmeet Chadha, Co-founder, Complete Circle Consultants, told ETNOW.

Overall, the fund house increased stakes in as many as 111 companies, and sold in 116 across sectors. The fund house held 552 stocks as of April 30.

Yes Bank, Axis Bank, Rain Industries, Coal India, ONGC, Bharti Airtel, Federal Bank, SBI, ITC, Suzlon Energy, SpiceJet, ICICI Prudential, Wipro, HDFC, Power Grid, Bank of Baroda, Ambuja Cement, Axis Bank and Zee Entertainment were among the stocks the fund house offloaded during the month.

Zee Entertainment shares declined nearly 10 per cent last week amid concerns over stake sale by its promoters.



Total asset under management (AUM) of ICICI Prudential AMC stood at Rs 3.30 lakh crore as of April 30, 2019. It was followed by SBI Funds Management (Rs 2.97 lakh crore) and Aditya Birla Sun Life AMC (Rs 2.50 lakh crore) in terms of AUM. HDFC Asset Management stood market leader with total AUM of Rs 3.47 lakh crore.

NEW DELHI: Nifty futures on the Singapore Exchange were trading 3 points, or 0.03 per cent, higher at 11,868, indicating a flat start for the Nifty50. Here are a few stocks which may buzz the most in today’s trade: 


Tech Mahindra, Jindal Steel, Bosch and DLF: Tech Mahindra, Jindal Steel, Crompton Greaves Consumer Electricals, Bosch, DLF, IFCI, KEI Industries, Bharat Financial are among a few companies which will disclose their March quarter results today. 


Adani group stocks: Adani Group is upbeat about the re-election of Australian Prime Minister Scott Morrison who has been a supporter of coal projects and has backed the group’s controversial mining project in Queensland. The group believes that the state government would have to pay heed to the “people’s mandate” and give all the necessary approvals needed for the project to take off.


Jet Airways: Lenders led by State Bank of India (SBI) are contemplating a payment of more than ₹200 crore (about $30 million) to US Exim Bank and take charge of six aircraft of Jet Airways as they struggle to keep the airline afloat till they agree on a durable restructuring plan.


Tata Motors: The automaker reported a 49 per cent decline in consolidated net profit to Rs 1,108.66 crore for the quarter ended March 31, mainly due to lower revenues and exceptional charge on account of its British arm Jaguar Land Rover.


Adani Green Energy: Two promoters Adani Tradeline LLP and Universal Trade and Investment together would offer 8.75 crore equity at an offer price of Rs 43 per piece on Tuesday.


Torrent Pharma: The drug firm reported a consolidated net loss of Rs 152 crore for the quarter ended March 31, 2019, mainly on account of exceptional items.


HPCL: Hindustan Petroleum Corp Ltd reported a 70 per cent jump in its fourth quarter net profit as inventory gains and rupee appreciation negated a dip in refinery margins. Net profit in January-March came at Rs 2,970 crore against Rs 1,748 crore in the same period a year back.


Eicher Motors: New-Delhi-based auto component maker Flash Electronics has filed a patent infringement lawsuit against Royal Enfield North America citing unlawful use of a technology it had developed in 2014.


Jindal Stainless: The company’s standalone profit plunged 71.9 per cent to Rs 32.2 crore in the quarter ended March 31. The company had posted a standalone profit of Rs 114.7 crore in the year-ago period, JSL said in a filing to the BSE.


Bharat Forge: The auto components major reported a nearly threefold jump in its standalone net profit to ₹299.5 crore for the March quarter. The company had posted a standalone net profit of ₹100.3 crore in the corresponding quarter a year ago, Bharat Forge said in a regulatory filing.


Dr Reddys Laboratories: The drug maker is planning to spend up to $300 million on research and development (R&D) during this financial year, a senior official of the company has said.


TV Today Network: The media firm reported a 38.02 per cent fall in standalone net profit at Rs 20.21 crore for the fourth quarter ended March 31, 2019.


GlaxoSmithKline Pharmaceuticals: The drug firm reported a 16.56 per cent rise in its standalone net profit to Rs 123.03 crore for the quarter ended March 31.


Zee Learn: The company has posted a 79.4 per cent increase in consolidated profit after tax to Rs 31.28 crore for the quarter ended March 31, on the back of higher revenue from operations.


BSE: ICICI Bank said it has entered into an agreement with the BSE to buy stake in its subsidiary INX - located at GIFT City Gujarat - for nearly Rs 31 crore.


Dalmia Bharat Sugar and Industries: The company reported a standalone net profit of Rs 46.18 crore in the fourth quarter of 2018-19 fiscal on strong sales. The company had posted a net loss of Rs 12.56 crore in the corresponding quarter in the previous fiscal, according to a BSE filing.


Lakshmi Machine Works: The company has registered standalone net profit for the January-March 2019 quarter at Rs 36.78 crore. The Coimbatore-based company had registered standalone net profit at Rs 61.23 crore in the year ago period.

Analyst calls• Reliance Securities has maintained buy rating on JK Tyre and Industries and revised target price to ₹115 from Rs 135. The brokerage said that the company may face challenging environment in the near-term, while its performance is expected to improve from second half of FY20 owing to sustained growth in sales volume, reduction in manpower cost and better cost control. 

• Edelweiss has downgraded Bajaj Finserv to reduce from hold and revised target price to ₹6,481 from ₹5,948 after rolling over valuation to September 2020. Bajaj Finserv reported a mixed performance in the fourth quarter with strong momentum in the financing business and lower profitability in general insurance as well as life insurance, said Edelweiss. 

 • Kotak Securities has a buy rating on Phoenix Mills with a target price of ₹754. Rental renegotiations, new project launches, and completion of under-construction assets are likely to maintain healthy performance for the company going forward, said Kotak Securities. Residential revenues are likely to witness contraction going forward due to revenue recognition largely done during FY19, it said. 

 • Nomura has maintained buy rating on Minda Industries and reduced target price to ₹454 from ₹490. Minda Industries' fourth quarter revenue growth of 8% year-on-year and EBITDA margins at 12.5% were largely in line with our forecast and the consensus estimate, said Nomura. Minda remains a key beneficiary of rising content in vehicles and regulatory push driving adoption of safety and BS-VI, said Nomura.

 • CLSA has maintained buy rating on Jammu & Kashmir Bank and rolled forward target price to ₹68 from ₹50. For the fourth quarter, the bank’s profit was ahead of estimates aided by a better top-line and treasury gains, said CLSA. The bank’s CASA franchise is strong, at 51% of deposits and its focus on home state retail loans will help improve profitability,it added.

Bull or Bear? Stay on top of the game with our LIVE MARKET BLOG

If you have a stable government and lower interest rates, then maybe the Nifty, Sensex companies may not be the right place for investors to look at parking their money. We could see a turnaround taking place in the midcap stocks, said Dipan Mehta, Director, Elixir Equities, in an interview with ETNOW. Edited excerpts:


It was a surprisingly big move yesterday. It almost seemed like the market is in a hurry to get all of it done by 23rd?
It is facing some resistance at higher levels and there is some amount of realisation that even if the new government was to come into power, the older problems still remain. Also, what is the strategy for the new government going to be faced with all the challenges in the economy? 

Overall I think some amount of absence of follow up buying is also taking place. There are fears about global markets as well and that is also affecting the sentiment but let us just wait and see what happens on the 23rd. If we have a solid number coming in for BJP and NDA, you could see gradual rejuvenation of the markets and overall improvement in sentiment.

A lot of investments and consumption is waiting on the sidelines for this election result to be over and done with. We could see that coming back into action and play post May 23rd. Also, one thing affecting the sentiment is the poor Q4 numbers. Apart from cement and a few NBFCs and may be private sector banks, by and large, the quarterly numbers have been disappointing and as such investors are very perturbed about turnaround in corporate profits.

We have been expecting it for several quarters and it has not been happening so that is resulting in a narrow range of movement for only the companies which have been able to deliver good performance. So, there are a few issues and speed breakers at this point of time, but I am hopeful that going forward, a lot of the issues will eventually get resolved.


How much anticipation are you tracking the election results with? Do you feel that we are almost in the clear or would you still be incredibly cautious on Thursday just to make sure the exit polls got it right?Investors ought to be cautious. One is an exit poll and the other is the actual result. You should always be prepared that the actual result may materially differ from what the exit poll was. At least, since the results have been out we have not been chasing any stocks or advising investors to put money to work. It is better to wait for the election numbers to come through. 

If the numbers are slightly lower than what the exit polls predicted, there could be a minor disappointment, slight decline in the sentiment and could have a sell on news type of syndrome playing out. It is best to just wait and watch. There will be a lot of opportunities to get into stocks.

Notwithstanding what move we saw yesterday, there will be many opportunities. One should just wait for the air to completely clear out as far as the election results are concerned and then perhaps take the plunge and decide on medium to long-term strategies. Also, stock selection may change if there is a change of government. Also important will be what the next government’s focus areas are going to be. That will come through perhaps in the budget or initial communication from the new government. 

It is best to just wait and watch. In any case, there is an earnings season underway and one would not want to buy into companies where the earnings are still left to come because there could always be nasty surprises. This is an ideal time to just sit tight, conserve liquidity and wait for opportunities once there is more certainty on earnings front and on political front. 


You seem to be looking at rate sensitives more favourably. Is that also in anticipation of a rate cut that seems inevitable or are you looking deeper into that arena?It is clearly based on interest rates going down steadily and the June policy of RBI is very important. It will be the first policy after the new government and if interest rates do come off at that point of time, then certainly it will be very positive. That is what the street is expecting. 

Also, there is the Jalan Committee report which we are looking forward to and if any there is transfer of dividend from the RBI to the centre, then that also would ease fiscal pressure and reduce government borrowing and that would give some amount of levy to the government to reduce taxes and give a boost to the economy. 

Lower interest rates are extremely positive for our economy and immediately results in rising consumption of automobiles and real estate and certain other non-discretionary products. That in itself has a chain effect down the line and we see ancillary units and then basic materials also start to do much better.

Broadly, if inflation remains under control and monsoons are as expected pretty much normal, than you were looking at benign inflation scenario and that should lead to lower interest rates and that could certainly be a trigger point for the markets to move up.


The Tata Motors management is claiming they are going to have that turnaround and we have seen brief periods of intense action on that stock price as well. Your view?We are not very positive on Tata Motors. It is a complicated company with a high degree of volatility in their earnings and JLR is difficult to get a handle on. Sometimes China does well and sometimes US does well and sometimes Europe does badly. Then there is this entire hedge strategy of theirs which also tends to confuse investors. 

There is just no sustainability of visibility of earnings as far as Tata Motors is concerned. The only reason to buy Tata Motors is perhaps its cheap valuation, apart from that there is very little in terms of what investors can make a projection of for the domestic business or for JLR for that matter. I would say it is best to avoid Tata Motors which is a highly complex and difficult to track and follow.

Within the auto space, the best pick still remains passenger car manufacturer like Maruti or a premium two-wheeler player like an Eicher Motors where there is some visibility that once this trough in the auto sales is over and done with, we will see revival in the auto industry and at least the market leaders will be the first to benefit from the volume growth that will come into the industry.


Would you buy more of the same? How much more ICICI Bank or Axis or Bajaj Finance? Do you think that once the uncertainty and the event risk of 23rd is behind us, maybe newer names would participate if there were to be a rally?
If you have a stable government and lower interest rates, then maybe the Nifty, Sensex companies may not be the right place for investors to look at parking their money. We could see a turnaround taking place in the midcap stocks. The midcap indices have been lagging Nifty, Sensex for many months now and that kind of underperformance seems to be unsustainable. 

A lot of midcap stocks are available at very attractive valuations having corrected anywhere from 30 to 50% from their top. So if you are convinced that gradually the political uncertainty, the monsoon uncertainty, the RBI uncertainty is getting resolved, which I think will happen by mid July-August or so, we could see a bull market coming back in to small midcap companies and across-the-board, auto ancillaries, cement companies, infrastructure companies, real estate companies, the smaller automobile manufacturers, to an extent some of these building material type of companies, appliances, media and entertainment coming into play. There is a wide variety of choice when it comes to small and midcap companies. There are many in the financial services space also which are quite attractive. 

So I would like to position our portfolio more towards midcap stocks once we are convinced that the May 23rd result has gone down well with the market and we have a stable government and monsoons are generally going to be okay and interest rate regime is going to be kind of soft going forward. 

2019 will be the year where you may see the midcaps starting to outperform the larger cap because end of the day the large index stocks be it Reliance or HDFC Bank or Bajaj Finance, HUL are priced to perfection and their earnings also are going to definitely slowdown because of the base effect and there is hardly any scope for the PEs for these companies to get rerated upwards. 

A government investment is one where you can see the alpha happening in the earnings and the PE multiple also expanding and those sort of scenario you will find more in the small, midcap stocks at this point of time than in some of the large index stocks which have frankly held up the index and that has led to a high degree of underperformance for the midcap indices. 


How would you advice investors to approach the NBFC space?We are very positive on NBFCs and apart from two or three NBFCs where clearly there has been a downgrade and which have some issues with NPAs, by and large most NBFCs have been able to manage the crisis pretty well. Those NBFCs which are connected with large business houses or which have been around for several decades have done pretty well. But they have curbed their lending because of fear that they may not get resources to lend going forward and there may be redemption, which is why they are sitting on higher cash levels as well. 

At the same time, they want to protect their capital adequacy. There are certain short-term challenges for the NBFC sector but by and large, we are seeing those getting resolved. At the same time, this provisioning for IL&FS also has dampened sentiment for a few NBFCs as well as few private sector banks and public sector banks as well. 

You need to give them some more time -- may be a quarter or two and once there is more clarity on IL&FS, once we see the debt markets getting back into rhythm and once these NBFCs get the resources to lend, you will see that their growth rates picking up and valuations become very attractive.

There are some pockets within NBFCs which despite the credit crisis have done exceedingly well like micro finance or gold loans and investors could look at those companies where not much has changed over the past few months or so.

I am extremely bullish on all India centric plays and that includes select autos and insurance, said Sanjiv Bhasin, Executive VP markets and corporate affairs, IIFL, in an interview with ETNOW.Edited excerpts:

What are you buying?They are the four Cs which we are extremely bullish on. It starts with cement, the second would be construction, the third would be corporate banks and fourth would be capex. All those four Cs are going to initiate a lot of local initiatives on the infrastructure. You have seen cement earnings. We think that will be the catalyst for housing both -- low cost and high end. Construction. which has been abysmally low will start to pick up in a big way. Corporate banks have been in the eye of the storm and now some of the banks are well positioned. Fourth is capex, which has not moved in the last two years. 

Stocks like L&T, hit a new high today. A disclosure, L&T has been one of our infrastructure top picks on the capex side and we think there is a whole plethora of midcaps which will actually join the party and outperform in the next six to nine months. 


The poll results are out tomorrow. We are flat but there are no wild gyrations on expected lines? Do you think this is in anticipation of tomorrow’s event?The real action was last Wednesday when you had me over and you were staring down the gun of 11150 and when I told you it is a counter trend rally of 600-700 points. I did not expect it will come so fast and I am sure tomorrow we are going to test 12000 and above. The market is sanguine, it is very optimistic that the real earnings catalyst is going to be this new government and they will be able to have a huge momentum not only locally but globally where lot of the money which is sitting on the sidelines, will find India to be the right destination. We think that for local capex, the government initiating a lot of reforms will be the catalyst.

Thirdly, the big issue of liquidity which has been missing and which has driven consumption to its lows will start to revive. So, I am very optimistic on the broader market and the economic performance and we think that these are times to buy and tomorrow and hopefully I will be proved correct.


Are you any accounting for any risk on the downside?Equity markets are all about risk and reward but the risk was there last week of missing this rally and hence if you recall that we stuck our neck out and we still think that the numbers may actually be just in line or if you do get 290 seats on the NDA then you are done. Now you have to look at the real action plan. 

The biggest change would be a new finance minister who can reinitiate a lot of the changes and so on. We are very very optimistic that there would be a total upturn and what the exit polls have shown, we will see that tomorrow.


Anything else that you are looking at from a short-term perspective?Two more sectors. One would be the PSUs and their rerating would be across the board. I would definitely recommend to investors the CPSE ETF which has about 15 of those stocks which are prime blue chip PSU stocks. Please buy that ETF as a SIP or buy that outright. You will definitely make much more returns than in any other account. 

The other would be insurance. It is just at the tip of the iceberg of pedigree stocks. These are very well-run companies like ICICI Pru, ICICI Lombard, HDFC life and SBI Life. All these are going to give you extremely good returns over the next three to five years. So if you are looking long term, these are very good candid plays. 

In the midcaps we suggested some of the construction plays. We think of autos as a dark horse. I could take three names -- Ashok Leyland, Eicher Motors and Bajaj Auto. These can be huge wealth creators in the next year, given that the extent on the commercial vehicle will pick up the LCV, MHV market. Eicher gets back its act in the Royal Enfield and Bajaj Auto which has been a huge market gainer by sacrificing of little margin. These three can also be huge wealth creators in the next one year.


What is your outlook about the capital goods space, infrastructure names. Lots of hopes being pinned here?Yes and rightly so. There has been almost three years of no growth and now capex is just waiting to go, particularly on the private side. Once you have clarity and stability and continuity of the government, it is going to be a huge income generator both on the employment and on the GDP. 

L&T, Siemens, ABB, Sadbhav Engineering, Nagarjuna Construction, NBCC are there. You will see rerating of the entire PSU pack, valuations have never been so cheap and now you are going to see a huge capex which will see cash inflows on a very big scale, particularly in most of the PSUs where there has been extreme value but a problem of liquidity. I am extremely bullish on all India centric plays and that includes select autos and insurance.


Within capital goods, what do you like?So L&T, Siemens, ABB, Sadbhav Engineering would be four top picks and in the midcap we like Nagarjuna Construction and NBCC. All quasi infrastructure capex/construction companies. 


Within the banking pack, can I get the pecking order from you?Clearly SBI has just broken out. I have a target of Rs 425 by the end of the year. SBI, ICICI, Axis are the largecaps and three stocks which are going to be midcap outperformers are DCB, Federal Bank and IDFC First. The numbers were weak but the management has explained that credit growth is the best they have had. Their margins are expanding on the NIMs and their CASA ratio is improving. These can be extremely good buy as a franchise for the next two years where you can get good numbers and capital creation. 


Any of the real estate names on your list?Yes, we have three companies that is Godrej Properties, Sobha and Prestige. A disclosure, these are under our buy list and we think that RERA, the other improvements, the liquidity which will comes back will see pedigree performance from the larger players which have stood out in this times of chaos.

The Narendra Modi-led government’s victory in 2014 triggered a bull run in Indian stock market that has led to the Nifty gaining 63% in the last five years. Financials, auto and consumer companies led the outperformance during this period. With the outcome of the national polls due today, ET takes a look at some of the top performers during the NDA regime from the BSE 100 index and details their outlook going ahead.


BAJAJ FINANCE
CMP: Rs 3,447.70 Change in last 5 years: 1,852%

Bajaj Finance has been the biggest wealth creator among BSE 100 constituents over the last five years due to consistent earnings performance. “The company has grown at a 35-40% CAGR for eight-nine-years in a low and its liability management has been strong. Profit has grown 10-12 times in the last eight-nine years,” said Digant Haria, AVP-research at Antique Stock Broking. Haria believes premium valuation of can sustain going forward till business execution stays strong


BRITANNIA INDUSTRIES
CMP: Rs 2,851.25 Change in last 5 years: 560%

Britannia did well in the last five years since new CEO Varun Berry was appointed in March 2014, just before the NDA was elected, said analysts. “He implemented a lot of strategy changes that resulted in margin expansion and return ratio expansion. The stock was adequately rewarded for this,” said Deepak Jasani, head of research at HDFC Securities. Jasani said the stock may not repeat its strong show in the next five years due to stretched valuations and a high base.


TITAN COMPANY
CMP: Rs 1,240.45 Change in last 5 years: 304%

The implementation of GST and lower corporate governance levels in other listed jewellery stocks made investors shift to Titan, said independent market expert Ambareesh Baliga. “Titan’s corporate governance was never under any question. Financial performance should sustain but stock may not outperform. The stock is not cheap, it will perform in line with the consumer space,” said Baliga.


HAVELLS INDIA
CMP: Rs 756.35 Change in last 5 years (%): 302%

Jasani of HDFC Securities said Havells has transformed itself from an industrial to a consumer facing company with strong focus on brands, mass premium markets, innovation and strong distribution across the country. “Investors recognised the moat in their business and pushed up the stock prices,” said Jasani. He believes the stock may not repeat its superlative performance in the next five years as valuations are high.


PIDILITE INDUSTRIES
CMP: Rs 1,212.30 Change in last 5 years: 289%

Demand revival, entry in new markets and adjacent categories, and anticipated demand shift from unorganised to organised players are likely to boost Pidilite’s revenue and earnings, said Abneesh Roy, senior vicepresident-institutional equities at Edelweiss Securities. Roy is optimistic on Pidilite Industries – which is a market leader in the adhesives segment, due to anticipated demand recovery and market leadership.


PAGE INDUSTRIES
CMP: Rs 22,526.8 Change in last 5 years: 280%

Page has underperformed in the last one-and-a-half years because of expensive valuation, consumer slowdown and margin pressure, it is one of the outperformers in the last five years, said Sanjiv Bhasin, executive VP-markets and corporate affairs at IIFL. “The management is very competent and the brand value of Jockey is immense. It is one of the best consumer companies in the midcap space,” said Bhasin.


BIOCON
CMP: Rs 519.6 Change in last 5 years: 263%

India’s largest bio-pharma company Biocon is expected to perform well going ahead as well, said analysts. HSBC expects biosimilars momentum to continue for Biocon on gradual launches, pick up in the US and the EU, and ongoing traction in emerging markets. “...progress on the biosimilars regulatory front in developed markets and launches in the developed as well as emerging markets are likely to be key levers for the company.”


HDFC BANK
CMP: Rs 2405.1 Change in last 5 years: 199%

Investor favourite HDFC Bank’s profit has grown at a compounded rate of 20.6% over the last five years. “Considering the healthy balance sheet growth, superior asset quality and management, the bank is well poised to deliver consistently with margin leadership and robust return ratios. It remains a portfolio stock with premium valuations,” said ICICIdirect, which sees the stock at Rs 2,700 in the next one year.


KOTAK MAHINDRA BANK
CMP: Rs 1495.50 Change in last 5 years: 230%

Another consistent performer from the banking space over the last five years is Kotak Mahindra Bank which Antique Stock Broking recently called ‘stock of all seasons’.”Kotak Mahindra Bank is currently trading at a P/B multiple of 5.7 times/4.9 times on FY20/ FY21 book value and we expect the premium valuation of the bank to continue on back of its superior asset quality, high ROE and balance sheet growth well supported by strong performance of its


EICHER MOTORS
CMP: Rs 21,221.85 Change in last 5 years: 233%

After rallying sharply over the years, the stock may face headwinds going ahead. There seems to be brand fatigue for Royal Enfield in metro cities which is visible in sharp moderation in same store sales, said HSBC. “The stock is facing sector headwinds as well as product headwinds. It could underperform going forward,” said independent market expert Ambareesh Baliga.


ASIAN PAINTS
CMP: Rs 1,366.75 Change in last 5 years: 155%

Although the stock trades at 50.2 times one-year forward earnings, having gained over 150% in the last five years, analysts are still bullish on the stock. “Given strong volume growth visibility for paints in the medium term and the competitive advantages of Asian Paints, we believe the current valuations present a good buying opportunity,” said UBS in a note recently.

Give me one company which was growing at 10% and people made 25x on it. I cannot find even one, said Basant Maheshwari, Co-founder, Basant Maheshwari Wealth Advisors, in an interview with ETNOW. I cannot see a recovery for the next 6-9 months at least, says Maheshwari.Edited excerpts:

You have migrated from Kolkata to Mumbai. So, the financial capital attracts everyone?
 It is more the idea of meeting like-minded people.


Buffett stayed in Omaha and he said look I am very happy, I do not need to interact with Wall Street people; Franklin Templeton is in Chennai, they said look we want to stay away.I wish I was Warren Buffett and Templeton. I would have gone to Asansol.


No, but he said that we want to stay away from the noise because the noise affects our day-to-day market thinking. You should be away from the noise. You have come to the centre where all the noise is there.That is very commonly said but it is not about noise. It is also about information, about sharing news and views but in today’s world, Twitter, Facebook, you get to know everything. It was just let us go and try and see what happens.


What a timing! You have come. What a welcome, what a decisive mandate and what a reaction by the market! What next? Is this the trigger point for all those bleeding small and midcaps to come back to form?I have a different view on this. The broad market is still in pain because if you have 6-6.5% GDP growth, you cannot have 200 companies doing very well. Just imagine a situation where there are five people in a room and there are just three mangoes. The stronger ones will go and take on each and the two weak guys will be left without a mango. If you are five people and seven mangoes, then each one gets to have one of them. The moment we have 7.5-8% GDP growth, it is that point where the smallcaps, the midcaps, the tiny caps and the penny caps do well. Also, there is no problem in the Nifty, there is no problem in the top 30-40-50 companies that are delivering earnings. 

See what happened a couple of weeks back; Pidilite came with a horrible set of numbers.We all thought that the stock is going to go down but it did not, it just went up because just three months of earnings cannot define a company which is going to stay for the next 50 years. We are back in the 2009-2015 era where a handful of 20-30-40 companies would do well, liquidity would chase growth and if there is growth, people will say okay let me get a pie of it.


So, there would not be a broad-based recovery? Would it be very selective even within broader market?I cannot see a recovery for the next 6-9 months at least.


We were taking cognisance of what is going on within the infrastructure space and there is a lot that has been done, a lot of reform push. A lot is anticipated in terms of picking up the overall private capex. If they stick to their promises for doling out sizable amounts, what do you make of the progress in infra?Infra, selectively the Bharatmala, where Nitin Gadkari was handling things, he was really pushing things around. But the problem in infra in 2019 and 2004 is, in 2004 you had probably 25 infra companies in India, in 2019 you have 250 companies and infra is always an L1 thing. The guy who bids the cheapest, gets the order. While infrastructure could make money, buying those infra companies will require a little more intelligence than what it did earlier.


The sliver of the market is growing within financials, consumption and those stocks are available at levels where you would say you got to be crazy to be buying silver at the price of diamond, forget buying gold at the price of silver. This is like if you buy a Bajaj Finance 8 times a book, if you look at AU Finance again, at same kind of a level, how does one invest in this market?I give this example most of the time; if me and you are being chased by a lion, I do not have to run faster than the lion, I have to run faster than you. The point is if there are say 200 companies and just seven of them are growing at 30%, money will chase those seven. A disclaimer, we own Bajaj Finance in truck loads, maybe up to the throat. But the point is, if I get something else at three times book growing at similar rate with similar valuations, I would sell Bajaj Finance the next day and tell the broker to switch all the trade. But there is not anything available. Look at the kind of beating the other NBFCs are taking right now.


Exactly a year ago, RC Bhargava came on the channel and said “itna demand hai ke gaadi ka shortage hai” (There’s so much demand that there is a shortage of cars.) The same guy after one year tell us that we are cutting our production because there is just no demand. HFC guys said a year ago, they were certain of a 15-18% or 18-25% growth. That grown has become de-growth. When demand turns around, it turns around so dramatically and radically that you cannot ever figure out?The theory is if there is a company which has 50% of market share like Asian Paints, Maruti, no recommendations. Maybe Pidilite, maybe a Horlicks which Glaxo Consumer used to sell sometime. When you are yourself 50% of the market, how can you grow at 25% when the market is growing at 10%? So there is an alarm bell and there is something to get very impressed about that this company has 50% of market share because if you are 50% of the market share you would not go out of business, you will still make the business but you cannot grow fast. 

All those companies with 50% market share will reach the growth plateau sooner than later. Look at what happened to Page Industries. In the mid segment, it has 60% of the market share. But you cannot grow fast when you have 50-60% market share. Look at companies where you have 2-3% market share but the market is expanding at say 10% then you can grow at 25% because all you have to do is grow and grab market share from others with a 50% market share.


So what within consumption has the potential to grow at 25%?, Right now we are seeing almost a blanket decline barring in two or three odd names?It is very difficult because a company that grows at two, three, four does not grow at 20%. A company that grows at 5%, grows at 7%. A company that grows at 20%, can grow at 22%. In the consumption space, we own just two companies -- a grocery retailer and a jewellery retailer. No recommendations again, because we think that these are the only two companies that can grow faster. 

Apart from that, I can make a case for Bata may be but then there is the same problem. Bata itself is quite dominant in its space and we like to look at top line growth whereas markets look at bottom line growth because once you have top line growth, the bottom line growth can come in and you can inflate bottom line growth by cutting expenses, advertising, expansion and capacity, but you cannot create top line growth and ultimately over the long term, it is the top line growth that matters. 

Look at companies like Amazon and Apple and Google. May be they spend billions of dollars just to get market share, but that is a way to look at it. I cannot find too many opportunities in even consumer and financials.


Another headline this morning on the Economic Times is that hopes of big reforms will take D-Street bulls to new highs. There seems to be a consensus that with the new government in place, we are going to see a boost in overall sentiments. Only global factors could come as a hindrance. Where do you think we stand on the market front now?The government is likely to go for a big infra push. It had tried to do DeMon so that it could get a couple of lakh crore but that did not happen and it asked the RBI for dividend, but that did not happen. It is looking for a big amount of money which they can put in through the infrastructure space. People tell me that may be an inheritance tax could be coming. But that is not for the stock market to celebrate because this government has told us that it will not walk one line, it will be somewhere between socialism and capitalism. 

If it is only capitalism, then it gets voted out like India shine in 2004. If it is only socialism, then what is the difference between the Third Front and the NDA government? So, the stock markets should celebrate but the celebration should not go beyond the designated time.


We compared the five-year chart of NDA-1 with global markets and realised that in the last five years, S&P and Nifty have given almost neck and neck returns. 4-5% here or there is point to point but that is a way all we need to do. What is the data telling us?Over the last five years, the Nifty has done almost nothing. If you go into the broader market, there is more mud there but still you could find your company. When we meet Bajaj Finance, it has done phenomenally well. It is said it is a stock pickers’ market, you have to become a value buyer. All those things are good enough but ultimately over the last 25 years of Indian stock markets, money has only been made in companies that are growing at above normal rates -- be it Infosys, L&T, Unitech, Pantaloon, Bharti Airtel, Page Industries or Eicher Motors.

Give me one company which was growing at 10% and people made 25x on it. I cannot find even one.

The revival in the earnings is not visible on a broad-based basis for the next couple of quarters. I definitely think that one should avoid the stocks which have been beaten down and where you are not seeing much growth visibility, said Hemang Jani, Senior VP, Sharekhan, in an interview with ETNOW.Edited excerpts:


The Indigo numbers are nothing short of a blow out. How much more headroom is left for Indigo? It has almost become a duopoly kind of a space now?See the market at this point of time is so polarised that wherever you see a good growth visibility and some stable margins, the money is only chasing those sort of stocks. And that is what we have seen in the last whole year, last six months or so. So we have very few stocks where one can really have a growth visibility. The Indigo management is telling us that in terms of international and domestic operations, they are extremely well placed. They are also going to get delivery of almost about 20-25 aircraft. 

The passenger growth has not been that great but even if it remains about 12-15% with only two major players. The overall environment is extremely favourable and so though the stock has run up, given the state of the market, we might see some more upside for a player like Indigo. 


I always thought that Divi's had this API model which was almost like an annuity business. Irrespective of what is happening to the pharma world, Divi's had a strong disruptive model.Yes, particularly after this US FDA related issue got resolved, the company started delivering good set of numbers and the good thing about Divi's is that unlike most of the other pharma companies which have a lot of dependence on the generic opportunity and the deal with pricing related issues, Divi's had a very different business model. 

But given the fact that the entire sector in the US and in many parts of the world is going through challenges in terms of litigation, etc, and when you are supplying to some of those pharma majors, somewhere you will also have to take a hit in terms of the slowdown whenever it happens. In case of Divi's, we have seen that but overall the business model and the margins part is playing out extremely well. So we are not too negative on Divi's. Yes the performance was weak so the stock has corrected but we are of the view that somewhere it will stabilise and will start doing pretty well.


Would you avoid any of these high PE haloed stocks -- Page, Eicher, Bosch? That is where the casualty is. Markets maybe at an all-time high but some of these stocks are at a multi-year low. How would you approach a Page, an Eicher or a Bosch or Shree Cement?Definitely because of the high valuations and the fact that we are seeing slowdown, particularly in the consumption space, the derating process may continue for a while because at the moment the entire money is chasing the set of stocks where there is a growth visibility and where you can expect quarter-on-quarter improvement in the performances.

Only a few sectors are showing signs of revival. The revival in the earnings is not visible on a broad-based basis for the next couple of quarters. I definitely think that one should avoid the stocks which have been beaten down and where you are not seeing much growth visibility. The focus should be on the banking and the financial space where there is going to be a good amount of traction a) because of the repo rate cut, liquidity infusion and because of the greater visibility because 60% of the earnings growth next year in the Nifty will come from the banking space. 


What do you make of this entire wave of buying in the PSU stocks? It reminds me of 2014 when after the NDA-1 mandate everything got re-rated.Yes, because of the underperformance and the possibility of liquidity infusion and the rate cut going ahead, the market has already started pricing that in for some of the PSU banks and yes selectively we do see State Bank of India and a couple of the large PSU banks are seeing decent amount of improvement in the operating growth, loan growth and the slippages part also has been sorted out. You might see some more upside mainly because of higher probability of rate cut but again this is not a sector where one can take one year, two year kind of a call. From a tactical opportunity perspective, there is more upside for SBI in particular.


What is going on with IndiGo? The promoter spat aside, it is a problem of restrictive choice. You only have SpiceJet and IndiGo now in the aviation space. IndiGo clearly is the leader with the largest market share. They are already guiding for a 30% increase in capacity in the next financial year.Yes absolutely. Partly because of the growth in the passenger traffic which has been pretty good in the last couple of quarters and the fact that because of the Jet saga some of these incumbent players could take a price hike so the pricing power to some extent is coming back plus operationally – a) because of the expansion on the international front and because of the expansion on the fleet per se on the neo part, there is a sense that the overall growth could be extremely good for a player like IndiGo which is extremely well placed.

They have also managed to get some more slots. The market is extremely positive there. But we have not really covered this airline sector because of the kind of volatility, news flow and sensitivity to government decision making. So yes we do appreciate the fact that IndiGo is extremely well placed but we are staying away from giving any specific recommendation for IndiGo or SpiceJet at this point of time.

Eicher Motors and Bajaj Auto may be professional rivals, but their managing directors are anything but. In a recent business magazine interview, London-based Eicher Motors CEO Siddhartha Lal spoke of his friendship with Bajaj Auto’s Rajiv Bajaj. He said, “Obviously, in the market, we have to do what we have to do. At the front end, there is no friendship. But at the backend, we are friends.” 

Lal added that Bajaj was like an older brother. “When we were tiny, and we needed guidance, he opened his doors. We always had an amazing friendship, there is no doubt about that. But at the front end, it is all competition.” 

There may be some truth to that statement. Even though Lal is currently London-based, the duo reportedly own holiday “cottages” next to each other in Rishikesh. Despite all speculation, the two have always spoken positively of each other. Once asked if he viewed Lal as a rival, Bajaj said, “I don’t think of him as a competitor. I don’t think things should be seen in such a small way.”

NEW DELHI: Nifty futures on the Singapore Exchange were trading 39.50 points, or 0.33 per cent, higher at 11,964.50, indicating a firm start for the Nifty50. Here are a few stocks which may buzz the most in today’s trade: 


Bharti Infratel: The Chandigarh bench of the National Company Law Tribunal (NCLT) has approved the merger of Indus Towers with Bharti Infratel, which will create one of the largest telecom tower companies globally.


Dilip Buildcon: The company company has executed an EPC agreement with the NHAI for saoner project valued at Rs 480.06 crore on EPC Mode in Maharashtra. 


YES Bank: Facing investor wrath over the actual amount of its stressed assets, the lender is in talks with two private equity investors – Advent International and Apax Partners – to raise equity funds to build investor confidence after attempts for a share sale to a broader set of institutional investors did not materialise.


Coal India: State-owned Coal India Ltd (CIL) produced 46.59 million tonnes of coal in May, registering a decline of 1.1% from the year-ago period, as per a regulatory filing. 


GSK Consumers Healthcare: The company said its shareholders approved its proposed merger with FMCG major HUL.


MOIL: State-run MOIL said it has decreased the rates of various grades of manganese ore and other products by 7.5 per cent.


Hero MotoCorp: The country's largest two-wheeler maker Hero MotoCorp reported 13.5 per cent rise in sales to over 6.5 lakh units in May over the previous month.


Tata Motors: Tata Motors reported 26 per cent decline in domestic sales to 40,155 units in May. The company had sold 54,290 units during the same month last year.


Eicher Motors: Royal Enfield, the two-wheeler division of Eicher Motors, Saturday posted sales of 62,371 motorcycles in May, registering a decline of 16.5 per cent.


Tata Steel: The company announced that it has completed the acquisition of debt-ridden Bhushan Energy Ltd.


Maruti Suzuki: The country's largest carmaker Maruti Suzuki India Saturday reported a 22 per cent decline in sales at 1,34,641 units in May.


Mahindra & Mahindra: The auto major reported 3 per cent decline in total sales at 45,421 units in May. The company had sold 46,848 units in the same month last year.


Lakshmi Vilas Bank: The bank is preparing a Plan B just in case its merger plan with Indiabulls Housing Finance gets delayed. The lender is seeking investment of as much as Rs 1,000 crore from private equity funds in the event of a regulatory hitch.


Mindtree: Infrastructure major Larsen and Toubro (L&T) picked up 7.11 lakh shares of IT firm Mindtree between May 27 and 30 for about ₹70 crore, as per regulatory data


Bharti Airtel: The telecom operator expects tariffs to firm up as stability returns to the telecom sector after over two years of intense competition, the top management said on an earnings call on Friday.


SpiceJet: SpiceJet plans to hire up to 2,000 staff, including pilots and cabin crew, of the defunct Jet Airways as the nofrills carrier continues to expand its operations.


BOARD MEETINGS
 


ANALYST CALLS
 • Citi has a sell rating on Glenmark Pharmaceuticals with a target price of ₹615. Notwithstanding the recent weakness in the stock, Citi said it is looking for signs of meaningful traction in the US business to turn constructive — as this is key for margin improvement as well as cash generation and meaningful reduction in debt. 

 • IIFL has an add rating on Bharat Electronics with a target price of ₹149. While gross margins are likely to moderate in FY20/21 due to sales mix, benign employee expenses and other fixed overheads will help operating profit margins sustain at 20-21% levels, with 13-15% sales growth, said IIFL.

 • Kotak Institutional Equities has maintained add rating on Ujjivan Financial Services with a target price of ₹375. The brokerage believes that FY20 should start seeing normalisation of the cost-income ratio, a key concern. The valuations are inexpensive with gradual recovery in return on equity towards normalised levels and addressing the issue on listing of the bank should aid valuation expansion from current levels, the brokerage said. 

 • IDBI Capital Markets has maintained buy rating on Nava Bharat Ventures and trimmed target price to ₹125 from ₹127. The company’s EBITDA in the March quarter was lower than estimated due to weaker-than-expected profitability in the power segment, said IDBI Capital Markets. The stock trades at an attractive valuation, the brokerage added. 

 • CLSA has maintained buy rating on J Kumar Infraprojects with a target price of ₹315. The key message from J Kumar Infra’s fourth quarter result was its pick-up in new orders despite election-led, slow-down fears and robust execution, said CLSA. The brokerage expects J Kumar’s EPS to see an 18% CAGR over FY19-FY22 and highlighted that the stock looks cheap at 4.6 times FY20 estimated EPS.
