By Bhavya Dilipkumar and Nehal Chaliawala

MUMBAI: Italian motorcycle maker Benelli has scrapped its plans of setting up a manufacturing plant in India after the government mooted a plan to ban two-wheelers with combustion engines up to 150cc capacity by 2025.

The company was planning to set up a global manufacturing hub in India as its plant in China was operating at full capacity. “We were considering making mass-market bikes also from here to export to other markets,” Vikas Jhabakh, managing director of Benelli India told ET. These included motorcycles with engine capacities below 150cc, he added.

The proposed plant would have had a capacity of manufacturing at least 200,000 units annually to make a business case and would have employed about 400 people, the company had found in its initial studies. 

However, following the clear indication from the government to move away from combustion engines, the company did not see viability in selling these products in India in the long run. “And keeping in mind the vision of the government, setting up manufacturing is not a viable option because these are projects that take a really long time to pay back,” the company’s MD said.

The company has instead doubled the capacity at its assembly facility near Hyderabad to 20,000 units annually and has room to double it further to serve demand in the local market in the future, Jhabakh said.

Benelli India plans to take on Royal Enfield and Jawa with the launch of a 400cc cruiser motorcycle in India with a sub-Rs-2-lakh price tag by the end of this year. The domestic market for motorcycles in the 300cc to 500cc segment is about 825,000 units annually and Eicher Motors-owned Royal Enfield has 93% market share.

The Italian company also plans to launch two 250cc motorcycles during the same period, but these will be on the more expensive side. Selling scooters in India is also under consideration but no decision has been made so far, Jhabakh said.

Benelli is a fully-owned subsidiary of China’s Qjian Jiang Group and in India it has a marketing tie-up with Hyderabad’s Mahavir Group. It had briefly halted operations in India in May 2018 after its previous partner in the country, Pune-based DSK Group, ran into financial trouble.

It resumed sales in January this year and has sold about 1000 units so far. The company sells six models in India in the 300cc to 600cc range, which are imported as knocked-down kits and assembled at a facility near Hyderabad.

NEW DELHI: The 35 bps repo rate cut by RBI failed to enthuse the stock market on Wednesday, with equity benchmarks Sensex and Nifty showing bouts of volatility after the policy outcome. 

Sensex jumped over 120 points right after the policy announcement but failed to hold the gain and tanked to trade 160 points down within minutes. 

Around 12.15 pm, the BSE Sensex pared the losses and traded 30 points higher at 37,006, while Nifty traded at 10,944, down 4 points.

"A 25 bps rate cut was already priced in and the market was expecting a 50 bps rate cut. Possibly, that is what disappointed Dalal Street. Also, a solid step for the revival of NBFC sector was missing in the policy announcement,” said Pankaj Pandey, Head of Research at ICICIdirect.

Rate-sensitive auto, bank and realty stocks remained lacklustre after the policy announcement.

Punjab National Bank (down 2.35 per cent), Bank of Baroda (down 1.15 per cent), Axis Bank (down 0.88 per cent), State Bank of India (down 0.73 per cent), Mahindra & Mahindra (down 2.02 per cent), Eicher Motors (down 1.47 per cent), Bosch (down 1.08 per cent), Indiabulls Real Estate (down 10.21 per cent), Sunteck Realty (down 1.08 per cent), Oberoi Realty (down 0.25 per cent) and DLF (down 0.42 per cent) all traded in the red. 

"We believe it is an overall negative policy, as the risk systems have been lowered, which is dangerous at the current juncture. There is no proactive action taken to address the slowdown or liquidity squeeze even after two policies since the new RBI governor took charge," said Sameer Kalra, Founder of Target Investing.

The Nifty Auto index was trading 0.21 per cent down at 6927.75 while the Nifty Realty index was trading 0.38 per cent up at 263.45 around 11:48 am. Meanwhile, the Nifty Bank index was trading 0.50 per cent up at 28,162.25.

Select banks, graphite makers and auto companies have seen the biggest target price cuts after their June quarter results as economic slowdown, liquidity crisis and industry specific issues dampened the performance of these companies.

ET analysed the BSE 500 index constituents which are tracked by at least 5 analysts, which showed that 227 of 356 such companies have seen target prices being cut. Yes Bank, which is tracked by 42 analysts, saw the consensus target price coming down by 51 per cent. The bank had reported a 91 per cent drop in profit for the June quarter on account of higher provisioning and lower other income.

Telecom service provider Vodafone Idea’s net loss of Rs 4,873 crore for the June quarter and continued competition from Jio have led to consensus target price on the stock reduced by 43 per cent.

HEG and Graphite India have seen consensus target prices coming down by 36 per cent and 35 per cent, respectively. The removal of anti-dumping duty in September 2018 and higher imports from China have hurt these companies.


Bloomberg
RBL Bank, JK Tyre, Apollo Tyres, Escorts, Ashok Leyland, Mahindra & Mahindra, Bharat Forge, Eicher Motors, Tata Motors, TVS Motor and Maruti Suzuki India have seen consensus target prices coming down by 11-22 per cent.

Dalmia Bharat has seen consensus target price increasing by 20.5 per cent. The company reported a 192 per cent jump in its net profit in the quarter ended June.

Life insurance companies have also seen a jump in consensus target prices owing to steady earnings growth in a slowing economy. The consensus target prices of HDFC Standard Life, SBI Life Insurance and ICICI Prudential Life Insurance went up by 3 per cent to 16 per cent after their June quarter results.

NEW DELHI: Benchmark equity indices BSE Sensex and NSE Nifty ended the truncated week in the red, following mixed macroeconomic data amid fears of a global economic slowdown. 

The 30-share Sensex shed 231 points, or 0.62 per cent, to end at 37,350 for the week ended August 16. Likewise, the 50-share Nifty lost 61.85 points, or 0.56 per cent, to end at 11,047.

The market kicked off the week on a bleak note on Tuesday as sentiment got hit after government data showed that India’s factory output growth, as measured by IIP, slowed down for the second straight month to 2 per cent in June compared with 7 per cent in June, 2018 and 3.1 per cent in May, 2019. 

However, the market pared some of the losses in the remaining two days of trade amid hope of a stimulus package for the economy from the government. Investors also took comfort as India’s retail inflation based on CPI eased to 3.15 per cent in July, 2019 from 3.18 per cent in June, 2019 and 4.17 per cent in July, 2018. WPI inflation also eased to a multi-year low of 1.08 per cent in the month of July, on account of cheaper fuel and food items. 

Meanwhile, trade deficit, the gap between imports and exports, narrowed to $13.43 billion in July from $18.63 billion a year ago, helped by a lower oil import bill.

Below are the top stocks and sectors that buzzed through the week. 


Stars of the week
Reliance Industries (RIL) advanced 10 per cent after Chairman Mukesh Ambani announced a non-binding Letter of Intent (LOI) with Saudi Aramco to sell a 20 per cent stake in the oil-to-chemicals business. Besides, he also unveiled plans for launch of Reliance Jio Infocomm’s broadband services and a partnership with Microsoft to accelerate digital transformation of the Indian economy. Shares of the company jumped to Rs 1,278 as of August 16 from Rs 1,162 on August 9.

Indiabulls Housing Finance (up 9 per cent), Zee Entertainment (up 5.64 per cent), GAIL (up 4.68 per cent) and Power Grid (up 4.53 per cent) were among other top gainers in the Nifty index for the week ended August 16. 


Nifty top loser
With a fall of 5.61 per cent, Eicher Motors finished as top index loser for the week. Wipro, Adani Ports, HDFC, NTPC, TCS, Britannia and YES Bank declined between 3 and 5 per cent. Auto majors came under pressure after SIAM reported that automobile sales in the country witnessed sharpest decline in nearly 19 years in July, dropping 18.71 per cent, which currently also led to almost 15,000 job losses over the past three months. Maruti Suzuki shares slipped around 2 per cent to Rs 5,975 from Rs 6,100.


Stocks that rallied up to 41%

As many as 10 stocks on the BSE500 index managed to deliver over 10 per cent returns to investors during the week gone by. They included Godfrey Phillips (up 41.18 per cent), Hathway Cable (25 per cent), Vodafone Idea (20 per cent), Suprajit Engineering (18 per cent) and The Lakshmi Vilas Bank (15 per cent). Tamil Nadu Newsprint, Redington (India), Narayana Hrudayalaya, Crisil and MMTC also advanced between 10-13 per cent.


Scrips that cracked

Half a dozen of stocks on the BSE500 plunged in double digits during the week. Shilpa Medicare melted 25.93 per cent, followed by GIC Housing Finance (18.89 per cent), Essel Propack (18 per cent), Glenmark Pharmaceuticals (15.29 per cent) and Inox Wind (15.25 per cent). The Jammu & Kashmir Bank, Coffee Day Enterprises, Jet Airways, Dishman Carbogen, eClerx and Sobha were among other firms that fell over 10 per cent during the week


Stocks @fresh all-time high

Just eight stocks on the BSE500 hit their fresh all-time highs during the week. They included Asian Paints, Aavas Financiers, SBI Life Insurance, Berger Paints, Pidilite Industries, Trent, Bata India and Glaxosmithkline Consumer Healthcare. 


Scrips at fresh life lows

In the BSE500 index, shares of General Insurance Corporation of India, Dishman Carbogen, Coffee Day Enterprises, Inox Wind, Housing & Urban Development Corporation, Parag Milk Foods, Lemon Tree and Oil India touched new all-time lows. 


Sectoral update

Sector-wise, the BSE IT, TECk, Capital Goods, Auto, Healthcare and Telecom indices dipped over 1 per cent during the week. However, the BSE Oil, Metal, Realty, Consumer Durables indices and Bankex declined up to 2.31 per cent.


IPO update

Ujjivan Small Finance Bank has filed draft prospectus for a Rs 1,200 crore initial public offer (IPO) with market regulator Sebi. The bank is proposing to float an IPO of equity shares of face value of Rs 10 each, comprising a fresh issue of shares aggregating up to Rs Rs 1,200 crore in accordance with the Companies Act, 2013, Ujjivan said in a regulatory filing.


IDBI Bank

Shares of IDBI Bank tumbled over 9 per cent to Rs 24.90 on August 16 from Rs 27.40 on August 9. Life Insurance of Corporation of India (LIC)-owned IDBI Bank net losses widen to Rs 3,801 crore in the quarter ended June on higher provision for NPAs. The lender had posted a net loss of Rs 2,410 crore in the corresponding quarter last year.


HEG slipped over 4%

Shares of HEG declined 4.29 per cent during the week. The scrip came under pressure after the graphite electrodes maker said its June quarter profit plunged around 70 per cent to Rs 234 crore for the June quarter. Total revenue slipped 46 per cent to Rs 856 crore.

Technically we are buying those companies which are double or 2.5 times the size in 2014 but at the same valuation it was in 2014, says Sunil Singhania, Founder, Abakkus Asset Manager. Excerpts from an interview with Nikunj Dalmia of ETNOW.

In one of your notes you are comparing the current market environment with Bollywood movies. So, what does Jo Dar Gaya So Mar Gaya mean?I meet lots of investors as we are raising the second fund which is more midcap and smallcap focussed. It is very difficult even to convince investors. We have tried to use Bollywood because everyone follows it in India and used some famous dialogues to give their perspective to what is happening in India. 


Jo Dar Gaya Woh Mar Gaya means if you are afraid you might as well be dead. I think fear is more now and even in a lot of companies which are now trading at below book, below intrinsic value, below replacement cost largely because the near term outlook is slightly muted, though they still have profits.


So is it time to take risk?It is time to take risk. Unless you do that, how are you going to make money? You can either be an investor who does not want to take risks in terms of profitability, in terms of the economic environment. Then 2017 would have been best for you as the prices then were not worth taking risk for; or you can take risk now when the economy is struggling slightly and the prices of the same stocks have fallen 50-60%.


You picked up an example from Three Idiots to say when others are in trouble, we feel happy?Yes, in Three Idiots there is this dialogue dost fail hota hai to dukh hota hain, but dost first ata hai to jyada dukh hota hai (You feel sad when your friend fails but even sadder when he comes first). We have tried to relate it to the fact that there are some factors in the world which are negative. Trade war issues are impacting some countries; falling oil prices are impacting some countries and then we have countries with negative interest rate scenario. 

If oil prices fall it is positive, if trade wars happen India is the least impacted in terms of their exports but indirectly impacted if we are able to attract those companies to set up facilities in India. Most importantly, India still has a fairly good interest rate with a stable foreign exchange reserves, we have never defaulted ever in our obligations. Our foreign exchange reserves are very stable, we still are net recipients of foreign money. Others’ problems can become a boon for India.


A year from now, can we say the famous punch line of Aamir Khan, “All is well”? We have to all start to convince ourselves that all is not as bad as we are making out to be.


For the economy and for the markets?I would say both will go hand in hand. Markets might as I said precede the economic recovery.


If not a very large permanent bottom, fundamentally we could be reaching a bottom. A 10% selloff could happen because of technical factors, Dow, trade war, Brexit but fundamentally speaking, 10% is there to lose and 30% is what you can gain in the next 12-18 months?I do not know how much to lose or how much to gain. I would say the risk reward is heavily loaded in favour of investments. Your chances of losing are much smaller than the chances of gaining. Another interesting study which we are doing right now is just comparing the conditions of the company in 2014 to 2019. There are so many good companies. I am not talking about companies which are obscure. These are good companies which have market cap similar to what they were in 2014 but the size of those companies in terms of sales, operating profit, debt equity ratio and in terms of net profit is 2-2.5 times of that was in 2014.

Technically you are buying those companies which are double or 2.5 times the size in 2014 and at the same valuation that it was in 2014.


Ultimately when you are buying a stock you are buying future profit. The point that you are making is that if you are buying some good NBFCs and barring consumer durable companies, you are buying them at market cap and profit levels as low as 2013 and 2014?With no business valuation built in, if you buy an NBFC, at one time book, you are giving zero value to the whole franchise.


Gold is suddenly available at the price of silver, to put it very simply?I do not know about that. I do not want to give hopes that prices will go up by 10 times but our competition is now with the alternative opportunities. I do not see real estate is going anywhere. For fixed income, you make 6.5% in fixed deposits and you have 3% as tax. So you are left with 3.5%. The equity from these levels should do significantly better than other asset classes. It is always good to buy when the prices are low rather than when the prices are high.


In a reverse swing segment, this time you are talking about pharmaceuticals. Again this is one of those dusty-rusty sectors. There are genuine concerns at the company level and at the manufacturing level. Why do you stick your neck out and say there is a case to buy pharma structurally and selectively?If you go back in history, the big run in pharma stocks started from 2008 and it lasted till 2016. The genesis of that was the market cap of the whole pharma sector in India was less than that of DLF in 2008. It was a screaming buy with prices very low and there was this huge tailwind because a lot of drugs internationally were going off patent. 

By 2016, you were looking at pharma companies which were trading at 40 times trailing and 50 times trailing and then you had a lot of headwinds; one was the growth slowdown because the generic prices started to fall. There was a big headwind from the US regulatory issues and almost all pharma companies had to go in for import alert or restriction.

As a result of the growth slowdown, PE multiples fell. We are coming to a stage when it is getting interesting. I am not saying that go ahead and buy anything and everything in pharma tomorrow. Pharma has become more individualistic in terms of the companies which you invest in, but the regulatory headwinds are receding because the companies in India have also realised that they cannot use shortcuts.

At the same time, a lot of these plants had issues and two, three years have passed and one by one, they are coming off the issues. Second, the pricing pressure, particularly in the US, is receding. The debt levels of generic companies like Mylan or Teva or some of the other ones have gone crazy and that is the reason for this big deal between Mylan and Pfizer also. 

The ability for them to keep on selling at lower prices is reducing. In fact, prices have started to move up and that should be good for India. We have had a 2-3% fall in rupee which again will be a tailwind for pharma. Valuations are now in your favour. You are getting large companies at 15 PE which was unheard of. 

These are high ROA companies. You do not have concerns of debt being very high in a lot of these pharma companies and so it is becoming interesting. Selectively, it makes tremendous sense to start looking at them and maybe over the next three, six months create some exposure to that sector. 


So buy US facing generic companies?No Indian facing companies are also interesting but they are very expensive. If you look at multinational pharma companies in India, over the last one year, they have moved up 20-25% and they have significantly outperformed the exporting companies which was reverse. There will be some movement again back to this generic companies which are more US facing.


Typically when the slowdown starts, you sell what is expensive. But Asian Paints is sitting at a 52-week high. NBFCs have melted down but Bajaj Finance from the recent low of sub-2000 is at Rs 3500-3600 now. I looked a Trent. The PE multiple has gone north of 80 times. D-Mart is still standing tall. Why good quality stocks which should have corrected have become more expensive? You can always find exception Eicher, Maruti. But those are auto stocks.No, I would say that some of the expensive stocks in other sectors have also taken a beating like Page Industries which were market’s darlings two-three years back. So it has been mixed. One common trait in stocks which have not fallen is that even in such a scenario, they have been able to maintain some growth -- 10%, 12%. Also, remember, the mutual funds money is still coming in. There has been net inflows and obviously portfolio managers do get impacted because they have to show the near term performances on a monthly, daily, weekly basis. There is a natural tendency in these kind of markets where there is so much uncertainty to go into companies or stocks where you are feeling or getting that feeling of safety. 


Is there anything wrong in it because that strategy frankly has made money. Asian Paints was expensive five years ago as was HDFC Bank.There will always be exceptions to those rules but Hindustan Lever for example made zero returns between 2000 to 2008.


ITC it is not giving you returns for the last few years.ITC has not given returns last five-seven years. Obviously, Asian Paints and Hindustan Lever and Nestles are the exceptions but we have seen other companies like Britannia, Page Industries, Eicher and Maruti fall. It has been mixed. As an analyst, there is a concept that the stock prices or the stock valuation should ultimately reflect the future earning potential. 

If there is this case of a company growing at 5-7% and trading at 50 PE, obviously at some point of time, this is going to break down. But if you have companies that are trading at 30-35 PE and still growing at 15-20%, maybe you can justify it. Even in this high PE companies, you will have to distinguish companies which are trading at the levels today because of technical reasons, that is money flowing into those companies. There is no dilution and so the pool of money has to chase a limited availability of stocks. 

You can basically invest in companies which are discounted compared to their future earning potential. We would go in for the second kind of thing. In fact, the second fund which we have launched has three criteria -- 15% or more ROE, 15% or more growth but less than 15 PE. So for us, this basket is untouchable. 



According to your analysis, the reason SIP is doing well is because the millennials in India prefer SIPs. That is a mega trend in making and that is reflective because now markets are cracking but SIPs are slow.I am sure our parents and their parents never even looked at equity as an investment. There were two-three reasons. One, savings were not available. Their whole salary or income used to go in meeting the basic roti, kapda and makaan for their family. Second is awareness was not there and third, at that point of time, equity market was perceived to be like a gamble rather than an investment avenues. 

Over the last 20-30 years, it has changed and a lot of credit is to be given to media, to the mutual fund industry which has popularised this concept of investing regularly and the new generation – one are aware; second, they are making decent salaries even at a young age and therefore they have disposable income to be invested and technology has made it very easy. 

At one click, you can invest. You do not have to fill 20 forms like you had earlier. So, it is a combination of these things and which is very healthy. If we are able to channelise more savings which goes into equity market, the over reliance on foreign flows has already come down and that will come down further. 

This can only go up because now you have this robo advisory and online firms and companies like Alibaba in China are becoming one of the biggest asset management companies in China. Hopefully in India also, we will have two-three-four of those kind of platforms available which will make investing easier and there is now transparency. People trust the mutual fund side or the organised way of investing side.


Alternates are doing poorly . That is also one factor which is at play. Real estate, gold frankly the alternates have not given great returns.I would say that is more cyclical. After four-five years that might change but the investors have realised that they need to have a balanced portfolio. Earlier 90% used to go in real estate, 10%, 15% into fixed deposit and that was it. Now the large investors have created family offices. They know the virtues of having a balanced diversification as far as their savings are concerned. This is also a very positive thing going forward.

Benchmark equity indices Sensex and Nifty cracked for a third straight session on Thursday after Chief Economic Adviser (CEA) Krishnamurthy Subramanian in virtually ruled out a major stimulus package for the economy. Meanwhile, a sharp fall in the rupee and mixed global cues further weighed on market.

The BSE Sensex tanked 587.44 points, or 1.59 per cent, to 36,473, while the NSE Nifty index dipped 180.95 points, or 1.67 per cent, to 10,738.

Vivek Ranjan Misra, Head of Fundamental Research, Karvy Stock Broking said, “The market is getting impatient with regards to the prospects of a stimulus package from the government and the comments made by some government officials have dimmed hopes. We continue to expect some weakness in the near term, but expect the economy to stabilise in Q2FY20 and recover in the second half.”


We walk you through the key highlights of Thursday’s session:

EPFO to invest 50% each in Sensex, NiftyThe Central Board of Trustees allowed EPFO to invest its funds in Sensex and Nifty ETFs in the proportion of 50 per cent each.

“In the 225th Meeting of Central Board of Trustees held on August 21, the board approved the proposal of equal allocation of funds in Sensex and Nifty by EPFO. The board has agreed to evenly divide the fund allocation between Nifty 50 and Sensex ETFs, in the ratio of 50 per cent to 50 per cent," the BSE said in its release.

Originally, the board had approved 100 per cent investments in Nifty which was later changed to 25 per cent in Sensex and 75 per cent in Nifty.


YES Bank cracks 14%Shares of YES Bank tumbled 13.91 per cent amid ongoing concerns over its exposure to CG Power and Industrial Solutions, which has been hit by alleged financial irregularities and unauthorised transactions. The scrip settled the day at Rs 56.30 on BSE against its previous close of Rs 65.40. On the other hand, CG Power continued to hit lower circuit for third straight session, settled around 10 per cent down at Rs 10.65.


LIC Housing Finance cracksShares of LIC Housing Finance dipped nearly 11 per cent, possibly on a block deal that saw 6.7 per cent of the NBFC’s shares exchanging hands at a discount. 

ET reported that some marquee investors were to sell the stake in Rs 425.15-449.50 price range, which implied a discount of 3-8 per cent to Wednesday’s closing price. The scrip closed 10.97 per cent down at Rs 412.85.


DLF slips 16%Shares of real estate major DLF tanked amid reports that Supreme Court has issued a notice to DLF and market regulator Sebi on non-disclosure of key information in QIP. According to a report, a petition was filed in SC highlighting how DLF suppressed key information regarding judicial proceedings against its largest chunk of land-bank in Haryana. SC has now issued a notice to the developer and Sebi, which too is party to the case. The scrip closed 15.91 per cent down at Rs 144.30.


NDTV tumbles Shares of NDTV dropped 3.58 per cent on BSE after CBI booked promoters Prannoy Roy and Radhika Roy, among others, for allegedly violating foreign direct investment (FDI) rules in a 2007-09 investment, a charge denied by the company. “NDTV strongly denies these allegations and is seeking legal advice in this regard,” the company told BSE.

The scrip settled the day at Rs 35, down 3.58 per cent against its previous close of Rs 36.30.


Most active stocksWith 31.46 crore shares changing hands, YES Bank emerged as the most traded stock on NSE, followed by Vodafone Idea (number of shares traded: 13.25 crore), DLF (8.67 crore), Tata Motors (5.86 crore) and Reliance Capital (4.45 crore). 

YES Bank (Rs 1,882.75 crore) also finished as the most active stock in terms of value. LIC Housing Finance (Rs 1,377.76 crore), Indiabulls Housing Finance (Rs 1313.39 crore), DLF (Rs 1,287.70 crore) and Maruti Suzuki (Rs 966.20 crore) also featured on the table of most active stocks in value terms. 


Spurt in open InterestWith a change of 61.83 per cent, LIC Housing Finance led the pack of stocks that witnessed the biggest spurt in open interest on NSE. It was followed by DLF (33.95 per cent), Grasim (23.03 per cent), Bajaj Finserv (20.45 per cent) and UPL (16.11 per cent). 


Nearly 500 @ 52-week low As many as 492 stocks, including Allahabad Bank, Avanti Feeds, Bajaj Consumer Care, Bank of Baroda, Bliss GVS Pharma, Borosil Glass, Eicher Motors, Hindustan Zinc and Quick Heal Technologies, hit 52-week lows on NSE.

On the other hand, Den Networks, GSK Consumer Healthcare, Dr Lal Path Labs and Nestle India were among 11 stocks that hit 52-week highs.


Sectoral updateThe BSE Realty index tanked 6 per cent with DLF falling the most at 16 per cent. It was followed by Indiabulls Real Estate (down 7 pe rcent) and Suntech (down 6.27 per cent) and Oberoi Realty (down 5.57 per cent). Other sectoral indices including Metal, Oil & Gas and Bankex also declined between 2-3.50 per cent.

To step into the market and start buying or sit on the side-lines, that is the question!

Most investors, seasoned or novice, are failing to make up their minds even after several Nifty50 stocks cracked up to 80 per cent from their 52-week highs.

In the broader market, only 87 stocks, representing just 2.9 per cent of BSE universe, have delivered positive returns since early 2018. The remaining 97 per cent have eroded up to 99 per cent of investor wealth in last 18 months. Several stocks have dived up to 98 per cent from their 52-week high levels.

Many of these are, of course, victims of a slowdown that is becoming more and more pronounced in the economy, while several others have perished because of issues related to corporate governance, large debt piles and sector-specific headwinds.

The biggest index loser is, of course, YES Bank, which has tanked 82 per cent to trade at Rs 65 on August 21 from its all-time high of Rs 404 hit on August 20 last year. The private sector lender recently raised Rs 1,930 crore through a qualified institutional placement (QIP).

Market expert Sameer Narayan says instead of looking at the stock from a short-term perspective, one has to see what kind of capital has come in and from what kind of investors. 

Mortgage lender Indiabulls Housing Finance, auto majors Tata Motors, Mahindra & Mahindra, Eicher Motors and metal players JSW Steel, Tata Steel and Vedanta are down between 40 and 60 per cent from their respective 52-week highs. 

Sanjiv Bhasin, Executive Vice President, IIFL, says Tata Steel and JSW Steel have become good value picks now.

Moody’s Investors Service has downgraded Indiabulls Housing Finance’s long-term corporate family rating to Ba2 from Ba1.

Analysts say overall the auto sector got hit primarily due to highly subdued volume performance across segments over the past three quarters, which has been attributed to higher insurance cost, a liquidity squeeze in the NBFC space, new axle load norm besides the forthcoming shift to BS-VI pollution norms from April, 2020. 

Even the country’s biggest carmaker Maruti Suzuki and the world's largest two-wheeler manufacturer Hero MotoCorp have slipped 39 per cent and 22 per cent, respectively, from their 52-week high levels. 

Both stocks have since started rising, but most analysts remain cautious. “I would wait for another quarter at least and see how the financing side pans out. I think it is too early to bottom-fish in auto sector,” said Ratnesh Kumar, MD & CEO, BOB Capital Market.

Other Nifty components like Sun Pharma, GAIL, Zee Entertainment, Coal India, Grasim Industries, ONGC, Hindalco, IndusInd Bank, Cipla, Britannia, IOC, UPL and Bharti Infratel have lost over 25 per cent from their year’s highs in this correction.

So what do you do now? Buy for keeps, wait for short-term play. That’s the verdict coming in from market veterans.

Considering the ongoing correction, market veterans are advising investors to stay cautious for the short term and adopt a stock-specific approach in this market. However, long-term investors with 5-10 years horizon should definitely start picking quality stocks. 

“Investors with long-time horizon should definitely start buying. We are bullish on manufacturing companies, especially those in the chemicals sector, select technology and private banking players. We are not bullish on infrastructure sector, apart from L&T,” says Narendra Solanki, Head Fundamental Research (Investment Services) – and AVP for Equity Research at Anand Rathi Shares & Stock Brokers.

Even shares of the most stable companies – Asian Paints, Hindustan Unilever, Infosys, TCS, Kotak Mahindra Bank, Bharti Airtel, Power Grid, ICICI Bank, Reliance Industries and HCL Technologies – have fallen between 1 and 10 per cent from their 52-week highs.

The benchmark NSE Nifty index is down around 9 per cent from its 52-week high of 12,103 hit on June 3, 2019. On August 21, the index traded at price-to-earnings ratio of 27 against its 10-year average and five-year of 22 times and 24.20 times, respectively. This indicates that the market is still looking overvalued at index level in terms of valuations.

Kuntal Shah, Partner, Oaklane Capital Management, says many cycles are playing out in the market at the same time.

“There is a business cycle, there is an economic cycle, there is a fiscal cycle, and more importantly, there is investor behaviour cycle,” says he. “If you have spent adequate number of years in the market, you know this too will turn around,” he said.

ET Intelligence Group: The stock of Nestle India hit a record high on the speculation of being included in the Nifty 50 index in its next reshuffle. However, short-term investors may well book profit in the stock if such an inclusion stands confirmed.

This is because two out of every three companies that have made it to the Nifty in the past five years have posted negative returns in the year after inclusion. As many as 19 out of the 21 stocks underperformed after a year of inclusion against their performance a year before, indicating that the Nifty inclusion comes at the time of peak performance. It is also indicative that much of the positive sentiment surrounding the inclusion gets factored in well before the actual inclusion.

For instance, the Britannia stock was included in the Nifty in March this year. The stock is down 18 per cent since, whereas it had gained 20 per cent in the year before the inclusion. Similarly, JSW Steel, which got added in October 2018, is down 44 per cent till now. It had posted 52 per cent gains in the year preceding its inclusion.

Only two – Eicher Motors and Bajaj Finserv – of the 21 stocks that got included in the Nifty in the past five years performed better a year after their inclusion in the benchmark index. Trading at very high valuation of 71 times of its trailing four quarter earnings, the Nestle stock will be the most expensive FMCG stock in the index, if included.


Guest contributor and other agenciesSource: ETIG Database
Nestle India reported an exceptional performance in the latest quarter to June, posting 10.5 per cent growth in volume amid overall slowdown in demand.

While acknowledging the slowdown, the management has hinted of single-digit growth this year. The company posted a smart recovery since FY16 when its flagship noodle brand Maggi got embroiled in controversy concerning its quality. The company has institutional holding of 20 per cent. Its return on net worth stands at 45 per cent and return on capital employed at 43 per cent. The company is relaunching its global malt-based drink Milo in India.

By Chandan Taparia
NSE Nifty failed to extend its winning run and drifted towards the 11,000 level on Wednesday. The index remained highly volatile as it failed to surpass 11,150, but the dips were bought into near 11,000.

The headline index has been finding multiple hurdles in 11,145-11,150 zone from the last four weeks and needs to cross and hold above the same to extend its bounce or else rangebound moves could return.

Now, Nifty has to hold above 11,000 to witness an upmove towards 11,145-11,150 while on the downside support exists at 10,980 and then 10,929.

On the Options front, maximum Put open interest stood at 11,000 followed by 10,800 strike while maximum Call open interest was at 11,200 followed by 11,100 strike.

We have seen meaningful Call writing at 11,100 followed by 11,200 strike while Put unwinding was seen at all the immediate strike price. Option data suggests a trading range between 10,950 to 11,100 zone.

India VIX surged 5.15 per cent to the 16.83 level.

NEW DELHI: Despite big discounts, automakers are likely to report up to 35 per cent drop in volumes in August. Carmakers are seen taking the biggest hit, while two-wheeler makers may report double-digit fall in sales on a yearly basis, brokerages said.

Wholesale volumes should have improved as festive season is starting 10 days earlier this year, but declining retail sales and high inventory levels may have kept wholesale volumes muted in August, said Nomura India.

“For August, we expect passenger vehicle industry volumes to decline sharply by 31 per cent YoY. This would be led by Maruti Suzuki, which we expect could report a 35 per cent dip in domestic volumes, affected by weak retail sales,” the foreign brokerage said.

Motilal Oswal Securities said its channel checks indicates no signs of demand recovery at retail levels, as inquiries-to-sales remains tepid.

“Feedback on prefestive demand is not very encouraging, partly impacted by floods in several parts of the country and demand deferment in anticipation of some sops from the government. Most OEMs continued their inventory cutting efforts through production cuts,” the brokerage said. Personal vehicle space saw weak poor conversion rate for existing models, even as new launches attracted good response,” it said.

The brokerage expects Maruti Suzuki’s volumes to plunge 31 per cent, whereas it sees Mahindra & Mahindra’s utility vehicle (UV) segment falling 18 per cent. Tata Motors volumes are estimated to decline 33 per cent.

Kotak Institutional Equities sees 28 per cent drop in volumes for Maruti, 27.7 per cent drop in passenger vehicle sales for Tata Motors and a 14 per cent drop in UV segment for Mahindra & Mahindra. 

In the two-wheeler space, Kotak Institutional Equities sees 9-13 per cent drop in sales for players such as Hero MotoCorp, Bajaj Auto, TVS Motors and Eicher Motors (Royal Enfield).

Motilal expects Bajaj Auto’s sales to fall by 9 per cent, with the domestic business expected to see 14 per cent decline in volumes. Hero MotoCorp’s wholesales are estimated to fall 25 per cent on a yearly basis.

Nomura expects two-wheeler industry’s volumes to decline 22 per cent, the steepest since December 2018.

“Inventory levels remain very high and a retail demand recovery is needed to correct the 6-8 weeks inventory ahead of the BS-IV changeover,” it said.

In case of commercial vehicles, Motilal Oswal Securities said demand from all major end-user segments remains tepid, resulting in further increase in average discounts.

“We expect CV wholesales for Ashok Leyland to decline 36 per cent and for Tata Motors to decline by 42 per cent due to continued inventory correction,” the brokerage said.

Nomura said that the commercial vehicle industry is likely to witness a volume decline of 44 per cent. It expects flat volume for M&M largely led by early festive season this year.

NEW DELHI: VE Commercial Vehicles Ltd, a Volvo Group and Eicher Motors joint venture, on Sunday reported a 41.7 per cent decline in total sales at 3,538 units in August.

The company had sold 6,069 units in August last year, VE Commercial Vehicles Ltd (VECV) said in a statement.

Eicher branded trucks and buses recorded sales of 3,462 units in August as compared to 5,948 units in the same month last year, a decline of 41.8 per cent, it added.

Volvo Trucks recorded sales of 76 units in last month as against 121 units in August 2018, down 37.2 per cent.

Domestic equity indices BSE Sensex and NSE Nifty cracked over 2 per cent on Tuesday amid heavy selling following a set of subdued macroeconomic data. The 30-share Sensex tanked as much as 770 points to 36,563 while NSE Nifty ended at 10,798, down 225 points or 2.04 per cent.

Here are the top domestic factors that have sent the stocks tumbling in early trade.


Subdued Q1 GDP print
Market sentiment got impacted after June quarter GDP data released on Friday showed the country’s growth rate slumped for the fifth straight quarter to hit an over six-year low of 5 per cent. According to an ICICI Bank economist, the lower-than-expected GDP print indicated that the slowdown is more pervasive, underscoring the need for coordinated monetary and fiscal policy actions.


Weak core data & other macros
Official data on Monday showed the growth of eight core industries dropped to 2.1 per cent in July, mainly due to a contraction in coal, crude oil and natural gas production. And a private forecaster’s PMI data showed the country’s manufacturing sector activity declined to its 15-month low in August. The IHS Markit India Manufacturing Purchasing Managers’ Index (PMI) declined to 51.4 in August, its lowest mark since May 2018, from 52.5 in July.


Falling rupee and FII outflows
The rupee tanked by 64 paise to 72 mark against the US dollar in early deals on Tuesday following weak macroeconomic data and sustained outflows by foreign portfolio investors (FPI). Overseas investors offloaded stocks worth a net of Rs 5,920 crore in the domestic market in August even after the government rolled back enhanced tax surcharge on FPIs. In July, they had pulled out a net of Rs 2,985.88 crore from Indian stocks.


Aug auto sales data showed pain
Most of the auto stock traded in the red following subdued auto sales numbers for August. Tata Motors, Eicher Motors, Mahindra & Mahindra, Ashok Leyland and Maruti Suzuki slipped up to 2.61 per cent. While Maruti reported a 33 per cent drop in August sales at 1,06,413 units, sale of passenger vehicles at Tata Motors fell 58 per cent.

Insurance, AMCs, consumption and infra sectors are likely to see mega structural trends, says Atul Suri, Founder & CEO, Marathon Trends - PMS. Excerpts from an interview with ETNOW.


Maruti and Eicher were fantastic stories two years ago. They were the real tall poster boys, great compounders, good company, direct play on consumption. Maruti is down 50% approximately from its all-time high, Eicher from Rs 30,000 has become Rs 15,000. What is going on with autos? In the three-month phase we are talking about, while the index is down 9%, auto sectoe is down 17%. I used to have all these marquee names in my portfolio at one stage but being trend investors, as trends change, earnings change and we exited them. What you really see is that the auto sector has three to five-year trends. They almost double and halve in all these phases. They are very secular in nature the important thing is to be able to some extent even time it. 

Autos also are a very good proxy to the underlying economy. I always think, auto is a very good bellwether sector. The overall economic cycle as we know is struggling and that is why as a precursor, these stocks have corrected. However, the fact is things will turn but we do not know when that happens. It is our job to look at the kind of numbers they report and kind of trends that will play out.


Are you happy to own the mega caps: Do you see more visibility in three months, six months?I think three years, five years because today I am outperforming but when markets revive, you will have a relative period of underperformance because all these small and midcaps spurt up too much. It is for you to have the maturity, it is for you to have a belief in your process so as to also go through those phases because as I said, when the cycle is over you, realise you are better off. You do get tempted to jump out, you do tempted to be that cute guy and play that trade and do a quick pop but it has never really made money because in the top or towards the end of the next cycle, you always find you are stuck with kachra (junk) where you never intended to be and when the tide turned, you are found swimming naked. 

You have to be a survivor of cycles and those stocks which fall less in falling markets, are the first to rise when the markets turn.


 I will divide the market into three parts; first structural trends,where for five years, 10 years, you can buy these trends not for yourself but for your son and for your grandson. Then there are cyclical trends where you could see a 2-3-year trend and then where there is scope for immediate gratification. How would you divide the market in these three components?The first category is where I would like to be positioned. We spoke of insurance companies. It is a very interesting space. AMC companies selectively. again If you are talking about a $5-trillion economy, these become very good places. Consumption selectively. Yes they will go through cycles, they are expensive but you realise that over years, they are the wealth creators. Financials, NBFCs which are of very high quality. Again these are expensive in PE terms but you will have to bite the bullet at some stage. I personally think that these are the spaces which tend to be the mega trends that is where I am positioned and that is where I would like to be positioned. 

As for the pop ups that will happen or the opportunities that can come, I am not positioned in them but I feel that the government will give a push to infrastructure and infrastructure related stocks.

NEW DELHI: Slowing economic growth coupled with other bleak macroeconomic numbers, including auto sales and core sectors data, forced benchmark equity indices Sensex and Nifty to shed over 2 per cent each on Tuesday. 

The 30-share Sensex tanked 769.88 points, or 2.06 per cent, to 36,562.91, while the 50-share Nifty dipped 225.35 points, or 2.04 per cent, to 10,797.90.

Sentiment on Dalal Street remained cautious after data on Friday showed that the country’s GDP growth slipped to an over six-year low of 5 per cent in the June quarter of 2019-20. Besides, manufacturing sector activity also slipped to its 15-month low in August. Growth of eight core industries also dropped to 2.1 per cent in July.

Vinod Nair, Head of Research, Geojit Financial Services said: “Deceleration in economic growth due to fall in consumption and subdued manufacturing activity diminished the scope for a turnaround in the near-term. Additionally, weak monthly auto sales and outflows by foreign investors added volatility to the rupee.” 


We walk you through the key highlights of Tuesday’s session:


IDBI Bank gains 8% Shares of IDBI Bank gained nearly 8 per cent after the government approved over Rs 9,000 crore capital infusion in IDBI Bank with a view to increasing the lender's capital base. The government will infuse Rs 4,557 crore, while LIC will inject Rs 4,700 crore in the bank.


Select sugar stocks sweetenSugar companies hogged limelight after the government announced a hike in the price of ethanol procured by public sector oil marketing companies for one year starting December. Shares of Dharani Sugars, Simbhaoli Sugars and Rajshree Sugars advanced between 5-10 per cent.


Nifty PSU Bank cracks 5% Nifty PSU Bank index tanked 4.87 per cent after the government on Friday announced the merger of 10 state-run lenders into four. Indian Bank cracked the most 11.96 per cent. It was followed by Canara Bank (down 11.94 per cent), Union Bank (down 10.11 per cent), Oriental Bank (down 10 per cent) and PNB (8.94 per cent).


Auto woes deepenBarring TVS Motor (up 2.20 per cent) and Ashok Leyland (up 0.93 per cent), other stocks in BSE Auto index slipped up to 4.44 per cent. The sector came under pressure after automakers reported dismal sales for August due to depressed consumer sentiment amid higher cost of ownership. Maruti Suzuki posted a 33 per cent fall in August sales at 1,06,413 units, sale of passenger vehicles by Tata Motors fell 58 per cent during the month under review. Shares of Maruti, Tata Motors, Eicher Motors and Mahindra & Mahindra slipped over 1 per cent each.


Who dragged my SensexWith a drop of 3.40 per cent, Reliance Industries contributed 134 points to the Sensex’s fall, followed by HDFC (down 3.67 per cent), ICICI Bank (down 4.45 per cent), HDFC Bank (down 0.88 per cent) and Larsen & Toubro (down 2.56 per cent). 


Most active stocksWith 19.63 crore shares changing hands, YES Bank emerged as the most traded stock on the NSE, followed by Punjab National Bank (number of shares traded: 6.83 crore), Vodafone Idea (5.85 crore), Ashok Leyland (4.78 crore) and Tata Motors (3.69 crore). On the other hand, YES Bank (Rs 1,170 crore) finished as the most active stock in terms of value, followed by Reliance Industries (Rs 1,047 crore), Indiabulls Housing Finance (Rs 874 crore), IndusInd Bank (Rs 844 crore) and HDFC (Rs 842 crore).


Spurt in open InterestWith a change of 55.36 per cent, Canara Bank led the pack of stocks in the biggest spurt in open interest on NSE. It was followed by MCX (50.59 per cent), IDBI (38.21 per cent) and PNB (32.69 per cent).


140 stocks hit 52-week lowsAs many as 140 stocks on NSE hit their fresh 52-week low. The list included stocks such as Tejas Network, Ujaas Energy, Shah Alloys, Sanwaria Consumer, Reliance Communications and Jaiprakash Power Ventures. On the other hand, Abbott India, HDFC AMC, Bata India, Infosys and TCS stood among 16 players that hit fresh 52-week highs.


Investors loses Rs 2.60 lakh croreDalal Street suffered a wealth erosion of Rs 2.60 lakh crore as market capitalisation of the BSE-listed firms slipped to Rs 138.38 lakh crore from Rs 140.98 lakh crore on August 30.


Put/Call writingOn the Options front, maximum Put open interest (OI) was at 10,800 followed by 10,600 strike, while maximum Call OI stood at 11,700 followed by 11,200 strike. Call writing was seen at 11,000 followed by 10,900 strike while minor Put writing was at 10,800 and 10,600 strike.

Option data suggests a lower trading range between 10,600 and 11,200 level, according to Chandan Taparia, Analyst-Derivatives at Motilal Oswal Financial Services.

NEW DELHI: Auto shares were trading in the red in Tuesday's morning session after major auto companies reported dismal sales for August, thanks to depressed consumer sentiment amid higher cost of ownership. 

Analysts said enhanced safety and emission norms and increased insurance cost have hurt buyers’ enthusiasm. While there are expectations of government sops in the days to come, analysts do not see any drastic improvement in volumes anytime soon. 

In the fourwheeler space, demand for small cars took the biggest hit in August. In the case of Maruti, while total volumes dropped 35.9 per cent in August, slightly above analysts’ estimate of 3033 per cent, demand for Alto and old WagonR dropped 71.8 per cent. 

“Consumer sentiment is depressed, but one must note that a lot of vehicles were sold in 20152017, which were the result of the replacement demand that generally happens in 56 years. After three years of strong sales, you can’t expect 2019 or 2020 to play out well. If the forthcoming festive season fails to boost demand, inventories may shoot up drastically and we may see a second leg of discounts in November and December. I am unsure how deep that can go,” said Sameer Kalra of Target Investing.

The Nifty Auto index was trading 1.23 per cent down at 6922.95 around 09:47 am. 

Shares of Tata Motors (down 3.83 per cent), Amara Raja Batteries (down 2.79 per cent) , Bosch (down 2.74 per cent) and Eicher Motors (down 2.50 per cent) were trading lower. 

Motherson Sumi Systems (down 2.30 per cent) , Ashok Leyland (down 2.09 per cent) , Mahindra & Mahindra (down 1.95 per cent) and Exide Industries (down 1.37 per cent) were the top losers in the index.

Mumbai: Stocks slumped the most in nearly a year as a triple whammy of dismal economic data combined with the shock of the decision to merge 10 public sector banks into four rattled investors reeling from the effects of slowing global growth and a trade war.

The rupee fell 99 paise, the most in over a year, weighed down by China’s decision to move the World Trade Organization. Foreign investors continued to dump shares on Tuesday though they kept up purchases in Indian debt.

The Sensex crashed 770 points, or 2.06 per cent, its biggest single-day fall in 11 months. The Nifty fell 225 points, or 2.04 per cent, as investors fretted over last week’s poor economic data and the short-term impact of the merger of PSU banks.

Large-caps fell the most, led by HDFC Bank, ICICI Bank and Reliance Industries. Mid- and smallcap stocks fared better, falling 1.6 per cent and 1.3 per cent, respectively. ICICI Bank fell 4.45 per cent while HDFC and RIL slipped 3.5 per cent each.


“A move below 10,740 might force the Nifty to breach the recent low of 10,637. That would be dangerous for the markets,” said Mehul Kothari, technical analyst at India-Nivesh Securities. “On the upside, a move above 10,810 might bring in some relief, but that could be temporary. We continue to advise traders to stay light and avoid aggressive bets.”

The Centre announced the merger of 10 state-run banks into four on Friday, but the move was overshadowed by poor economic data.


Auto stocks witness a sharp selloff

First quarter GDP growth slipped to a six-year low of 5 per cent while core sector data — which captures the growth of eight crucial infrastructure industries — showed just 2.1 per cent expansion in July, down from last year’s 7 per cent. Auto sales had another bad month in August, falling 26.7 per cent, as buyers stayed away owing to high interest rates and slowdown in credit.

“Markets have reacted to the weak auto sales data, (and) lower-thanexpected GDP growth number which indicates the slowdown is more pronounced, thus requiring both monetary and fiscal policy measures,” said Arun Thukral, MD, Axis Securities. “News flow from global markets is not conducive either. The US-China trade conflict has reached a new high, with both the nations continuing to talk but also imposing additional tariffs on goods from each other.”

State-owned banks declined sharply as most banking analysts forecast near-term pain following the mergers.

The Nifty Bank index fell 2.2 per cent while Nifty PSU Bank index plunged 4.87 per cent. The PSU bank index has fallen 28 per cent in the past one year, compared with a 6.77 per cent decline in the Nifty during the period.

Overseas investors have sold shares worth Rs 2,016 crore in August while domestic investors have picked up stocks worth Rs 1,251 crore. Since April, foreign investors have net sold shares worth Rs 8,700 crore while domestic investors have bought Rs 39,000 crore of shares.

“The continuing negative global cues, the raging tariff war between the US and China, and the likely sluggishness in economies around the world have been behind the rot in the markets here as well as elsewhere,” said Joseph Thomas, head of research, Emkay Wealth Management.

Auto stocks witnessed a sharp selloff following subdued sales numbers for August. The BSE Auto index declined 1.64 per cent. Tata Motors, Motherson Sumi, Eicher Motors and Mahindra & Mahindra fell nearly 3 per cent each. Investors were not enthused by the government’s announcement on Monday that it is considering a duty cut for automobiles.

IDBI Bank rallied 8 per cent to Rs 28.80 after the Cabinet approved a mega fund infusion into the bank.

Shares of HDFC Asset Management Company jumped 3.57 per cent to close at a record high of Rs 2,649.75.

IT shares gained on weak domestic currency. Tech Mahindra and HCL Technologies rose a per cent each while Infosys ended flat.

“Given the overall negative news flow, one should take a contrarian call by investing in sound companies with growth potential. These stocks are now available at relatively attractive valuations. As Warren Buffett has time and again emphasised, ‘one must be greedy when the world around you is fearful’,” said Thukral of Axis Securities.

As long as you do not overpay when you are investing over three, five years, you should do reasonably well. And I think in that sense it is a great market, says Prashant Jain, ED & CIO, HDFC Asset Management Co. Ltd. Excerpts from an interview with ETNOW. 
Even though it feels like a bear market in mid and smallcap stocks, your view is that it is not a bear market for the economy and the earnings.What has happened is very simply growth has slowed down. Bear market is not the correct way to describe it. I would say there is a slowdown in the economy; consumer discretionary is particularly impacted; other segments are not impacted. The equity markets are offering good value. When largecaps start offering good value, you are unlikely to get things wrong because these are large businesses with low leverage. Corporate leverage in India has come down. Most of the businesses which were in deep pain have either been sold or they are in a state where it does not really matter. The businesses are doing reasonably well and things are okay.


In last five years, we have seen one event after the other -- demonetisation, GST, election cycle, IBC. The way Indian corporates have done business has changed in the last couple of years and will change. The transition is causing pain. When do you think the pain will get over and real resilience in earnings come?This is a very tough question to answer but we know what is missing in the economy and what needs to be done. What needs to be done is that private capex has to revive and when private capex revives with a six month lag consumption will automatically and sustainably revive. All questions that we need to ask is what can be done to revive private capex which has been so weak for so long. The answers are lower interest rates, resolving the IBC cases ASAP and moderating the supply by the government in primary markets, so that there is room for the private sector to raise capital. 

The supply of primary capital in the economy is limited. It is 20 billion which is 1% of GDP roughly that is not a lot. If that also we start impounding, then how will the capex revive? Please remember the leverage ratio in core sectors in the private sector are much higher than in public sector firms. Who needs to raise primary capital are the private sector core companies. Unless they get that capital, I do not think we will see a sustained revival in private capex.


You have shied away from autos. Maruti was part of your portfolio in 2014-15. I do not see mention of Maruti in your declared portfolio. Did you sell out of autos? Do you think we may not see again the kind of PE multiples autos commanded -- Maruti went to 40 times, Eicher went to some 40-50 times?We sold automobiles or at least I reduced automobiles in my portfolio mainly driven by valuations.


It was not a call on disruption?It was at the back of the mind that it will create challenges but in the passenger vehicle market we think the electric disruption will come in the last. It will happen first in two- wheelers, three-wheelers and public transport. So, it was there at the back of your mind but the primary reason were the valuations. At the peak, some of these companies were trading close to 40 times and we are also aware that a reasonable part of the growth has been sustained due to increased household leverage and that is telling you that when you are borrowing and spending and if income growth is not there, you will hit a roadblock. We were not so optimistic on sustained growth in this space despite the low penetration levels. But valuation is the primary reason.


But now that pain is also reflecting in the stock prices, If you are confident of investment and consumption recovering first, do you think there is merit in revisiting autos?The prices have come down but the multiples have not come down because earnings will also degrow sharply. First investment has to revive, salaries have to go up and then we can make a case for sustained revival in consumer discretionary . There are a lot of factors at play here because if you look at the way the passenger car market is evolving, the UV space is growing much faster. The scooters gained share massively in the two-wheeler market, the sedans are losing share and the market share in the UV space are very different from the SUV space. The UV space is a reasonably open market with three-four players and each have 20-25% share.


You have a large exposure to utilities. Typically utilities do well when interest rates are on their way down. Interest rates have come down, 8.5% has become 6.5%. Why are utility stocks not going high?Value investing works but it does test your patience and that is why it is difficult and challenging. In some places, it took three, five years for stocks to correct and in some cases it took two, three years for them to go up also. Look at what happened to NBFCs, pharmaceuticals, automobiles and auto ancillaries, they did not correct or go up overnight. It took a few years. So in utilities, in India, value is on our side. If you look at the price to book values of these companies, they are at lifetime lows, dividend yields are good. These are good large, dominant businesses. They are not going away anywhere and interest rates are low so the room for price to book value is to go up is actually significant. The challenge here again has been that there has been continuous supply at every price point and we have to wait either for that supply to get absorbed or for it to get curtailed. But in the end, because the business values are not at risk and are growing, lower interest rates means more value for the same profits. What we are debating is when will stock prices go up? It is the nature of the animal that there is uncertainty over that but if value is there, we will realise it one day.


You made this point on this show in 2015 about pharma that prices had come down but PE multiples did not contract. But now PE multiples have also contracted. I have been told that globally generic prices have also bottomed out. You were bearish on pharma. Have you turned bullish now?Pharma is reasonably valued. It is not deep value but risk is also limited and Indian companies are very competitive globally just like in IT and I think profits should grow from here. 

But please remember, two things are happening; one your share in US markets is pretty large and as I said earlier, export growth for a country like India, 80% export growth comes by way of market share gains and not by market gains itself. 

When you are a large part of the market, you can see the Indian business in US generics and IT exports both are growing in single digits. So, you cannot lose sight of that fact. 

Number two, if you look at the local markets for a variety of reasons, the growth rates in local markets in pharmaceutical industry has come down to close to single digits. Earlier, this industry used to grow in mid to high double digits but those times have changed. It could be because of Jan Aushadhi. It could be because of new players, it could be because of one or two new e-commerce websites which are doing business. It could also be because of low inflation. I feel the sector is close to fairly valued.


You have owned largecap IT for a reasonable amount of time. What did trick for largecap IT was the fact that America did much better than what we thought. BFSI businesses have stabilised and the buyback kicker has kicked in. Post budget, the entire romance of a buyback is gone thanks to a tax. What happens to IT stocks then?As shareholders, we are and we should be indifferent to dividends or buybacks.


 You buy the business you do not buy it for...No, whether you share cash by way of dividends or by way of buybacks, we are indifferent but to the extent that buybacks are being taxed, it will not make a difference whether you share cash with by-- but the payout ratios of IT companies are 80-90%. That is a great business which can keep on growing and share 80-90% of profits or free cash flow as dividends or buybacks. It tells you about the fundamental strength of that.


Do you think for a long term investor, the differentiating factor would be patience and time? Equities need more patience than intelligence and that is time tested. Anyone who has held equities for long periods in a reasonably disciplined and diversified way has done well. It should not be different anytime around, if at all there is any correlation between your returns over three, five years and investments it is only with valuations. Forget about the economy, forget everything. As long as you do not overpay when you are investing over three, five years, you should do reasonably well. And I think in that sense it is a great market.

By Swapneel MantriTechnical analyst, Sushil Financial Services

Where we are: The holiday curtailed week goneby saw Nifty largely trading rangebound on back of mixed news of weak GDP numbers and positive US-China tariff talks. Nifty ended the week at 10,946.


What is in store: Expect rangebound trade to continue with some form of short-term bottom in place for Nifty around 10,800-10,850. On levels, 10,990-11,090 immediate target zone. Close above 11,120 levels may see Nifty heading towards 11,220-11,300 zone. Further, advance-decline ratio has been healthy in past few trading sessions indicating improving market breadth and some form of intermediate bottoming can be seen amongst select midcap counters.


What could traders do: The current downturn offers a good opportunity for investors to accumulate quality scrips at low level and bolster the portfolio from long term point of view. Stock-specific frontline banking counters like IndusInd, SBI offer a good entry point at current levels and can be accumulated from short-to-medium term point of view for higher targets of 1,450 and 320-340, respectively. Further, two-wheeler stocks like Eicher Motors, Hero MotoCorp showing intermediate bottoming signs and expect to head towards 18,500 and 2,990 levels, respectively, in the short-to-medium term. Among the metal counters, Tata Steel, Hindalco arelooking good for short-to-medium term targets of 390 and 210 levels, respectively.

Auto companies could see another round of earnings cuts as the asking monthly run-rates for the remaining months of FY20, given the current projections, appear rather tall.

Projected EPS of auto companies have been slashed 15-35 per cent for FY20. Still, the risk of negative earnings growth is mounting for several auto companies, such as Ashok Leyland, Tata Motors, Maruti and Eicher Motors, according to IIFL.

Despite the sharp fall in volumes in the first five months, the Street is penciling in volume decline of 8-15 per cent for FY20. This suggests the Street is building in a pickup in volume growth of 10-70 per cent for the second half.

On the face of it, such run-rates appear optimistic.




First, the second quarter volume growth has been mainly driven by inventory filling to stock up dealer’s inventory ahead of the festival season. However, in the current scenario due to elevated inventory at the dealer end, off-take by the dealers has remained muted. Some dealers told ET on the sideline of the ET Auto retail summit that the turnaround time for trucks carrying vehicles has become too long as yards are stocked full due to low retail offtake.

Second, expectations of lower prices for BS-4 vehicles from the beginning of next year and the likelihood of a GST rate cut are prompting buyers to defer their purchases even though discounts hit a record.

Expectations of a recovery in the second half can be gauged from the fact that Maruti’s volume growth in the first five months dropped 24 per cent. Yet, the Street is factoring in a 10 per cent decline, implying growth of 27-30 per cent in the second half of the year, which appears to be a hard task given the challenging environment. In simple terms, the current five monthly volume run-rate is 124,000, while the implied volume for the second half is 158,000-160,000 units based on the projected volume growth for the current fiscal.

Ashok Leyland’s heavy commercial business volume is estimated to increase 60 per cent in the remaining seven months of FY20 to achieve the current volume guidance. Ashok Leyland’s MHCV monthly run-rate is about 8,000 units in the first five months, and it must reach 12,000 units to meet the existing full-year volume forecast.

Volumes of two-wheelers, passenger cars and trucks fell 20-50 per cent YoY between April and August. The decline in volumes has been accentuated in the past two months due to the rising cost of ownership, stringent lending terms by the banks, and a muted macro environment.

The passenger car segment witnessed the highest ever monthly drop in August in more than two decades, and volume growth remains negative for 12 months in a row. In the past 25 years, passenger vehicle monthly growth remained negative for such a long period only on five occasions.

Separately, inventories of two-wheelers and heavy commercial vehicles continued to be nearly double the average.

Auto stocks were in top gear in Wednesday’s session on Dalal Street, after Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman on Tuesday said the government would soon respond to the demands of the auto sector. Cement stocks rallied on the FM’s pledge to frontload infrastructure spends, trying to get the engines of growth buzzing.

YES Bank hogged limelight amid reports that promoter Rana Kapoor was in talks with Paytm promoter Vijay Shekhar Sharma to sell a stake. ICICI Lombard tanked amid reports that 2.70 per cent equity changed hands in a block deal.

Equity benchmark Nifty rallied for the fifth straight session and closed 32.65 points higher at 11,035, while the 30-share Sensex extended its rally into a third day, settling 125 points up at 37,270.

“With global cues turning favourable, buying interest emerged in the broader market across underperforming sectors such as auto, metals and others. The government’s plan to front-load capital investment in infrastructure development to support the economy boosted sentiments,” said Gaurav Dua, Senior VP and Head of Capital Market Strategy at Sharekhan by BNP Paribas.


We walk you through the key highlights of Wednesday’s session:

YES Bank rallies over 13%Shares of YES Bank soared over 13 per cent to Rs 71.60. Denying media reports, the lender said news related to a stake sale in the bank were speculative. The bank said YES Bank in the usual and ordinary course of its business continues to explore various means of raising capital through issuance of securities to diverse set of investors.


Cementing gainsMost cement stocks ended in the green on the back of Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman’s comments that the government will frontload expenditure on infrastructure amid hopes of rate cuts for the industry at the upcoming GST council meet next week. Cement stocks such as Anjani Portland Cement gained 8 per cent, NCL Industries, Sanghi Industries, Kakatiya Cement and Shayadri Industries rose more than 5 per cent each.


DFM Foods tanksShares of Crax manufacturer DFM Foods cracked nearly 8 per cent after the company informed the bourses that the US-based private equity firm Advent International Corporation signed a deal with the company’s promoter to buy 67.90 per cent stake for around Rs 852 crore in an all-cash deal. The scrip settled the day at Rs 249.70 against the previous close of Rs 270.20.


Auto stocks on a rollWith a gain of over 3.50 per cent, the auto index outpaced other sectoral indices on BSE. All the 16 components on the index ended the day in the green with Tata Motors gaining the most at 10.21 per cent. It was followed by Eicher Motors (up 4.98 per cent), Maruti Suzuki (up 4.18 per cent), Mothersn Sumi (up 4 per cent) and TVS Motor (up 3.64 per cent). There are hopes that the GST Council would soon decide on slashing GST rate on automobiles.


Second-rung stocks outperformMidcap and smallcap indices outperformed the benchmark Sensex. The BSE Midcap index closed 1.04 per cent higher at 13,635 with Wockhardt Pharma (up 20 per cent) and Jindal Steel (up 13 pe cent) ending as top gainers. On the other hand, the Smallcap index settled 1.43 per cent higher at 12,891. Trigyn, Goa Carbon and Marathon Nextgen gained 20 per cent each in the index.


CG Power gains 5%Shares of fraud-hit CG Power gained 5 per cent after Chief Executive Officer K N Neelkant resigned from all the positions he held in company subsidiaries amid mounting pressure. Neelkant confirmed resigning from the subsidiaries, but said he believed investors and lenders would not want him to step down from CG Power in the “best interest” of the company.


Spurt in open interestWith a change of 19.33 per cent, Tata Motors led a pack of stocks that witnessed the biggest spurt in open interest. It was followed by Escorts (18.90 per cent), Maruti (18.72 per cent), ICIC Prudential Life (17.31 per cent) and GAIL (16.44 per cent).


Reliance Nippon slips 3%Shares of Reliance Nippon Life Asset Management (RNAM) declined over 3 per cent after the company on Monday informed the bourses that it would sell up to 1.93 crore shares, representing 3.15 per cent equity, in RNAM for over Rs 505 crore on stock exchanges through an 'offer for sale' on Wednesday and Thursday.


Who moved my SensexOil-to-telecom major Reliance Industries contributed 38 points to the Sensex rally on Wednesday. Auto major Maruti Suzuki and country’s biggest lender by assets SBI added 34 points and 27 points, respectively. Tata Motors, IndusInd Bank and Axis Bank together contributed nearly 61 points. On the other hand, IT majors Infosys and TCS dragged Sensex by 64 points.


Most traded stocksWith over 33.29 crore shares changing hands, YES Bank emerged as the most traded stock on NSE, followed by Vodafone Idea (number of shares traded: 10.82 crore), Tata Motors (9.65 crore), Ashok Leyland (6.21 crore) and Suzlon Energy (4.15 crore). On the other hand, YES Bank (Rs 2,327 crore), ICICI Lombard General Insurance (Rs 2,126.38 crore), Maruti Suzuki (Rs 1,620 crore) and Tata Motors (Rs 857 crore) stood among most traded stocks in terms of value.


55 stocks readying to riseMomentum indicator MACD showed 55 stocks, including Punjab National Bank, Indiabulls Housing Finance, Union Bank of India, Kalpataru Power and Bharti Airtel, with bullish crossovers, signalling these stocks may log gains in the coming sessions. On the other hand, Somany Ceramics, InterGlobe Aviation, DFM Foods, NIIT Technologies and Solar Industries were among the 16 stocks that showed bearish crossovers.

Mumbai/New Delhi: Auto stocks were, once top wealth creators on Dalal Street, continue to languish amid prolonged sales slump. But analysts say the sector will soon be past its worst, and festive season may bring back in the much-awaited rebound.

Since the global financial crisis, auto stocks were the second-best wealth creators among all sectors for around a decade, with the BSE Auto index registering a whopping 752 per cent rise between December 31, 2008 and December 31, 2018.

Ever since, they have been become the second-worst wealth destroyers in terms of the performance of the sectoral index. BSE Auto index has eroded 23 per cent value since the end of 2018.

“I think it is time to buy auto stocks. Some sort of green shoots after the recent meltdown should revive interest in these stocks,” said Ambareesh Baliga, an independent analyst.

Baliga said auto sales numbers have continuously plunged over the past 8-9 months, leading to their worst show in August.

“Expectation is that the government will take some further remedial action to ease the pain. The festive season should give some impetus to demand. It will still be less than a year ago, but better on a month-on-month basis,” he said.

Baliga also hoped the production cuts that carmakers have resorted to over the past few months would help ease the inventory buildup.

“An additional push by the government will lead to some sort of demand pickup. A scrappage policy, if it happens, would provide a major booster to the sector,” he said.

Domestic car sales witnessed the highest decline of 31.57 per cent to 196,524 units in August, with passenger cars recording the steepest decline of 41% at 1,15,957.

For the first time in over a decade, the downfall in the passenger vehicle segment has continued for over a year despite the stimulus provided by the government.

Many believe the festive season could kick in demand for the sector. “This season could be a trendsetter,” Sanjiv Bhasin, Executive Vice-President, IIFL Securities, told ETNOW

“Fundamentals may take another two quarters for balance sheets to start showing the numbers, but we think going into 2020, this could be the best sector to be in,” Bhasin said.

Stocks like Eicher Motors, Balkrishna Industries, TVS Motor Company , MRF, Motherson Sumi Systems, Maruti Suzuki India, Bajaj Auto, Ashok Leyland, Bharat Forge, Apollo Tyres, Mahindra & Mahindra have multiplied wealth more than 10 times between 2008 and 2018.

All components of BSE Auto index, with the exception of Bajaj Auto, have corrected 13-40 per cent since the start of this year.

Some analysts still have a pessimistic view, and say the best phase of auto sector is behind us.

““When you have such a sharp slowdown in sales, clearly there is a structural slowdown, and not a cyclical one. We made a mistake in auto and now we are looking for exit,” Dipan Mehta, Director, Elixir Equities, told ETNOW.

“Look back at the high growth industries like telecom, IT or pharma, when they were going through structural changes. They used to have high growth phase of 20-25 per cent expansion and then suddenly earnings would collapse and when they recover, they would be in high single digits to low double digits and never in those big growth phase,” he said.

Mehta said something similar will play out in automobiles as well, where after a period of very high earnings growth and volume growth. “I think the best years for auto are behind us,” said he.
