If earnings show green shoots, then confidence will be back and participation level should start going up, says Sameer Narayan, Market Expert. Excerpts from an interview with ETNOW.

Everybody is contemplating whether, this market will hit a new high and stay there or is the best behind us in the short term and markets will consolidate or fall? What is your view?What happened last week was definitely tectonic.This was the hard bullet that nobody expected the government to bite! It was done so quickly, going even against the DTC recommendations of 25%, we have actually brought it down to 22%. So it is a great move. 

Now, in the last three days, the so-called animal spirits were definitely unleashed. Today corporate India thinks that yes the government will act and the government is serious about ensuring that the economy is back on the growth track. So those are very big positives. But having said that, we do not see that there is a lot of commitment on part of the FIIs. Even in terms of recent stock movements, wherever the effective tax rate differential has been large, even within sectors like auto. For example, Eicher Motors was at 35% tax rate whereas M&M was at 25%. Therefore, the pronounced move that you have seen in the last three days in both these stocks has been very different

The market has clearly made a differential that once the tax rate has come down, it is for good and hence there has been stock-wise movements within sectors. Now does this lead to increase in capex? That is a function of what is my current capacity and the estimation of demand that I see here on. The monsoon has definitely been good. In fact, India has probably seen an excess monsoon for the first time after almost six years. 

So even though the rainfall distribution may not be great and you may not get a very big kharif output, at least the outlook on rabi crop is positive and that is a big sentiment booster. But look at it this way. In July, after the first quarter numbers were out, everybody bought the earnings down to 8-10%; today because of that tax cut, you are back to the expectation of 25% for FY20 on Nifty earnings. That is why the market is back where it is. But from here onwards, the big mover is the September quarter is earnings. If somehow this shows green shoots, then confidence will be back and participation level should start going up.


Are you betting on the consumption theme then? Given that some of those factors will see a revival in growth, will that positively impact these companies?Apart from consumption which is fairly well owned and well valued, the government is the big mover here. Today when you see the bills that were pending for long have started getting cleared, money is back into the system and orders are being given out. You will probably see the domestic cyclicals more in favour than perhaps consumption or FMCG. Apart from that, even where there has been a massive drawdown in terms of prices like in cases of PSU banks or where the tax rate was very high, those themes are likely to play out far better.


Are you betting on the consumption theme then or being positive on the outlook that given some of those factors we will see a revival in growth and that will positively impact these companies?Apart from consumption, which is fairly well-owned and well-valued, the government is the big mover here. So today when you see the bills that were pending for long have been starting to get cleared, money is back into the system and orders are being given out, I think you will probably see the economy facing, the domestic cyclicals probably more in favour than perhaps the consumption or the FMCG and I think apart from that even where there has been a massive draw down in terms of prices like some of the state owned banks or where the tax rate was very high -- those themes are likely to play out far better.


We saw IT, pharma the defensive plays so to speak, completely lag when the markets were on fire. Yesterday they were back in play. What does one make of it?Most of the tech space has been at 25% effective tax rate and to that extent, there will not be any immediate benefit because of the change in taxation. Also, they have not seen any upgrades and that is where the positive news is not forthcoming. Therefore, the optimism was not there on Friday and Monday. Yesterday, there were some sort of tempering and people realised a lot of catch-up has to be done. 

In case of a demand revival, it is likely to show up in these sectors as well because IT is a large employment generator. The other thing that plays out is that tax cut will definitely give some sort of positive sentiment on a capex outline which is a larger long term decision for a corporate. The next thing that probably needs to be looked at in terms of a followup is personal tax reduction, which will lead to a direct demand stimulus.

If you do both of these, then there is likely to be some amount of fiscal strain and because of that, one should definitely hear some positive action on the divestment front. Since only a few months are left for the fiscal to get over, the space for piecemeal steps like CPSE ETF probably will not move the needle much. One needs to look at real strategic divestments to get in big money. In case the government moves on that, it will set the market on the right track.


Do you believe that one is safer sticking to private corporate names?From here onwards, one has to look at the improvement in margins. Private banks have been fairly valued and so the asset improvement is likely to be visible in case the economy picks up in banks which have not been priced. Public sector banks would be a larger beneficiary of the incremental flow and the improvement in business due to a revival in economy.


Within consumption where is the opportunity to buy afresh? From Titan to D-Mart to Asian Paints, all are trading at exuberant valuations?The incremental flow will perhaps be not that high. Bigger returns are likely to be made where ownership is low and the delta is likely to be bigger. 


Why do you say that? Sometimes you need to buy simple compounding stories; over ownership, under ownership are important factors but they cannot be the only factor. Just because HDFC Bank is owned, why should you not buy it?You have a point there. But HDFC Bank, Titan, all these are franchise companies. Now franchise value is a very different connotation from the classic valuations that an investor would look at. You can make a SIP on them on a monthly basis.. Even on an individual case, you can keep buying them and these will compound because demand will be there. They will be able to run an efficient business model and there will be returns for the investors to make. 

But I thought the question was where will be the larger flow from here onwards for investors to look at in terms of allocating capital? I think one should make a case of allocation to these franchise companies which will continue on their growth path but don’t expect a large change in them because of the tax cut as perhaps in some other cases where the tax rates were far higher. That is the only limited point I am trying to make because the tax rate reduction is a profit opportunity that is available on a permanent ongoing basis for any corporate. That is where for a company with a 35% effective tax rate coming down to 25% effectively means a 10% secular earnings growth.


Which names would you pick up?Coal India and Eicher Motors are companies where there is some element of franchise value and an element of competitiveness, a monopolistic situation and these are places where one is likely to see a good pick up in revenue if the sentiment and the economy pick up.


Will you buy BPCL with this view or for that matter any PSU, thinking that tomorrow will be better for these PSUs?Our view on OMCs has always been good because they are fantastically run businesses, available at great value. These are also great assets for somebody to chase them. If BPCL and HPCL see the light of divestment some day, the amount of windfall they can unlock for the government is tremendous. Also, there would be a re-rating. For example, HP is available at 6 times EV EBITDA. These companies are fantastic cash machines. The petrol price deregulation mechanism is seamless. In the recent week also, the prices have been marked up appreciably. There is no reason for somebody not to go in for them especially when the entire auto sector, auto fuel retailing story in India is just about to be unleashed.

There is a strong chance of cash flow and appetite of investors for PSUs as a basket. The chances of a strategic divestment before the financial year runs out is far higher than what it was a month back. These are great stocks available at great value and a trigger of divestment also is a good tailwind. These can be prime stocks for long. 


What is your view on Zee?The business is in good shape. It is just that today there is a short-term overhang over how the promoters settle their debt and the stake sale and the discussions with the MFs etc. If there is clarity, the stock can perhaps retrace earlier levels because at Rs 30,000 crore, it is not a bad business in case the economy was to pick up from here.

Will you buy the Zee stock?At this price, it is a fairly good risk reward equation.


How are you mapping the price? Why is it good, why is it bad? Just because this has fallen or you think it has become cheap? Their OTT platform, Zee5, is losing money.Yes but the fact is it was not expected to make money from day one any way. When businesses and verticals are in investment mode, there is a certain amount of runway that is given them for them to play out in terms of accretion, content creation, etc. There is enough for us to give them some time and this overhang has perhaps seen a very disproportionate amount of price impact on the stock price. That is why I said that Rs 30,000 crore it is not a very bad risk reward equation given the fact that the business does not seem to have completely fallen off the cliff.

Companies which have a moat around them will have the ability to retain the tax cut and will benefit but in sectors where there is too much competition, companies will have to pass on the tax benefits and would not gain much, says Samit Vartak, Founding Partner & CIO, SageOne Investment Advisors. Excerpts from an interview with ETNOW’s Nikunj Dalmia.


We are calling it the big reset, is it a big reset?Definitely. It is one of the biggest fundamental changes for India. Now, the question is whether it is a big reset for all the companies or if it is a big reset for selective companies. It is very important to understand that from the investment perspective. If it is a competitive industry with too many players at a similar level, it is going to be very difficult for them to retain profits. If their ROE goes up by 15% because of earnings going up by 15%, in a very short period of time, they will price each other out and then the ROE will come down to the same levels as they were before. 

But there are many industries where competition has been decimated and you will find it across various sectors -- be it capital goods, specialty chemicals or alloys. That is where the pricing power will be retained because such companies have built up the capacity over the last four-five years and the valuations are at multi-year lows or even at historical lows. That is where the opportunity is.

There are dominant players which everyone is aware of -- be it the top banks or the top NBFCs. They will definitely benefit. But the question is how much of that is already priced in. This is a rare opportunity where there is a real fundamental change but still people are very sceptical about the changes, especially the ones where the stocks are beaten down. But that is where the big opportunity will be and you need to dig through and understand the competitive environment in that specific industry and bet on the players where they are so dominant that it is almost impossible for the new competition to come in. Whether it is the offshore or domestic competition, it will be very difficult to build the kind of competitive advantages they have and these are very basic industries which are not going to be disrupted by any high-tech developments. 

If you talk to the PE or the venture capital guys, they are excited about a lot of disruptions that are going to come through in India. For them, many of the consumer-oriented distribution channels are very important. One does not know whether five years down the line and when distribution channels get disrupted, big moats of consumer oriented companies can be disrupted. So you need to be very careful on those aspects because if you are paying 70, 80, 90 times for earnings growth of 10% to 15% and if there is a big disruption which comes through in the next 5-10 years, the derating which can start can be a big hit on your portfolio.


So you are saying that yes, there is a big fundamental change in the economy but not every company or every sector will benefit in the same manner. Companies with a moat around them will have the ability to retain the tax cut; but companies who are just one more in the crowd, will have to pass on the tax benefits. Markets have gone up like in a rising tide on the hope every company would benefit.Yes, that is the general risk. When things change at an industry level or a complete macro level it is very difficult to retain the profits. Again I have always been talking about the theme of market share gain. Market share gains happen only if there is one dominant player and there are other weaker players. The difference between the competitiveness of these players is huge. All the dominant players across the sectors are the players who have grown at a significantly higher rate compared to the rest of the competition.

So, that kind of theme is going to accelerate and this theme anyway works across the up and the down cycles and this is a complete fillip that the government has given such companies and the profitable ones will get even more dominant. So you got to find companies where valuation is in your favour.


Are you fully invested in this market?Yes, we were not raising money until 2018. We have stopped taking funds.


Your view was that midcaps were reaching a bubble level. After that, reality has dawned and you raised capital after that. That was a great call. What is your call now?No, I think in this kind of market you need to be completely invested.


So one should not be biased. Just because midcaps have suffered in the past, they would continue to suffer and just because largecaps have made money, they would continue to make money?For me, the dominant player can be the largest player in that industry but if the industry is small, you know he may not be a largecap, but he would have as big a competitive advantages as many of the largecap players. That is where the opportunity is because even the best of such players have taken a hit because it is part of the midcaps. Suddenly, in the last two years, markets are differentiating midcaps and largecaps which generally does not happen and you got to differentiate by looking at the competitive advantages.


Differentiate between the businesses rather than the market capitalisation.Exactly and that is what the market has done and that is where the opportunity is.


Give me an example. You have identified themes or companies which are dominant and very good quality companies with higher return ratios though the size of the market may not be large? One such example is steel pipes. You know the steel pipes which are used in building factories, building airports, all kind of infra projects or even affordable housing where you use it for door frames. Steel pipes is a very basic industry but over the last five-six years, the number of players have shrunk. There are only two or three dominant players.


PSL used to be one, Man used to be one, some of those companies do not even exist now.Right. And I am talking about a cross section where they manufacture these square or rectangular pipes. The industry has been decimated and there are only a couple of players left who have built up the capacity. The return on capital is upwards of 25%. 

If this theme of attracting new capex and especially foreign money also comes in, India will go through a huge construction boom at least in terms of factories and the guys who have the capacity are going to benefit the most. It is a small industry; probably a $10-billion industry. But the biggest beneficiary of the capex build up will be top guy in this field. I find people are just not giving any valuation to such companies. I would say that their growth rate going forward as well as their dominance will be bigger than some of the consumer-oriented companies.

Many of the consumer oriented companies do not even manufacture those products, they just brand it. When you look at guys like Amazon with all of their private level products available on the website which are available at 20-30% discount and all of these companies now trading at 50-60-60 times multiple, I am not sure if their dominance is going to last for too long. It is an extremely competitive industry. 

Anyone can come in, get the product manufactured by outsourcing it and put its own stamp and sell it in the market. There is no real differentiation between the products. The competitive advantage is that some of these basic steel manufacturing companies are at various levels of dominance -- be it sourcing the raw material, working capital lines, the kind of rates they get, their manufacturing as well as distribution abilities. It is very difficult to build all those four aspects of the business. Dominance is going to last much more than many of the haloed consumer oriented companies.


There is one sector where the disruption is real and where disruption will change the way how future business would be conducted. It is the auto sector. EV is eventually going to cap the PE upside for a Maruti, Bajaj Auto and auto ancillary companies. Do you own auto or auto ancillary stocks?I am very careful about the auto or auto ancillary companies, especially the ones geared towards passenger vehicles side because there are huge headwinds. It is not just in India, globally also, all the passenger vehicle players are going through a huge structural change even in China, Europe and the US. 

So you cannot bet on themes where anyway there is a big disruption which may or may not happen in the next two to five years but definitely in the next 10 years. At the same time, consumer behaviour is also changing with the Ola, Ubers of the world. If I do not see 20% growth, I just avoid that kind of a sector and auto is one of those. 


Great compounders like Asian Paints, HDFC Bank, Bajaj Finance have always been expensive and the quest for a fund manager like you is to avoid the haloed, overcrowded stocks. Is there a learning for all of us when we look at some of these classic businesses but avoid buying them because they look expensive or are over-owned?During the last two years, one has seen the benefit of owning those quality stocks but two years is not a long period. You got to look over a cycle. Most of these companies barring maybe like a Bajaj Finance, typically grows at much lesser than 20% and especially the consumer oriented companies. So, if your returns expectations are in the range of 10 to 15%, there is no reason for you to go hunting for anything else. Just hold on to these companies and the valuations do not matter, if you are going to hold on to them for at least 15-20 years. So, it is a no-brainer for a passive investor. 

For a fund manager, if your return expectations cross 20%, you cannot hope for rerating perpetually in these stocks. They are already trading at such valuations that going forward, you can see only the earnings growth as your return. If the earnings growth is going to be 10-12% and if you are happy with those returns, then it is great for you. So that is my problem. But yes, there are certain companies like Bajaj Finance which I am happy to hold and I am fine overpaying for higher growth. But if it falls, like in the case of Page Industries. I held it for multiple years but by 2016, the growth rate fell below 20%.

As soon as the growth rate stops and comes back to the normalised growth rate, these companies lose their PE multiple and you would never know which company will go through that kind of a cycle. There will be only two or three such companies which will sustain it for the next 20 years or 25 years, but I do not know whether you have the ability because you would have said the same thing about Eicher or a Page and you may have the same kind of losses which a lot of midcaps have gone through if you have bought them at the highs. 

Now, in which part of the market is the risk reward in your favour? I would say it is not in your favour if you are buying at such valuations and if your time horizon is five or seven years. You can imagine that at a 10-11% growth, it takes seven years to double the earnings and 80 times PE multiple goes down to 40 times PE multiples. It can happen because historically they have never traded at such valuations. You end up making zero returns. 

Whether you want to take that kind of a risk, especially given that India can go through with this incentive -- once the higher growth rate phase starts and there are more alternatives available for investors to get into such companies. People will start to get out of those because in the last seven years, the rest of the universe had stopped growing and these were the only companies which consistently grew and that is where a lot of foreign investors as well as Indian investors flocked into these companies. If it reverses, I am not sure these companies will maintain such high PE multiples. 


There is a big if over when corporate India will start spending and when the earning cycles will pick up. Corporate capex was supposed to pick up in 2016. We are staring at the ugly reality where the government had to give a tax cut to kick start the investment cycle. What if it does not pick up? It is possible because it is not that companies will flock into the country just because of one incentive. Coming into the country has to become easy and starting a business also has to become easy. For that, the government has to go for the land reforms and then labour reforms. Given the conviction of this government, I think they will get it done. 

If that is done, you can look at the interest rate at lowest levels. Commodity prices including steel are at extremely low levels. The tax rates are at the lowest levels. I feel the tax cut move would not have been as valuable if it was done under any normal circumstances. 

The US-China trade war is giving you an opportunity where many American companies may shift to some other geographies, away from China. So you get this window and you got to grab it. If you do not grab it now, those companies are not going to shift their plants once they are already set up in Indonesia or Thailand or Vietnam. So the timing is extremely important. 


Can India survive in manufacturing? Made in India ended up becoming only a slogan by the NDA-1 government. Frankly in the last six years, with the exception of two or three large big ticket investments, nothing has come.Look at the chemical belt. After China, India probably is the dominant chemical producer. A belt was formed, right incentives were given and the ecosystem was there. That is what needs to be created. It does not need to happen across the nation. You find certain pockets where the land prices are really low, where the ecosystem is there, where you have the right skill sets. If it is planned well, I do not think we lack anything which any other country may have and if the government plans it right and has the right intention, it can be done. 


Would you say that you need a different strategy for every pitch? Sometimes go on the front foot and sometimes go on the back foot? In 2019, those who played a defensive strategy in the stock market, have benefitted. Do you think now it is the time to take a leap of faith and start buying risk in the portfolio? I am not in favour of buying risk. Obviously you can take a tactical call on that but it is betting too much on luck. I feel you find dominant players available at cheaper prices compared to historical valuations and they will definitely be more dominant three, four, five years down the line. Go after B2B players which are geared towards capital goods. 

Look at these steel pipes, electrical cable manufacturer because whether this theme plays out or not, they are dominant and highly profitable. They will benefit from it and they are exposed to the real estate sector. They are exposed to factories, all kinds of construction as well as the consumer-oriented retail business. 

There are certain niche businesses like alloys which are used in steel manufacturing and there are such industries where there are just one or two players, extremely dominant, almost impossible to get into those businesses because most of them have burnt their fingers and got out of such businesses. If India grows at a higher rate, their growth rate also can be significantly higher. 

If this theme works out and the commodity growth is higher like steel industry, these companies are trading at two, three, four times multiples with over 30% return on capital, sitting on huge cash, no issue of debt or balance sheet and promoter holding of 75%. Such companies can go through a huge re-rating as well as huge growth over the next five years. That is where the opportunity is.


How have you managed to convince your clients to keep calm? All midcap stocks have got beaten. Price damage and collateral damage has been there. What are you telling your clients? How should they keep the calm when the entire sector has got de-rated?No, it is extremely difficult because whatever you tell them, if they see damage in their portfolio, people get concerned. It is human nature because a fund manager may see visibility in certain companies but as a passive investor, you may not have the same conviction or visibility in those names.

By Chandan Taparia
Nifty50 opened negative and witnessed sustain selling pressure for most part of Wednesday’s trading session as it drifted towards the 11,400 mark. It formed a Bearish Belt Hold candle and negated the formation of higher lows of last three sessions. It partially filled the pending gap between 11,380 and 11,471 levels left three days back.

Major trend of the index is positive, but weakness of last two sessions has caused a pause in the bullish sentiment. Now, the index has to cross and hold above 11,500 to witness an upward move towards 11,600 and then 11,666 levels, while on the downside supports are seen at 11,380 and then 11,333 levels.

On the options front, maximum Put open interest was at 10,800 followed by 11,000 levels, while maximum Call OI was at 11,500 followed by 11,600 levels. Meaningful Call writing was seen at 11,500, followed by 11,600 levels, while there was minor Put writing at 11,400 followed by 11,450 levels.

Options data suggested a trading range between 11,300 and 11,600 levels. India VIX fell 3.35 per cent to 16.17 level.

Bank Nifty opened negative and drifted towards the 29,500 mark. It has negated the formation of higher lows of last three sessions and partially filled the gap between 29,418 and 29,776 levels. Now, it has to cross and hold above 29,750 to witness a bounce towards 30,100 and then 30,250 levels, while on the downside, major support is seen at 29,400 and then 29,250 levels.

Nifty futures closed negative at 11,461 with a loss of 1.31 per cent. There was long buildup in PowerGrid, TCS, ICICI Pre and NTPC while shorts were seen in NMDC, Ambuja Cements, Eicher Motors and Asian paints.


(Chandan Taparia is Technical & Derivative Analyst at MOFSL. Investors are advised to consult financial advisers before taking an investment calls based on these observations)

NEW DELHI: ZEEL with over 0.24 crore shares changing hands was leading among the most traded stocks on NSE on Thursday.

Shares of Vikas Multicorp (number of shares traded: 0.16 crore) , Techno Electric & Engineering Company (number of shares traded: 0.10 crore) , YES Bank (number of shares traded: 0.10 crore) , Max India (number of shares traded: 0.09 crore) , Gammon Infra (number of shares traded: 0.09 crore) , RattanIndia Power (number of shares traded: 0.07 crore) , Reliance Comm (number of shares traded: 0.07 crore) , IRB InvIT Fund (number of shares traded: 0.06 crore) and Cox & Kings Financial Services (number of shares traded: 0.06 crore) also featured among the most traded stocks on the NSE.

ZEEL (Rs 65.27 crore) was also leading the pack of most active stocks in value terms.

It was followed by Techno Electric & Engineering Company (Rs 25.83 crore), RIL (Rs 17 crore) , HDFC (Rs 16.53 crore), Tata Communications (Rs 15.63 crore), HDFC Bank (Rs 13.28 crore), ICICI Lombard General Insurance Company (Rs 12.86 crore), Dalmia Bharat (Rs 12 crore), ITC (Rs 10.35 crore) and SBI (Rs 9.80 crore). 

The NSE Nifty index was trading 43.60 points up at 11,483.80 while the BSE Sensex was up 126.34 points at 38,719.86 around 09:16 am. 

In the Nifty index, Eicher Motors (up 1.68 per cent) , Zee Entertainment Enterprises (up 1.33 per cent) , Vedanta (up 1.28 per cent) , Maruti Suzuki India (up 1.18 per cent) and Indiabulls Housing Finance (up 1.17 per cent) were among the top gainers. 

While Axis Bank (down 0.87 per cent) , Coal India (down 0.57 per cent) , Infosys (down 0.23 per cent) , HCL Technologies (down 0.22 per cent) and ITC (down 0.22 per cent) were the top losers in the index.

NEW DELHI: Auto shares were trading in the red in Friday's morning session.

Shares of Tata Motors (down 4.14 per cent), Amara Raja Batteries (down 2.34 per cent) , TVS Motor Company (down 2.25 per cent) and Ashok Leyland (down 2.18 per cent) were trading lower.

Mahindra & Mahindra (down 1.67 per cent) , Hero MotoCorp (down 1.24 per cent) , Bosch (down 0.98 per cent) and Eicher Motors (down 0.90 per cent) too were trading in the red. 

The Nifty Auto index was trading 1.23 per cent down at 7565.40 around 09:44 am. 

Benchmark NSE Nifty50 index was down 14.10 points at 11,557.10 while the BSE Sensex was down 12.70 points at 38,977.04. 

Among the 50 stocks in the Nifty index, 14 were trading in the green, while 36 were in the red. 

Shares of YES Bank, Tata Motors, Dish TV India, NMDC, SBI, Vodafone Idea, GMR Infra, SAIL, ITC and Ashok Leyland were among the most traded securities on the NSE.

By Ronojoy Mazumdar

Poor demand from Indian consumers could dampen the mood during festivals next month, especially for automobile makers and retailers that count on the season for a sales boost, analysts predict.

Indians typically buy everything from new cars to shoes for themselves and as gifts during celebrations steeped in religion and tradition. Yet the slowest economic growth in six years, unemployment at a 45-year high and tepid private consumption may see sales fall short of recent years, even after the government’s $20 billion tax break to companies earlier this month.

“You can make the product 50 per cent cheaper, but there has to be income to spend,” said Nitin Gupta, an analyst at SBICAP Securities in Mumbai. “In the short-term, I don’t see any kind of an income boost. Rather than giving cash to individuals, they have given it to companies.”

Car sales in August fell the most on record and Maruti Suzuki India Friday reduced the price on its Baleno RS model by 100,000 rupees ($1,420) to pass on the benefit from the tax cut. Market researcher Nielsen has lowered its 2019 growth estimate for fast-moving goods to 9 per cent-10 per cent from 11 per cent-12 per cent, while a stock gauge of consumer discretionary firms is set for its first annual back-to-back losses since at least 2005.



Even so, the industry’s fortunes beyond the approaching festival season are poised to improve, according to BNP Paribas SA. Plentiful rainfall seen this monsoon season and cash handouts to farmers will help lift rural incomes, helping sales of staples recover in the second half of the year that began April 1, the brokerage said in a recent report.

Here’s what other analysts say:


SBICAP Securities’ Gupta



The festive season is likely to be dull. Consumption is hit and household income has to increase for there to be better demand for companies selling fast-moving consumer goods.
Corporate tax cuts are a long-term phenomena and won’t help in the short term. It’s uncertain how much companies could pass on the benefit in terms of lower prices.
Recommends buying shares in Dabur India Ltd., holding ITC Ltd., Colgate-Palmolive India Ltd., and Hindustan Unilever Ltd., and selling Nestle India.


Aditya Soman and Aditya Gupta, analysts at Goldman Sachs Group Inc



Don’t expect a significant change in underlying demand trends across categories and geographies in 2Q
“We would look for color on festive demand outlook especially given the normal monsoon which could have a positive impact on demand,” in 2Q earnings calls
Recommends buying shares in ITC, Britannia Industries Ltd., and Page Industries Ltd., selling shares in Dabur, Hindustan Unilever and Marico.


Harshit Kapadia, an analyst at Elara Securities India



I’m not expecting a blockbuster festive season. It won’t be muted either, but will be decent. Even last year demand was largely flat, that’s why double-digit growth in demand on the lower end is possible.
Distributors are preparing for the Navratri and Diwali season, but nobody is stocking up heavily. They are following the normal trend of keeping 15-20 days of inventory, whereas in past years they would keep 30-35 days ahead of the festival season
Recommends buying Havells India and selling Voltas shares


Ravi Swaminathan, an analyst at Spark Capital Pte



Sales growth in refrigerators and washing machines has been moderate (mid to high single digit).
With early festive demand traction not very encouraging, dealers are hopeful for better traction over the next 2-3 months.
Recommends adding Whirlpool of India., Havells and Crompton Greaves Consumer Electricals shares


Basudeb Banerjee, an analyst at Ambit Capital Pvt.



The best case scenario for automobiles is for demand to remain flattish on a year-on-year basis as last festival season was bad for demand. Things have gotten worse since then.
Investors should avoid commercial vehicles and producers of lower-cost two wheelers, which face a bigger inventory pileup.
Recommends selling Hero MotoCorp Ltd., Ashok Leyland and Tata Motors shares, buying Eicher Motors Ltd., Bajaj Auto and Maruti Suzuki India.


Shirish Pardeshi, an analyst at Centrum Broking Ltd.



Demand is there, it’s only the size of the wallet that’s come down. In difficult times, people don’t stop buying the product. If someone was buying a large pack before, maybe they’ll buy a small pack now.
In the festive season people tend to forget the bad times.
Recommends buying shares in Dabur, Britannia, and Hindustan Unilever and Bajaj Consumer Care Ltd., on improving consumer sentiment, helped by a good monsoon that should support demand from rural areas, selling shares in Colgate-Palmolive

NEW DELHI: Investors expecting positive signals from September auto sales could be in for some disappointment as passenger vehicle (PV) volumes may fall by over 20 per cent amid high inventory levels.

Growth slowdown, inauspicious Shraddh period and floods in select regions are likely to impact wholesales, said analysts. The festive season, which kicked off on Sunday, could see some demand improvement in the runup to Diwali, they added.

September sales momentum has not seen much improvement, said Nomura India.

“However, for PVs, with heavy discounts on offer, the footfalls have improved, which should translate into much improved retail sales, as the festive season begins on September 29,” it added.

Brokerage Sharekhan said that inventories in the passenger vehicle (PV) segment stood at 4-6 weeks and at two-wheeler segment at 5-7 weeks, which have led to sustained weakness in demand. Commercial vehicles (CV) segment is likely to be the worst impacted segment with volumes likely to drop by 40 per cent, it said.

Higher base effect and financing issues may play a spoilsport in September, said Emkay Global, which expects auto sale cycle to see a gradual recovery due to the confluence of factors such as increasing discounts, better rural sentiment, lower interest rates, higher government spending and a possible introduction of the scrappage policy.

For the month gone by, Nirmal Bang Institutional Equities is expecting Maruti Suzuki to log a 32.4 per cent YoY drop in sales on a high base.

“For Mahindra and Mahindra, we expect tractor sales to decline by 41.5 per cent on a high base. Tata Motors is most likely to continue to underperform the market in the PV segment with ongoing inventory correction and slowdown in retail sales. We expect its commercial vehicle sales to continue to be affected by increased fleet capacity and slowdown in the economy. Similarly, we expect Ashok Leyland and Eicher Motors’ CV sales to also decline in high double digits YoY,” the brokerage said. 

In the two-wheeler space, it expects Bajaj Auto sales to decline over a high base, although MoM may grow, driven by new model launches.

“Hero MotoCorp dealers already had high inventories at the start of the month and hence there seems to be very little scope for stocking up. Hence, we expect its sales to decline by 25 per cent YoY. TVS Motor’s sales are expected to decline by 29.4 per cent YoY on a high base. Its 3Ws continue to garner strong demand in export markets,” Nirmal Bang Institutional Equities said.

On net-net basis, Nomura India expects PV industry volumes to decline by 20 per cent on YoY basis, with sales fort Maruti Suzuki falling 24 per cent in domestic volumes.

For two-wheelers, it expects industry volumes to decline 17 per cent as inventory levels remain very high, and a retail demand recovery is needed to correct the 6-8 weeks’ inventory ahead of the BS-6 changeover.

The MHCV industry is likely to have a volume decline of 49 per cent.

NEW DELHI: Auto shares were trading on a mixed note in Tuesday's session as major auto companies announced their sales for September.

According to analysts, the inauspicious Shraddh period and floods in some regions impacted auto sales. But inquiries and footfalls rose towards end of September after heavy discounts and promotional offers by companies which lead to some increase in sales as compared to the previous month, brokerages said.

Bajaj Auto's sales slipped 20 per cent, year-on-year marking a bigger slump than it had seen the previous month. However, the company sold 4.02 lakh units, higher than the 3.9 lakh units sold in August.

Meanwhile, Maruti Suzuki’s total sales dipped over 24 per cent year-on-year to 1.22 lakh units, but rose sequentially from 1.06 lakh units in August. Also, Ashok Leyland’s sales slipped 55 per cent to 8,780 units in September.

M & M's auto sales fell 21 per cent on a yearly basis to 43,343 units in September while its tractor sales were down 2 per cent year-on-year to 37,011 units.

The Nifty Auto index was trading 0.70 per cent up at 7545.55 around 12:56 pm. 

Shares of Mahindra & Mahindra (up 2.95 per cent) , Eicher Motors (up 1.63 per cent) , Maruti Suzuki India (up 1.55 per cent) and Exide Industries (up 1.26 per cent) were the top performers in the index.

Apollo Tyres (down 5.64 per cent) , Ashok Leyland (down 1.67 per cent) , MRF (down 1.24 per cent) and Motherson Sumi Systems (down 0.76 per cent) were among top losers in the index. 

Benchmark NSE Nifty50 index was down 3.20 points at 11,471.25 while the BSE Sensex was up 12.05 points at 38,679.38. 

Among the 50 stocks in the Nifty index, 18 were trading in the green, while 31 were in the red. 

Shares of YES Bank, Vodafone Idea, Indiabulls Housing Finance, IDFC First Bank, SBI, Ashok Leyland, Tata Motors, BPCL, SAIL and Indian Oil Corp were among the most traded shares on the NSE.

NEW DELHI: Most of the cement stocks were trading on a mixed note on Tuesday's afternoon session.

Shares of Mangalam Cement (up 7.58 per cent), India Cements (up 3.28 per cent), Keerthi Industries (up 2.95 per cent), Kakatiya Cements Sugar & Industries (up 2.70 per cent), Birla Corporation (up 2.70 per cent) and Gujarat Sidhee Cement (up 2.62 per cent) were among the top gainers. 

While Barak Valley Cements (down 4.96 per cent), Shri Keshav Cements(down 4.92 per cent), Andhra Cements (down 4.78 per cent), Shree Digvijay Cement (down 3.74 per cent), NCL Industries (down 2.48 per cent) and Prism Johnson (down 1.63 per cent) were among the top losers. 

The NSE Nifty50 index was trading 27.15 points up at 11,501.6, while the 30-share BSE Sensex was up 85.24 points at 38,752.57 around 11:36 am. 

Bharat Petroleum Corporation (up 5.93 per cent), Housing Development Finance Corporation (up 2.14 per cent), Mahindra & Mahindra (up 1.92 per cent), Indian Oil Corporation (up 1.90 per cent) and Eicher Motors (up 1.77 per cent) were among the top gainers in the Nifty pack. 

On the other hand, Indiabulls Housing Finance (down 4.98 per cent), IndusInd Bank (down 4.43 per cent), Bharti Airtel (down 2.70 per cent), Coal India (down 2.43 per cent) and Grasim Industries (down 2.10 per cent) were trading in the red.

Panic selling in bank and other financial stocks and continued slump in auto sales weighed on market sentiment on Tuesday, which caused the Sensex to dive over 700 points at one point before paring the losses to close 361 points, or 0.94 per cent, down at 38,305. Nifty fell 1 per cent, or 114 points, to end at 11,360. 

Rumours in the market about disruption in online transactions at several banks forced RBI to come out with a clarification to assure panicking public. 

YES Bank shares continued to fall and it was joined by RBL Bank; the first ended with 23 per cent loss while the second shed 9 per cent.

Auto sales continued to contract in September. Barring Maruti, Eicher Motors and M&M, other auto stocks closed in the red. 

"A contraction in core sector and concern over the government plan to stick with its 3.3% fiscal target in spite of huge tax cut raised concern over spending. Investors are not expecting a meaningful recovery this festival season due to continued weakness in auto sales. Volatility in bank stocks and a fall in the rupee triggered profit booking," said Vinod Nair, Head of Research, Geojit Financial Services. 

Here is a lowdown on key movers and shakers of Tuesday’s session:


YES Bank continues to tankYES Bank continued its downhill journey, as stock crashed 23 per cent on BSE to close at Rs 32. The scrip tumbled after founder Rana Kapoor and associated promoter entities sold a large stake in the bank. YES Capital (India), Morgan Credits Private and Rana Kapoor together sold 552 lakh shares, or 2.16 per cent stake, in the open market during September 26-27.


Mysterious plunge in RBL BankShares of RBL Bank plunged as much as 22 per cent in intraday trade, but recovered at the end to close about 9 per cent down at Rs 800. Vishwavir Ahuja, MD and CEO, RBL Bank, said selling is looking highly speculative and misplaced. Ahuja said the bank continues to grow and remains profitable. "You will see this in our earnings, which are little over two weeks from now. Nothing has changed fundamentally in the bank," he said.


Panic selling in PSU banks Public sector banks also came under pressure after Jefferies warned that bad loans could rise in the banking system. In a note, the global brokerage suggested that there was a divergence between ratings and debt repayment ability of companies. The Nifty PSU Bank index dived about 4 per cent for the day. Bank of Baroda and SBI in the PSU Bank pack are most prone to high risk emanating from defaulting companies, it said.


Little hope from auto sales Auto sales continued to slide in September. M&M’s volume declined 21 per cent, while SML Isuzu (26 per cent), Eicher Motors (30 per cent), Maruti Suzuki (24 per cent) and Ashok Leyland (27 per cent) all report drop in sales. Only Escorts (up 2.2 per cent) and Atul Auto (4 per cent) registered growth in monthly sales. Most of the auto stocks ended in the red. However, M&M, Eicher Motors and Maruti registered gains. Overall, Nifty Auto index dropped 0.4 per cent. 


All sectoral indices in the redAll sectoral indices on NSE ended in the red, with Nifty Realty and Nifty Media indices plunging over 4 per cent. Bank, pharma and metal indices were other big losers. 


Key Sensex moversReliance Industries and bank stocks on the index were the biggest drags on Sensex. RIL dragged Sensex by 85 points, followed by ICICI Bank (55 points), SBI (55 points) and IndusInd Bank (51 points). HDFC twins provided some support, lifting it over 120 points. 


Investors lose Rs 1.85 lakh croreDomestic equity investors lost some Rs 1.85 lakh crore in Tuesday turmoil, as the market-cap of all BSE-listed companies shrank to Rs 145 lakh crore from Rs 147 lakh crore on Monday. 


Spike in volatilityIndia VIX, a measure of volatility in the market, jumped 5 per cent to 16.7. Increased volatility usually means pain for investors, as it is a symbol of instability and the market could move either way very swiftly. 


Over 190 stocks blink ‘sell’ signalsOver 190 stocks crossed below the MACD Signal line on Tuesday. They included SBI, RBL Bank, Bank of Baroda, PNB , Motherson Sumi, Adani Power, Rail Vikas Nigam, Bharti Infratel, etc. The MACD is one of the technical indicators used to spot trends, though it is seldom used as a standalone indicator.


Most active stocksYES Bank and Vodafone Idea were the most traded stocks in terms of trading volume on NSE. They were followed by Indiabulls Housing, SBI and IDFC First Bank. In value terms, Axis Bank, YES Bank, Indiabulls Housing, SBI and HDFC topped the list.

NEW DELHI: Domestic benchmark indices Sensex and Nifty succumbed to fears of more distress in the banking sector only to end Tuesday's session 1 per cent lower after meandering through losses and gains in intraday trade.

Weak auto sales figures and macro data numbers that signalled acute economic pain added to the worries on Dalal Street.

BSE flagship index Sensex ended 362 points or 0.94 per cent lower at 38,305. It tanked over 700 points during the day only to recover a bit. NSE barometer Nifty settled at 11,360, down 115 points or 1 per cent lower. India VIX surged 5.22 per cent.

In the Sensex pack of stocks, only seven ended in the positive zone. HDFC Bank, M&M, Maruti and HDFC were among the top gainers. Meanwhile, YES Bank, IndusInd Bank, SBI, Bharti Airtel and ONGC were the top drags.

Bank stocks cracked as the rumour mill on Dalal Street hinted at more distressed names coming out thus pushing the NPAs higher. Buzz over the exposure of banks of Indiabulls group was another reason behind the fall. BSE Bankex dropped 1.55 per cent.

A Jefferies report said that bad loans could rise in the banking system. In a note Jefferies suggested that there is a divergence between the ratings and the debt repayment ability of companies.

Shares of YES Bank cracked 22.80 per cent amid fears of exposure to IB Housing and stake sale by promoters Rana Kapoor, YES Capital and Morgan Credits.

RBL Bank tanked 8.7 per cent. Its CEO and MD Vishwavir Ahuja in an interaction with ET NOW blamed the selling to speculations doing rounds in the market.

HDFC Bank and Kotak Mahindra Bank proved resilient to this selloff in banking names.

Besides the poor Auto sales figures for the month of September was another dampener for Dalal Street. Sales for M&M declined 21 per cent, SML Isuzu (26 per cent), Eicher Motors (30 per cent), Ashok Leyland (27 per cent). BSE Auto ended 0.41 per cent lower.

In the sectoral space, telecom and realty fell the most. BSE Telecom shut shop 4.53 per cent down while BSE Realty ended 3.88 per cent lower. Consumer Durables index ended flat.

BSE Midcap and BSE Smallcap dropped 1.54 per cent and 1.61 per cent.

Weak macro data remained another cause of worry for investors. India’s core infrastructure industries’ output declined for the first time in more than four years in August, reflecting weak demand in the economy. The index of eight core infrastructure industries, which comprises output of coal, crude oil, cement and electricity among others, fell 0.5 per cent in August. It had last declined in April 2015.


Expert Take

"Contraction in core sector and concern on government’s plan to stick with original fiscal target of 3.3% in spite of huge cut in tax raised concern overspending. Investors are not expecting a meaningful recovery in the festival season due to continued weakness in auto sales. Volatility in banks and fall in rupee also influenced profit-booking tendency in the market" -- Vinod Nair, Head of Research, Geojit Financial Services

The domestic stock market continued to bleed on Tuesday with Sensex and Nifty falling nearly 2 per cent each. Rumours of more debt distress, muted auto sales and weak macro data weighed on the stocks.

Sensex plunged as much as 737.44 points during the session to 37,929.89, while Nifty tanked up to 226.55 points to 11,247.90. 

However, benchmark indices recouped losses with the 30-share Sensex ending the day at 38,305.41, down 362 points or 0.94 per cent. Its NSE counterpart Nifty settled the day at 11,365.70, down 109 points or 0.95 per cent.

Yes Bank was the biggest index loser, tumbling over 22 per cent after its promoter entities sold a part of their stake in the company.

The rupee was also weak amid heavy selling in equity market, down 0.28 per cent or 20 paise at 71.06. The volatility index, India VIX surged 11.54 per cent in the afternoon trade to hit 17.7 level.

Later in the day, data showed that GST collection dropped below the Rs 1 lakh crore mark to Rs 91,916 crore in September, a 19-month low.

Here are the key factors that weighed on Dalal Street today:


Banks bleed
Banking names crashed on Tuesday as Nifty Bank came down by 2.44 per cent led by YES Bank that plummeted over 22 per cent. RBL Bank also tumbled 18 per cent on NSE. Except HDFC Bank, all constituents of the index were trading in the red.

Rumours of more distressed names coming out weighed on the banks. Banking stocks fell on Monday as well on buzz of their exposure to Indiabulls Group.

A Jefferies report said that bad loans could rise in the banking system. In a note Jefferies suggested that there is a divergence between the ratings and the debt repayment ability of companies.

YES Bank, Bank of Baroda, SBI, IndusInd Bank and RBL Bank are amongst the banks that are most prone to high risk emanating from Anil Dhirubhai Ambani Group (ADAG), Cox & Kings, CG Power, DHFL and Essar Shipping, it said.

RBI said the banking system is safe and stable and asked bank customers not to panic on the rumours doing the rounds.

"There are rumours in some locations about certain banks including cooperative banks, resulting in anxiety among the depositors. RBI would like to assure the general public that Indian banking system is safe and stable and there is no need to panic on the basis of such rumours," the central bank posted on its Twitter handle.


There are rumours in some locations about certain banks including cooperative banks, resulting in anxiety among the… https://t.co/Xt4fw0D5TF— ReserveBankOfIndia (@RBI) 1569924803000

Weak macro dataIndia’s core infrastructure industries’ output declined for the first time in more than four years in August, reflecting weak demand in the economy. The index of eight core infrastructure industries, which comprises output of coal, crude oil, cement and electricity among others, fell 0.5 per cent in August. It had last declined in April 2015.



The core infrastructure sector constitutes two-fifths of total industrial production and the weakness will have negative impact on factory output, data for which is due next week.


Auto sales stay sluggishAuto sales continued to slide in September. Sales for M&M declined 21 per cent, SML Isuzu (26 per cent), Eicher Motors (30 per cent), Ashok Leyland (27 per cent). This dampened the mood dragging Nifty Auto 0.7 per cent.

However, a couple of companies registered a growth in monthly sales, including Escorts (up 2.2 per cent) Atul Auto (4 per cent).

Maruti Suzuki stock price climbed 0.4 per cent to Rs 6,745 despite the company reporting 24 per cent fall in sales.


Fitch forecasts more gloomThe sentiment on D-Street also took a hit after Fitch said global GDP growth will hit eight-year low in 2019. Fitch said the outlook for the global economy deteriorated significantly due to escalation in the US-China trade war. The rating agency said lower growth in China will prolong the slump in global trade and manufacturing, which will, in turn, continue to pressure eurozone expansion.

Auto stocks nudged higher after the Reserve Bank of India’s Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) cut policy rates on Friday. The MPC cut the repo rate by 25 basis points to 5.15 per cent.

The lower repo rates mean a lower interest rate on auto loans that may boost the vehicle sales. The auto industry has been going through a slowdown and traders celebrated the rate cut by buying auto stocks. 

Ashok Leyland was up 2.8 per cent and M&M up 1 per cent on NSE in the afternoon trade. 

Hero Moto, MRF, Apollo Tyres, Eicher Motors and Maruti Suzuki were other gainers. Overall Nifty Auto was up 0.22 per cent. 

Bharat Forge, Amara Raja Batteries, Exide Industries and Tata Motors were trading 1-2 pert cent lower. 

MPC however showed concern over a “staggered and incomplete” transmission of the rate cuts. “As against the cumulative policy repo rate reduction of 110 bps during February-August 2019, the weighted average lending rate (WALR) on fresh rupee loans of commercial banks declined by 29 bps” it said.

If the real interest rates do not go down in tandem with the repo rate cut, auto industry may not benefit much from it

NEW DELHI: Majority of interest-rate-sensitive counters from auto, banking and realty sectors were trading in the green in Friday's session ahead of the Reserve Bank of India’s monetary policy decision.

The BSE Auto index was trading 0.29 per cent higher at 16,804 at around 9.20 am with Hero MotoCorp gaining the most at 1 per cent. It was followed by Maruti Suzuki (up 0.81 per cent), TVS Motor (0.91 per cent) and Eicher Motors (0.65 per cent).

Tata Motors, Mahindra and Mahindra and Ashok Leyland were down between 0.25 per cent and 1 per cent.

The BSE Bankex index was up 0.93 per cent at around the same time. YES Bank, RBL Bank, IndusInd Bank and State Bank of India were up 7 per cent, 2.55 per cent, 2.26 per cent and 1.53 per cent. HDFC Bank, Axis Bank, Kotak Mahindra Bank and ICICI Bank was trading higher between 0.30 per cent and 1 per cent.

YES Bank extended its gain to the second straight session after the lender said its financials are strong and liquidity is well in excess of regulatory requirements.

On the other hand, the benchmark BSE Sensex was up 0.69 per cent, or 264 points, at 38,370.

Real estate majors also advanced up to 2 per cent in the early trade. The BSE Realty index was trading 0.57 per cent up at 1934. Godrej Properties, Oberoi Realty, DLF, Indiabulls Real Estate and Prestige were up over 0.40 per cent. On the other hand, Sobha and Sunteck were down up to 2 per cent.

Bank of America Merrill Lynch (BofAML) expects the RBI MPC to follow RBI Governor Shaktikanta Das into another ‘out-of-the-box’ 35 basis points repo rate cut on October 4. This should send a strong signal for bank lending rate cuts with the ‘busy’ industrial season round the corner. “With the 2018 liquidity crunch still hurting growth, our India Activity Indicator points to continued slowdown,” said BofAML.

There are expectations that RBI may deliver a fifth straight interest rate cut, although economists are unsure of the quantum following an unconventional 35 basis-point easing last time.

While all 33 economists surveyed by Bloomberg News expect a reduction, their forecasts range from 20 basis points to 40 basis points. The RBI has lowered borrowing costs to a nine-year low of 5.4 per cent through 110 basis points of easing so far in 2019.

MUMBAI: The Delhi Auto Expo, once a big draw for companies and the public alike, is no longer an event that every marque needs to attend. Some of the big names that plan to miss the February 2020 event — it’s held every two years — include Honda Cars, Hero MotoCorp, Ashok Leyland and BMW. The muted enthusiasm is in keeping with the slump in auto sales. For the public, there are few surprises to be had, with many new models already launched or displayed in detail online.

However, new entrants such as Kia and MG Motor, are attending. Then there’s the return of Volkswagen, Skoda and Great Wall Motors, China’s biggest maker of SUVs and pickup trucks. They will occupy about 3,500 sq ft each, similar to the area that Maruti Suzuki, India’s biggest car maker, will use for its displays. Hyundai Motor India will also be attending.

Others that won’t be attending include Ford and Fiat Chrysler. 


Top Truck Cos Staying Away
Nissan is said to be deliberating its options. In the luxury car space, Mercedes-Benz and Lexus are the only participants in the coming edition.

At this time of the year, almost all of the space is typically booked up, but not this time. A sluggish market, migration to Bharat Stage VI emission norms, lack of exciting product launches and high ownership costs are among the key factors keeping brands away. BMW India managing director Rudratej Singh said the company has already launched its products and there’s no major offering to showcase.



“Our focus is more on targeted marketing and using our money more appropriately to ensure product launches are executed well,” he said. “It’s not to say that we are not going to look at the Auto Expo again. With the right products and timing, we may come back.”

A Honda Cars India spokesperson said the company’s release schedule wasn’t in sync with the Auto Expo timeline.

The top five two-wheeler makers are unlikely to attend. Suzuki and Piaggio will do so. Apart from Hero, Bajaj Auto, TVS Motor, Royal Enfield and Yamaha aren’t participating, sources said, adding that Honda Motorcycle may join them.

“In keeping with our prioritised objectives, we have decided after much deliberation to skip the upcoming Auto Expo,” a Hero Moto-Corp spokesperson said. “At a time such as this (transition to BS VI emission norms), it is prudent for us to prioritise our resources towards meeting business objectives for the benefit of our customers and stakeholders.”

Yamaha, Nissan, Honda Motorcycle and FCA (Fiat Chrysler Automobiles) Group didn’t respond to queries.

Top truck brands are also staying away. Only Tata Motors and Mahindra have pavilions since Ashok Leyland, Eicher and Bharat Benz have decided not to attend.

More than 90% slots are usually booked by October for the expo, but this year Society of Indian Automobile Manufacturers (SIAM) is still trying to get companies to confirm attendance.

The Hero MotoCorp spokesperson said participation would require months of preparation and allocation of resources — in terms of money and manpower — which is a challenge.

The last edition of the week-long event recorded a marginal rise in footfalls to 605,000. Over 500 products were showcased by 119 exhibitors, with 22 product launches, 81 product unveilings and 18 concepts. As many as 11 startups showed up. Audi, Ford, FCA, JLR, Nissan, Volkswagen, Bajaj Auto, Royal Enfield and Harley-Davidson missed Auto Expo 2018. Green machines ruled the show in the previous edition, with 25 electric vehicles displayed.

MG Motor, though, is upbeat about the Delhi Auto Expo. “It is a great engagement platform for the company to interact with all the stakeholders, including prospective customers, and get feedback,” said marketing head Gaurav Gupta.

Kothari Sugars & Chemicals (down 1.97 per cent), KCP Sugar & Industries (down 1.66 per cent) and KM Sugar Mills (down 0.82 per cent) were among the top losers.

Indian Oil Corporation (up 2.18 per cent), Bharat Petroleum Corporation (up 1.30 per cent), Asian Paints (up 1.22 per cent), Eicher Motors (up 1.13 per cent) and HCL Technologies (up 1.04 per cent) were among the top gainers in the Nifty pack. 

On the other hand, Indiabulls Housing Finance (down 6.77 per cent), JSW Steel (down 2.64 per cent), Tata Motors (down 2.42 per cent), Infosys (down 1.84 per cent) and Vedanta (down 1.39 per cent) were trading in the red.

Hefty fines from RBI weighed on Lakshmi Vilas Bank and Syndicate Bank, as they hit their 52-week lows on Tuesday. Bharti Airtel halted its winning spree as profit booking pulled the stock down 2 per cent.

HUL gained about 2 per cent after impressive Q2 numbers. Eicher Motors ended as biggest gainer on Nifty, jumping nearly 5 per cent. Among sectoral indices, all but IT ended in the green on NSE. Nifty IT index slipped 0.5 per cent dragged by Infosys and JustDial.

Sensex ended 291 points higher at 38,500 while Nifty climbed 87 points to 11,428.

“Despite early weakness in global markets, our market managed to stay higher amid exceptional strength in FMCG, auto and private bank stocks. Amid specific positive news on US tariffs on China, metal stocks helped keep market momentum intact,” said Shrikant Chouhan, Senior Vice-President, Equity Technical Research, Kotak Securities.


Here we list out key movers and shakers of Tuesday’s session.

LVB, Syndicate Bank crackStrict RBI penalties dented investor sentiments on the counters of Lakshmi Vilas Bank and Syndicate Bank causing their shares to plumb to 52-week lows. Lakshmi Vilas Bank, which is already under the PCA framework, tanked 5 per cent to Rs 22.05 after RBI slapped Rs 1 crore penalty for rule violation. Syndicate Bank fell 2.24 per cent to Rs 24 after it was penalised Rs 75 lakh.


Bharti Airtel fallsShares of Bharti Airtel closed in the red for the first time in six sessions as traders preferred to book profit. The stock slipped 2.5 per cent to close at Rs 383.55 on BSE.


Infosys continues to slideIT major Infosys continued its slide for the second day this week after posting Q2 earnings on Friday. The stock fell over 2 per cent to Rs 769 on NSE.


Eicher Motors jumps 5%Royal Enfield maker Eicher Motors soared 5 per cent to close above Rs 19,000 level, amid a general rally in auto stocks. The stock rose by Rs 888 to close at Rs 19,200 on BSE.


HUL rises on strong Q2 showA robust performance in the September quarter helped shares of Hindustan Unilever end the day with gains. The company posted a YoY profit growth of 21 per cent. Its stock rose 2.4 per cent to Rs 2,063 on BSE.


Nifty IT index sole loserIT index on NSE was the only sectoral loser on ending with a cut. The Nifty IT index closed 0.45 per cent down dragged by JustDial (down 5 per cent) and Infosys (down 2.27 per cent). Mindtree, which is scheduled to post its Q2 on Wednesday, also ended with a loss of 0.5 per cent. The biggest gainer among the pack was NIIT Tech, rising 1.6 per cent.


Broader market underperformsBroader market couldn’t match the headline indices as small and midcap indices ended with marginal gains. The Nifty Smallcap index was up 0.1 per cent while Nifty Midcap was up 0.2 per cent.


45 stocks blink ‘buy’ signalsAs many as 45 stocks climbed above their MACD signal line on the daily charts, signalling a bullish trend. They included YES Bank, Jindal Steel and Power, Ashok Leyland, DLF, Dabur India and Lupin, among others. MACD is one of the indicators to spot a shift in trend in a stock, but it is seldom used alone.


Over 120 stocks ‘oversold’As many as 122 stocks entered ‘oversold’ zone on RSI indicator. They include GVK Power, Bajaj Consumer, Allahabad Bank, JustDial, Piramal Enterprises and Glenmark Pharma, among others. The relative strength index is a momentum indicator that measures the magnitude of recent price changes to evaluate overbought or oversold conditions in the price of a stock or other asset. If a stock crosses below 30 on the index, it is generally considered oversold.

Every time the stock market goes up, we need to take a shorter position than go long in auto because industry dynamics are becoming akin to something like telecom. It is going to be a dog-eat-dog world for market share, says Ajay Srivastava, CEO, Dimensions Corporate. Excerpts from an interview with ETNOW.



While winter has arrived in Delhi and Gurgaon, is the winter getting over for Indian stock markets?It is already over for a few select stocks. The rest are going to face a freezing winter. They will be kept out of the party for a long time to come. Nothing has changed in two-three years. Everything remains the same. I am sorry to say this, but it is going to get accentuated in the smaller cap stocks. It is going to be a long time before they come back into favour. 

As far as we are concerned, for the larger stocks -- MNC stocks and some of the PSU stocks -- will be fine but 70% of the Indian stock market will remain out in the Tundra cold for this winter at least. You can imagine what happens to midcaps who remain out in the cold.


What gives you the confidence that the winter is over for some? What makes you believe that the worst is now behind us?It has nothing to do with the current economic scenario. The institutional framework of a stock market has changed over the last two-three years and now it is dramatically different from what it was before. One of the things is that the holding with individuals for at least the good quality stocks is now at its historical low at this point of time.

Even individuals who hold them are not selling those shares. If you look at the top 10-15 stocks, the MNC stocks for instance, you will find that dwindling supply of stocks in the market and with the new F&O rules, we are talking of physical delivery versus the older model of settlement on your trade.

You will find that it will be more and more difficult to short these stocks as time goes by. For instance, nobody wants to sell a Lever, nobody wants to sell a Nestle, nobody wants to sell the Astrazeneca Pharma. Whatever you have, you are buying and you are holding. 

Gradually you are seeing that the private holding is about 10% to 11%, out of that maybe 2% to 3% actually comes for trading in the market. Wait for another year or two and if this economic situation of low growth continues, more and more people who have not bought it, will keep buying these stocks defying the gravity of 60 PEs and 70 PEs because now it does not matter what the PE is, you want those stocks and you want to hold it irrespective of what result comes in the quarter. So even if you have a bad result, I doubt any of the diehards are going to sell those stocks, maybe a few thousand shares for a day or two but rest will come and buy the stocks. 

We are clearly seeing lack of supply in the market of good quality stocks, people who are holding are holding it firm and institutional holding is now 80-85% plus for most stocks of top 20 names, leaving very little credence to a market trading in terms of delivery and insurance companies will keep adding up. The corpus is going up. So, where will the delivery come from from these shares.


 It seems there is a rush towards the government papers. Maybe, Saudi Aramco is looking at buying a government stake in BPCL though the talks may be at a very nascent stage. IRCTC papers made a stellar debut. Do these prized government possessions make for a wise, prudent investment call?Of course, during the last budget, we spoke about PSU stocks. Earlier, it was a case of choice to sell or not to sell. Given our current scenario there is no choice, the government has to sell and it is doing whatever it takes to find a way to sell them. Look at what has happened to Air India. They are going to warehouse Rs 45,000 crore debt and pay it from whatever resources they got to hand over a clean airline. The market and investors have to realise that it is now no more a question of if; it is a question of when will they do it.

The last gambit of tax cut has played out in a very different way. Hindustan Lever increased the dividend and that money is not going to come back into the system for capex or any further growth of the economy. The only way to plug this gap and to build some corpus for development of infrastructure is sell the PSUs and these are dirt cheap. These are dirt cheap stocks. Resource companies like Nalco and NMDC are available dirt cheap. Even oil companies, given the infrastructure, they are not so expensive. 

Maybe BPCL has run up a little bit further but it is in the zone where the buyer will pay much higher than what the price is today. By and large, it is so cheap that you really cannot go wrong if these companies are sold. Number two, they have exhausted their ability to pay dividends and the government’s old model of taking dividend is not going to be valid anymore. Most of them are down to bare minimum in terms of cash reserves and profitability. The only option is to sell and if you sell them they are very valuable stocks. 

It is a very safe bet, it may take a little longer but you are comfortably placed in the all the PSU shares, at least the profit-making ones.


What are you making of earnings so far -- IT names in particular? Wipro was surprising while Infy looked better than TCS. Consumption is the other theme where HUL has set the tone and it is pretty decent?The earnings have disappointed and the biggest disappointment has been TCS. Among all the companies so far, Infosys has done okay. The stock may not have done well after the announcement but it is doing decently well. TCS has been a disappointment and may disappoint further, I am not too sure. I believe that next year, the result would be remarkably better because if you look at the forward premiums, they must have taken something between Rs 73-75 to a dollar next year on their sales, which augurs well as even their volumes remain constant and the currency benefit is going to be pretty steep in the next 12 months.

But there is no reason to sell, just keep TCS. A huge dividend is coming your way because that is the only way they can compensate. By and large, good dividend, good placement, low risk, less worries, keep going it is not bad for the next year. 


Another interesting development is promoter pledged share reduction. In Bajaj Consumer, Kushagra Bajaj has offloaded 29% stake in the last seven months. We have seen that with Emamiwhere about 19.5% was offloaded in two tranches; Zee sold 11% to Oppenheimer. Sterlite Technologies and Apollo Hospitals also reduced pledged shares. Is there any investment opportunity amongst any of these high debt companies?We have a large holding in Apollo Hospital, but I think, it is not a good sign because the whole idea of an entrepreneur is to take risk to risk capital and increase the wealth of the country and grow the economy. When a promoters start to shrink themselves and sell the assets and cut debt, that is not a good sign as far as the economy is concerned. 

It may be good for the companies per se so that the stock is doing well but broadly as an indicator of what they see in the future, it is not a good sign. But since everyone wants to deleverage that means they do not want to take more economic risk in this country.

My personal view is yes it is positive for the stock in the short term but not necessarily good for the economy because if all the entrepreneurs shun risk, then who is going to take new projects forward and where is the new capital going to come from? Will it be only institutional capital from abroad which will dictate India in the future? That is one way to look at it but will it mean that the entire Indian diaspora of entrepreneurs are going to vacate new project space? That is not a good sign for an economy by and large. 

So I do not get a great feeling when everybody including Reliance is deleveraging. It is not good because the idea is to take some risk, get some new projects going, get growth going and that will make sense as an entrepreneur. 


Would your view remain a little cautious on auto?We are cautious because we have just gone short again. The optimism on auto is perhaps a little misplaced even at today’s levels and let us see how the quarter’s results come out because the discount would start to play out and it is not that the festive season is going that great.

We need to relook at auto in a fundamental way because of two reasons. One is demand has compressed and look at the competition. Three years back, Hero was the sole maker in 100 cc, 125 cc market. Look at what is happening today. Look at Eicher in the larger categories. Now there is Java, Enfield, Indian, just name the brands just sitting there; look at the car companies and watch the competition.

We need to fundamentally re-rate the automobile sector from a monopolistic situation of the last three years to a very competitive, low-return industry in the near future. Our view is that every time the stock market goes up, we need to take a shorter position than go long because industry dynamics are becoming akin to something like telecom. It is going to be a dog-eat-dog world for market share and that is not good news. Yes Maruti with Rs 36,000 crore of cash need to use it at some place, but they are losing their market standing as well at this point of time. So, I am not so gung ho on autos even if sales revive now. Most companies are pretty expensive even at the current prices.
