NEW DELHI: Italian automaker Piaggio is looking to enter the mid-weight motorcycle market in India to take on Eicher Motors-owned Royal Enfield.

The firm was earlier looking at launching products in the 150cc motorcycle segment, but with the market moving towards higher-displacement bikes, the plan now is to introduce products in the 250-300cc range, managing director Diego Graffi told ET.

“Definitely, we are looking with a lot of interest at the motorcycle segment in India. It is natural, having a brand like Aprilia, which is well known across the world for winning in racing competitions,” Graffi said.

As many as 773,855 motorcycles with engine capacity in the range of 250-350cc were sold in the domestic market in the last financial year. With sales of 764,012 units, Royal Enfield had almost 99% market share in the category. “We are now looking more at this range (250-300cc). We need some time to introduce the products … But it is in our plans,” he said.

Piaggio additionally is working on introducing an India-specific scooter in the next financial year and refreshing its range of products here under the Vespa brand. Overall — domestic sales and exports — Piaggio India is targeting selling over 100,000 two-wheelers in 2019.

According to data available with industry body SIAM, twowheeler sales dropped 15.74% to 12,864,936 units in the first eight months of the ongoing financial year starting April, amid a broader slowdown in the local automotive market. At Piaggio — which currently sells scooters under the Vespa and Aprilia brands — two-wheeler sales declined 16.86% to 48,471units in the same period.

In the three-wheeler segment, Piaggio intends to remain fuel-agnostic and provide options in petrol, diesel and LPG/CNG even after the switch-over to BS-VI emission standards from April 1, 2020. The company will also have electric options available in three-wheelers and has partnered with SUN Mobility to set up battery swapping stations for the Ape Electrik range. Piaggio aims at introducing the range along with adequate battery swapping facilities in 10-15 cities in India by March 2020.

The company sold 106,943 three-wheelers in India till November this fiscal year, a 7.64% fall compared with the same period last year.

Midcaps could start doing much better in the next 12 months considering volatility does not spike, says Naveen Kulkarni, Head of Research, Reliance Securities. Excerpts from an interview with ETNOW.


Which are the themes you are going to be most bullish on in 2020?2020 is going to be a very interesting year. We are pretty much closing the year on high levels, which was not expected as we started the year. Also, in between, there were quite a few challenges that we witnessed. But having said that, the global construct for equity markets continues to remain positive. More importantly, we are seeing two major themes emerging; a)there is a lot more interest in value stocks. The likes of metal stocks have started doing better, the larger banks are doing much better. b)The second theme which is expected to emerge over the next 12 months could be the midcaps or the high quality midcaps. Smallcaps might take a little more time but the midcaps could start doing much better in the next 12 months considering the volatility does not spike. That is a very good setup for the midcap allocation to significantly increase. That is the overall theme we are banking on and are bullish on for the next 12 months.

What is the outlook on individual sectors? We are banking big on the overall rural theme picking up. The trend having been fairly soft so far, do you think there is merit in the story?There is a clear-cut merit in the story, primarily because we are likely to see a very good rabi season. So from that perspective, if we consider the sowing patterns, where we have done some bit of channel checks, we have seen quite a bit of improvement in Maharashtra in two crops. Overall, the farm income and the rural income should rise significantly over the next six to 12 months. That is going to be a major theme. 
 From the perspective of what to play, we are quite bullish on Escorts. Escorts is one of our top picks in the midcap space as well as in the auto space. One is of course, tractors as a play. We see that the cycle has shortened in terms of the turnaround that can happen. 

Second is when the rural income rises and probably in the next 12 months we could see two things; one is the earnings picking up and the second something like Escorts rerating. That gives a significant upside to stock picks like Escorts. 

Apart from that, in the consumption space, Dabur is a very traditional rural play but the company is going through a very different kind of phase in terms of strategy and development. I would not put Dabur as a pure rural play but as an overall consumption play, it makes a lot of sense to allocate more capital there. 
 I would be very choosy in terms of playing the rural theme but there are certain ideas which make a lot of sense to invest at this point in time. 

If you are looking at the broader markets, we are starting to see more opportunity there, particularly in light of recovery. Would you be looking deeper into specific stocks where you see earnings catch up?Recovery is a very critical aspect. Something which is going to be a clear cut standout play on the recovery cycle will be the auto sector. If I were to look at pure consumer staples kind of a play, Hindustan Unilever on an average over a last 20-year period would have delivered a volume growth of around 6%. 

In auto we like four stocks. Escorts is one name. The second theme is a big play on the recovery cycle. It could be Ashok Leyland. Apart from that Maruti is another play which can give decent upside. The last name I would be bullish on would be Eicher Motors.-Naveen Kulkarni
Currently, in the last quarter, they delivered a volume growth of 5%. Essentially, the staples play are plus/minus 1% or 2% over the long-term average in good times and bad times. So that is not something. The discretionary part in the consumption theme is where auto fits. We have to see whether it is the CV cycle or the PV cycle or if it is the two-wheelers.

There is a case to play the recovery theme from autos perspective. Apart from that, we are quite bullish on banks. Coming back to the auto theme, as I just mentioned, Escorts is one name. The second theme is a big play on the recovery cycle. It could be Ashok Leyland. Apart from that Maruti is another play which can give decent upside. We are positive on the stock and I would say that the last name which I would be quite bullish on would be Eicher Motors. 

These are the four stocks in the auto sector where I would allocate most of my capital. Apart from that, the large banks are something and there are value plays where we would allocate more capital.



What about IT? Valuations are also looking comfortable now. Does it merit a look in the New Year?From an IT perspective, the earning visibility in that sector always tends to be reasonably strong. Second, cash flows are never a challenge in that sector and most of the companies are reasonably sound in terms of balance sheet. They do not need to raise capital. So all the positives are known. Valuations are reasonable, there are names in the largecap space as well as in the midcap space which merit looking at. 

In the largecap space, we like Infosys. The valuations are quite reasonable. The operating performance is quite good and that stands out. Apart from that, in the midcap space, we continue to like Sonata Software and Mindtree. It is going to be an interesting play to look at from quarter on quarter improvement perspective.


Let us talk about a few other specific names that are on your radar. You are bullish on Aarti Industries, Coromandel and even Nesco. Why are they looking attractive to you?Aarti Industries is a long-term play, it is not a short-term play. It is in the specialty chemical space. Their focus is on Benzene derivatives. If I were to look at one name where they have a certain moat, Aarti Industries clearly stands out. 

Second is in terms of the kind of deals that they have done in the space, they are consistently investing capital where they understand the category well. So, there is a long-term growth path. Apart from that, in the last quarter, we saw a bit of gross margin compression. The revenues are lower than what it was estimated, but it was essentially because the low product margin business did not do well, whereas the high product margin businesses have been doing better. Strategically, the company continues to do well. This is a time to accumulate the stock where the valuations have corrected a bit and it looks reasonable. 

Coromandel is a more straightforward story. We are banking on a better sowing season for the rabi crop. The rabi output is going to be pretty good and Coromandel is a straight-forward beneficiary of that. Apart from that, the quality and management and everything continues to be very strong. Coromandel is more of a medium-term play. Aarti is a very long-term kind play. Escorts is a very straightforward story on rural growth theme and rerating that can happen and the earnings growth that the company can deliver over the next two years.


What would be the three triggers for the markets to see a significant leg-up next year?The biggest factor for the market is going to be the economic recovery. A lot of music and sound and noise happens around the Budget. The clear cut factor there will be to look at what fiscal deficit target the government gives and where they are right now. 

The borrowing programme for the government will be a very clear-cut number because that determines the cost of funds in the overall economy, that is the second factor. The first factor is economic recovery and the high frequency indicators whether it is the auto numbers or some of the other factors like the IIP numbers. All these data will have to be very carefully watched.

The third factor will be the constructive global set up. The global scenario, whether it is in terms of a trade deal, the US elections being right next year etc. How the global market continues to emerge in the next 12 months is going to be very critical. If the global scenario continues to be constructive, the Indian markets will continue to do well. If supported by some of the domestic factors that are just talked about, the markets will do very well in the next 12 months.


What do you like among midcap banks? Do you have any midcap preferences?We do have midcap preferences like DCB Bank, but lately there are some challenges. It is a long-term bet but SBI stands out very clearly in terms of the resolutions that we are witnessing and the benefits that the bank is going to enjoy. Apart from that, if we see the overall improvement that has been taking place, probably this year they might do a 9.5% kind of an ROA and next year the ROA will improve. Apart from that, the valuations are quite reasonable. SBI is a clear-cut standout. There is also a subsidiary. SBI right now is our top pick in the whole banking space, followed by Axis Bank and ICICI Bank.

Shares of United Breweries were on a high on Tuesday after a media reports said Heineken may launch an open offer to raise its stake in the company above 51 per cent.

Shares of IFCI and YES Bank climbed due to separate reasons. Dishman Carbogen Amcis plunged 20 per cent after income-tax department raided the company.

BSE benchmark Sensex rose 181 points to 41,461 while NSE barometer Nifty shed 50 points to 12,212.

“IMF's statement that India is in the middle of a significant economic slowdown pushed the market into the negative terrain on Tuesday. Persisting weakness in the rupee and a gradual surge in crude prices also turned the market sentiment gloomy,” said Shrikant Chouhan, Senior Vice-President, Equity Technical Research, Kotak Securities.

Here is a lowdown of the movers and shakers of Tuesday’s session on Dalal Street:


UB jumps on likely open offer
Shares of United Breweries climbed 4.79 per cent to Rs 1,299.40 after a media report that promoter of the company Heineken is considering an open offer to increase the stake in the company. Heineken is likely to launch a voluntary open offer for 10-15 percent stake in the company.

YES Bank out of F&O ban
Shares of YES Bank rose 3.12 per cent to Rs 51.20 after the stock came out of Futures & Options ban. The stock was banned from trading in the futures segment recently after the combined open interest in its derivatives contract crossed 95 per cent of the market-wide position limit.

IFCI surges 8%
Shares of IFCI soared 7.64 per cent to Rs 6.76 after the company said has realized an amount of approximately 805.60 crore from the stake sale in NSE.

Dishman Carbogen Amcis plunges
Dishman Carbogen Amcis plummeted 19.98 per cent to Rs 72.10 after income tax department raided its offices. The officials of income-tax department have visited the company’s head offices and manufacturing sites in connection with search under Section 142 of the Income-Tax Act on December 19, 2019 and search enquiry is continuing, the company said.

Volatility slumps further
India VIX, the measure of volatility in the market, slipped 4.66 per cent to 11.40.

Key Sensex movers
Reliance Industries and HDFC twins were among the biggest negative contributors for Sensex. RIL bled 75 points while HDFC and HDFC Bank shed 71 points together. IndusInd Bank was the biggest positive contributor during the day.

Most active stocks
Indiabulls Housing Finance was the most active stock on NSE in terms of turnover. It was followed by Reliance Industries, YES Bank, SBI and IndusInd Bank. In terms of volume YES Bank topped the charts followed by Vodafone Idea, Dish TV, Indiabulls Housing Finance and SBI.


121 stocks hit 52-week lows
As many as 121 stocks hit their 52-week on BSE. In the BSE 500, Dishman Carbogen Amcis, GHCL, Gujarat Narmada Valley Fertilizers & Chemicals and V-Mart Retail were among the stocks that hit 12-month low. 


46 scrips flash ‘sell’ signals
As many as 46 stocks turned bearish slipping below the MACD signal line. They include Canara Bank, TV18 Broadcast, Petronet LNG, Dabur India, Aditya Birla Fashion, Eicher Motors, Kansai Nerolac Paint and Rico Auto, among others.

MUMBAI: Mahindra & Mahindra’s board is betting on tried and tested leaders from within the group to take over key positions to lead it in a market that is undergoing transformation.

The maker of sport utility vehicles and tractors announced more names on Monday to head its second rung of top management, relying heavily on internal roster.

The developments are part of the second phase of M&M's succession plan, following last week’s announcement that Anand Mahindra would step down as executive chairman of the board, but continue as non-executive chairman, effective April 1.

The company said on Friday that Pawan Goenka would be re-designated managing director and take additional charge of CEO with effect from April 1, till retirement in 2021. Anish Shah will succeed Goenka after April 1, 2021.

In fact, the top-level management at the auto maker has hardly relied on lateral hires even as the group went global, making acquisitions and entering foreign markets with products made in India.

Analysts tracking the developments said the company may be taking one risk too less in the everevolving market space by promoting in-house talent. Rival Tata Motors, for instance, had brought in a globally proven talents like Carl-Peter Forster and Guenter Butschek to take its brand forward. Truck makers Ashok Leyland and Eicher Motors, too, have relied on a leader from outside to chart its future course.

VG Ramakrishnan, managing partner at consultancy firm Avanteum Advisors, “Mahindra is a well-oiled organisation with a solid governance structure in place. An outsider may be needed to change the culture, but Mahindra is not at a stage of such transformation, hence they don’t need a radical change. Plus, where is the talent in the automotive industry today? It is better off to reward internal talent even though they may face challenges in retaining volumes or market share.”

M&M cannot be faulted for not participating in future disruptions like shared, electric or autonomous vehicles, but experts say there is need for a fresh approach or a set of young leaders — dynamic, aggressive or risk-takers — to pursue an approach different from its conservative, long-haul perspective.

An outside view may be missing, but at least key roles have gone to young talent from within the group.


BUILD VERSUS BUY
Most organisations have an explicitly defined build versus buy philosophy. Typically, mature organisations work on an 80:20 ratio — meaning most senior positions are placed from within the organisation. A higher build also signifies a sign of maturity of succession planning practices and drives a structured plan for providing career visibility to internal, high potential talent, said Anurag Malik, Partner - People Advisory Services, Ernst & Young.

The auto maker has started implementing recommendations by management consultant BCG on a Simplicity project it undertook more than a year ago, but the results have yet to show.

Whatever the management changes, industry experts said the company should get back to its winning ways, especially in the utility vehicles space where its market share has dipped to less than half, compared to eight years ago.

The three automotive products it launched recently have not been too successful. Additionally, strain of its two-wheeler and electric vehicles business, both of which have yet to see healthy growth, and a painstaking endeavour by subsidiary Ssangyong Motor Company to build scale and get back in the green, too, has not borne fruit.

Given the competitive scenario, regaining past glory is challenging for M&M, especially in utility vehicles, Ramakrishnan said. "It still needs a steady pair of hands to move the company in a direction that has been defined," he reasoned.

Goldman Sachs said in a note to clients that M&M’s underperformance in various auto and non-auto businesses in the last few quarters has pulled down its consolidated results despite the solid performance of the domestic business.

There has been a remarkable comeback in the auto stocks. If someone is looking at high-risk stocks, then Eicher Motors and Bajaj Auto at current levels hold a lot of potential. Another high-risk stock, Tata Motors could be a strong candidate for a multibagger from current levels, says Kunal Bothra, kunalbothra.co.in.


What will be your outlook for 2020?The start of 2020 could be on a positive note. That can be attributed to a lot of readings for the markets, one of which transpired on Friday. It is the increased cost of carry and the Nifty Futures premium is going up, nearing 1% mark. That is a very positive comeback because the end of December series was more on a tepid or a dull note but the start of the Jan series was more on a strong note. 

The beginning of 2020 looks to be on the healthier side for the markets. The India VIX dropped back to 10-10.5 levels, which also indicate that the markets are more confident that this uptrend would sustain. 

We need to see how the largecap stocks perform, especially Reliance, ICICI Bank, HDFC etc, which have done remarkably well in the last three to four months. If they carry the baton forward, then the confidence level of the markets would improve going forward. So, there are a lot of positives which transpired especially on Friday and a good part of last week.


What do you make of some of these banking names? The select ones have done very well this year? How would you look at the financial sector?The space seems to be fairly attractive. The markets earlier in the second half of this year were more polarised and more specific towards largecap stocks. Private sector banks like ICICI Bank, Kotak Bank and HDFC Bank used to find a lot of investor traction, but as now, we came very close to the year end and the markets got into a sort of a mature phase.

Suddenly, the sentiment is becoming positive. A lot of the other financial names have started to spring up. IndusInd Bank is also trading above its 200-day moving average. SBI and the PSU banking pack made a very good comeback in the last one-and-a-half to two months. 

A lot of flavour is now getting added to the banking pack and that is a healthy sign. A lot of bank largecaps have done very well and they are the ones to keep on holding their key support levels. The new emerging names add a lot of flavour to the traders as well as investors’ plate. It is a healthy sign for the market internals as well.


As far as the decade is concerned, are there stocks that you would like to talk about?From a longer-term view, I will go with ICICI Bank as one of the prominent buys. If someone is looking at more high-risk stocks, then Eicher Motors at current levels holds a lot of potential. There has been a remarkable comeback in the auto stocks. I believe Eicher Motors and Bajaj Auto have a lot of potential. Tata Motors is more of a high beta stock because of the news flow. But if anyone is looking for more high risk stocks, Tata Motors could be a strong candidate for multibagger from current levels.

NEW DELHI: Seasonality, year-end shutdowns and inventory management in the runup to BS-VI transition will likely result in another tepid month for auto companies when they report their monthly sales numbers for December on January 1, 2020. The numbers are likely to suggest that the slowdown that has engulfed the sector for almost a year now is not over yet, analysts said.

On a year-on-year basis, the picture isn’t good. Passenger vehicle (PV) sales are likely to be tepid. While Nomura estimates a marginal 2 per cent year-on-year increase in PV sales, Prabhudas Lilladher has projected a 5-6 per cent drop.

Two-wheeler (2W) sales may decline 2 per cent. However, the fall in sales of commercial vehicles is projected to be the higher at 30 per cent.

“With the impending price hikes of 13-15 per cent for BS-VI models coming in from April, 2020, demand headwinds should continue in FY21F for the two-wheeler segment,” Nomura said in a report.

Brokerage Prabhudas Lilladher sees some pre-buying in CVs in Q4FY20 but expects demand to remain under pressure till H1 of FY21. A significant price hike of 15-20 per cent in CVs is on the cards for BS-VI models.

Brokerages have a mixed view on Maruti Suzuki. Nomura expects the industry leader to post a 6 per cent year-on-year (YoY) rise in sales while Prabhudas Lilladher projects it to post a 2 per cent decline. Nirmal Bang Securities expects a sequential decline of 0.1 per cent for the auto major due to the year-end shutdown. However, the brokerage expects strong consumer offers to help drive higher retail volume.

Maruti shares fell 0.65 per cent in Mumbai trading to end the year at Rs 7,367 on Tuesday in a weak market that saw the benchmark Sensex tank 304 points.

Overall sales for Mahindra and Mahindra (M&M) are projected to decline 2-8 per cent with a steeper fall seen in tractor sales. Nirmal Bang expects M&M's tractor volumes to drop 5 per cent to 16,534 while Nomura pegs December sales figure to come in at 16,700, down 4 per cent. The stock fell over 1 per cent in Tuesday's trade to Rs 531.

Tata Motors is most likely to continue the trend of rapid decline in PV and CV sales. The projections are for 41-33 per cent drop in PV sales and 32-22 per cent YoY decline in overall sales. "High double-digit decline in CVs is likely to continue due to high inventory, economic slowdown, limited disbursals for infra projects, excess fleet capacity and tepid freight rates," said Nirmal Bang. The stock bucked the trend in the auto pocket to close nearly 1 per cent higher at Rs 185 on Tuesday.

Ashok Leyland is projected to post a 28-38 per cent YoY decline in December volumes. ALL shares fell about half-a-per cent to Rs 81 in Mumbai trading.

Brokerages expect Bajaj Auto to fare better than peers. Prabhudas Lilladher projects a 2.3 per cent jump in December sales while Nirmal Bang sees a 3.4 per cent rise. Nomura pegs growth in Bajaj Auto sales at 10.9 per cent. The stock dropped over 2 per cent in Mumbai trading to close the year at Rs 3,182.

Hero MotoCorp's sales are likely to fall 4-15 per cent, while those of TVS may dip 3.5-11 per cent. The stock slipped one-and-a-half per cent to Rs 2,443.

Nirmal Bang expects Eicher Motors to post a 5 per cent decline in sales of Royal Enfield bullets and a 40 per cent decline in VECV volume. Prabhudas Lilladher expects a marginal dip of just 0.5 per cent in Royal Enfield sales, while Nomura expects them to rise 3 per cent. The stock fell over 1 per cent to Rs 2,251 on Tuesday.

“We do not see growth in auto demand anytime soon. Consumer sentiment is not good. Auto is a good business going through a down cycle. We will wait for some signs of growth coming in before we buy into the auto or auto ancillary pack,” said Amit Jeswani, CIO, Stallion Asset.
